transcription:
[doctor] hi , brian . how are you ?
[patient] hi , good to see you .
[doctor] it's good to see you too . so , i know the nurse told you a little bit about dax .
[patient] mm-hmm .
[doctor] i'd like to tell dax about you , okay ?
[patient] sure .
[doctor] so , brian is a 58 year old male with a past medical history significant for congestive heart failure and hypertension , who presents today for follow-up of his chronic problems . so , brian , it's been a little while i've seen you .
[patient] mm-hmm .
[doctor] whats , what's going on ?
[patient] i , i just feel out of sorts lately . i do n't know if it's the change in the seasons or if we're just doing a lot of projects around the house and , and some , some construction on our own . i'm just feeling out of it . lack of , uh , energy . i'm just so tired and fatigued , and i feel kinda ... i feel lightheaded every once in a while .
[doctor] okay . all right . um , how long has that been going on for ?
[patient] uh , probably since labor day , so about five weeks or so .
[doctor] okay . and , have you noticed any , like , symptoms of weight gain , like , like swollen legs , or , you know , your belly feels bloated and things like that ?
[patient] i feel , i feel bloated every once in a while .
[doctor] okay . all right . um , and , are you taking your , your medications ?
[patient] uh , yes , i am .
[doctor] okay . and , how about your diet ? are you watching your diet ?
[patient] uh , it's been a little bit of a struggle . we began construction on our kitchen over labor day weekend , and it was ... hard to cook or prepare meals so we ate out a lot, and not always the best food out. it , it , it kind of reeked havoc , uh , so it's been maybe off a little bit .
[doctor] okay . all right . and , how about , you know , other symptoms , like , have you had a fever or chills ?
[patient] no .
[doctor] okay , and any problems breathing ? do you feel short of breath ?
[patient] uh , just when i'm doing doing the projects . again , not even lifting anything really heavy , it's just that if i'm ex- exerting any energy , i , i kinda feel it at that point .
[doctor] okay . do you have any chest pain ?
[patient] slight cramps . that seems to go away after about , maybe about an hour or so after i first feel it .
[doctor] okay , and how about a cough ?
[patient] a , a slight cough , and again , i'm not sure if it's just the change of seasons and i'm getting a cold .
[doctor] mm-hmm . okay . all right . well , you know , for the most part , how , you know , before all of this-
[patient] mm-hmm .
[doctor] . how were you doing with your heart failure ? i know that we've kinda talked about you being able to watch your healthy food intake and that's been kind of a struggle in the past .
[patient] i , i , i've actually been pretty good about that ever since . the , the , the last year , it's been a little chaotic , but i wanted to make sure i stayed on top of that .
[doctor] okay . all right . are you excited for halloween ?
[patient] uh , ca n't wait .
[doctor] okay .
[patient] our home renovations should be complete by then
[doctor] all right , yeah , right .
[patient] yeah .
[doctor] and , so , lastly , for your high blood pressure , how are you doing with that ? have , are , did you buy the blood pressure cuff like i asked ?
[patient] yeah , i , i did , and we do mon- , i , i monitor it regularly . my wife makes sure i stay on top of that , but it's been pretty good .
[doctor] okay . all right . well , i know you did the review of systems sheet when you checked in , and you were endorsing this fatigue-
[patient] mm-hmm .
[doctor] . and a little dizziness and we just talked a lot about a lot of other symptoms .
[patient] mm-hmm .
[doctor] any other symptoms i might be missing ? nausea or vomiting , diarrhea ?
[patient] no .
[doctor] anything like that ?
[patient] no .
[doctor] okay . all right . well , i just want to go ahead and do a quick physical exam .
[patient] mm-hmm .
[doctor] hey , dragon ? show me the vital signs . so , looking at your vital signs here in the office , everything looks good . you know , your blood pressure and your heart rate and your oxygenation all look really good .
[patient] mm-hmm .
[doctor] so , i'm gon na just take a listen to a few things and check some things out , and i'll let you know what i find , okay ?
[patient] perfect .
[doctor] okay . so , on your physical examination , you know , i do appreciate some jugular venous distention to-
[patient] mm-hmm .
[doctor] to about eight centimeters . on your heart exam , i do appreciate a three out of six systolic ejection murmur , which we've heard in the past . and , on your lung exam , i do appreciate some fine crackles at the bases bilaterally , and your lower extremities have , you know , 1+ pitting edema . so , what does all that mean ? that means i think you're retaining a little bit of fluid .
[patient] mm-hmm .
[doctor] okay ? i wan na just go ahead and look at some of your results , okay ?
[patient] sure .
[doctor] hey , dragon ? show me the chest x-ray . so , looking here at the results of your chest x-ray , it does look like you have a little bit of fluid in your lungs there , and that can be just from , um , your heart failure , okay ? hey , dragon ? show me the echocardiogram . so , this is the echocardiogram that we did about four months ago , and this shows that the pumping function of your heart is a little bit reduced at 45 % , and it also shows that leaky valve , the mitral regurgitation that , that you have , okay ? um , so , let me just go over and talk about , a little bit , my assessment and my plan for you .
[patient] mm-hmm .
[doctor] okay ? so , for your first problem , your congestive heart failure , i think you're retaining fluid , and i wan na go ahead and increase your lasix to 80 mg once a day .
[patient] mm-hmm .
[doctor] i want you to weigh yourself every day . i want you to call me if you're gaining more weight .
[patient] mm-hmm .
[doctor] and , i certainly want you to call me if you have any other symptoms of shortness of breath , and i wan na go ahead and order another echocardiogram , okay ?
[patient] sure .
[doctor] hey , dragon ? order an echocardiogram .
lastly , for your high blood pressure , it looks like you're managing it well at this time , okay ? so , i wan na go ahead and continue with the lisinopril 20 mg a day . i want you to continue to record your blood pressures at home , and report them to me in the patient portal if you see they're getting elevated , okay ?
[patient] mm-hmm .
[doctor] does that sound like a plan ?
[patient] that sounds fine .
[doctor] okay . um , i'm gon na be in touch with you after we get your test results , and we'll go from there , okay ?
[patient] sure .
[doctor] all right . hey , dragon , finalize the note .
SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Fatigue, feeling "out of sorts"
* History of present illness: Fatigue, low energy, tiredness, lightheadedness intermittently for about five weeks since Labor Day, occasional bloating, mild shortness of breath with exertion (during household projects), slight chest cramps lasting about an hour and resolving, slight cough, no fever, chills, nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea
* Past medical history: Congestive heart failure, hypertension
* Social history: Increased eating out and less healthy dietary habits due to ongoing home/kitchen renovations, actively involved in home construction projects, adheres to regular blood pressure monitoring at home with help from spouse
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Blood pressure, heart rate, and oxygen saturation within normal limits in office
* Physical exam: Jugular venous distention to 8 cm, grade 3/6 systolic ejection murmur, fine crackles at lung bases bilaterally, 1+ pitting edema of lower extremities
* Test results: Chest x-ray shows small amount of fluid in lungs, echocardiogram (4 months prior) shows reduced ejection fraction (45%), presence of mitral regurgitation

A (Assessment):

* Congestive heart failure with fluid retention
* Mitral regurgitation
* Hypertension, well controlled

P (Plan):

* Increase Lasix to 80 mg orally once daily
* Daily weight monitoring; patient to call if weight increases or with any worsening symptoms such as shortness of breath
* Order repeat echocardiogram
* Continue lisinopril 20 mg orally once daily
* Continue home blood pressure monitoring and report elevated readings via patient portal
* Await additional test results and follow up after review

transcription:
[doctor] hi , ms. thompson . i'm dr. moore . how are you ?

[doctor] hi .
[patient] i'm doing okay except for my knee .

[patient] well , i was , um , trying to change a light bulb , and i was up on a ladder and i kinda had a little bit of a stumble and kinda twisted my knee as i was trying to catch my fall .
[doctor] okay . and did you injure yourself any place else ?
[patient] no , no . it just seems to be the knee .
[doctor] all right . and when did this happen ?
[patient] it was yesterday .
[doctor] all right . and , uh , where does it hurt mostly ?
[patient] it hurts like in , in , in the inside of my knee .
[doctor] okay .
[patient] right here .
[doctor] all right . and anything make it better or worse ?
[patient] i have been putting ice on it , uh , and i've been taking ibuprofen , but it does n't seem to help much .
[doctor] okay . so it sounds like you fell a couple days ago , and you've hurt something inside of your right knee .
[patient] mm-hmm .
[doctor] and you've been taking a little bit of ice , uh , putting some ice on it , and has n't really helped and some ibuprofen . is that right ?
[patient] that's right . yeah .
[doctor] okay , let's review your past history for a second . it looks like , uh , do you have any other past medical history ?
[patient] uh , afib .
[doctor] okay , and are you taking any medications for that ?
[patient] yeah , i am . um , begins with a d.
[doctor] uh , digoxin ?
[patient] that's it . yeah , that's it .
[doctor] okay , all right . how about any surgeries in the past ?
[patient] i have had a nose job .
[doctor] all right . um , let's do your exam , okay ? so is it tender ... where is it mostly tender right now ?
[patient] right on the inside of my knee . right here .
[doctor] all right , so if i bend your knee forward , does that seem to hurt ?
[patient] yes , that hurts .
[doctor] all right , how about if i twist it a little bit that way .
[patient] that hurts a lot .
[doctor] okay , okay . and how about down here ? do you feel me touch you down here ?
[patient] yes .
[doctor] all right . any other pain down here in your calves ?
[patient] no .
[doctor] no , okay . so on exam you do have some tenderness over the medial portion of your knee over the medial meniscus area . uh , there is no , uh , there is a little bit of tenderness when i flex your , uh , when i , uh , uh , do some valgus stressing on your , on your leg . um , you have normal sensation . so let's take a look at your x-rays .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] okay . hey dragon , show me the x-rays . so looking at the x-ray , um , of your left knee , uh , it appears to be there's no fractures there right now . i do n't see any , uh , there's a little bit of , uh , fluid , uh , but there is no , uh , there's no , um , fracture or there's no dislocation . everything else seems to be lined up properly , okay ?
[patient] okay .
[doctor] so in summary after my exam , uh , looking at your knee , uh , on the x-ray and your exam , you have some tenderness over the medial meniscus , so i think you have probably an acute medial meniscus sprain right now or strain . uh , at this point , my recommendation would be to put you in a knee brace , uh , and we'll go ahead and have you use some crutches temporarily for the next couple days . we'll have you come back in about a week and see how you're doing , and if it's not better , we'll get an mri at that time .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] i'm going to recommend we give you some motrin , 800 milligrams . uh , you can take it about every six hours , uh , with food . uh , and we'll give you about a two week supply .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] okay . uh , do you have any questions ?
[patient] no , i think i'm good .
[doctor] all right . hey , dragon , order the medications and procedures discussed , and finalize the report . okay , come with me and we'll get you checked out .
SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Right knee pain
* History of present illness: Twisted right knee while trying to catch fall from a ladder yesterday; pain is mostly on the inside of the knee; ice and ibuprofen used with little relief
* Past medical history: Atrial fibrillation
* Past surgical history: Rhinoplasty
* Medications: Digoxin
* No other injuries reported
* No information provided for social history
* No information provided for family history

O (Objective):

* Physical exam: Tenderness over medial portion of right knee/medial meniscus area, pain with knee flexion and valgus stress, normal sensation, no calf pain
* Test results: Right knee x-ray shows no fracture or dislocation, mild fluid detected, normal alignment

A (Assessment):

* Acute medial meniscus sprain/strain, probable

P (Plan):

* Prescribe Motrin 800 mg every 6 hours with food for 2 weeks
* Apply knee brace
* Use crutches temporarily for the next few days
* Outpatient follow-up in 1 week
* If not improved at follow-up, order MRI

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Back pain
- History of present illness: Lower back pain started on Saturday morning after lifting heavy boxes, heard a "pop," had to lie down for an hour before pain relieved; has been stiff since; tingling in right toes until Sunday afternoon (now resolved); difficulty finding a comfortable sleeping position (lying on right side helps slightly); Tylenol, ibuprofen, and topical Icy Hot provided minimal relief.
- Past medical history: Type 2 diabetes, hypertension, osteoarthritis (knee)
- Social history: Diet has been poor in recent weeks due to travel and lack of home-cooked meals; monitors blood pressure at home during the week but not consistently on weekends
- Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: Office blood pressure slightly elevated; home readings run a little on the high side (exact values not specified)
- Physical exam: 2/6 systolic heart murmur (stable, present in the past), lumbar spine pain on palpation, pain with flexion and extension of the back, negative straight leg raise
- Test results: Hemoglobin A1c elevated at 8.0%, back x-ray normal with good bony alignment and no fracture

A (Assessment):

- Lumbar strain
- Type 2 diabetes, suboptimally controlled
- Hypertension, suboptimally controlled
- Osteoarthritis (knee), stable

P (Plan):

- Lumbar strain: Prescribe meloxicam 15 mg once a day, continue icing, avoid strenuous activity, refer to physical therapy
- Type 2 diabetes: Increase metformin to 1000 mg twice daily, order repeat hemoglobin A1c in 6 months
- Hypertension: Increase lisinopril from 10 mg to 20 mg daily
- Osteoarthritis (knee): Continue current management, no additional workup needed at this time
- Follow-up: No information provided

* Depression, well controlled
* History of lobectomy, stable with no current concerns
* Hypertension, well controlled on current regimen
* 2/6 systolic ejection murmur
* Nasal congestion, likely allergic

P (Plan):

* Continue Prozac 20 mg daily; refill prescribed
* Continue Norvasc for hypertension

* Order routine blood work
* No further follow-up needed with thoracic surgery for lobectomy
* Follow-up via patient portal with test results
* No specific new intervention for nasal congestion at this time
* Annual follow-up or as needed

transcription:
[doctor] hi , ms. brooks . i'm dr. baker . how are you ?
[patient] hi , dr. baker .
[doctor] is your , is your right finger hurting ?
[patient] yes .
[doctor] okay . hey , dragon , uh , sharon brooks is a 48 year old female here for right finger pain . all right . so , tell me what happened .
[patient] well , i was skiing over the weekend-
[doctor] okay .
[patient] . and as i was , um , coming down the hill , i tried moguls , which jumping over those big hills , i tend to get my strap caught on my finger-
[doctor]
[patient] . and it kind of bent it back a bit .
[doctor] okay .
[patient] yeah .
[doctor] and when did this happen ?
[patient] it happened , uh ... that was sunday .
[doctor] okay . and have you tried anything for this or anything made it better or worse ?
[patient] i tried , um , putting ice on it .
[doctor] okay .
[patient] uh , and then i- i've been taking ibuprofen , but it's still very painful .
[doctor] okay . and , uh , is it worse when you bend it ? or anything make it ... so , just wh-
[patient] yeah , movement .
[doctor] okay .
[patient] yes .
[doctor] okay . so , it sounds like you were skiing about four about days ago and you went over a mogul and got it hyper extended or got it bent backwards a little bit , ? okay . do you have any other past medical history at all ?
[patient] um , i have been suffering from constipation recently .
[doctor] okay . all right . and do you take ... what medicines do you take for constipation ?

[doctor] miralax ?
[patient] miralax . that's it .
[doctor] okay . miralax is sufficient .
[patient] miralax . yes .
[doctor] and any surgeries in the past ?

[doctor] okay . let's do your exam . uh , so , it's this finger right here . and does it hurt here on your , on this joint up here ?
[patient] no .
[doctor] okay . and how'bout right there ? no ?
[patient] no .
[doctor] right here ?
[patient] that hurts .
[doctor] all right . uh , can you bend your finger for me ?
[patient] yeah .
[doctor] all right . and how about extend it ? all right . and can you touch your thumb with it ?
[patient] yes .
[doctor] all right . so , on exam , you do have some tenderness over your distal phalanx , which is the tip of your finger . there is , uh , some tenderness over that joint itself . i do n't feel any tenderness over your proximal joint or your metacarpophalangeal joint , which is right above your knuckle . uh , you have some pain flexion as well . so , let's look at your x-rays . hey , dragon , show me the x-rays .
[doctor] all right . so , on this x-ray.
everything looks normal right now . uh , i do n't see any fractures . everything lines up pretty well . uh , so , your x-ray looks normal with no fractures . so , based on the x-ray and your exam , you have some tenderness right here . i think you've got a little contusion right here . there's no fracture on the tip of your finger . uh , so , the diagnosis would be a right hand , uh , index finger contusion on the tip of your finger , okay ? so , i would recommend we get you a s- uh , aluminum foam splint and we'll get you some motrin . uh , we'll give you 600 milligrams every six hours and we'll take that for about a week . and if it does n't get better , why do n't you call us and come back at that point ?

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Right finger pain
* History of present illness: Finger bent backward while skiing over moguls 4 days ago, ongoing pain especially with movement; has tried ice and ibuprofen with persistent pain
* Past medical history: Constipation, appendectomy at age 18
* Medications: Miralax for constipation, ibuprofen used for finger pain
* No information provided: Social history, family history

O (Objective):

* Physical exam: Tenderness over distal phalanx (tip) of right index finger and the distal interphalangeal joint, no tenderness over proximal interphalangeal joint or metacarpophalangeal joint, pain with flexion, able to perform opposition with thumb
* Test results: X-ray of right finger normal, no fractures, normal joint alignment
* No information provided: Vital signs

P (Plan):

* Apply aluminum foam splint to right finger
* Prescribe Motrin (ibuprofen) 600 mg every 6 hours for 1 week
* Follow-up if symptoms do not improve or worsen
* No information provided: Additional tests, referrals, patient education, or specific follow-up schedule

transcription:
[doctor] today i'm seeing christina cooper . her date of birth is 07/01/1954 . uh , ms. cooper is a new patient who was referred by diane nelson for a long-standing iron deficiency anemia .
[doctor] hello , how are you ?
[patient] i'm good , thank you .
[doctor] so tell me what brings you in today .
[patient] recently i tried to donate blood , around december i think , and they told me i was anemic , which is something i've been dealing with for a while , so it's not the first time i've been told i'm anemic .
[doctor] or how have you been feeling in general with this ?
[patient] not great . i have been feeling fatigued often during the day , and even feverish with chills at times . when i try to be active i like i ca n't catch my breath and i feel like i'm wheezing . i've had some headaches too , which is not like me .
[doctor] okay . are there any other symptoms ?
[patient] i've been noting some chilling sensations . i also get cold so easily . it's annoying . i feel like i have to really bundle up . i do n't know if this is related but my anxiety and depression feel like it has been getting worse lately . i feel like a mess .
[doctor] sounds like you're not feeling great , obviously . and i'm glad you came to see us . um , we're certainly going to try to figure this out and figure out what's going on , uh , but it sounds like you've been dealing with this anemia for a long time ?
[patient] yeah , i've been anemic since i was 13 years old .
[doctor] right . so why do your doctors think you're anemic ? do you have a history of heavy periods ?
[patient] well i did have heavy periods until i had a hysterectomy in 1996 . but no , they have not told me why they think i'm anemic , which is frustrating honestly .
[doctor] yeah . i can imagine that is . um , let's see if we can help though . since you had your hysterectomy your periods , of course , are no longer the issue . um , when was your last colonoscopy ?
[patient] about five to six years ago .
[doctor] and was it relatively a normal exam ? did you have any polyps ?
[patient] no . they said they'd see me in 10 years .
[doctor] well that's good news .
[patient] yeah , i agree .
[doctor] um , do you have a pacemaker or defibrillator , or have sleep apnea , or use oxygen at night ?
[patient] no .
[doctor] all right . do you ever drink alcohol ?
[patient] yeah , but only once or twice a year .
[doctor] okay . are you taking any supplements such as iron or vitamin b12 ?
[patient] i already started taking my iron pills which i have not taken in about a year .
[doctor] all right . and what are you taking ?
[patient] i'm taking 25 milligram tablets , twice daily .
[doctor] okay , and that's the , the ferrous sulfate ?
[patient] yeah , that's it . i take one in the morning and one in the evening .
[doctor] okay . anything else ?
[patient] yeah , i take vitamin b12 , just the over the counter stuff .
[doctor] okay , very good . all right , well let's go ahead and take a look and see what's going on .
[patient] sounds good . thank you .
[doctor] of course . you'll hear me , uh , talk through your exam so that i get all the information documented .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] all right . so use my general physical exam template . i will start by listening to your heart and lungs .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] all right . next , i'd like you to lay back so i can examine your abdomen .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] is there any tenderness where i'm pressing ?
[patient] no .
[doctor] okay . you can sit up . so your physical exam is normal without any significant findings . all right ms. cooper , often when we initially see anemia and your host of symptoms , we suspect internal bleeding .
[patient] is that why they want me to have another upper endoscopy ?
[doctor] actually it would be an upper endoscopy and a colonoscopy , but yes , likely that's the reason why .
[patient] lovely .
[doctor] yeah . unfortunately our cameras do not meet all the way in the middle , so if those tests back , come , if those tests come back fine , then we'll have you swallow a pill camera to take pictures as it moves through your , uh , system .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] we may not need to , but it's just the first thing we can do to make sure that you're not losing blood . um , the second thing we can do is have you see a hematologist . they will tell us if you need to give any , to give you any intravenous iron , or maybe something to help your body store the iron better .
[patient] all right .
[doctor] so let's go ahead , get your upper endoscopy and colonoscopy scheduled .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] um , have you ever had any issue with sedation in the past ?
[patient] no , i was just sleepy afterwards .
[doctor] okay . well we will give you a bowel prep to clean out your bowels ahead of time . um , if we do these tests and they are normal , like i said , then we will consider that capsule endoscopy .
[patient] okay . sounds like a plan .
[doctor] all right . so after that you'll be all done and we will send you to the hematologist . additionally , i'm going to need you to start taking your iron pills with orange juice . uh , the vitamin c will help you absorb the iron better . do this for about 8-12 weeks , uh , and then we can reassess your blood work .
[patient] okay , that sounds great .
[doctor] all right . well i think we have our plan . on your way out , stop by and schedule your upper endoscopy and c- colonoscopy . uh , we will send a referral to dr. flores who is is the hematologist , so schedule that appointment . um , here are your instructions for the pre- uh , the bowel prep . uh , call us if you have any questions or worsening symptoms . we'll be happy to help you .
[patient] thank you .
[doctor] you're welcome . have a great day , have a great day ms. cooper .
[patient] you too .
[doctor] all right . this is christina cooper , pleasant 65 year old female who was diagnosed with iron deficiency anemia in 12-2019 , and w- and was unable to donate blood . um , her followup blood work on 01/20/20 was revealed a low hemoglobin , stable hematocrit and normal iron labs , although ferritin was low . um , she was taking ferrous sulfate , three hundred , twenty phil- 25 milligrams by mouth . i've asked her to continue each dose with vitamin c found in orange juice , for the next 12 weeks , then recheck to the cbc , iron , ferritin , b12 , and folate . um , a referral was sent to her hematologist . we will plan for an egd and a colonoscopy to assess for potential sources of anemia or gi bleed . if this is inconclusive , capsule endoscopy will be considered . thanks .
SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Long-standing iron deficiency anemia
- History of present illness: Fatigue during the day, feelings of feverishness with chills, dyspnea and wheezing on exertion, headaches, increased sensitivity to cold and chilling sensations, worsening anxiety and depression; reports anemia since age 13, most recently noticed when attempting blood donation in December (denied donation due to anemia)
- Past medical history: Hysterectomy in 1996 (history of heavy periods prior)
- Social history: Alcohol use 1–2 times per year
- Medications: Ferrous sulfate 25 mg orally twice daily (recently restarted after a year off), over-the-counter vitamin B12
- Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Physical exam: Normal, no significant findings, no abdominal tenderness
- Test results: January 2020 labs with low hemoglobin, stable hematocrit, normal iron studies, low ferritin; prior colonoscopy 5–6 years ago normal (no polyps, next follow-up in 10 years)
- Vital signs: No information provided

A (Assessment):

- Iron deficiency anemia
- Internal bleeding, suspected as potential etiology of anemia

P (Plan):

- Continue ferrous sulfate 25 mg orally twice daily, take each dose with orange juice for vitamin C to improve absorption, for 8–12 weeks
- Schedule upper endoscopy (EGD) and colonoscopy
- If endoscopy and colonoscopy are normal, consider capsule endoscopy
- Refer to hematology (Dr. Flores) for further evaluation and management, including possible intravenous iron or alternative treatments
- Repeat CBC, iron studies, ferritin, B12, and folate after 8–12 weeks
- Provide instructions for bowel preparation prior to endoscopy/colonoscopy
- Advise patient to call with questions or if symptoms worsen

transcription:
[doctor] patient , bruce ward . date of birth 5/21/1969 . please use my neuro consult template . this is a 52-year-old male with dia- newly diagnosed pituitary lesion . the patient is seen in consultation at the request of dr. henry howard for possible surgical intervention . mr . ward presented to his primary care provider , dr. howard , on 3/1/21 complaining of worsening headaches over the past few months . he denied any trouble with headaches in the past . his past clinical history is unremarkable .
[doctor] worked out for worsening headaches was initiated with brain mri and serology where pituitary lesion was incidentally discovered . i personally reviewed the labs dated 3/3/21 including cbc , unes , uh , coagulation , and crp . all were normal . pituitary hormone profile demonstrates a low tsh , all other results were normal . um , i personally reviewed pertinent radiology studies including mri for the brain with contrast from 3/4/21 . the mri reveals a pituitary lesion with elevation and compression of the optic chiasm . the ventricles are normal in size and no other abnormalities are lo- are noted .
[doctor] hello , mr . ward . nice to meet you . i'm dr. flores .
[patient] hi , doc . nice to meet you .
[doctor] i was just reviewing your records from dr. howard and he's referred you because the workup for headaches revealed a mass on your pituitary gland . i did review your mri images and you have a significant mass there . can you tell me about the issues you've been experiencing ?
[patient] yeah sure . so i'm really getting fed up with these headaches . i've been trying my best to deal with them but they've been going on for months now and i'm really struggling .
[doctor] where are the headaches located and how would you describe that pain ?
[patient] located behind my eyes . it's like a dull nagging ache .
[doctor] okay . was the onset gradual or sudden ?
[patient] well it started about three months ago . and they've been getting worse over time . at first it was like three out of 10 severity , and it just gradually worsened . and now it's about six out of 10 severity . the headaches do tend to be worse in the morning and it feels like a dull ache behind the eyes . they last a few hours at a time , nothing makes them better or worse .
[doctor] okay . can you tell me if the pain radiates , or if you have any other symptoms ? specifically feeling sick , fever , rashes , neck stiffness , numbness , weakness , passing out ?
[patient] no . i have n't been sick or felt sick . ca n't recall a fever or any kind of rash . no- no neck issues , no numbness , no tingling . and i've never passed out in my life . but , um , for some reason recently i seem to be bumping into door frames .
[doctor] okay . have you noticed any change in your vision or with your balance ?
[patient] no i do n't think so . my eyes were checked in the fall .
[doctor] okay . let's see , do you have any other medical problems that you take medicine for ?
[patient] no i do n't have any medical problems and i do n't take any medicines . i tried tylenol a few times for the headaches but it did n't work , so i stopped .
[doctor] i see . anyone in your family have any history of diseases ?
[patient] i was adopted so i really have no idea .
[doctor] okay . um , what kind of work do you do ? and are you married ?
[patient] i work as a computer programmer and i've been married for 25 years . we just bought a small house .
[doctor] that's nice . um , do you drink any alcohol , smoke , or use recreational drugs ?
[patient] nope . i do n't do any of those and never have .
[doctor] okay . um , well let me take a good look at you . um , now you'll hear me calling out some details as i perform the examination . these will be noted for me in your record and i'll be happy to answer any questions you have once we're done .
[patient] sounds good , doc .
[doctor] all right . the patient is alert , oriented to time , place , and person . affect is appropriate and speech is fluent . cranial nerve examination is grossly intact . no focal , motor , or sensory deficit in the upper or lower extremities . visual acuity and eye movements are normal . pupils are equal and reactive . visual field testing reveals bitemporal hemianopia . and color vision is normal .
[doctor] all right , mr. ward . i'm going to review these pictures from the mri with you . um , now this appears to be a benign pituitary adenoma , but there's no way to be sure without sending the removed adenoma to pathology to make the diagnosis , which we will do . um , here you can see it's a well defined mass . and it's pressing right here on what we call the optic chiasm . and today when i was having you look at my fingers , you could n't see them off to the sides , that's what we call bitemporal hemianopia . and explains why you have been bumping into door frames .
[patient] yeah i never noticed that i could n't see out of the side until you did that test , and you closed one eye with both eyes . i really could n't tell .
[doctor] no because you're having this vision loss from the mass compressing the optic chiasm , the only option we have is to do surgery .
[patient] okay , i understand . do you think i'll regain my vision ?
[doctor] well there's no guarantees , but it is a possibility . i'm gon na refer you to the eye doctor for a full exam and they'll do what's called visual field test . this will map our your peripheral vision or side vision prior to surgery . and we can monitor after surgery to see if your vision is improving .
[patient] all right .
[doctor] and let's discuss the surgery a little more . um , we would do what's called a transsphenoidal approach to do the surgery . this is minimally invasive and we go through the sphenoid sinus . there are some risks i have to inform you of . uh , risk of anesthesia including but not limited to the risk of heart attack , stroke , and death . risk of surgery include infection , need for further surgery , wound issues such as spinal fluid leak or infection , uh , which may require long , prolonged hospitalization or additional procedure . uh , seizure , stroke , permanent numbness , weakness , difficulty speaking , or even death .
[patient] well i guess we have to do it regardless .
[doctor] okay . so i will have you see our surgery scheduler , deborah , on the way out to get you set up . we will get this scheduled fairly quickly so i do n't want you to be alarmed . um , she'll also get you set up today or tomorrow to have the visual field test and you may not be able to see the eye doctor until after surgery . but we have the pre-surgery visual field test for comparison after surgery .
[patient] okay . i look forward to these headaches going away . i never thought it could be something like this going on .
[doctor] yeah . come this way , we'll get your things lined up . please call if you think of any questions .
[patient] thanks , doctor .
[doctor] diagnosis will be pituitary adenoma . mr . ward is a very pleasant 52-year-old male who has benign appearing pituitary adenoma , incidentally discovered during workup for worsening headaches . he is symptomatic with clinical and radiographical evidence of optic chiasmal compression , therefor surgical intervention to excise and decompress the pituitary fossa is indicated . end of note .
SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Worsening headaches over the past few months
- History of present illness: Headaches began approximately three months ago; initially 3/10 in severity, now 6/10; described as a dull, nagging ache located behind the eyes, lasting a few hours at a time, worse in the morning, unresponsive to acetaminophen, no clear alleviating or aggravating factors; has started bumping into door frames recently
- Associated symptoms: Denies fever, rash, neck stiffness, numbness, weakness, tingling, syncope, or recent illness; no noticed changes in vision or balance by patient; eyes were checked in the fall
- Past medical history: Unremarkable; no chronic medical problems; not on regular medications
- Family history: No information provided (patient adopted)
- Social history: Works as a computer programmer, married for 25 years, recently bought a house, denies tobacco, alcohol, or recreational drug use

O (Objective):

- Physical exam: Alert and oriented to time, place, and person; appropriate affect; fluent speech; cranial nerves grossly intact; no focal motor or sensory deficits in upper or lower extremities; visual acuity and eye movements normal; pupils equal and reactive; visual field testing reveals bitemporal hemianopia; color vision normal
- Test results: Brain MRI with contrast (3/4/21) shows pituitary lesion with elevation and compression of the optic chiasm, ventricles normal, no other abnormalities; labs (3/3/21) including CBC, U&Es, LFTs, coagulation, CRP all normal; pituitary hormone profile shows low TSH, all other pituitary hormones normal

A (Assessment):

- Benign-appearing pituitary adenoma with symptomatic optic chiasmal compression
- Diagnosis: Pituitary adenoma

P (Plan):

- Recommend surgical excision and decompression of pituitary fossa via transsphenoidal approach
- Refer for preoperative visual field test and eye doctor evaluation for baseline assessment
- Schedule surgery promptly
- Discussed surgical and anesthetic risks (including infection, stroke, heart attack, wound complications, permanent neurological deficits, and death)
- Instructed patient to contact the clinic with further questions or concerns

transcription:
[doctor] next is betty hill , uh , date of birth is 2/21/1968 . she has a past medical history of uterine fibroids and anemia . she's a new patient with a referral from the er of esophagitis . um , i reviewed our records from the er , including the normal cardiac workup , and we're about to go in and see her now . good morning . you miss hill ?
[patient] good morning . yes . that's me .
[doctor] hey , i'm dr. sanders . it's nice to meet you .
[patient] nice to meet you too .
[doctor] so tell me about what brings you in today ?
[patient] well , i really needed to see you three months ... three months ago , but this was your first available appointment . when i called to make the appointment , i was having chest pains , but it stopped after four days , and i have n't had any since then .
[doctor] okay . when did these four days of chest pain occur ?
[patient] um , early october .
[doctor] of 2020 , correct ?
[patient] yes .
[doctor] okay . can you think of anything that might have caused the chest pain ? did you wake up with it ?
[patient] no . it just it randomly . i tolerated it for four days but then had to go to the emergency room because nothing i did relieved it . they did a bunch of testing and did n't find anything .
[doctor] okay . can you point to the area of your chest where the pain was located ?
[patient] well , it was here in the center of my chest , right behind my breastbone . it felt like i was having a heart attack . the pain was really sharp .
[doctor] did they prescribe you any medications in the er ?
[patient] no . they ran an ekg and did blood tests , but like i said , everything was normal .
[doctor] okay . i see .
[patient] they thought it was something to do with the gi system , so that's why they referred me here .
[doctor] interesting . uh , do you remember having any heartburn or indigestion at , at the time ?
[patient] uh , maybe . i do n't think i've ever had heartburn , so i'm not sure what that feels like .
[doctor] was the pain worse with eating or exercise ?
[patient] yes . with eating .
[doctor] okay . any difficulty swallowing ?
[patient] mm-hmm . i did .
[doctor] okay . and that's also resolved since the initial episode three months ago ?
[patient] yes . thankfully . the chest pain and swallowing problem got better about three days after i went to the er . but i just feel like there's something wrong .
[doctor] okay . so how has your weight been .
[patient] i've been trying to lose weight .
[doctor] that's good . any in- ... issues with abdominal pain ?
[patient] uh , no .
[doctor] okay . good . and how about your bowel movements ; are they okay ?
[patient] they're normal .
[doctor] all right . are you aware of any family history of gi problems ?
[patient] i do n't think so .
[doctor] have had you had any surgeries on your abdomen , or gall bladder , or appendix ?
[patient] yes . they took my gall bladder out several years ago .
[doctor] okay . if you wan na lay down here on the table for me and lets take a look at you .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] so when i push on your lower belly , do you have any pain , or does it feel tender ?
[patient] no .
[doctor] okay . how about up here in your upper abdomen ?
[patient] yes . it , it hurts a little .
[doctor] okay . and even when i press lightly like this ?
[patient] yes . uh , just a little uncomfortable .
[doctor] okay . does it hurt more when i press over here on the left or over here on the right ? or is it about the same ?
[patient] i'd say it's about the same .
[doctor] okay . so we'll say you have some mild tenderness to light palpation in the upper abdominal quadrants , but everything on your exam looks normal and looks good .
[patient] okay . good .
[doctor] so let's talk about your symptoms real quick . obviously , with the chest discomfort , we worry about heart issues , but i'm reassured that those were ruled out with all the testing they did in the er . um , other potential causes could be anxiety , esophagitis , which is irritation of the esophagus . but typically with these , um ... but typically , these cause the pain that would last for a long time rather than that isolated incident like you had . um , it's also possible that you had intense heartburn for a few days .
[patient] well , since you mention anxiety , i was going through a really stressful job transition right around the time this happened .
[doctor] okay . that's good to know . so stress from this could be , um ... could be , uh ... could be very well have contributed to your condition .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] so we could do an , uh , egd or upper endoscopy to take a look at your esophagus and stomach . this would allow us to look for esophagitis . but your symptoms occurred three months ago and you have n't had any additional episodes , so likely if it were esophagitis , it's already healed by the point ... by this point , and we would n't be able to see anything . the other option is just to continue to monitor , uh , for any additional symptoms at which point we could do the egd . uh , with you being asymptomatic for so long right now , i'm comfortable with that option . but what do you think ?
[patient] i'd like to hold off on the egd and wait to see if i have more symptoms .
[doctor] that sounds good . um , so you can call the office if you have any additional episodes of pain or any other symptoms you're concerned about . if that happens , we'll get you scheduled for an egd to take a look . if not , you can follow up with me ... follow up with me as needed for any other gi complaints .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] all right ? if you do n't have any questions for me , i'll walk you out to the check-out desk .
[patient] no . that's it . thank you .
[doctor] you're welcome . right this way . all right . uh , in assessment , please summarize the patient's history briefly , and let's list her possible etiologies such as , uh , gerd , dyspepsia , esophagitis , musculoskeletal etiologies , and anxiety . uh , suspect she had an anxiety attack related to her job transition , plus or minus a contribution from her musculoskeletal etiologies . um , in the plan , include our discussion of the egd versus monderning ... monitoring for symptom . patient elected to self-monitor her symptoms and will call with any reoccurrence or change . thanks .
SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Chest pain episode in early October 2020, referred for evaluation of esophagitis
- History of present illness: Four days of sharp, central chest pain behind breastbone, resembling a heart attack; worsened with eating; not relieved by home measures; nausea/heartburn unclear; difficulty swallowing during the episode; both chest pain and swallowing complaint resolved approximately three days after ER visit; no recurrence of symptoms since
- Past medical history: Uterine fibroids, anemia, cholecystectomy (gall bladder removal) several years ago
- Social history: Recently experienced significant job stress/transition at the time of symptom onset; actively trying to lose weight
- Family history: No known GI problems

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: No information provided
- Physical exam: Mild tenderness to light palpation in upper abdominal quadrants, otherwise normal abdominal and general exam
- Test results: Normal cardiac workup in ER (including EKG and blood tests)

A (Assessment):

- History of chest pain and dysphagia, resolved
- Differential diagnosis: GERD, dyspepsia, esophagitis, musculoskeletal etiologies, anxiety
- Anxiety attack related to job transition suspected, with possible contribution from musculoskeletal etiologies

P (Plan):

- Discussed options including EGD (upper endoscopy) versus monitoring for symptoms; due to resolution and absence of symptoms, endoscopy deferred
- Patient elected to self-monitor symptoms and will call office if any recurrence or new symptoms occur
- Follow up as needed for any additional GI complaints

transcription:
[doctor] hello .
[patient_guest] hi .
[doctor] i'm dr. evelyn , one of the kidney doctors . it's good to meet you guys .
[patient_guest] it's nice to meet you also .
[doctor] yeah . so i was reading about this syndrome that i actually have never heard of .
[patient_guest] yeah , me too .
[doctor] i do n't think it's very common .
[patient_guest] definitely not . it's c- pretty rare .
[doctor] so-
[doctor] can you start at the beginning ? i know she's a twin , so are these your first two babies ?
[patient_guest] no , i have a son also who is nine . he also has autism .
[doctor] okay .
[patient_guest] and when the twins were born , katherine , she was about 4 pounds , 8 ounces . and her twin was a bit smaller , at 3 pounds , 13 ounces .

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Right wrist pain and swelling after a fall
- History of present illness: Slipped on stairs yesterday morning while carrying laundry, fell and caught herself with outstretched arms, immediate severe right wrist pain (pain score 9/10), swelling developed, used ice and ace wrap, took ibuprofen with partial relief; pain worsens with movement, slight tingling in fingers but can still feel them, denies pain radiating elsewhere, never injured this arm before, pain less severe when wrist is supported at rest level (e.g., on pillow)
- Past medical history: No information provided
- Social history: No information provided
- Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: Blood pressure 140/70 mmHg, heart rate 80/min, temperature 97.2°F, respiratory rate 20/min, no fever
- Physical exam: No head or neck adenopathy, no thyromegaly, no carotid bruit, heart regular with no murmur/rub/gallop, lungs clear bilaterally, no lower extremity edema, upper extremities show normal range of motion except right wrist; right wrist with tenderness on palpation (both medial and lateral), significant swelling and bruising, pain on flexion, extension, radial and lateral deviation, pain with abduction and adduction, decreased ability to make a tight fist, metacarpals intact, bony crepitus present
- Test results: X-ray positive for Colles’ fracture: extra-articular fracture proximal to the radioulnar joint, dorsal angulation of distal fragment (dinner fork deformity if severe), presence of ulnar styloid fracture

A (Assessment):

- Colles’ fracture, right wrist

P (Plan):

- Apply brace to right wrist (to be worn for six weeks)
- Schedule surgical fixation (as soon as possible) with likely overnight hospital stay
- Start Ultram 50 mg every six hours for pain management
- Refer to physical therapy to start a few weeks post-surgery (anticipated three times per week, frequency to be determined by therapist)
- Schedule follow-up in one month to assess healing and physical therapy progress, to determine readiness for planned vacation
- Patient education provided regarding injury, brace, surgery, and expected course

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Right knee pain
- History of present illness: Slipped and fell while working on property 1 week ago, right knee pain with flexion and extension, history of a popping sensation at time of injury, mild swelling since incident, pain score 4–5/10 with movement, minimal pain at rest
- Past medical history: Hypertension
- Current medications: Lisinopril 20 mg daily, ibuprofen (OTC) as needed for swelling
- Diet history: Sodium intake higher than recommended (2,300 mg/day goal), difficulty making dietary changes since the pandemic
- Social history: No information provided
- Family history: No information provided
- Review of systems: Denies chest pain, abdominal pain, and shortness of breath

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: Blood pressure on arrival 150/70 mmHg
- Physical exam: Lungs clear bilaterally, no wheezes or crackles; cardiac exam grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur (previously known); right knee with edema, effusion, pain to palpation medially, pain with flexion and extension, no pain to lateral palpation
- Test results: Right knee x-ray shows no fracture or bony abnormality

A (Assessment):

- Medial collateral ligament (MCL) strain of the right knee
- Hypertension

P (Plan):

- Prescribe ibuprofen 800 mg orally twice daily for pain and swelling
- Apply knee brace for support
- Recommend icing the knee 20 minutes at a time, 3–4 times per day
- Instruct to elevate and rest right leg, avoid strenuous activity for a couple of weeks
- Continue lisinopril 20 mg daily
- Refer to nutritionist for assistance with dietary modifications and sodium reduction
- Follow up as needed for symptom progression or if questions arise

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Left shoulder pain
* History of present illness: Left shoulder pain for approximately three weeks, no specific injury recalled, possibly related to increased physical activity during basement renovation. Pain is constant, worsens with pressure, lifting objects, or reaching overhead; severe when lying on the affected side at night. Takes two extra strength Tylenol every 6-8 hours with partial relief. No prior significant shoulder pain beyond mild aches previously managed with Tylenol.
* Social history: Active lifestyle, recent increased physical work during basement renovation.
* Review of systems: Denies numbness or tingling in arms or hands.
* Past medical history: No information provided
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Reviewed, within normal limits
* Physical exam: Left shoulder with limited active and passive range of motion, tenderness over greater tuberosity of humerus, no tenderness at sternoclavicular or acromioclavicular joints, good hand grips; neurovascular exam shows capillary refill <3 seconds, sensation intact to light touch in left arm
* Test results: Left shoulder X-ray reviewed, no fractures observed

A (Assessment):

* Left shoulder pain due to rotator cuff tendinopathy, most likely

P (Plan):

* Order MRI of left shoulder
* Refer to physical therapy for 6-8 weeks
* Continue Tylenol as needed
* Consider steroid injection if no symptomatic improvement
* Provide patient with educational materials about physical therapy
* Schedule follow-up visit after completion of physical therapy

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Intermittent left knee pain and episodes where the knee "gives out" while walking
- History of present illness: Left knee gives out less than once per day while walking, sudden onset and resolves quickly, feels internally at the kneecap, no popping sensation, no identifiable injury, not interfering with daily activities, avoids line dancing due to concern over knee stability, does not take pain medication as symptoms are brief
- Past medical history: Hypertension, diabetes mellitus
- Medication history: Takes Farxiga, amlodipine, lisinopril, hydrochlorothiazide, and metformin regularly at 8:30 am and 8:30 pm, uses phone alarm for adherence
- Blood sugar history: Fasting blood glucose approximately 130 mg/dL, concerned about slightly higher readings in the morning
- Social history: No information provided
- Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: Temperature 98.2°F, pulse 72/min, respirations 16/min, blood pressure 122/70 mmHg
- Physical exam: Cardiac exam: regular rate and rhythm, 2/6 systolic ejection murmur at left base; Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally; Left knee: no pain to palpation, no ecchymosis, no edema, no effusion, full range of motion, negative varus and valgus tests; Right knee: no ecchymosis or edema
- Test results: Left knee x-ray shows no fracture or bony abnormality

A (Assessment):

- Left knee arthritis
- Hypertension
- 2/6 systolic ejection murmur, needs evaluation with echocardiogram
- Diabetes mellitus

P (Plan):

- Prescribe meloxicam 15 mg daily for left knee pain
- Recommend physical therapy for knee strengthening
- Continue lisinopril 20 mg daily for hypertension
- Order echocardiogram to evaluate heart murmur
- Order hemoglobin A1c to monitor diabetes control
- Order lipid panel
- Schedule follow-up after tests completed
- Nurse to assist with echocardiogram scheduling

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Follow-up during neoadjuvant chemotherapy for recently diagnosed stage III non-small cell lung cancer
- History of present illness: 4.4 cm left upper lobe lung nodule (biopsy positive for adenocarcinoma); currently has minimal dry cough, intermittent sore throat, slight but not overwhelming fatigue, no nausea or vomiting, denies shortness of breath, no sensation of food being stuck; decreased oral intake compared to usual
- Past medical history: Stage III non-small cell lung cancer (adenocarcinoma)
- Social history: Supported by family (who accompany her to treatments) and medical staff; feels mentally strong
- Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: Oxygen saturation and vitals "look good"
- Physical exam: Neck—no cervical or supraclavicular lymphadenopathy; cardiac—regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs; lungs—bilateral crackles on deep inspiration; skin—erythema anterior left chest; lower extremities—no edema
- Test results: Recent chest X-ray shows mild radiation pneumonitis; molecular testing for tumor pending

A (Assessment):

- Stage III non-small cell lung adenocarcinoma
- Radiation pneumonitis
- Esophagitis (causing painful swallowing)
  
P (Plan):

- Continue chemotherapy regimen with cisplatin and etoposide
- Continue radiation therapy at 45 Gy
- Prescribe prednisone 40 mg daily for 5 days for radiation pneumonitis
- Prescribe lidocaine swish and swallow, 4 times daily for esophagitis/painful swallowing
- Repeat imaging after completion of radiation to assess tumor response
- Advise patient to maintain oral intake and hydration to prevent dehydration and weight loss
- Outpatient follow-up at next scheduled visit

- Chief complaint: Referred for low immunoglobulin A (IgA) level after abnormal lab work

- Social history: No history of receiving blood transfusions or blood products, traveled recently to Zambia
- Family history: No known immune deficiencies, family reported as healthy

A (Assessment):

- IgA deficiency
- Type 2 diabetes

P (Plan):

- Order additional blood work to check other antibody levels

- Patient education regarding signs and symptoms to monitor (infections that do not resolve, severe diarrhea)
- No immediate intervention required other than additional testing
- Follow-up after lab results or if significant symptoms develop

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Right elbow pain
- History of present illness: Developed pain in the inside of the right elbow over the past 4 days, associated with increased pottery activity; pain is rated 6/10, worsens at night, limits ability to lift and perform activities, occasionally radiates down into the forearm, not into the shoulder; denies any trauma or previous injury to the right elbow
- Alleviating factors: Ibuprofen (partial relief)
- Aggravating factors: Lifting, some wrist movements
- Past medical history: No information provided
- Social history: Increased pottery activity during the pandemic
- Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: Within normal limits
- Physical exam: Moderate tenderness of the right medial epicondyle, pain to palpation of the right medial epicondyle, pain with resisted flexion of the wrist, pain with forearm pronation, no pain with supination, no pain with resisted wrist extension
- Test results: Right elbow x-ray shows no fracture or bony abnormality

A (Assessment):

- Medial epicondylitis, right elbow

P (Plan):

- Prescribe sling for right arm to be worn while awake
- Apply ice to right elbow for 20 minutes, three times daily
- Ibuprofen 600 mg orally every 6 hours with food for 1 week
- Advise patient to rest and avoid pottery or similar activities for the next few weeks
- Follow-up visit in 1 week
- Have nurse assist with sling application

SOAP:

transcription:
[doctor] hi russell how are you what's been going on
[patient] well i've been having this sharp pain on the right side of my abdomen below my ribs for the last several days
[doctor] i saw my doctor and they ordered a cat scan and said i had a kidney stone and sent me to see a urologist okay well does the pain move or or or go anywhere or does it stay right in that same spot yeah it feels like it goes to my lower abdomen in into my groin okay and is the pain constant or does it come and go it comes and goes when it comes it's it's pretty it's pretty bad i feel like i ca n't find a comfortable position okay and do you notice any any pain when you urinate or when you pee
[patient] yeah it kinda burns a little bit
[doctor] okay do you notice any blood i do n't think there is any you know frank blood but the urine looks a little dark sometimes okay and what have you taken for the pain i have taken some tylenol but it has n't really helped okay and do you have any nausea vomiting any fever chills i feel nauseated but i'm not vomiting okay is anyone in your in your family had kidney stones yes my father had them and have you had kidney stones before yeah so i i've i've had them but i've been able to pass them but this is taking a lot longer okay well i'm just gon na go ahead and do a physical examination i'm gon na be calling out some of my exam findings and i'm going to explain what what those mean when i'm done okay
[patient] okay
[doctor] okay so on physical examination of the abdomen on a abdominal exam there is no tenderness to palpation there is no evidence of any rebound or guarding there is no peritoneal signs there is positive cva tenderness on the right flank so essentially what that means russell is that you know you have some tenderness over your over your right kidney and that just means that you might have some inflammation there so i i reviewed the results of the ct scan of your abdomen that the primary care doctor ordered and it does show a . five centimeter kidney stone located in the proximal right ureter so this the ureter is the duct in which urine passes between the kidney and the bladder there's no evidence of what we call hydronephrosis this means you know swelling of the kidney which is good means that things are still able to get through so let's talk a little bit about my assessment and my plan okay so for your first problem of this acute nephrolithiasis or kidney stone i i wan na go ahead and recommend that you push fluids to help facilitate urination and peeing to help pass the stone i'm going to prescribe oxycodone five milligrams every six to eight hours as needed for pain you can continue to alternate that with some tylenol i'm going to give you a strainer that you can use to strain your urine so that we can see it see the stone when it passes and we can send it for some some tests if that happens i'm also gon na order what we call a basic metabolic panel a urinalysis and a urine culture now i wan na see you again in one to two weeks and if you're still having symptoms we'll have to discuss further treatment such as lithotripsy which is essentially a shock wave procedure in which we sedate you and use shock waves to break up the stone to help it pass we could also do what we call a ureteroscopy which is a small telescope small camera used to go up to to the urethra and bladder and up into the ureter to retrieve the stone so let's see how you do over the next week and i want you to contact me if you're having worsening symptoms okay okay sounds good thank you
SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Sharp pain on the right side of the abdomen below the ribs for the last several days
* History of present illness: Pain radiates to lower abdomen and into groin, comes and goes, severe when present, unable to find comfortable position during pain episodes, burning sensation with urination, urine appears dark sometimes, nausea without vomiting, Tylenol taken for pain with little relief
* Past medical history: Previous kidney stones (self-reported)
* Family history: Father has history of kidney stones
* Social history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Physical exam: Abdomen non-tender to palpation, no rebound, no guarding, no peritoneal signs, positive right costovertebral angle (CVA) tenderness
* Test results: CT scan shows 0.5 cm kidney stone in proximal right ureter, no hydronephrosis

A (Assessment):

* Acute nephrolithiasis (kidney stone)

P (Plan):

* Recommend increased fluid intake to facilitate passage of the stone
* Prescribe oxycodone 5 mg every 6–8 hours as needed for pain
* Continue alternating with Tylenol for pain management
* Provide urine strainer for stone collection
* Order basic metabolic panel, urinalysis, and urine culture
* Outpatient follow-up in 1–2 weeks
* Discuss further treatment options (lithotripsy, ureteroscopy) if symptoms persist
* Advise to contact physician if symptoms worsen

transcription:

[doctor] okay now i know this was caused by a new pair of shoes you had mentioned before to your pcp and he relayed this to me that you really like to go on hikes you and your wife have been hiking have you gone to the new trails that that were just opened up here behind the park

[patient] i do n't feel that right there
[doctor] okay i'm gon na review the results of your right foot x-ray that we did when you came in today the good news is i do n't see any evidence of osteomyelitis meaning that there is no infection of the bone so let's talk a little bit about my assessment and plan for this nonhealing diabetic foot ulcer i'm going to order a test to check blood supply for this wound also i'm going to do a debridement today in the office we may have to look at we are going to do a culture and we may have to look at different antibiotic therapy i am concerned about the redness that's moving up your leg as well as this the the swelling and pain that you have in your calf so we're gon na monitor this very closely i wan na see you again in seven days and then as far as your diabetes is concerned i do want you to follow up with your endocrinologist and make sure that we do continue to keep your hemoglobin a1c below seven and we're gon na need to closely monitor your blood sugars since we're going to be doing some medication therapy with antibiotics and and potentially some other medications any other questions comments or concerns before i have the nurse come in we're gon na prep you for that procedure

[doctor] correct
[patient] if i heard
[doctor] yep that's correct so what we're gon na do is you said you're six days in do a ten or twelve day course so we're gon na go ahead and continue your antibiotics therapy that your pcp put you on i do want to get the culture back and then we'll make the determination as far as additional or changing that antibiotic therapy
[patient] okay sounds good
[doctor] alright
SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Nonhealing right foot ulcer
* History of present illness: Six-week history of right heel ulcer initially due to blister from new, tight shoes; burning and stinging sensation at onset, now described as severe throbbing pain ("like a fire poker"); foul odor, yellow drainage, black area at wound edge, increased pain radiating up to knee, cramping of calf muscle, red streak ascending to inside of calf, area very hot to touch; started on antibiotics by PCP six days ago; developed chills and mild fever (99.7°F), but no nausea or vomiting; cough for last two days, shortness of breath on exertion
* Past medical history: Diabetes mellitus (well controlled, A1c 6.7 for two years), diabetic neuropathy, previous history of poorly controlled diabetes (prior A1c 13), checks blood sugars 2–3 times daily, recently more variable with readings 300–400 mg/dL over past two weeks, one recent spike to 500–600 mg/dL
* Social history: Enjoys hiking, uses diabetic shoes and inserts (changed every 3–4 months), went hiking shortly after getting new shoes, daily foot checks
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Slight fever noted (exact value not specified), otherwise stable
* Physical exam: Necrotic 2x2 cm wound on right heel, tissue sloughing, yellow drainage, foul odor, cellulitis and erythema around lesion, no bony exposure, area very hot to touch, red streaking up medial calf, calf muscle hard and tender, decreased sensation to pain at wound
* Vascular exam: Bilateral femoral and popliteal pulses palpable; dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses not palpable but present by Doppler
* Test results: Right foot x-ray negative for osteomyelitis

A (Assessment):

* Diabetic foot ulcer, nonhealing with necrosis and cellulitis
* Diabetes mellitus, well controlled previously, now poorly controlled
* Possible vascular compromise to right lower extremity
* Differential diagnosis: Deep vein thrombosis, infection with ascending cellulitis

P (Plan):

* Continue current antibiotic therapy, adjust based on wound culture results
* Perform office wound debridement today
* Obtain wound culture
* Order additional test to assess blood supply to the wound
* Monitor redness and swelling; close follow-up in 7 days
* Instruct patient to follow up with endocrinologist to optimize diabetes management, aim for continued A1c <7%
* Closely monitor blood glucose during antibiotic and any new medication therapy
* Prepare patient for procedure (nurse to assist)

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Tick bite around the right knee with burning and annoyance for over a week
- History of present illness: Burning sensation and annoyance at right knee tick bite site for over a week, reports the area feels warm, no fever or chills, no difficulty moving knee, no trouble walking, no flu-like symptoms except for headache and generally not feeling well since the tick bite, no cough, shortness of breath, or dizziness, no new joint pain aside from usual arthritic pain
- Past medical history: Hypertension, diabetes mellitus, history of multiple prior tick bites (when younger), no prior diagnosis of Lyme disease
- Social history: Frequently outdoors, works in yard, hunts, recently went hunting about two weeks ago, sometimes takes grandchildren hunting
- Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: Blood pressure 122/70 mmHg, heart rate 67 bpm, temperature 98.4°F
- Physical exam: Erythema and edema with area of fluctuance over right patella, bull’s-eye rash present over right knee, pain to palpation at right anterior knee, full range of motion of right knee, no murmur, rub, or gallop on cardiac exam, lungs clear bilaterally
- Test results: No new lab/imaging results available at this visit; patient reports home blood sugars run in the 120s mg/dL, kidney function previously normal when checked two months ago

A (Assessment):

- Suspected Lyme disease (based on tick bite, bull's-eye rash, local findings)
- Hypertension, well-controlled
- Diabetes mellitus, well-controlled

P (Plan):

- Start doxycycline 100 mg orally twice daily for 3 weeks
- Order Lyme titer and Western blot
- Monitor response to antibiotics; avoid intravenous antibiotics unless necessary
- Continue lisinopril 20 mg once daily
- Order lipid panel
- Continue metformin 1000 mg twice daily
- Order hemoglobin A1c
- Order basic metabolic panel to check kidney function
- Outpatient follow-up as needed

P (Plan):

- Apply ice for pain and swelling
- Prescribe Motrin 800 mg three times a day with food
- Advise follow-up in one week if no improvement
- Order procedures and medications as discussed

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Shortness of breath
- History of present illness: Shortness of breath with exertion (e.g., walking up a flight of stairs) for approximately 10 days, mild lower extremity swelling, lethargy, discomfort and stiffness in the morning upon waking, one episode of waking acutely short of breath at night about one week ago with no recurrence, recent intake of salty foods at house parties, no chest pain, fever, chills, cough, or abdominal pain
- Past medical history: Type I diabetes (on insulin pump), congestive heart failure, depression, reflux
- Social history: Admits to difficulty reducing alcohol intake during holidays, consumes chocolate bars, no reported illicit drug use or tobacco use (No information provided)
- Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: Within normal limits, oxygen saturation normal in office
- Physical exam: No jugular venous distension, no carotid bruits, 3/6 systolic ejection murmur, bilateral basal crackles on lung exam, 1+ pitting edema in lower extremities
- Test results: Chest x-ray with no evidence of airspace disease or pneumonia, laboratory results with normal white blood cell count (no infection)

A (Assessment):

- Acute heart failure exacerbation
- Type I diabetes
- Depression
- Gastroesophageal reflux disease

P (Plan):

- Prescribe furosemide (Lasix) 40 mg orally daily
- Daily weight monitoring; instruct patient to call if weight does not decrease or increases, or if experiencing increased shortness of breath at rest
- Advise emergency department visit or calling 911 if significant respiratory distress occurs
- Order hemoglobin A1c in approximately one month
- Recommend follow-up with endocrinologist
- Ensure recent eye exam completed for diabetes management
- Refer to psychiatry for talk therapy for depression (no medications to start at this time)
- Continue omeprazole 20 mg daily for reflux
- Reinforce follow-up by phone if symptoms worsen

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Back pain
- History of present illness: Sudden onset of lower back pain approximately 6 days ago while walking (30–60 minutes daily), described as back "seizing up" or spasm. Patient has increased lifting activity to three times a week (deadlifts performed prior to onset). Pain affects both sides of lower back equally, stiffness persists despite ibuprofen and heat application. No trauma reported, may have used back muscles more than legs. No numbness, tingling, or weakness in lower extremities.
- Past medical history: Hypertension
- Medications: Lisinopril
- Social history: Increased exercise frequency, walking daily, boyfriend supporting dietary changes for blood pressure control
- Review of systems: Endorses back pain and mild nasal congestion attributed to seasonal allergies; denies fever, chills, cough, chest pain, or shortness of breath
- Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: Blood pressure well controlled (per office and home measurements), other vital signs within normal limits
- Physical exam: Heart exam reveals stable 2/6 systolic ejection murmur; back exam shows pain to palpation on right lateral lumbar spine, pain with flexion and extension, negative straight leg raise; remainder of exam unremarkable
- Test results: Lumbar spine x-ray shows good bony alignment, no obvious fracture; laboratory results normal, no elevated white blood cell count or signs of infection

A (Assessment):

- Lumbar strain
- Hypertension, controlled

P (Plan):

- Prescribe meloxicam 15 mg orally once daily for back pain
- Continue ibuprofen and heat or ice as needed
- Refer to physical therapy for back strengthening exercises
- Continue lisinopril 10 mg orally daily
- Refill lisinopril prescription
- Monitor blood pressure at home and report any increases
- No further follow-up instructions provided
- No information provided regarding additional patient education or return precautions

[patient] um , can i take all my medicine at the same time ? does it matter ?
[doctor] yeah . you can set an alarm so that it reminds you to take your medication . but yeah , you can , you can take them altogether .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] all right . hey , dragon , finalize the note .
