SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Possible kidney stone; follow-up for hypertension and diabetes
- History of present illness: Intermittent kidney pain starting last week, went to ER, believes stone passed 3 days ago; previously noted blood in urine (resolved); reports no current pain. History of 7-8 kidney stones, most recent episode resolved.
- Past medical history: Hypertension, type 2 diabetes, recurrent nephrolithiasis
- Current medications: Norvasc 2.5 mg daily, metformin 500 mg daily, recent Percocet use (provided in ER for kidney stone pain)
- Medication adherence: Reports regular use of Norvasc and metformin
- Home blood pressure readings: Typically 130-140/60-70 mmHg; describes "white coat syndrome" during office visits
- Diet: Difficulty reducing fast food intake due to busy lifestyle
- Blood glucose: Does not check often, believes it has been "pretty good"
- Social history: No information provided
- Family history: No information provided
- Other symptoms: Denies current chest pain, abdominal pain, or back pain
- Sleep: Occasional insomnia attributed to worry; tries meditation apps (reports some benefit); sleeps with TV and phone on; not interested in prescription sleep aids; previous minimal benefit from melatonin

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: Blood pressure 150/90 mmHg (in office today)
- Physical exam: Lungs clear bilaterally, no crackles; heart with grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur (stable from previous exams); abdomen non-tender on palpation; no costovertebral angle (CVA) tenderness bilaterally; back non-tender
- Test results: Last hemoglobin A1c reported at 6.7% following previous visit
- No additional laboratory or imaging data provided

A (Assessment):

- Recurrent nephrolithiasis, currently resolved episode
- Hypertension, controlled on Norvasc, possible white coat syndrome
- Type 2 diabetes mellitus, stable (A1c 6.7%)
- Insomnia

P (Plan):

- Order urinalysis and urine culture
- Refer to urology (specific request for Dr. Harris)
- Continue Norvasc 2.5 mg daily; no change, no immediate refills needed
- Continue metformin 500 mg daily
- Nutrition referral for dietary counseling
- Advise reduced sodium intake (<2300 mg/day)
- Instruct patient to monitor blood glucose before each meal
- Prescribe melatonin 10 mg as needed for sleep
- Reinforce sleep hygiene practices (limit electronics at bedtime, dark/cool room)
- Outpatient follow-up in 3 months

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Persistent asthma symptoms with frequent coughing and wheezing
- History of present illness: Asthma flares occurring every month or every other month for the past six months, typically triggered by respiratory infections; one episode triggered by exposure to a cat; frequent use of albuterol inhaler (almost daily use, including a few times per week at night); waking up a couple of times a week due to symptoms; previous urgent care, primary care, and emergency department visits for asthma, with treatment including antibiotics and steroid tapers (prednisone); last exacerbation about one month ago
- Past medical history: Hospitalized for asthma as a child (around age 8); no hospitalizations since then
- Social history: Enjoys outdoor activities like walking and hiking (currently limited by asthma symptoms); does not smoke cigarettes, marijuana, or vape; occasional exposure to secondhand smoke in bars, which causes irritation; avoids aunt’s house due to cat allergy trigger
- Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: Blood pressure 128/82 mmHg, respiratory rate 16/min, oxygen saturation 99% on room air
- Physical exam: Heart regular rate and rhythm with no murmurs, rubs, or gallops noted; lung exam reveals diminished breath sounds with occasional slight expiratory wheeze bilaterally; neck supple, trachea midline, no lymphadenopathy, no carotid bruit; hands with strong bilateral pulses, no clubbing, brisk capillary refill
- Test results: Pulmonary function test consistent with asthma

A (Assessment):

- Asthma, moderate intermittent

P (Plan):

- Initiate Flovent (fluticasone) 110 mcg, one puff twice daily (inhaled steroid)
- Continue Ventolin (albuterol) inhaler, two puffs every 4–6 hours as needed
- Create and provide an asthma action plan
- Advise consistent use of inhaled steroid to reduce daily symptoms and albuterol use
- Schedule follow-up in 1 month or sooner if symptoms worsen

[patient] yeah it feels like a sharp stabbing pain in my back and it does go down even down to my right leg sometimes all the way down to my toe it feels like my big toe

[patient] no nothing like that

[patient] i would n't say i have any weakness no

[patient] no
[doctor] okay now you mentioned earlier that you you have some tried tried some things in the past so tell me what were they
[patient] so i've tried some physical therapy before and so when it gets really bad they've even had to prescribe some strong pain medications for me but that was only temporary and they even mentioned surgery to me in the past but i really would like to avoid surgery
[doctor] okay sure so tell me what is your day like
[patient] my day so i try to be as active as i can but of course it's been difficult with my back pain and so because of that i have gained some weight over the past years
[doctor] okay alright well i'm sorry to hear that i know that you used to like playing golf
[patient] yeah i and you know golf is relatively new for me i've been trying to get into it but this has definitely set me back
[doctor] yeah i'm sorry yep probably now at the peak of you know just learning it and being able to do more with it this comes and this happens right
[patient] exactly
[doctor] well let's see what we can do for you here so you can go out into the you know the golf course again now do you tell me do you have any family members with spine conditions
[patient] no i ca n't recall any family members
[doctor] okay alright and do you smoke
[patient] not now i i quit about twenty years ago
[doctor] okay alright well alright well i like to do a quick physical exam on you here
[patient] okay
[doctor] i'm gon na go ahead here i reviewed your vitals and they overall look pretty good so that's a good sign now on your musculoskeletal back exam there is no overlying erythema and that just means redness or ecchymosis and that just means bruising of the skin now there is midline tenderness at l4 l5 disk space with right-sided lumbar paravertebral tenderness so do me a favor and i'm gon na just have you you know bend forward and straighten up a bit

[doctor] sorry so definitely some pain with lumbar flexion and supine straight leg test is positive so on your neurological examination there is decreased sensation to light touch at the right lateral thigh at l4 dermatome okay and i'm just gon na take a look at your knees here real quick and then your your ankles so patellar and achilles reflexes are symmetrical so good now i reviewed the results of your mri and it shows disk herniation with nerve impingement so let me tell you about my assessment and plan here larry so for your problem of chronic lumbar back pain so based on your symptoms your exam and reviewing your mri results your symptoms are consistent with an l4 l5 herniated disk with radicul radiculopathy so this means that one of your disks that sits between your spinal vertebrae is bulging out and this bulge is pinching on some nerves and that's why you feel that tingling in your leg so yeah yeah so i am recommending a spinal injection with a strong inflammatory medication called a corticosteroid and what i do is i will inject the corticosteroid into that lumbar spine under fluoroscopy which you can think of you know an x-ray to help localize to the exact area of your pain now this should this should help the inflammation that is causing the pain so what do you think about that
[patient] is there something i'm gon na have to do all the time
[doctor] well you know patients are different so what we do is we will monitor you and we see how you respond to the injection and the patient's intervals can be different as well but we usually do not do more than four times a year
[patient] okay okay
[doctor] alright and it's not a long procedure it's it's relatively quick and common and you should be out of the office within an hour
[patient] okay
[doctor] okay
[patient] alright sounds good

[doctor] alright thank you
[patient] bye
SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Chronic back pain
* History of present illness: Back pain present for a couple of years, began after moving furniture, described as sharp stabbing pain in the back radiating to the right leg and big toe, associated with numbness and tingling to the right leg and foot, discomfort worsened when sitting, unable to get comfortable, denies weakness, denies loss of bladder or bowel control, denies loss of sensation in genital or rectal area
* Past treatments: Tried physical therapy, intermittent use of strong pain medications, surgery previously mentioned but prefers to avoid it
* Impact on daily life: Difficulty being active due to back pain, weight gain over past years, reduced ability to play golf
* Past medical history: No information provided
* Social history: Former smoker (quit 20 years ago), tries to remain active
* Family history: No known family members with spine conditions

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Reviewed, overall within normal limits
* Physical exam: No overlying erythema or ecchymosis of the back, midline tenderness at L4-L5 disk space, right-sided lumbar paravertebral tenderness, pain with lumbar flexion, positive supine straight leg test, decreased sensation to light touch at right lateral thigh (L4 dermatome), patellar and Achilles reflexes symmetrical
* Test results: MRI shows disk herniation with nerve impingement

A (Assessment):

* L4-L5 herniated disk with radiculopathy

P (Plan):

* Recommend and initiate spinal injection with corticosteroid under fluoroscopic guidance
* Monitor response to injection, repeat as needed but not to exceed four times per year
* Outpatient procedure, expected duration under one hour
* No other plans documented

SOAP:

- History of present illness: Right knee pain and swelling began five days ago after twisting injury while water skiing (landing from a jump); no popping sound or sensation, felt like something stretched; swelling developed after injury; pain is worse with squatting or bending; no numbness or tingling in the foot; over-the-counter Aleve twice a day and cold packs provided some relief but pain persists; first episode, no prior right knee injuries

O (Objective):

- Physical exam: No cervical lymphadenopathy, regular heart rate and rhythm, no cardiac murmur, lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally, right knee with ecchymosis, edema, effusion, pain to palpation of right medial knee, decreased range of motion, negative varus and valgus stress tests, negative Lachman sign, palpable dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses, no lower extremity edema

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Incidentally found lung nodule
* History of present illness: Cough that began approximately 3 months ago after loading hay, worsened during that period, was accompanied by a cold, led to visit to PCP who diagnosed bronchitis, cough has since resolved
* Past medical history: Rheumatoid arthritis (RA)
* Medications: Methotrexate 7.5 mg weekly
* Social history: Previous smoker, quit 7 years ago, bikes frequently, worked with horses, no current tobacco use
* Family history: Mother had breast cancer (currently doing well), no family history of lung cancer or other malignancies, no history of lung infections or pneumonia reported
* Associated symptoms: No pain, no shortness of breath reported

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Blood pressure 124/76 mmHg, heart rate 70 bpm, respiratory rate 16/min, SpO2 98% on room air, afebrile
* Physical exam: Lungs clear and equal bilaterally, heart regular rate and rhythm without murmurs, clicks, or rubs, skin pink/warm/dry, no lower extremity edema, mild swelling of third digit knuckles on both hands, pulses intact, capillary refill brisk
* Test results: Chest X-ray and CT scan reveal solitary 2 cm smooth nodule in lateral aspect of right upper lobe, no evidence of emphysematous disease

A (Assessment):

* Incidentally found solitary right upper lobe lung nodule
* History of rheumatoid arthritis
* Previous smoking history

P (Plan):

* Order pulmonary function test (PFT) for baseline lung function
* Schedule PET-CT to evaluate metabolic activity of lung nodule
* Plan for video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery (VATS) with resection of lung nodule and adjacent lung tissue under general anesthesia
* Admit for post-operative monitoring, anticipate 1-night hospital stay with chest tube removal the following day
* Continue rheumatology follow-up and methotrexate for rheumatoid arthritis
* Support and reassurance provided
* Complete treatment consent paperwork before proceeding

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Difficulty swallowing
- History of present illness: Sensation of something stuck in throat for past 4–5 weeks, occasionally mildly painful, more noticeable with solid foods (e.g., sandwich, steak or meat), requires liquids to help swallow solids at times, no full choking episodes but concern about possibility, no issues with liquids, no difference with hot or cold liquids, no blood in vomit or stools, no vomiting, no weight loss, no chest pain, no shortness of breath.
- Past medical history: Diabetes mellitus, hypertension
- Medication history: Metformin 500 mg twice daily for diabetes, Norvasc for hypertension
- Social history: No information provided
- Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: Blood pressure 120/50 mmHg (in office)
- Physical exam: Neck normal, no swelling, no thyroid enlargement or masses, no lymphadenopathy; throat normal, no masses, swelling, or redness; no carotid bruit; lungs clear; heart exam normal, no murmurs; abdomen with epigastric tenderness, no palpable masses or significant swelling; back exam normal; extremities normal; neurological exam normal
- Test results: Previous hemoglobin A1c 7.4%; no current lab results available

A (Assessment):

- Dysphagia, possible esophageal stricture or narrowing, needs gastroenterology evaluation
- Diabetes mellitus
- Hypertension

P (Plan):

- Refer to gastroenterology for endoscopic evaluation (scope) of esophagus
- Start Prilosec 20 mg once daily
- Advise careful and thorough chewing of solid foods, especially tough meats; emergency department visit if food fully stuck and not passing
- Repeat hemoglobin A1c and order additional blood work (including kidney function)
- Refer to ophthalmology for diabetic retinopathy screening
- Continue metformin 500 mg twice daily
- Continue Norvasc; refill sent to pharmacy
- Outpatient follow-up in 1 month to review blood tests and management
- Instructed to contact office with new or worsening symptoms or medication issues

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Right ankle injury with pain, swelling, and bruising
- History of present illness: Landed awkwardly on right ankle after being fouled during basketball, resulting in pain on the outside of the ankle, visible bruising and swelling, difficulty walking, and sensation of instability; injury occurred while playing basketball with son, wants to avoid disruption to recently resumed exercise routine and upcoming coaching commitments
- Past medical history: No information provided
- Social history: Recently resumed gym workouts, participates in recreational basketball, plans to coach a basketball team in April, works from home, concerned about inability to walk dogs due to injury
- Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Physical exam: Swelling on the lateral side of right ankle, exquisite tenderness laterally, some tenderness over the medial deltoid region, skin intact without epidermolysis, brisk capillary refill, no significant malalignment observed
- Vital signs: No information provided
- Test results: Right ankle x-ray shows displaced lateral malleolus fracture at Weber C level, no evidence of medial or posterior malleolar fractures

A (Assessment):

- Lateral malleolar fracture of the right ankle

P (Plan):

- Surgical intervention recommended: plate and screw fixation of lateral malleolus
- Prescribe meloxicam for pain and swelling
- Advise ice and elevation of affected ankle
- Provide crutches for mobility support
- Estimated recovery time: approximately three months before resuming full activity
- Encourage continuation of coaching role as able
- No information provided regarding follow-up schedule

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Stabbing, shooting pain in the right cheekbone area of the face
- History of present illness: Pain present for 2-3 months, episodes of excruciating, stabbing, shooting pain on the right side of the face (cheekbone area); pain sometimes feels very hot, lasts from a few minutes up to an hour, usually a few minutes; pain triggered by certain temperatures, cold, and wind; no reported sensory loss initially but later noticed some numbness on the right side during examination; pain severity rated as 10/10 at peak; ibuprofen, Motrin, and tiger balm provided no relief
- Past medical history: No history of multiple sclerosis, brain tumors, or migraines; occasional headaches responsive to Tylenol
- Social history: No information provided
- Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Physical exam: Extraocular movements intact, facial symmetry intact on smiling, hearing symmetric bilaterally, decreased sensation and dullness to pinprick and light touch on the right side of the face compared to the left
- Test results: MRI demonstrates a small blood vessel abutting and possibly compressing the trigeminal nerve

A (Assessment):

- Trigeminal neuralgia due to vascular compression

P (Plan):

- Prescribe Tegretol (carbamazepine)
- Discuss potential side effects of Tegretol, including memory loss, tingling, imbalance, dermatologic reactions, and need for genetic testing in certain populations
- Genetic testing to assess Tegretol safety if indicated
- Follow-up appointment in 1 month to assess response to therapy
- Consider surgical options (nerve decompression) if medication is ineffective

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Right knee injury with pain and inability to bear weight
- History of present illness: Right knee injury sustained while skiing in Vermont; caught ski when coming off the lift and fell, experienced a "pop" in the knee, pain localized to the outside (lateral aspect), feeling of instability and risk of buckling, unable to bear weight and required ski patrol assistance, initial ability to bend knee, now unable to bend it easily, pain with full extension, no numbness or tingling in toes, can feel toes normally
- Past medical history: No hypertension, no diabetes, generally healthy
- Social history: Active lifestyle, cares for twin four-year-olds, husband works and is frequently away, currently uses crutches, desires to return to running, no other regular exercise at this time
- Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: No information provided
- Physical exam: Heart sounds regular rate and rhythm, no murmur; lungs clear to auscultation; right knee shows edema and effusion, pain to palpation of right lateral knee, decreased flexion and extension, positive Lachman sign; dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses palpable; no edema at the ankle
- Test results: Right knee X-ray shows no bony abnormality

A (Assessment):

- Suspected right anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) rupture
- Pain lateral aspect of right knee, concern for additional structural injury

P (Plan):

- Order right knee MRI to evaluate ACL and other possible structural injuries
- Continue ibuprofen 600–800 mg every 8 hours as needed for pain
- Apply knee brace for support
- Follow-up after MRI to discuss results and further management
- No change in pain medication as patient declines stronger analgesics

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Neck pain
* History of present illness: Severe, sharp, incapacitating neck pain since a car crash in February (year not specified); prior history of multiple car crashes, neck pain worsened after the most recent incident; pain intensity reported as 12/10, worsened by movement, cannot work due to pain; reports stiffness, occasional bruising, spasms, numbness in left arm and right leg, occasional dizziness, headaches, fatigue since the accident; no recent visual disturbances
* Past medical history: Previous surgery after a third car crash, previously attended therapy following prior accidents
* Medication history: Recently prescribed fentanyl (no prescription for several weeks), previously prescribed at a pain clinic
* Social history: No information provided
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided
* Physical exam: Pain on palpation over both midline bony process and lateral neck muscles, moderate range of neck movement observed with significant pain on movement (side-to-side, flexion, extension), no visible bruising, swelling, or laceration on exam, patient unable to actively move neck without severe discomfort
* Test results: Neck x-ray reviewed in clinic—no fracture noted

A (Assessment):

* Neck sprain
* Plan for further evaluation to rule out fracture or additional pathology with MRI

P (Plan):

* Order MRI of the cervical spine
* Prescribe Robaxin 1500 mg every 6–8 hours for muscle relaxation and pain relief
* Refer to physical therapy; provide exercise instructions for neck mobility
* Advise use of ice for any observed bruising or swelling, consideration of heat pad, IcyHot, or Biofreeze if needed
* Refer to pain medicine for further management/injections if pain is refractory to current treatment
* Excuse patient from work pending MRI results
* Consider local injections based on MRI findings
* Follow-up after MRI to reassess treatment plan

SOAP:

* Chief complaint: Annual exam
* History of present illness: No chest pain, no shortness of breath, no leg swelling reported; recent increase in travel and hiking; patient received COVID-19 vaccine and feels safer about traveling; some nasal congestion due to fall allergies; no nausea, vomiting, or abdominal pain.
* Past medical history: Congestive heart failure, depression, hypertension
* Medication adherence: Taking medications for heart failure, sometimes forgets to take blood pressure medication, especially during periods of increased work stress.

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Blood pressure today is a little elevated; past blood pressure readings running high
* Physical exam: 3/6 systolic ejection murmur appreciated on heart exam (consistent with history), 1+ pitting edema in lower extremities
* Test results: Echocardiogram from last year shows left ventricular ejection fraction ~45%, mitral regurgitation present; Lipid panel from last year shows cholesterol slightly high

A (Assessment):

* Congestive heart failure
* Depression, stable on therapy
* Hypertension, uncontrolled

P (Plan):

* Increase lisinopril to 40 mg daily
* Start Lasix 20 mg daily
* Continue current heart failure medications and low sodium diet
* Repeat echocardiogram
* Repeat lipid panel

* Continue weekly therapy for depression; no need for medication at this time
* Schedule annual mammogram
* Follow up as needed for further management and review of test results

S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Joint pain
- History of present illness: Bilateral knee pain worsening after moving boxes up and down stairs over the weekend; pain equally severe in both knees, no preceding injury, not relieved by acetaminophen or ice, pain was severe enough to disrupt sleep on Saturday night
- Past medical history: Kidney transplant (for polycystic kidneys), hypothyroidism, arthritis, prior knee problems
- Medications: Acetaminophen (for knee pain, partial relief), synthroid (taken regularly), immunosuppressive medications (taken as prescribed)
- Review of systems: No fever, chills, muscle aches, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, headaches, or additional joint pain (aside from occasional mild elbow pain)
- Family history: No information provided
- Social history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: Within normal limits, afebrile, heart rate and blood pressure normal
- Physical exam: 2/6 systolic ejection murmur (stable, previously known), right knee with edema, erythema, tenderness to palpation, decreased range of motion; left knee normal in appearance
- Test results: Right knee X-ray – good bony alignment, no acute fracture; laboratory results – normal white blood cell count, normal kidney function

A (Assessment):

- Acute exacerbation of arthritis (of the right knee)
- Hypothyroidism
- Status post kidney transplant

P (Plan):

- Prescribe ultram (tramadol) 50 mg every 6 hours as needed for pain
- Order autoimmune panel
- Advise patient to take it easy; if symptoms persist, consider additional imaging and referral to physical therapy
- Continue synthroid; order thyroid panel
- Monitor arthritis, consider physical therapy referral if symptoms do not improve
- Outpatient follow-up as needed

S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Back pain
- History of present illness: Back pain for the last four days, initially intermittent but constant and severe for the last 48 hours; pain shifted from right to left side; similar to pain during kidney stones two years ago; reports possible blood in urine (urine appears off-color); dizziness and lightheadedness with exertion (e.g., climbing stairs, running for bus); some body aches attributed to favoring back while walking; increased abdominal pain on exertion; Tylenol taken for pain without relief.
- Past medical history: Kidney stones, migraines, reflux
- Social history: Recent increased consumption of take-out and fast food due to pain preventing going out and climbing stairs; reports adequate hydration.
- Family history: No information provided.

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: Blood pressure elevated (exact value not provided)
- Physical exam: Right-sided costovertebral angle (CVA) tenderness to percussion, right lower quadrant abdominal tenderness to palpation, heart and lung sounds normal
- Test results: Creatinine slightly elevated, abdominal x-ray shows possible kidney stone in lower tract (awaiting official read)

A (Assessment):

- Recurrence of kidney stones
- Migraine, stable on current therapy
- Gastroesophageal reflux disease

P (Plan):

- Order CT scan without contrast of abdomen and pelvis
- Prescribe Ultram 50 mg every six hours as needed for pain
- Advise increased fluid intake and urine straining
- Continue Imitrex for migraines
- Refill Protonix 40 mg daily for reflux
- Schedule CT scan with nursing assistance
- Provider to follow up in 1–2 days
- Instruct patient to call if symptoms worsen

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Back pain
- History of present illness: Hurt back during golf backswing on Saturday morning (4 days ago), felt a pop with immediate pain, tried Tylenol, ibuprofen, ice, and heat with minimal relief; pain improved slightly by Monday but remains sore; struggled with right leg, described as foot drop and some weakness, minimally improved this morning; able to walk slowly, avoiding strenuous activity.
- Past medical history: Congestive heart failure, type 2 diabetes, lower back surgery about 10 years ago.
- Social history: Trying to exercise regularly, adheres to heart failure diet (avoids salty foods), some weight gain over the summer (<5 lbs), struggles to limit sweets (jelly beans) for diabetes.
- Family history: No information provided.

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: Normal, within normal limits in office.
- Physical exam: 2/6 systolic ejection murmur (stable, heard previously), pain to palpation over lumbar spine at L5, decreased range of motion (flexion and extension), positive straight leg raise, right lower extremity strength 4/5, left lower extremity 5/5.
- Test results: Lumbar spine X-ray—normal, good bony alignment, no abnormalities; last diabetic labs—hemoglobin A1c elevated at 8.

A (Assessment):

- Acute lumbar strain
- Type 2 diabetes, uncontrolled (A1c elevated)
- Congestive heart failure, stable

P (Plan):

- Prescribe meloxicam 15 mg once daily for back pain
- Refer to physical therapy for lumbar strain
- If persistent symptoms, order MRI of lumbar spine to rule out disc herniation
- Increase metformin to 1,000 mg twice daily
- Order repeat hemoglobin A1c in a couple of months
- Continue current congestive heart failure medications: lisinopril and furosemide (Lasix)
- Refill lisinopril 20 mg once daily
- Outpatient follow-up in a couple of weeks

- Start Zoloft 25 mg once daily
- Repeat hemoglobin A1c in three months
- Continue home monitoring of blood sugars
- Outpatient follow-up as usual
- No information provided regarding referrals or additional education

[doctor] perfect . so , let me go grab your discount card for the unithroid . um , when you go in to activate it , the instructions are on this card , and then you use your insurance ... then , show them this , and ask how much it'll cost . if it's too expensive , just let me know .

[doctor] so , under the plan , under abnormal liver enzymes , they have improved since discontinuation of her birth control . under abnormal weight gain , her dexamethasone suppression test was normal . two out of three salivary cortisol tests were normal , not consistent with cushing's , and therefore we're ruling out cushing's . under her hirsutism , her androgen levels were normal . for the acne vulgaris , the epiduo was not covered , so we'll try benzoyl peroxide with clindamycin , and remove the previous information . on the hyperthyroidism , we'll print out her prescriptions . unithroid should be better priced with the discount card , and we'll repeat levels of everything before next visit . thanks .
SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Weight gain, acne, concerns about thyroid medication affordability
* History of present illness: Difficulty affording newly prescribed thyroid medication (unithroid), continuing old medication; unable to afford prescribed gel for acne; questioning whether prior birth control may have contributed to weight gain; intermittent foot swelling; constipation; sensitive skin prone to rashes; asking about CLA and chromium supplements for weight loss (no prior use), asking about amino acids for workout; interest in weight loss study; has meal plans from previous visit; planning to resume gym workouts after July 8th
* Past medical history: Thyroid disorder, history of elevated liver enzymes (ALT as high as 254 in October, improved after stopping birth control)
* Social history: No information provided
* Family history: No information provided
* Medication allergies: No known medication allergies

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided
* Physical exam: Heart and lungs auscultation normal, feet and ankles unremarkable at exam
* Test results: 
    - COVID vaccine completed
    - Dexamethasone suppression test passed (no evidence of Cushing’s syndrome)
    - Salivary cortisol: 2/3 normal, 1 abnormal (may repeat in the future)
    - Cholesterol: Total 222, HDL 44, LDL 153, non-HDL 178 (LDL >100, non-HDL >130, HDL <50)
    - Screen for diabetes: Normal
    - Vitamin D deficiency present
    - Pituitary hormones and iron levels: Within normal limits
    - ALT improved: 254 (October) → 128 (recent) → 30 (recent), improved after discontinuing birth control
* Medications: Currently taking older thyroid medication, vitamin D supplement started
* Other: Unable to afford prescribed gel for acne (epiduo), sensitivity to topical products noted

A (Assessment):

* Abnormal liver enzymes, improved since discontinuation of birth control
* Weight gain
* Thyroid disorder
* Vitamin D deficiency
* Acne vulgaris
* Constipation
* Sensitive skin
* No evidence of Cushing’s syndrome (ruled out based on dexamethasone suppression test and salivary cortisol)
* Hirsutism, androgen levels normal

P (Plan):

* For liver enzymes: Continue monitoring, anticipate further improvement with weight loss
* For weight gain: Low-carb diet, avoid alcohol and fatty foods, focus on low-cholesterol foods, resume exercise; weight loss study information provided—eligible due to BMI and cholesterol, consider participation; avoid CLA and chromium supplements if entering study
* For thyroid disorder: Provide discount card for unithroid; encourage patient to shop around at different pharmacies; print prescriptions for patient to compare prices; repeat thyroid labs before next visit
* For vitamin D deficiency: Continue vitamin D supplementation, transition to 2000 IU daily after completion of current dose, defer rechecking vitamin D level for now
* For acne vulgaris: Prescribe clindamycin gel and benzoyl peroxide separately to reduce cost; apply benzoyl peroxide at night to avoid sun reaction, caution about bleaching sheets
* For contraception: Offer information on Phexxi (vaginal gel), to be applied before intercourse, available if needed
* For constipation: Continue or initiate Miralax as previously recommended
* For sensitive skin: Monitor for rashes with new topical agents, advise patient to report issues
* Labs: Order comprehensive labs before next visit
* Follow-up: Call research office within a month if interested in weight loss study, return for follow-up after labs and trial of new medications

transcription:
[doctor] this is philip gutierrez , date of birth 1/12/71 . he is a 50-year-old male here for a second opinion regarding the index finger on the right hand . he had a hyperextension injury of that index finger during a motor vehicle accident in march of this year . he was offered an injection of the a1 polyregion , but did not want any steroid because of the reaction to dexamethasone , which causes his heart to race . he was scheduled to see dr. alice davis , which it does n't appear he did . he had an mri of that finger , because there was concern about a capsular strain plus or minus rupture of , quote , " fds tendon , " end quote . he has been seen at point may orthopedics largely by the physical therapy staff and a pr , pa at that institution .
[doctor] at that practice , an mri was obtained on 4/24/2021 , which showed just focal soft tissue swelling over the right index mcp joint , partial-thickness tear of the right fds , and fluid consistent with tenosynovitis around the fdp and fds tendons . radial and ulnar collateral ligaments of the index mcp joint were intact , as the mcp joint capsule . extensor tendons also deemed intact .
[doctor] his x-rays , four views of the right hand today , show no bony abnormalities , joint congruency throughout all lesser digits on the right hand , no soft tissue shadows of concern , no arthritis . hi , how are you , mr . gutierrez ?
[patient] i'm good , how about you ?
[doctor] well , how can i help you today ?
[patient] so i was a passenger in , uh , a car that was rear-ended , and we were hit multiple times . i felt two bumps , which slung me forward and caused me to stretch out my right index finger .
[doctor] so hitting the car in front of you all made that finger go backwards ?
[patient] um , i do n't really know . i just felt , like , it felt like i laid on my finger , and so , i felt like it went back , and it's been hurting since about march . and it's been like that ever , ever since the wreck happened . so i , and i ca n't make a fist , but sometimes the pain's unbearable . and , like , even driving hurts .
[doctor] okay , so this was march of this year , so maybe about three months ago ?
[patient] yeah , and it's still swollen . so i was seeing , uh , an orthopedist , and they sent me to an occupational therapist . and i've been doing therapy with them , and then they sent me to go back and get an mri . so i went and got the mri . uh , then they told me that the mri came back , and it said i had a tear in my finger , but he was n't gon na give me an injection , because the injection was going to make the tear worse .
[doctor] mm-hmm .
[patient] and then , after he got the mri , he said that i have , uh , a tear in my finger , and that he did n't wan na do surgery , but he would do an injection . then i'm thinking that you told me you would n't do an injection in there , and then the oper- , occupational therapy says it's because of the tear . and then , they do n't want me to keep rubbing the thing , and doing things with my hand . so i feel like i'm not getting medical care , really .
[doctor] yeah , i see that .
[patient] so i came to see if you could do anything for this hand , because i am right-handed , and i kinda need that hand .
[doctor] what do you do for a living ?
[patient] uh , i'm an x-ray tech .
[doctor] well , um , so do you have any diabetes or rheumatoid arthritis ?
[patient] nope .
[doctor] uh , do you take any chronic medications of su- , significance ?
[patient] uh , i do take a blood pressure pill , and that's it .
[doctor] okay , and it looks like you suffer from itching with the methylprednisolone ?
[patient] uh , that's correct .
[doctor] all right , well , i'm gon na scoot up closer and just take a quick look at your hand . all right , so , lean over here . all right , so on this exam today , we have a very pleasant , cooperative , healthy male , no distress . his heart rate is regular rate , rhythm , 2+ radial pulse , no swelling or bruise , bruising in the palm over the volar surface of his index finger , normal creases , slightly diminished over the pip of the index finger compared to the middle finger .
[doctor] his index finger rests in a 10-degree pip-flexed , uh , position . all right , is that uncomfortable to correct that , and is it uncomfortable now here ?
[patient] yeah , uh , when you push on it , yeah .
[doctor] all right , how about here ?
[patient] um , there , it's not .
[doctor] okay , not as bad ?
[patient] yeah , it feels , uh , a little numb .
[doctor] gotcha , all right . bend , bend the tip of this finger . bend it as hard as you can . keep bending . keep bending . all right , straighten it out . all right , and now , bend it for me as best you can .
[patient] my goodness . it feels like it's , it's tearing in there .
[doctor] okay , okay . well , bend the tip of this finger , and bend it as hard as you can . keep bending . all right , straighten that out , and now , bend it for me as best you can . all right , good . now , bend that finger , and i'm going to pull , put it down like this . and then bend that finger for me . okay , sorry , can you bend it for me ? all right . now , make a fist . great , so relax the finger . all right , so just keep it , keep , when i bend the finger , we're just going to bend that finger where it meets the hand . is that okay there ?
[patient] ow , .
[doctor] okay , okay . so all the hurt , it seems , is stretching , because you have n't been doing this for so long . so , you know what i mean ? so , um , you're going to have to start really doing that .
[patient] well , i've tried . i even bought myself a splint .
[doctor] well , but a splint does n't help move you . it actually immobilizes you .
[patient] okay . i thought it would straighten it out .
[doctor] no , no . so , so you really need to start bending the finger right here for me , as hard as you can , and keep going , going . all right , so , so you're okay . all right , so i would say the following , that there is a partial tear in one of the two flexor tendons . there is the fdp and the fds , and the fds is the least important of the two . so the mri shows that it's the fds , the flexor digitorum superficialis , which is the least important of the two .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] uh , now , there's two halves of it . so it's a partial tear of one half of a whole tendon . that's not that important , and the other one is just fine .

[doctor] right trigger finger injection template . attempted to inject one cc of celestone with f- , a half a cc of lidocaine . however , the patient had a dramatic and violent painful reaction to the introduction of the needle , with contortions of the hand , and with dangerously withdrawing the hand with concerns for secondary needle stick . needle was withdrawn . the patient was counseled as to the importance of attempting to get some therapeutic steroid in the flexor tendon sheath . we attempted a second time for a similar injection using the same technique with one cc of celestone and half a cc of lidocaine . a small parma- , uh , palmar vein bled a scant amount , which was cleaned up and band-aid applied . reassured on multiple occasions that no harm was done to his finger . recommended icing in it this evening , and taking ibuprofen .
SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Persistent right index finger pain and inability to make a fist since a motor vehicle accident in March of this year
- History of present illness: Hyperextension injury to right index finger following MVA as a passenger (rear-ended, felt finger stretch backwards), persistent pain and swelling for ~3 months, pain sometimes unbearable, difficulty driving, finger remains swollen, unable to make a fist, previous therapy and MRI, advised against steroid injection due to reaction to dexamethasone and methylprednisolone (itching and heart racing), tried splint and occupational therapy maneuvers, finger swelled after therapy
- Social history: Right-handed, works as an x-ray technician, needs right hand for work
- Past medical history: No diabetes, no rheumatoid arthritis
- Medications: Blood pressure medication (unspecified)
- Allergies/adverse reactions: Pruritus with methylprednisolone, tachycardia with dexamethasone
- Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: No information provided
- Physical exam: No distress, cooperative, healthy appearance, regular heart rate and rhythm, 2+ radial pulse, no swelling or bruising on volar index finger, normal creases except slightly diminished over PIP of index finger compared to middle, right index finger rests in 10-degree PIP flexed position, correction of deformity and PIP motion elicits discomfort, decreased ability to make a fist, reports numbness during examination, all other fingers normal, collateral ligaments and extensor tendons intact
- Test results: MRI (4/24/2021): focal soft tissue swelling over right index MCP joint, partial-thickness tear of right FDS tendon, fluid consistent with tenosynovitis around FDP and FDS tendons, intact radial and ulnar collateral ligaments, intact MCP joint capsule and extensor tendons; X-ray (today, 4 views): no bony abnormalities, joint congruency maintained, no soft tissue shadows of concern, no arthritis
- Procedures: Attempted injection of 1 cc celestone (betamethasone) with 0.5 cc lidocaine into right index finger flexor tendon sheath, patient had significant painful reaction and withdrew hand (first attempt unsuccessful), second attempt completed with minor palmar vein bleeding (controlled, band-aid applied), patient reassured, instructed to ice and take ibuprofen

A (Assessment):

- Post-traumatic rather severe stenosing tenosynovitis of the right index finger
- Partial-thickness tear of right flexor digitorum superficialis (FDS) tendon
- Scar tissue and inflammation around the FDS tendon with limitation in excursion of tendons

P (Plan):

- Injection of celestone (betamethasone) 1 cc with lidocaine 0.5 cc into right index finger flexor tendon sheath (completed on second attempt)
- Recommend icing the finger this evening and taking ibuprofen as needed
- Outpatient occupational therapy once weekly for 6 weeks
- Encourage full active and passive range of motion exercises for the right index finger without restriction
- Patient education regarding the importance of movement and adherence to therapy
- Follow up as needed for reassessment and consideration of possible repeat injection if necessary
