SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Headache
- History of present illness: Dull pain in the back of the head started about a week ago, comes and goes, worse in the evening, sometimes accompanied by flushing and heat in ears and mild dizziness, temporarily relieved by Tylenol or Advil but recurs, no fever, no visual changes, no neck or shoulder discomfort except in the back of the head, no recent head trauma, stress onset associated, similar headaches previously but not the worst headache ever
- Past medical history: Type 2 diabetes mellitus
- Medications: Metformin 500 mg twice daily, Tylenol, Advil
- Social history: Not eating well and not exercising over the last week due to stress and headache, works extensively on the computer without frequent breaks, no recent golfing activity (usual sport)
- Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Physical exam: Eye exam—extraocular motions intact without pain, funduscopic exam shows no papilledema; neck exam—mild posterior paraspinal muscular tenderness in cervical spine, bilateral trapezius muscle tenderness and tightness; heart exam—grade 3/6 systolic ejection murmur unchanged from prior exam, otherwise normal heart exam; overall physical exam otherwise normal and unremarkable
- Vital signs: No information provided
- Test results: No information provided

A (Assessment):

- Tension-type headache
- Diabetes mellitus type 2

P (Plan):

- Continue Tylenol for headache pain
- Prescribe Flexeril (cyclobenzaprine) 5 mg orally three times a day as needed for muscle relaxation
- Advise follow-up or call if headaches worsen, suddenly become severe, or if fever develops
- Continue metformin 500 mg twice daily for diabetes
- Order hemoglobin A1c, CBC, and chem-12 panel
- Instruct patient to check blood sugars daily and bring records to next visit
- Encourage resumption of exercise routine and healthy diet
- Schedule follow-up appointment in 4 weeks
- Advise earlier follow-up if headache does not improve in the next few days or if symptoms worsen

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Sore throat for 4 days
* History of present illness: Sore throat with difficulty swallowing, pain with every swallow, hard to eat but able to drink cold water which soothes symptoms; possible fever last night (very sweaty, experienced chills, did not measure temperature); mild stuffy nose; believes tonsils are swollen; no nausea
* Past medical history: Hypertension, diabetes, history of strep throat as a child
* Social history: Drinks wine nightly, works as a cashier in a supermarket, has young children who attend school (often have runny noses/cough), does not follow sports
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Temperature 100.4°F, blood pressure 132/80 mmHg, heart rate 84 bpm
* Physical exam: No facial tenderness to palpation; nasal turbinates with bilateral edema and erythema, clear discharge; throat with bilateral peritonsillar erythema and edema, bilateral exudates, uvula midline; cervical lymphadenopathy on right; lungs with coarse rhonchi at bases that clear with cough; heart regular rate and rhythm, no murmur or rub
* Test results: Rapid COVID-19 test negative
* Home blood pressure: Systolic range 120–140 mmHg reported, diastolic not recalled
* Home blood sugar: Morning 80–90 mg/dL, evening up to 140 mg/dL
* Current medications: Lisinopril 20 mg daily, metformin 1000 mg twice daily, multivitamin, vitamin D

A (Assessment):

* Upper respiratory infection
* Suspected streptococcal pharyngitis
* Hypertension
* Diabetes mellitus

P (Plan):

* Rapid strep test to be performed
* If strep test is positive, prescribe amoxicillin 500 mg three times daily for 10 days
* Prescribe lidocaine swish and swallow for throat pain
* Recommend ibuprofen as needed for pain and fever
* Recommend increased oral hydration
* Increase lisinopril to 40 mg once daily for blood pressure control
* Order lipid panel
* Order hemoglobin A1c for diabetes monitoring
* Continue metformin as currently prescribed
* Follow-up as needed; no additional instructions provided

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Right ankle pain
* History of present illness: Slipped and fell on ice yesterday while taking out the trash, heard a pop at the time of injury, initially unable to walk, currently able to bear some weight but still limping
* Pain level: 6/10 without ibuprofen, improves to 1/10 with ibuprofen, currently 4/10 with ibuprofen
* Aggravating factors: Weight-bearing
* Relieving factors: Ice, elevation, ibuprofen
* Past medical history: Multiple prior ankle injuries (not on right ankle)
* Social history: Previously played soccer in college and currently recreationally, has not played since injury
* Associated symptoms: Denies numbness or tingling in right foot
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Stated as within normal limits
* Physical exam: Ecchymosis (bruising) and edema (swelling) over lateral malleolus of right ankle, tenderness to palpation of anterior lateral soft tissue, no bony tenderness of foot or ankle, no laxity on anterior drawer and inversion stress tests, neurovascular exam of right foot shows brisk capillary refill (<3 seconds), strong dorsalis pedis pulse, intact sensation to light touch, compares equally with left side
* Test results: Right ankle x-ray shows no fracture

A (Assessment):

* Right ankle sprain involving lateral ligament complex, specifically the anterior talofibular ligament

P (Plan):

* Continue elevation and icing of right ankle
* Provide air cast for stabilization
* Prescribe crutches; remain non-weight bearing initially, advance to weight-bearing as tolerated after a few days
* Continue NSAIDs or ibuprofen as needed for pain and inflammation
* Outpatient follow-up in 14 days

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Difficulty quitting smoking
* History of present illness: Smoking since high school, initially social then daily; current consumption 1.5 packs/day; first cigarette within 1 hour of waking; previous quit attempt lasted almost a year (cold turkey), relapse due to work-related stress; motivated to quit due to impending birth of daughter; recent coping strategies include meditation and gym membership
* Past medical history: Type 2 diabetes, history of gout
* Social history: No other tobacco use reported; currently employed; impending fatherhood
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Blood pressure 128/88 mmHg, heart rate 68 bpm, respiratory rate 16/min, oxygen saturation 98% on room air
* Physical exam: Heart regular rate and rhythm, 2/6 systolic murmur appreciated, lungs clear and equal bilaterally with no expiratory wheezes, rales, or rhonchi, no lymphadenopathy in neck, no carotid bruit
* Test results: No information provided (hemoglobin A1c ordered for next visit)

A (Assessment):

* Nicotine dependence
* Type 2 diabetes
* Gout, history of

P (Plan):

* Prescribe 21 mg nicotine patch starting on designated quit date (next Monday), with plan to decrease dosage over time; instructions to change patch location daily to prevent skin irritation
* Provide handouts on smoking triggers; advise patient to monitor stress levels, especially related to work and impending fatherhood
* Encourage continued exercise, meditation, and consideration of yoga for stress management
* Schedule follow-up in 2 weeks to reevaluate nicotine patch dosage and review quit progress
* For type 2 diabetes: maintain current management with diet and exercise, order hemoglobin A1c for next blood draw, review results at follow-up
* For history of gout: continue allopurinol, continue dietary management to avoid foods that increase uric acid
* No additional questions from patient at this time

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Bilateral knee pain for approximately six months
- History of present illness: Deep, achy pain located behind both kneecaps, worsened by standing up after sitting, and going up or down stairs; pain decreases with rest and after taking ibuprofen, Aleve, or Tylenol, though not completely pain-free unless resting; no remembered injury or specific incident causing onset; unable to run more than half a mile due to knee pain (previously ran 5–6 miles/day)
- Past medical history: No previous knee injury or fractures; no prior bone injury
- Social history: Works from home, mostly seated at a desk, runs regularly (currently limited by knee pain)
- Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: Blood pressure 120/70 mmHg, heart rate 60/min, respiratory rate 14/min
- Physical exam: Normal gait, lower extremity muscle strength 5/5 except for abduction of legs bilaterally (3/5), no redness, ecchymosis, warmth, or effusion in knees, tenderness to palpation over knees, positive patellar grind test, knee pain with squatting, Lachman/anterior drawer/posterior drawer/McMurray tests all negative bilaterally, patellar and Achilles reflexes symmetrical, heart auscultation regular rate and rhythm without murmurs
- Test results: X-rays of both knees show no fractures or osteoarthritis; MRI reviewed (no additional findings mentioned)

A (Assessment):

- Patellofemoral pain syndrome

P (Plan):

- Continue ibuprofen or other anti-inflammatory medications (e.g., Aleve) as needed for pain
- Recommend physical therapy for lower extremity strengthening, mobility improvement, and correction of running mechanics
- Advise to take activity easy for now
- Plan to resume running gradually after improvement
- No further immediate interventions discussed
- No information provided regarding follow-up appointment or referrals

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Newly diagnosed ovarian cancer, evaluation and management
- History of present illness: Severe pain and bleeding prompted initial evaluation; reports constipation and weight loss; denies vomiting; feels "pretty good" but reports feeling depressed
- Past medical history: Type 2 diabetes
- Gynecologic history: Menarche at age 13, menopause at age 28, never pregnant, no use of oral hormone replacement therapy, no history of endometriosis
- Family history: Adopted; no information available regarding family history of gynecologic cancers
- Social history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Physical exam: Palpable mass on the left side of abdomen, slight tenderness to palpation in left lower quadrant, no rebound or guarding; on vaginal exam, no external lesions on labia, vaginal vault within normal limits, cervix pink without lesions; bimanual exam revealed a left adnexal mass, no right-sided masses
- Test results: Abdominal CT shows a 3 cm left ovarian mass with associated localized lymph node involvement; no evidence of gross peritoneal or metastatic disease

A (Assessment):

- Ovarian cancer, most likely stage IIIA based on CT and lymph node involvement

P (Plan):

- Order blood tests: CA-125, hCG, AFP, LDH
- Refer for genetic counseling and genetic testing
- Surgery: Plan for hysterectomy, bilateral oophorectomy, lymph node dissection, and sampling of any suspicious tissues
- Postoperative management: Initiate adjunct chemotherapy with cisplatin and taxol after recovery from surgery; consider intraperitoneal chemotherapy based on intraoperative findings
- Await final pathology report for definitive staging and prognosis determination
- Provide patient education regarding diagnosis, treatment plan, and prognosis
- Address emotional support for depression; monitor and refer as indicated
- No information provided regarding follow-up schedule

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Difficulty urinating
- History of present illness: Abnormal urination for at least 6 months, weak urinary stream, occasional sensation of incomplete bladder emptying, prolonged time required to urinate, nocturia (wakes up 3-4 times nightly to urinate), symptoms worsening over the last 6 months, denies dysuria
- Bowel symptoms: Diarrhea last week after suspected food-related cause, denies constipation
- Past medical history: Coronary artery disease with stent placement in right coronary artery in 2018, diabetes
- Medication history: Currently taking metformin
- Specialist history: No prior visits to urologist, last cardiology follow-up in November with unremarkable findings
- Social history: No information provided
- Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Physical exam: Systolic ejection murmur grade 3/6 at left base, lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally, abdomen nontender and nondistended with no masses or rebound or guarding, prostate enlarged on rectal exam with no masses
- Vital signs: No information provided
- Test results: No information provided

A (Assessment):

- Benign prostatic hyperplasia, suspected
- Coronary artery disease, follow up
- Diabetes mellitus, controlled

P (Plan):

- Prescribe Flomax (tamsulosin) 0.4 mg once daily at night
- Order PSA, routine blood tests, urinalysis, and urine culture
- Refer to urologist
- Continue Lipitor 40 mg daily, aspirin, and metoprolol for coronary artery disease
- Order echocardiogram and lipid panel
- Continue metformin 1000 mg twice daily
- Order hemoglobin A1c
- Schedule follow-up visit in 3-4 weeks
- Advise patient to call or message via patient portal with any concerns
- Physician to contact urologist for prompt appointment

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Right foot pain
* History of present illness: Acute right foot injury occurred a couple of days ago while playing tennis after falling on top of foot during a doubles game, immediate inability to bear weight, required assistance off the field, reports pain and some improvement with ibuprofen (wears off after a while), has been icing, elevating, and wrapping foot, denies numbness or loss of sensation
* Past medical history: Previous injury to left foot (not right foot)
* Social history: Recreational tennis player, unable to afford lessons, plays with friends, right-handed
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Blood pressure 125/70 mmHg, respiratory rate 18/min, temperature 97.1°F, oxygen saturation 100%, pulse 60/min
* Physical exam: Right foot with bruising of plantar and dorsal aspects, associated swelling, tenderness to palpation over midfoot, positive piano key test at first and second metatarsals, foot warm to touch; neurovascular exam of right foot shows capillary refill <3 seconds, strong dorsalis pedis pulse, sensation intact to light touch; left foot with normal capillary refill, strong pedal pulses, intact sensation; heart exam clear (no murmur, rub, gallop, regular rate and rhythm), lung exam with mild stridor (no wheeze or rales), abdomen with no rebound or guarding, skin/hair/mucosa/head normal and symmetrical, normothermic
* Test results: X-ray of right foot—subtle dorsal displacement of base of second metatarsal, 3mm separation between first and second metatarsal bases, presence of bony fragment in Lisfranc joint space

A (Assessment):

* Right foot pain consistent with Lisfranc fracture

P (Plan):

* Recommend surgical intervention (open reduction and internal fixation with plates and screws)
* Order MRI of right foot to assess for ligamentous injury
* Postoperative plan includes cast immobilization, non-weight bearing for 6–8 weeks, followed by gradual weight-bearing as tolerated
* Outpatient follow-up in 1 week
* Post-surgical referral to physical therapy for rehabilitation
* Counsel patient regarding surgical risks (bleeding, nerve injury, loss of sensation)
* Provide written information regarding procedure and risks
* Advise patient will be unable to drive and will need assistance for transportation
* Educate patient about expected absence from tennis/play for remainder of season, with goal to return next season

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Severe left back pain, started about three days ago, described as constant and radiating lower, not relieved, not yet passed kidney stone
- History of present illness: Current episode is similar to previous kidney stone episodes (3rd occurrence), has not passed the stone yet, associated with visible blood in urine today, pain is not relieved by Tylenol or ibuprofen; unable to get comfortable; reports inability to eat and some nausea, no fever but reports chills, no chest pain, no abdominal pain
- Past medical history: Hypertension, diabetes mellitus, prior kidney stones (3rd episode)
- Medication use: Tylenol and ibuprofen unsuccessfully for pain, currently on Norvasc 2.5 mg for hypertension, Metformin 500 mg for diabetes
- Home blood pressure monitoring: Systolic typically in the 130s-140s, once up to 150; diastolic between 70-80; inconsistent with home monitoring; previously much higher (180s) at diagnosis, currently has BP cuff at home
- Social history: Difficulty lowering salt intake, continued consumption of high-salt foods (e.g., French fries), open to help with dietary changes
- Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: Blood pressure on admission described as "a little bit high," no specific values provided
- Physical exam: Grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur on cardiac auscultation (previously known), lungs clear bilaterally (no crackles or wheezes), abdominal tenderness to palpation without rebound/guarding, costovertebral angle tenderness on right flank, back tenderness to palpation
- Test results: Previous A1c 7.3, prior in-clinic glucose ~300 mg/dL a few months ago, home blood sugars now in low 100s
- Other: No information provided

A (Assessment):

- Kidney stone (recurrent, current episode confirmed)
- Hypertension (adequately controlled on Norvasc 2.5 mg, no changes recommended)
- Diabetes mellitus (stable, continue Metformin 500 mg)
- Diet/nonadherence to salt recommendations (needs dietary support)

P (Plan):

- Prescribe oxycodone 5 mg every 6–8 hours as needed for pain
- Continue Tylenol for breakthrough pain
- Encourage high fluid intake to facilitate stone passage
- Provide urine strainer for stone capture
- Refer to urology for evaluation of recurrent nephrolithiasis, regardless of stone passage
- Continue Norvasc 2.5 mg for hypertension
- Continue Metformin 500 mg for diabetes
- Refer to dietitian/nutritionist for dietary counseling and salt intake reduction
- No information provided regarding follow-up interval

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Sudden onset right back pain
- History of present illness: Sudden right back pain started about one week ago while working in the barn, associated with sweating and nausea; pain radiated almost to the groin; pain has recurred a couple of times but did not last as long as initial episode; currently not experiencing pain; has been straining urine as advised and has not seen any stones or noticed any blood or darker urine
- Past medical history: No prior history of kidney stones
- Family history: Father has a history of kidney stones
- Social history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: Within normal limits; blood pressure, heart rate normal, afebrile
- Physical exam: No abdominal tenderness, rebound, or guarding; right costovertebral angle tenderness present
- Test results: CT scan shows 0.5 cm stone in proximal right ureter, no evidence of hydronephrosis

A (Assessment):

- Right ureteral kidney stone

P (Plan):

- Prescribe oxycodone 5 mg every 6–8 hours as needed for pain
- Continue acetaminophen (Tylenol) as needed for breakthrough pain
- Encourage increased fluid intake to facilitate stone passage
- Continue using urine strainer
- Order basic metabolic panel (BMP), urinalysis, and urine culture
- Consider antibiotics if urinalysis suggests infection
- Outpatient follow-up in 1–2 weeks to reassess stone passage; consider lithotripsy if stone not passed by then

- History of present illness: Right foot ulcer near the fifth metatarsophalangeal joint, possibly worsening, no pain, slight purulent discharge, associated with granulation tissue, no fever or chills, occasionally experiences numbness and tingling in feet (worse in cold), frequent tension headaches in the forehead, blood glucose levels running higher than normal, denies calf pain with walking, denies chest pain or shortness of breath
- Past medical history: Diabetes mellitus (on insulin), coronary artery disease (myocardial infarction in 2018 with right coronary artery stent), former tobacco use (smoked 2 packs/day for over 20 years, quit ~4 years ago)
- Social history: No current tobacco use, previously active outdoors, recent activity limited to staying around the house
- Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: Blood pressure 127/80 mmHg, heart rate in the 60s, afebrile
- Physical exam: No jugular venous distention, no carotid bruits, lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally; cardiac exam: 2/6 systolic ejection murmur at the left base; lower extremities: no palpable dorsalis pedis or posterior tibial pulses, 2 x 3 cm ulcerated lesion with granulation tissue and slight purulent discharge on right lateral foot near fifth metatarsophalangeal joint, no surrounding cellulitis, no pain to palpation
- Test results: No information provided

A (Assessment):

- Nonhealing right foot ulcer
- Peripheral vascular disease, suspected
- Diabetes mellitus, poorly controlled
- Coronary artery disease, history of myocardial infarction with stent

P (Plan):

- Order arterial ultrasound of lower extremities to assess blood supply
- Refer to podiatry for wound evaluation and wound care management
- Continue aspirin and statin as per current regimen
- Consult primary care physician for optimization of diabetes management
- Discuss with cardiologist regarding cardiac clearance for potential vascular procedure
- Consider vascular intervention (angioplasty/stent or bypass surgery) pending results of vascular studies
- No information provided regarding specific follow-up interval

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Right-sided back pain
* History of present illness: Back pain on right side for about a week, pain is constant, has moved to right lower side, mild nausea (no vomiting), noticed blood in urine, no pain with urination, ibuprofen provided partial relief but pain persists, pain worsened over Easter weekend, first episode of kidney stones
* Past medical history: No information provided
* Family history: Father had kidney stones (unsure of details)
* Social history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Normal, no fever, blood pressure and heart rate within normal limits
* Physical exam: Mild abdominal pain and tenderness to palpation, no rebound or guarding, right costovertebral angle (CVA) tenderness
* Test results: Abdominal CT shows 0.5 cm stone in proximal right ureter, no hydronephrosis

A (Assessment):

* Kidney stone in proximal right ureter

P (Plan):

* Prescribe ibuprofen 800 mg as needed for pain
* Advise increased fluid intake to facilitate passage of stone
* Provide urine strainer to monitor for passage of stone
* Order basic metabolic panel (BMP), urinalysis, and urine culture
* Plan to evaluate urinalysis results to determine need for antibiotics if infection is detected
* Follow-up appointment in 1–2 weeks; consider further treatment (e.g., lithotripsy) if symptoms persist

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Itchy scalp pain
- History of present illness: Persistent, worsening itchy scalp for several months (noted as worsening over past 6 months), associated with dandruff and embarrassment, unable to stop itching
- Past treatments: Used over-the-counter treatments including Head & Shoulders shampoo, T-Gel shampoo, castor oil; no significant improvement
- Use of hair products: Dyes hair, but has done so for years; no new products recently
- Associated symptoms: No rashes elsewhere on body, denies joint pain, fever, or weight loss
- Family history: Sister with dry scalp, no one else in family with similar symptoms
- Social history: No information provided
- Psychosocial: No new mental or emotional stressors reported

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: Blood pressure 130/68 mmHg, heart rate 98/min, respiratory rate 18/min, temperature 97.7°F
- Physical exam: Demarcated, scaly erythematous plaques in a patchy distribution diffusely present across the back of the scalp, visible dandruff
- Test results: No information provided

A (Assessment):

- Scalp psoriasis

P (Plan):

- Prescribe clobetasol 0.05% solution, to be applied twice daily to affected scalp areas (morning and night)
- Continue use of T-Gel shampoo regularly
- Educate patient on the chronic and unpredictable course of scalp psoriasis and the need for ongoing management
- Use steroid solution during flare-ups as directed
- Follow-up appointment in 3 months or sooner if symptoms significantly worsen

[doctor] okay alright so when you dropped that brick on your foot were you able to get up and keep working or did you have to get off your you know not stop weightbearing and and get off that foot can you tell me a little bit about after the traumatic incident
[patient] i you know it was a little sore i called a few names you know god damn why is this in my foot but you know i kept working putting it around a little bit but now it's got swollen so i got to see my doctor he told me i had to go see you here i am so tell me what's going on with it

[patient] lucken it up
[doctor] okay have you taken any medications safe for example tylenol or ibuprofen for the pain
[patient] no i feel like taking the medicine
[doctor] okay and then just out of curiosity you said you were doing some landscaping have you been over to landscapes warehouse new here in town my wife and i were just over there this last weekend and picked up a whole bunch of stuff you had a chance to make it over there yet
[patient] no not yet i heard about it though i might have to make a trip once my foot heals
[doctor] alright that sounds good now just out of curiosity can you rate your pain for me right now zero being none ten being the worst pain you've ever been in your life
[patient] eleven out of ten
[doctor] okay and then have you experienced any numbness or tingling of that foot since the incident
[patient] yeah the whole foot is numb
[doctor] okay
[patient] but been now for a long time
[doctor] okay i'm gon na do a quick physical exam now your vitals look good and i would like to do a focused exam of your right foot the there is some bruising on the bottom part of your foot and on the top part as well and i do appreciate the associated swelling and i also recognize that you do have tenderness to palpation for midfoot now for your neurovascular exam of your right foot your capillary refill is brisk in less than three seconds i do note a strong bounding dorsalis pedis pulse with motor and sensation is intact for that foot i also like to call out the fact that it matches bilaterally which is important i'm gon na go ahead and review the diagnostic imaging results so we did a x-ray of that right foot and i do notice dorsal displacement of the base of the second metatarsal with a three millimeter separation of the first and second metatarsal bases and presence of bony fragments so let me tell you a little bit about my assessment and plan now your right foot pain is due to a lisfranc fracture which is a fracture to your second metatarsal bone and the top of your foot this is where the metatarsals meet those cuboids okay so it where the bones come together in your foot now there are a lot of ligaments in your foot so i do want to order an mri just to assess if there is any injuries to those ligaments now based on your exam and looking at the x-ray you're most likely going to need surgery now the reason why this is important is if we have poor bone alignment or ligament healing you can this can lead to losing the arch in your foot you could becoming flat-footed and also developing arthritis now what's gon na be key here is the surgery is going to allow those bones and ligaments to heal properly we are going to put them back into place using plates and screws now the key thing is going to be it's going to be outpatient surgery so it's going to be same day i'll see you in the morning and then you'll be discharged home that evening and we will do a follow-up i wan na see you in twenty four hours post procedure but then i'll see you again in two weeks you're gon na be in a cast and i'm gon na have you use crutches you're not gon na be able to weight-bear on that foot for six to eight weeks what we'll do is we'll advance your ambulating gradually based on how you heal and based on how you tolerate the procedure i know i have covered a lot of material quickly but this is really gon na be the best course of action for you to have a good outcome now do you have any questions come answers concerns before i have the nurse come in finish the paperwork and get you set up for your procedure which we are going to do tomorrow if you're agreeable to that
[patient] what about putting in a cast can i just stay in the cast
[doctor] you could but what we found is the best outcome is aligning those bones with plates and screws to make sure that they heal properly so you have the best outcome possible
[patient] so if the surgery is going to be tomorrow when am i going to get my mri
[doctor] so what what we will do is the good news is we have an outpatient mri facility downstairs and i'm going to send the order down and we'll get you your mri this afternoon
[patient] can i think about it and we have some time
[doctor] sure
[patient] okay
[doctor] alright thanks elijah
SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Right foot pain and swelling after dropping a landscape brick on foot
- History of present illness: Dropped heavy brick on right foot during yard work yesterday, continued working despite soreness, pain rated 11/10 currently, swelling and bruising noted, history of previous right ankle fracture 20 years ago (treated with casting, occasional residual soreness and swelling), previous left ankle surgery (persistent occasional soreness, possible instability)
- Associated symptoms: Numbness of the whole right foot (chronic)
- Medications tried: None for pain
- Social history: No information provided
- Family history: No information provided
- Past medical history: Right ankle fracture (20 years ago, casted), left ankle surgery

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: Vitals reported as good
- Physical exam: Bruising present on dorsal and plantar aspects of right foot, swelling noted, tenderness to palpation over midfoot, brisk capillary refill (<3 seconds), strong bounding dorsalis pedis pulse, motor and sensation intact, neurovascular status matches bilaterally
- Test results: X-ray of right foot shows dorsal displacement of the base of the second metatarsal, 3 mm separation of first and second metatarsal bases, bony fragments present

A (Assessment):

- Lisfranc fracture of the right foot (fracture of the base of the second metatarsal involving the tarsometatarsal joints)
- Ligamentous injury, possible (MRI ordered for assessment)
- Post-traumatic foot pain

P (Plan):

- Order MRI of right foot to assess for ligament injuries
- Outpatient surgery scheduled for tomorrow: open reduction and internal fixation of right Lisfranc fracture with plates and screws
- Postoperative care: cast placement, crutches, non-weightbearing for 6–8 weeks, gradual weightbearing advancement as tolerated
- Postoperative follow-up: clinic visit in 24 hours after procedure, then again at 2 weeks
- Provide patient education regarding injury, prognosis, and procedure
- Discussed risks and benefits; patient considering options
- Nurse to complete preoperative paperwork

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: New right eye twitch
* History of present illness: Right eye twitch noticed a couple of weeks ago, varies in frequency from several times an hour to not at all on some days, has been present daily for several weeks, each episode lasts several seconds and involves movement of the whole side of the face; patient feels an urge to move her face before the twitch and feels better afterwards; no associated pain; symptoms do not interfere with activities
* Past medical history: No significant past medical history
* Social history: Plays soccer every Saturday, enjoys spending time with father after soccer
* Family history: No family history of seizures or Tourette's syndrome
* Additional symptoms: No seizures, no fever, no chills, no cough, no headache, no problems with sleep, no abnormal movements outside of facial twitch

O (Objective):

* Physical exam: Patient awake, alert, and oriented ×3, speech clear and fluent, gait steady, heel-toe walking normal, cranial nerves intact with no focal neurologic findings, no pronator drift, sensation intact, reflexes 2+ and symmetric at biceps, triceps, knees, and ankles
* Vital signs: No information provided
* Test results: No information provided

A (Assessment):

* Transient tic disorder

P (Plan):

* Recommend observation and reassurance, advise to ignore the tic as drawing attention may worsen symptoms, no treatment recommended at this time
* Advise follow-up if symptoms worsen or interfere with school or activities
* Provided education to patient and parent regarding natural history and typical resolution of transient tics
* No medications or additional testing indicated at this time

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Recurrent lower respiratory infections
* History of present illness: Last week had cough with copious mucus, shortness of breath, and low-grade fever; symptoms lasted a few days to up to a week, typically improve with fluids and over-the-counter cough medicine (Robitussin); current episode resolved, but similar episodes every month or every other month for the past 6 months, sometimes requiring antibiotics or emergency room visits
* Occupational exposure: Works on a farm, recently started unloading hay; symptoms tend to start on days when unloading hay; does not wear a mask during exposure
* Past medical history: No history of seasonal allergies reported
* Social history: Does not smoke; does not live with smokers; lives with large family (10 siblings)
* Family history: No history of allergies reported

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Respiratory rate 20/min (breathing a little fast), oxygen saturation 99% on room air
* Physical exam: Heart with regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs/rubs/gallops; lungs with fine rales, no wheezes; no finger clubbing on musculoskeletal exam
* Test results: Chest x-ray shows ground glass opacities

A (Assessment):

* Hypersensitivity pneumonitis (Farmer’s lung), suspected as cause of recurrent pulmonary infections

P (Plan):

* Prescribe oral steroid course for current symptoms
* Order chest CT scan
* Order pulmonary function test
* Advise to eliminate exposure to hay or, if not possible, to wear a respirator when handling hay
* Recommend recruiting other siblings to reduce personal exposure
* Follow up as needed for further management and to review results

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Pain and redness of the big toe
- History of present illness: Intermittent big toe pain for approximately 2 weeks, significant worsening over the past week resulting in inability to walk at a trade show, described as throbbing pain with occasional sharp, stabbing episodes; aggravated by movement and walking, somewhat relieved by avoiding toe flexion; redness and warmth noted, pain with light touch such as from bed sheets at night; denies remembered injury or trauma
- Activities: Regular cyclist (800+ miles last year, uses regular shoes and flip flops, pedals with back of feet to avoid toe pain); pain does not worsen with cycling, but does interfere with walking/standing for work
- Self-treatment: Takes 2 ibuprofen daily without relief
- Past medical history: No history of stomach problems or gastrointestinal intolerance to anti-inflammatory drugs reported
- Social history: Works on feet daily, enjoys fishing and cycling
- Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Physical exam: Big toe red and warm to touch, significant pain on movement (especially plantar flexion beyond 10–20 degrees), pain on palpation medially and laterally, grinding sensation on joint manipulation, palpable bone spur on dorsal aspect of big toe joint
- Test results: X-ray shows large bone spur on top of big toe joint, significant loss of cartilage in joint

A (Assessment):

- Hallux rigidus (arthritis of the big toe joint)

P (Plan):

- Prescribe orthotic insert for shoes
- Prescribe anti-inflammatory medication (meloxicam) 1 tablet daily
- Counsel patient to continue regular activities and work, avoid extra rest
- Educate about potential gastrointestinal side effects of meloxicam; advised to stop medication and contact clinic if heartburn or stomach pain develops
- Follow-up appointment scheduled in 2 weeks to assess response to treatment
- Contingency plan: If significant improvement is not seen, discuss options including corticosteroid injection or surgical intervention (joint debridement or fusion in severe cases)

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Hospital follow-up after anterior STEMI with new stent placement
- History of present illness: Reports occasional tiredness but feels overall well, able to do light housekeeping and short walks around the block, no chest pain or shortness of breath, able to sleep with two pillows (as usual), denies difficulty sleeping, denies lower extremity swelling, compliant with prescribed medications, able to afford medications, aware of dietary recommendations to limit salt intake, interested in returning to walking, gardening, and photography
- Past medical history: Coronary artery disease (CAD), prior RCA stent (2018), hypertension, diabetes mellitus, recent anterior STEMI with drug-eluting stent placed in LAD, newly reduced ejection fraction (35%), moderate mitral regurgitation
- Social history: Enjoys walking, gardening, photography; no specific details regarding tobacco, alcohol, or drug use provided
- Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: Vital signs normal (no abnormalities noted during visit)
- Physical exam: No jugular venous distention, no carotid bruits, grade 3/6 systolic ejection murmur at the left base (same as last year), lungs clear, no extremity edema, right radial artery cath site clean/dry/intact, palpable RRA pulse
- Test results: EKG shows normal sinus rhythm, good R wave progression, evolutionary changes as expected; echocardiogram with ejection fraction 35%, moderate mitral regurgitation

A (Assessment):

- Coronary artery disease, status post recent anterior STEMI with LAD drug-eluting stent
- Left ventricular dysfunction (newly reduced ejection fraction), moderate mitral regurgitation
- Hypertension
- Diabetes mellitus

P (Plan):

- Continue aspirin 81 mg daily, Brilinta 90 mg twice daily, atorvastatin (Lipitor) 80 mg daily, metoprolol (Toprol) 50 mg daily for CAD
- Refer to cardiac rehabilitation program for heart education and exercise re-initiation
- For left ventricular dysfunction and mitral regurgitation: Continue lisinopril 20 mg daily, add spironolactone (Aldactone) 12.5 mg daily, monitor volume status, no diuretic at this time
- Order labs in 1 week to monitor for medication effects
- Repeat echocardiogram in approximately 2 months
- Monitor blood pressure regularly for hypertension; continue current regimen
- Encourage dietary salt restriction and continued medication compliance
- Outpatient follow-up as indicated

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Difficulty breathing during sports, concerns about mood
- History of present illness: Asthma symptoms (difficulty breathing, chest tightness, coughing, wheezing, phlegm sensation, lightheadedness) occurring during aerobic activities such as water polo or running, necessitating use of albuterol inhaler and temporary rest; exposure to smoke also triggers coughing; albuterol inhaler causes shakiness; asthma not waking patient at night. Mood concerns include increased sadness, stress related to academic pressures (SATs, AP classes), decreased motivation, social withdrawal, and frequent tiredness; symptoms noted as new and beginning this year.
- Past medical history: Asthma, seasonal allergies (self-reported)
- Social history: Plays sports (water polo), increased academic workload and stress
- Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: No information provided
- Physical exam: Heart and lungs auscultation normal, ears with small amount of fluid, throat normal (no tonsils), abdominal exam normal, reflexes normal, eyes normal
- Test results: No information provided

A (Assessment):

- Asthma (with exercise-induced symptoms)
- Allergic symptoms, possible
- Mood disturbance, possible depression – further screening recommended

P (Plan):

- Start daily medication with Singulair (montelukast)
- Continue albuterol inhaler as needed, advised to rest after use to mitigate side effects
- Schedule follow-up in 6 weeks to reassess asthma symptoms
- Initiate screening questionnaires for mood and emotional health
- Recommend starting therapy with a mental health professional
- Follow-up visit in a few weeks regarding mood concerns

gradually start walking on your foot based on how you tolerate it and we'll see how you do at that point so i do believe you're gon na need surgery i i'm recommending this because there are SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Foot pain
- History of present illness: Right foot pain following soccer injury yesterday; sustained when another player fell directly onto right foot, accompanied by twisting motion; unable to continue playing, had to be helped off the field; has been elevating foot, icing, using compression wrap, and taking ibuprofen; pain level without ibuprofen 3/10, with ibuprofen 7–8/10; denies numbness, tingling, or abnormal sensations in affected foot
- Past medical history: Multiple previous soccer injuries, but never to this (right) foot
- Social history: Plays soccer since age 4–5; plays soccer at school and town leagues
- Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: Blood pressure 118/72 mmHg, heart rate 58/min, respiratory rate 14/min, afebrile, oxygen saturation 99% on room air
- Physical exam: Bruising and swelling on dorsum and plantar aspects of right foot, tenderness to palpation of midfoot, positive piano key test, brisk capillary refill (<3 seconds), intact dorsalis pedis pulse, intact motor function and sensation to light touch, regular heart rate and rhythm without murmurs/rubs/clicks/ectopic beats, lungs clear and equal bilaterally
- Test results: X-ray shows subtle dorsal displacement of base of second metatarsal, 3 mm separation of first and second metatarsal bases, and bony fragment at the Lisfranc joint space

A (Assessment):

- Lisfranc fracture of right foot
- Ligament injury of right foot, needs MRI for further evaluation

P (Plan):

- Order MRI of right foot to assess ligament injury
- Recommend surgery (open reduction and internal fixation) for Lisfranc fracture
- Apply cast and instruct non-weight-bearing with crutches for 6–8 weeks
- Plan gradual return to weight-bearing after 6–8 weeks as tolerated
- Outpatient surgery with same-day discharge
- Follow up in clinic after surgery
- Nurse to assist with paperwork and preoperative preparation
- Advised out for rest of the soccer season, with intent to prepare for next season

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Right knee pain
* History of present illness: Injury to right knee during basketball 7 days ago; patient reports being run into on the inside of the knee by another player, fell to the ground and was unable to continue playing. Pain is localized to the inside of the right knee, worsens with movement. No report of hearing or feeling a pop during injury. Patient has been using ice, ace wrap, exercises, and Mobic for pain.
* Past medical history: Diabetes
* Medications: Metformin 500 mg twice daily, Mobic (meloxicam) (prior to visit), other nonsteroidals (Motrin or Advil)
* Social history: Recreational basketball player, family owns a sporting goods store
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided
* Physical exam: Swelling and ecchymosis on medial aspect of right knee, tenderness with palpation on the medial side, evidence of small effusion in right knee, decreased range of motion with pain on movement, negative varus and valgus stress tests
* Test results: Right knee X-ray shows good bony alignment, no evidence of fracture, small knee effusion

A (Assessment):

* Medial collateral ligament strain, right knee, suspected
* Diabetes mellitus, under ongoing management

P (Plan):

* Discontinue nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs other than meloxicam
* Prescribe meloxicam 15 mg once daily for pain and swelling
* Continue use of ace wrap, provide right knee brace
* Refer to physical therapy for right knee strengthening
* Encourage light walking and continued exercise as tolerated with knee support
* Monitor blood sugars daily, follow up with primary care physician if significant increases occur
* Outpatient follow-up appointment in 7 days to reassess right knee, consider advanced imaging (MRI or CT) if no improvement or worsening swelling
* No basketball or strenuous activity for at least 7 days until reassessment

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Difficulty swallowing
- History of present illness: Difficulty swallowing certain foods for several weeks, pain when swallowing in the chest, sensation that bigger pieces of food get stuck, epigastric pain at times, denies weight loss (reports weight gain), no blood in stool or dark stools
- Social history: Recent move from West Coast to East Coast, increased stress, change in diet (more pizza and burgers), increased alcohol intake, concerned about moving with pet dog
- Past medical history: No information provided
- Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: Blood pressure 133/70 mmHg, heart rate normal, temperature afebrile, oxygen saturation 100%, respiratory rate 19/min
- Physical exam: Gained approximately 10 pounds over last month, no mouth ulcers or thrush, tonsils midline, no cervical adenopathy, no thyroid enlargement, abdomen nondistended with active bowel sounds, pain to palpation in epigastric area, negative Murphy’s sign, no peritoneal signs, no rebound, lungs clear bilaterally, no rash, lesion, or bruising, pupils equal and reactive to light
- Test results: Barium swallow shows two areas of mild narrowing in mid and lower esophagus

A (Assessment):

- Acute esophagitis

P (Plan):

- Prescribe Protonix 40 mg once daily in the morning
- Prescribe Carafate 1 gram four times daily for one month
- Schedule upper endoscopy
- Diet modification: decrease alcohol and caffeine, avoid citrus and spicy foods, eat slowly, chew food thoroughly
- Follow-up visit next week for endoscopy
- Patient education: maintain healthy diet, lifestyle modification to support recovery

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Shortness of breath
* History of present illness: Trouble sleeping for past 2 weeks due to shortness of breath and choking sensation when lying down, cannot catch breath shortly after lying down, no exertional shortness of breath as patient mostly sedentary, noticed inability to see ankles and approximately 10-pound weight gain, occasional coughing up mucus in the morning, no fever, no regular Lasix use, dietary noncompliance (enjoying high-salt foods, recent party), no chest pain or tightness except when short of breath at night, urinating frequently despite not drinking much, blood sugar self-checked a couple weeks ago (~230 mg/dL), difficulty adhering to diabetic diet
* Past medical history: Diabetes, back pain, congestive heart failure (CHF), chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)
* Social history: Sedentary lifestyle (mostly sits on couch and watches TV)
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Oxygen saturation 92% in office
* Physical exam: Neck exam with mild swelling and jugular venous distention, no bruits; lung exam with basal crackles, rales, intermittent wheezing; heart exam shows 2/6 systolic ejection murmur (previously present), regular rate and rhythm; abdomen slightly distended, nontender, no guarding; lower extremities with 1+ to 1.5+ pitting edema bilaterally, no calf tenderness, negative Homan’s sign; neurologic exam normal; back exam with paraspinal tenderness in lower back, no midline tenderness, good reflexes
* Test results: Last hemoglobin A1c 7.5%, self-reported home blood glucose approximately 230 mg/dL two weeks ago

A (Assessment):

* Congestive heart failure exacerbation
* COPD
* Diabetes mellitus, suboptimally controlled
* Muscular low back pain

P (Plan):

* Increase Lasix from 20 mg to 60 mg daily for 4 days, check daily weight
* Reinforce salt restriction
* Prescribe/albuterol and atrovent inhalers, refill as needed
* Monitor symptoms; follow up in a few days; if no improvement, consider further increase in Lasix or hospital admission
* Order hemoglobin A1c and fasting blood sugar
* Review diet and diabetes control at follow-up; adjust metformin or add medication if needed
* Start naprosyn and flexeril for back pain
* Provide back exercises; consider physical therapy if no improvement
* Patient education regarding medication adherence and lifestyle modifications

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Left ankle pain
* History of present illness: Twisted left ankle after stepping off a curb while walking with spouse yesterday; pain located on the outside of the left ankle, ongoing for a couple of days, described as "killing me"; felt extended and stretched at the time of injury, no audible pop; able to walk home after the incident but with significant pain
* Pain severity: Rated as 8/10 without medication, decreases to about 7/10 with ibuprofen or acetaminophen
* Actions taken: Taking ibuprofen, elevating and icing the ankle, limiting weight-bearing
* Past medical history: No substantial prior injuries to left ankle
* Social history: Takes walks frequently with spouse, particularly since starting to work from home during COVID
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Stable, mildly elevated (attributed to pain)
* Physical exam: Ecchymosis (bruising) and edema over lateral malleolus, tenderness to palpation on lateral aspect of left ankle, no joint laxity, no bony tenderness on foot palpation, intact and symmetric motor/sensation bilaterally, capillary refill brisk (<3 seconds), strong dorsalis pedis pulses bilaterally
* Test results: Left ankle x-ray shows no fracture or bony abnormalities

A (Assessment):

* Left lateral ankle sprain (lateral ligament complex)

P (Plan):

* Continue RICE protocol (rest, ice, compression, elevation)
* Provide air cast for ankle stabilization
* Prescribe crutches
* Advise non-weightbearing, begin walking as tolerated over the next few days as symptoms permit
* Continue NSAIDs for pain and swelling
* Outpatient follow-up in 2 weeks
* Advise return for reevaluation if significant pain persists or worsens

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Right ankle pain after a fall
* History of present illness: Slipped on ice while taking out trash last night, heard a "pop" at the time of injury, initial inability to bear weight followed by partial weight-bearing with limping, current pain rated 6/10 (throbbing and constant), ankle feels warm to touch, ibuprofen taken (last night and this morning) with little relief, ankle elevated and iced at home
* Past medical history: History of playing soccer in high school, previous injuries (not to the right ankle), no prior right ankle sprain
* Social history: No information provided
* Family history: No information provided
* Review of systems: No numbness or tingling in the right foot

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Blood pressure 120/80 mmHg, heart rate not specified, SpO2 98%
* Physical exam: Right ankle ecchymosis over lateral malleolus, swelling, tenderness to palpation anterior-laterally in soft tissue, no laxity on anterior drawer and inversion stress tests, no bony tenderness on foot palpation, capillary refill <3 seconds, strong dorsalis pedis pulse, sensation intact to light touch
* Test results: Ankle X-ray shows no fracture or bony abnormality

A (Assessment):

* Right ankle sprain (medium grade)

P (Plan):

* Advise elevation of leg when seated
* Continue icing ankle five times daily for 20 minutes at a time
* Provide air cast for stabilization
* Provide crutches; advise non-weight-bearing for 1–2 days, then gradual weight-bearing as tolerated
* Anticipated full recovery in 2–3 weeks, soreness may persist for a couple of weeks
* Instruct to follow up if pain persists after one week for further evaluation (possible MRI if needed)
* No work excuse note provided (as patient has sedentary/computer-based work)

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Back pain
- History of present illness: Onset of lower back pain 4 days ago after bending while working in the yard; pain radiates down the left leg; tingling in leg in certain positions but mostly pain; no bowel or bladder dysfunction; occasional previous back pain but no surgeries; used ibuprofen with some relief
- Past medical history: Diabetes, hypertension, hyperlipidemia
- Medications (by patient report): Metformin 500 mg twice daily, Norvasc 5 mg once daily, ibuprofen as needed
- Social history: No information provided
- Family history: No information provided
- Additional symptoms: Swelling in ankles started about 1-2 months after starting Norvasc
- Home monitoring: Blood glucose checked 2-3 times/week (typically 120–140 mg/dL); blood pressure checked weekly or a few times/month (typically 120–130/70–80 mmHg)
- Diet and lifestyle: Struggling to avoid sweets, but making an effort to eat fewer carbohydrates and sweets; self-reports could benefit from losing 15 pounds

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: Blood pressure in clinic 120/70 mmHg
- Physical exam: Neck exam without JVD or bruits, lungs clear (no rales or wheezing), heart regular rate and rhythm with 2/6 systolic ejection murmur (previously noted), abdomen soft, left paraspinal tenderness, lower back paraspinal tenderness, straight leg raise negative, normal reflexes, neurological exam normal, extremity exam shows 1+ nonpitting edema of lower extremities, no calf tenderness, negative Homans sign
- Test results: Hemoglobin A1c at previous visit 7.1%
- Imaging: No information provided

A (Assessment):

- Muscular back sprain
- Diabetes mellitus, controlled, but could be improved
- Hypertension
- Edema, likely secondary to Norvasc (Amlodipine), suspected

P (Plan):

- Start naprosyn 500 mg twice daily for back pain
- Start flexeril 10 mg twice daily
- Refer to physical therapy for lower back strengthening
- No imaging (x-ray) for now; consider if no improvement
- Continue metformin 500 mg twice daily
- Repeat hemoglobin A1c today
- Discontinue Norvasc, begin hydrochlorothiazide 10 mg once daily
- Order laboratory tests: CBC, BMP (to assess kidney function)
- Order EKG and chest x-ray
- Follow up in 2 weeks to review test results and reassess diabetes and edema
- Patient education provided regarding diet and importance of blood sugar/blood pressure control
- No refills needed at this time

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Right knee pain following skiing accident two weeks ago
- History of present illness: Twisted knee after colliding with a tree while skiing (black diamond run); reports pain primarily on the medial aspect of the right knee, pain rated 7/10 (sometimes up to 11/10, aggravated by walking, duration depends on activity), right knee swelling and morning stiffness, mild instability in the left knee without significant pain, prior left knee "pop" at time of injury but current pain is minimal, describes limp ("waddle")
- Aggravating factors: Walking, especially for longer periods or walking dog, windy weather
- Alleviating factors: Use of knee brace and THC cream, which the patient finds helpful
- Past medical history: Prior surgery on right knee (“reconstructed the whole thing”) at age 14 following gymnastics injury with a “pop”, persistent right knee problems since then
- Medications: Uses THC cream and THC gummies, no current prescribed medications
- Social history: Skis approximately three times per week, no other regular exercise reported
- Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: No information provided
- Physical exam: Tenderness on palpation of the medial aspect of the right knee, no pain on palpation of the lateral aspect of the right knee, mild swelling and bruising of the right knee, right knee stiff in the morning, slight limp observed in gait, pain with abduction of right knee, pain radiates to ankle with kneecap manipulation (no frequent radiation), no pain with knee adduction, able to bend the right knee
- Test results: Right knee x-ray shows no fracture, mild development of arthritis

A (Assessment):

- Posterior cruciate ligament strain, right knee
- Mild arthritis, right knee
- Left knee mild instability (no significant pain, no bracing or medication required, to be monitored)

P (Plan):

- Continue using brace for right knee
- Refer to physical therapy (recommended 3 times per week)
- Advise against skiing and gymnastics until further notice
- Prescribe meloxicam 15 mg once daily
- Prescribe ibuprofen 800 mg, up to twice daily as needed
- Patient education on activity modification: listen to body, follow physical therapist's guidance regarding exercises
- No specific intervention for left knee at this time; monitor for any changes

- Chief complaint: Back pain
- History of present illness: Back pain started after falling against a stair railing at a birthday party while jumping up and twisting; pain is more on the right side of the back; worsened by lying flat and twisting motions; no pain or numbness radiating down the legs
- Past medical history: Lumbar fusion surgery, anxiety (on medication)
- Medications: Ibuprofen, medication for anxiety
- Social history: No information provided
- Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Physical exam: Back pain elicited with twisting; no pain or symptoms elicited with straight leg raise bilaterally; sensation intact in lower extremities
- Test results: X-ray shows prior fusion at T4, no compression fractures or significant abnormalities aside from fusion
- Vital signs: No information provided

A (Assessment):

- Lower back strain

P (Plan):

- Continue ibuprofen (Motrin) 800mg three times a day with food
- Use alternating ice and heat on the back
- Encourage walking and maintaining activity
- Advise follow-up if symptoms do not improve or worsen within a few days or over the next week
- Order medications and procedures as discussed

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Right knee pain
- History of present illness: Began experiencing significant right knee pain over the past week, associated with increased swimming activity (breaststroke). Pain begins after a few laps, whereas previously could swim ten laps without discomfort. Denies any memorable injury, fall, or twist.
- Past medical history: Carpal tunnel release (a few years ago), chronic back pain (currently well controlled), depression (currently stable)
- Social history: Reports increased physical activity, swims regularly; no information provided on smoking, alcohol, or occupation
- Family history: No information provided
- Review of systems: Denies pain radiating down legs, denies sleep or appetite disturbances, denies suicidal or homicidal ideation

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: No information provided
- Physical exam: No swelling in right knee joint, pain with patellar inhibition, pain with knee range of motion, full grip strength and range of motion in hands, heart regular, lungs clear, no adenopathy, normal thyroid, rest of exam normal
- Test results: Right knee x-ray normal

A (Assessment):

- Chondromalacia of the patella (right knee), attributed to overuse from swimming
- Chronic back pain, stable
- Depression, stable
- Status post carpal tunnel release, stable

P (Plan):

- Prescribe ibuprofen 600 mg orally four times daily with food
- Begin straight leg raising exercises to strengthen quadriceps
- Avoid activities that put extra pressure on knees (no lunges, avoid breaststroke)
- Switch to other swimming strokes with straight legs if comfortable, or rest from swimming as needed
- Follow up in a couple of weeks if no improvement
- Continue current management for chronic back pain and depression; no medication changes
- Continue monitoring carpal tunnel syndrome; no changes in management
- Patient advised to call if back pain flares up

- Family history: No information provided

P (Plan):

- Counsel on dietary modification: avoid foods high in sugar
- Continue metoprolol 25 mg orally twice daily (refill ordered)
- Continue protonix 40 mg orally once daily
- Follow up once laboratory results are available
- Nurse will provide additional diabetes education
