SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Shortness of breath
- History of present illness: Shortness of breath for a couple of weeks, worse in the mornings and with exertion, cough with hemoptysis (three to four cups per day) for about three weeks, knee pain (chronic, no swelling), no fever, no bruising or bleeding from gums, no recent hospital or emergency room visits, attempted to book appointment but had scheduling issues.
- Past medical history: Diabetes, hypertension, asthma
- Social history: No information provided
- Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: Blood pressure in clinic 120/70 mmHg, home blood pressure occasionally in the lower 90s, pulse oximetry 94% on room air
- Physical exam: No jugular venous distention, no neck swelling, no carotid bruits, lung exam with rales and rhonchi more on right side, diminished breath sounds on right side, no wheezing, heart exam with 2/6 systolic ejection murmur unchanged from prior, regular rate and rhythm, abdomen soft, extremities with 1+ nonpitting edema on both ankles, no calf tenderness, negative Homan's sign
- Test results: Most recent hemoglobin A1c approximately 7.7% (from prior visit), self-monitored blood glucose 150 mg/dL in the morning, post-prandial over 200 mg/dL

A (Assessment):

- Shortness of breath, etiology to be determined (suspect infection vs. pulmonary embolism vs. other)
- Hemoptysis, needs further evaluation
- Diabetes, suboptimally controlled
- Hypertension, currently borderline low
- Asthma, history of

P (Plan):

- Refer to emergency department for chest x-ray, chest CT, and blood tests to evaluate shortness of breath and hemoptysis
- Hold Norvasc until further notice
- Order repeat hemoglobin A1c
- Plan to increase metformin from 500 mg twice daily to 750 mg twice daily after acute illness resolves
- Outpatient follow-up in 3 weeks to reassess diabetes and hypertension management
- Patient advised to return for further management after diagnostic evaluation

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Right knee injury with limited motion and pain
- History of present illness: Injury occurred 3 days ago while playing soccer; felt a pop in the right knee, subsequent swelling (somewhat improved), functional limitation in knee motion, pain increased with end ranges of knee movement; knee feels loose; able to bear weight but feels abnormal; pain initially 6–7/10, currently 4–5/10 as swelling subsided
- Medications attempted: Ibuprofen (anti-inflammatory), provided some relief; patient taking it regularly
- Social history: Regular jogging and walks dog, currently unable to jog; works at desk job, finds sitting uncomfortable now
- Past medical history: No information provided
- Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Gait: Marked limp on right leg observed with ambulation
- Physical exam: Significant effusion and slight ecchymosis in right knee, pain to palpation at medial joint line, limited passive range of motion (lacking a few degrees of terminal extension to ~115°, lacking 20–30° of terminal flexion due to pain), positive Lachman exam, neurovascularly intact bilateral lower extremities, muscle strength 5/5
- Vital signs: No information provided
- Test results: No information provided

A (Assessment):

- Right anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) tear, suspected

P (Plan):

- Order MRI to evaluate integrity of ACL
- Prescribe meloxicam 50 mg orally once daily for inflammation and pain
- Advise icing knee as needed for swelling and pain
- Recommend knee immobilizer and use of crutches to offload knee
- Advise to moderate activities, including no jogging and limiting work/desk activities as tolerable, with encouraged gentle movement to prevent stiffness
- Outpatient follow-up after MRI results
- No information provided regarding referrals or additional recommendations

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Right elbow pain
- History of present illness: Pain localized to the inside (medial aspect) of right elbow, radiating down the arm along the inside; onset 4 days ago after increased activity performing pottery; pain severity rated as 7/10; disrupts sleep, worsens with certain wrist movements; has attempted ibuprofen and ice with minimal relief; denies trauma or previous elbow injuries; pain not improving
- Past medical history: Hypertension, diabetes mellitus
- Medication history: Lisinopril 10 mg daily (reports good adherence, sets an alarm), Metformin 500 mg twice daily (sometimes misses doses)
- Social history: Engages in baking and pottery; walks 1–2 miles daily; enjoys making and taste-testing sweet baked goods
- Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: Blood pressure 120/70 mmHg, respiratory rate 18/min, temperature 97.9°F, oxygen saturation 100%, pulse (rate not specified, but stated to be appropriate)
- Physical exam: Moderate tenderness at medial epicondyle of right elbow, pain with resisted pronation and flexion of right wrist, pain with bending right wrist, no pain with resisted supination, no rash, bruising, swelling, discoloration, or lesions noted, pulses equal bilaterally, heart sounds normal (no murmur, rub, or gallop), lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally
- Test results: Right elbow X-ray—no fracture or bony abnormality
- Weight: 5 lbs increase since previous visit

A (Assessment):

- Right medial epicondylitis (explicitly stated as consistent with clinical findings)
- Diabetes mellitus
- Hypertension

P (Plan):

- Right medial epicondylitis: Rest, order sling for right arm to be worn while awake, ice elbow for 20 minutes 3 times daily, ibuprofen 600 mg orally every 6 hours with food for 1 week, avoid pottery and similar activities for next couple of weeks, possible referral to physical rehabilitation if not improved at follow-up
- Diabetes mellitus: Increase metformin to 1000 mg twice daily, daily blood glucose monitoring and recording, order hemoglobin A1c, referral for diabetic counseling/nutrition consult, follow-up in a couple of weeks
- Hypertension: Continue lisinopril 10 mg daily
- Follow-up: Return in a couple of weeks to reassess elbow pain and glycemic control
- Patient education: Advise on dietary modifications and adherence to diabetes and hypertension management recommendations

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Low back pain for approximately one week
* History of present illness: Back pain began after possible twisting/turning movement, possibly associated with lifting an object; initial pain subsided but recurred after a few hours and has persisted since. Pain is located mainly in the center and lower back, sometimes radiates towards the left; aggravated by sudden movements to the left.
* Aggravating factors: Twisting or sudden movement to the left
* Past medical history: Diabetes mellitus
* Medications: Metformin (twice daily), over-the-counter pain medications used without significant relief
* Social history: Visits family-owned bakery, occasionally consumes sweets, tries to exercise; no mention of tobacco or alcohol use
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided
* Physical exam: Eyes and ears—normal, lungs clear, heart regular rate and rhythm, tenderness to palpation in central and left lower back (including left buttock), minimal tenderness on right; mild pain on right straight leg raise, tenderness on left straight leg raise; no pain, numbness, or tingling in lower extremities
* Test results: No current lab or imaging results; reports higher blood glucose readings at home, A1c not done in past 5 months

A (Assessment):

* Musculoskeletal low back strain
* Diabetes mellitus, assessed as under control

P (Plan):

* Order low back X-ray (outpatient)
* Prescribe physical therapy (for pain relief and back muscle strengthening)
* Prescribe ibuprofen 400 mg as needed, up to three times per day; may be alternated with acetaminophen for severe pain
* Prescribe Flexeril (cyclobenzaprine) 1 tablet once daily in the evening, avoid hazardous activities after taking
* Continue metformin, no change to current diabetes medications
* Continue dietary management and exercise for diabetes; limit sweets/carbohydrate intake from bakery
* Order hemoglobin A1c
* Monitor and record fasting blood glucose daily in the morning, keep a written record
* Possible referral to pain specialist if symptoms persist or if imaging suggests further concern
* Possible further imaging (CT scan) depending on X-ray results and symptom persistence
* Outpatient follow-up after results of X-ray and A1c are available

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Right knee pain
- History of present illness: Right knee pain began 2.5 weeks ago after stepping off a curb and twisting the ankle outward; initial ankle soreness resolved, but persistent pain and clicking in the lateral right knee remain. No fall occurred. Clicking is most noticeable with full squats, otherwise no significant pain except on prolonged one-foot standing or when resting on the heel. Knee does not hurt when walking or at rest (unless on heel). Feels "locked" after standing on one foot, needing time to resume walking. Reports symptoms have been stable over the last two weeks, with temporary worsening during activities like gardening or moving heavy objects, but without persistent worsening. Uses ibuprofen occasionally and ices the knee (20 minutes on, 20 minutes off) at least four times daily, with mild symptom improvement in the morning and at bedtime.
- Past medical history: History of three right second toe fractures over the past ten years resulting in intermittent numbness/tingling in right foot (shoe-dependent), not related to current knee injury.
- Social history: Works from home in sales, rides bike regularly (Peloton indoor cycling during winter), currently avoiding cycling due to knee pain.
- Family history: No information provided.

O (Objective):

- Physical exam: Slight edema and effusion in right knee, full range of motion, no pain to palpation of right lateral knee, pain only with varus stress; positive varus test, negative Lachman sign. Palpable dorsalis pedis and posterior tibialis pulses.
- Test results: Knee X-ray shows no acute fracture or bony abnormality.
- Vital signs: No information provided.

A (Assessment):

- Lateral collateral ligament strain of right knee

P (Plan):

- Prescribe meloxicam 15 mg once daily
- Refer to physical therapy for knee rehabilitation and strengthening
- Continue icing the knee as currently practiced
- If pain persists, consider MRI in future
- Follow up as needed

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Pain in the back of right heel
- History of present illness: Pain typically occurs after a workout or when first getting up in the morning, extends from the back of the right heel up into the calf, described as tight and almost tearing upon waking, eases after walking 10–15 minutes, becomes sore again after sitting for extended periods or following activity, primarily affects the right side, no significant relief from current self-medication (no specific medication named)
- Exercise history: Training for a triathlon involving running (about 10 kilometers in the morning, 5 days/week), biking (45–60 minutes at lunch), and swimming (30–60 minutes in the evening), alternates long run or bike on weekends, one rest day per week
- Stretching routine: Does not stretch before or after workouts
- No information provided for past medical history, social history, or family history

O (Objective):

- Physical exam: Pain elicited with dorsiflexion of right ankle, pain with resistance against foot flexion, right heel very tender on palpation, tenderness along right Achilles tendon, Thompson test negative bilaterally, no pain on calf squeeze bilaterally
- No information provided for vital signs
- No information provided for test results

A (Assessment):

- Achilles tendinitis from overuse

P (Plan):

- Advise cessation of training for 1–2 weeks to allow healing
- Prescribe ibuprofen (Advil) 3 tablets every six hours as an anti-inflammatory
- Order physical therapy for instruction in stretching and strengthening exercises for lower extremities
- Follow-up visit recommended in 7–10 days after first physical therapy appointment to monitor progress
- No x-ray indicated at this time; may consider further imaging if significant pain persists after 10 days of activity modification

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Nonhealing foot ulcer
- History of present illness: Right foot ulcer present for approximately 1 year, initially appeared as a small blister without preceding trauma, patient picked at it and it became red and infected; treated with Keflex antibiotics 5 months ago, initial improvement but ulcer persists with increased drainage lately and feeling more tired; reports no pain but has decreased sensation in the foot; no reported fever or chills
- Past medical history: Type 2 diabetes, neuropathy
- Medication history: Previous course of Keflex for foot infection, currently prescribed insulin and metformin for diabetes
- Social history: Plans to walk for extended periods (e.g., visit to the zoo), has not been wearing a surgical shoe as recommended
- Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: No fever, other vital signs within normal limits
- Physical exam: 1 x 2 cm circular ulcer on the dorsal aspect of the lateral right foot proximal to the fifth metatarsophalangeal joint, yellow slough present, minimal granulation tissue, no surrounding erythema or cellulitis, no fluid collection, no necrosis or odor, no bony exposure, no tenderness to palpation, decreased sensation of foot
- Test results: Previous right foot x-ray negative for osteomyelitis, last HbA1c approximately 10, blood glucose “in the two hundreds”

A (Assessment):

- Diabetic foot ulcer
- Type 2 diabetes mellitus with poor glycemic control

P (Plan):

- Order ankle-brachial index (ABI) to assess blood supply to the foot
- Perform debridement of the ulcer in the office today
- Prescribe collagenase ointment to be applied to the wound once daily with sterile dressing
- Recommend use of a surgical shoe to offload pressure from the ulcer
- Continue current diabetes management; advise follow-up with primary care provider for glycemic control
- Return for follow-up in 2 weeks for wound evaluation and possible repeat debridement
- Patient education regarding pressure offloading, wound care, and importance of glycemic control

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Follow-up after anterior STEMI and stent placement
* History of present illness: Recent anterior STEMI with recurrent chest pain similar to previous episode; underwent stent placement after presenting to the emergency room due to persistent chest pain
* Symptom review: No current chest pain or shortness of breath, notes some lower leg swelling since hospital discharge, able to walk daily (1.5–2 miles with dog), occasional need to sleep with extra pillows but generally able to lie flat
* Past medical history: Coronary artery disease (prior RCA stent in 2018), hypertension, diabetes mellitus
* Medications: Reports adherence to prescribed medications; able to afford medications due to good insurance
* Social history: Walks dog daily, enjoys pizza (favorite food, mentions pepperoni and vegetables as toppings), dietary sodium restriction not strictly followed recently, expresses willingness to improve diet
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Unremarkable (physician notes vitals look good)
* Physical exam: No jugular venous distention, no carotid bruits, 3/6 systolic ejection murmur at left base, clear lungs, 1+ pitting lower limb edema, right radial artery cath site clean/dry/intact without hematoma, palpable right radial pulse
* Test results: EKG—normal sinus rhythm, good R wave progression, evolutionary changes post-STEMI; Echocardiogram—left ventricular ejection fraction 35%, moderate mitral regurgitation

A (Assessment):

* Coronary artery disease
* Reduced left ventricular function with moderate mitral regurgitation (newly reduced, post-STEMI)
* Acute heart failure
* Hypertension

P (Plan):

* Continue aspirin 81 mg daily
* Continue Brilinta (ticagrelor) 90 mg twice daily
* Continue high-dose statin (Lipitor/atorvastatin) 80 mg daily
* Continue Toprol (metoprolol) 50 mg daily
* Continue lisinopril 20 mg daily
* Initiate Lasix (furosemide) 40 mg once daily
* Add Aldactone (spironolactone) 12.5 mg daily
* Order laboratory tests (monitor response to therapy and electrolytes)
* Refer to cardiac rehabilitation program
* Repeat echocardiogram in approximately 2 months
* Refer to nutrition counseling for dietary education, especially sodium restriction and alternatives to preserved meats
* Outpatient monitoring and follow-up as needed

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Concern about number of medications, occasional dizziness upon standing, request for medication refills, feeling down since heart attack
- History of present illness: Reports dizziness when standing up quickly, denies chest pain or shortness of breath, states medications are helping overall; expresses concern about management of diabetes and need for updated referral to dietitian; inquires about pain medication options due to inability to use NSAIDs
- Past medical history: Myocardial infarction (heart attack) approximately 6 months ago with left anterior descending artery stent placement, diabetes mellitus, stage 3 chronic kidney disease
- Social history: Lives alone with pet dog, recently retired, describes feeling lonely; admits to a preference for sweets, variable diet adherence; follows up with cardiologist, not seen nephrologist in approximately one year, requests referral for diabetes education
- Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: Blood pressure 127/80 mmHg
- Physical exam: No jugular venous distention, no carotid bruits, 3/6 systolic ejection murmur at left base, 1+ nonpitting edema in lower extremities, no significant fluid retention
- Test results: Stable kidney function (creatinine within normal/stable range); fasting blood glucose approximately 130 mg/dL; hemoglobin A1c reported by patient as “close to sixty” (likely 6.0% or possibly a reporting error noted as high by physician)

A (Assessment):

- Coronary artery disease, status post percutaneous coronary intervention with stent to left anterior descending artery, stable
- Chronic kidney disease, stage 3
- Diabetes mellitus, suboptimal glycemic control
- Mild depressive symptoms, possibly adjustment disorder after myocardial infarction
- Dizziness, likely related to medication (metoprolol)

P (Plan):

- Refill prescriptions for: metoprolol 50 mg once daily, Crestor 40 mg once daily, aspirin, Brilinta (to continue for 6 more months), fish oil
- Refer to cardiac rehabilitation program
- Refer to nephrologist (Dr. Miller) for follow-up regarding chronic kidney disease
- Avoid NSAIDs (Motrin, Advil); recommend acetaminophen (Tylenol) for pain/headache
- Order repeat hemoglobin A1c test
- Refer for diabetes dietary education (dietitian)
- Consult with primary care physician regarding insulin regimen
- Refer to psychiatry for evaluation of depression and support post-myocardial infarction
- Advise patient to report any new chest pain or shortness of breath promptly
- Outpatient follow-up as scheduled

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Abdominal pain
- History of present illness: Abdominal pain for the past one week, gradually increasing in severity, located on both sides of the upper abdomen, worsens with physical activity such as jogging or running, associated with nausea (about three times in the past week) and vomiting (a couple of times), no fever reported, recent increase in coffee intake starting last week with reduction to one cup this week, reports eating a lot of spicy food lately, believes coffee and spicy food may be contributing factors.
- Past medical history: Type 2 diabetes, asthma, history of moderately heavy alcohol use
- Medications: Metformin 500 mg twice daily (recently increased from once daily), Flovent twice daily, albuterol as needed for wheezing (sometimes forgets to take Flovent, no recent asthma attacks)
- Social history: Alcohol use (moderately heavy, frequency not specified)
- Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Physical exam: Heart exam reveals grade 3/6 systolic ejection murmur unchanged from prior exam, otherwise normal heart exam; mild tenderness in the epigastrium, abdomen otherwise soft with no tenderness in right lower or upper quadrants; lung exam reveals mild end-expiratory wheezes, otherwise normal lung exam with excellent air movement; overall physical exam otherwise unremarkable
- Vital signs: No information provided
- Test results: No information provided (urinalysis, urine pregnancy test, CBC, and comprehensive metabolic panel ordered)

A (Assessment):

- Acute gastritis, likely related to caffeine intake and spicy food consumption
- Type 2 diabetes
- Asthma

P (Plan):

- Prescribe Zantac (ranitidine) to be taken twice a day as needed for gastritis symptoms
- Advise reduction of caffeine intake and spicy food consumption
- Advise reduction of alcohol intake to less than 2-3 drinks per week
- Order urinalysis, urine pregnancy test, CBC, and comprehensive metabolic panel
- Adjust metformin dose: increase to 1000 mg in the morning and 500 mg in the evening
- Continue Flovent daily and albuterol as needed for asthma
- Continue regular blood sugar monitoring and report at next visit
- Follow-up appointment in 4 weeks
- Advise to contact clinic with any questions before next visit

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Numbness and tingling in right hand
- History of present illness: Numbness and tingling in right hand for approximately six months, becoming more persistent over the last month; pain associated with typing and mouse use; numbness and tingling present all the time now; pain relieved by resting and taking ibuprofen; no sleep disturbance reported
- Medication history: Self-medicating with ibuprofen for pain
- Affected fingers: Thumb, index, and middle finger of right hand
- Laterality: Mostly right hand
- Social history: Occupation involves prolonged keyboard use (data entry)
- Past medical history: No information provided
- Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Physical exam: Pain in right hand with wrist flexion and extension, decreased grip strength on right side, positive Tinel's sign at right wrist, numbness in right thumb, index, and middle finger; no abnormalities reported in ring and little finger
- Test results: No information provided
- Vital signs: No information provided

A (Assessment):

- Carpal tunnel syndrome

P (Plan):

- Recommend use of wrist splint at night
- Increase ibuprofen dose to 600 mg four times daily
- Order outpatient EMG (nerve conduction study) of right wrist
- Discuss follow-up after EMG results to determine need for physical therapy or possible surgical intervention (carpal tunnel release) if conservative measures fail
- No information provided regarding follow-up appointment date

- Continue metformin 500 mg daily
- Order hemoglobin A1c test
- Routine follow-up as needed

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Follow-up after hospitalization for acute on chronic congestive heart failure exacerbation
- History of present illness: Recent hospitalization due to acute exacerbation of CHF, noticed ankle swelling and severe shortness of breath necessitating EMS call and ER visit, blood pressure in ER reported as “super high”; reports feeling much better since discharge after receiving IV and oral “water pill” and change in blood pressure medications; currently adherent to medications and dietary recommendations since discharge; denies current shortness of breath, chest pain, or trouble sleeping; patient monitoring blood pressure at home with cuff, reports “really good” readings; admits occasional non-adherence to medications and dietary indiscretion prior to hospitalization (frequent intake of pizza and chicken wings at weekend gatherings)
- Past medical history: Hypertension, stage 3 chronic kidney disease, congestive heart failure
- Social history: Enjoys social gatherings with football, previously indulged in high-salt foods at parties
- Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: Blood pressure 128/72 mmHg, heart rate 79 bpm, respiratory rate 26/min, oxygen saturation 99%
- Physical exam: No jugular venous distension, 2/6 systolic ejection murmur (stable and previously noted), lungs clear bilaterally, trace lower extremity edema
- Test results: Echocardiogram shows preserved ejection fraction (EF) of 55%, abnormal diastolic filling, mild to moderate mitral regurgitation

A (Assessment):

- Acute on chronic congestive heart failure exacerbation due to dietary indiscretion and uncontrolled hypertension (hospitalized; currently improved)
- Hypertension
- Chronic kidney disease stage 3

P (Plan):

- Continue bumetanide 2 mg once daily
- Continue Cozaar (losartan) 100 mg once daily
- Continue Norvasc (amlodipine) 5 mg once daily
- Continue dietary salt restriction, avoid salty foods such as pizza and chicken wings
- Weigh daily; call if weight increases by 3 pounds in 2 days
- Referral to nutritionist for dietary education
- Order renal artery ultrasound to evaluate for secondary causes of hypertension
- Order laboratory blood work to monitor renal function and medication tolerance
- Outpatient follow-up in three months

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Right ankle pain and swelling after a fall on ice yesterday
* History of present illness: Fell while taking out trash, was unable to walk immediately after the injury, required assistance to stand, kept ankle elevated and iced overnight, mild improvement today but still limping and unable to walk normally; ibuprofen has provided some relief
* Past medical history: No previous right ankle injuries reported; regular participation in soccer
* Social history: Active in community soccer league, family members also play soccer
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Stable; all vital signs within normal limits
* Physical exam: Ecchymosis and swelling over the lateral malleolus of right ankle, tenderness to palpation anterolaterally in the soft tissue, no laxity on anterior drawer or inversion stress, no bony tenderness on palpation of the foot, neurovascular exam of right foot shows capillary refill <3 seconds, strong dorsalis pedis pulse, intact sensation to light touch
* Test results: Right ankle x-ray shows no fracture

A (Assessment):

* Right ankle sprain

P (Plan):

* Continue leg elevation, especially while seated
* Continue icing right ankle
* Prescribe aircast for ankle stabilization
* Prescribe crutches for 1–2 days; may begin weight-bearing as tolerated
* Continue NSAIDs for pain as needed
* Follow-up appointment in 2 weeks to reassess readiness for return to activity
* Advise to call clinic if symptoms worsen or new concerns arise

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Newly diagnosed elevated cholesterol
* History of present illness: Patient reports elevated cholesterol found on finger prick test during annual checkup, prior borderline result last year, no symptoms noted, confused about cause given active lifestyle and healthy diet attempts
* Past medical history: No significant past medical history
* Social history: Non-binary, emancipated minor, lives independently, physically active (frequent bicycling and outdoor activities), denies smoking and exposure to secondhand smoke at home or from friends, previously lived with parents who smoked
* Family history: No known family history of hypercholesterolemia, grandparents denied early cholesterol issues, cousin died of presumed heart attack at age 44-45
* No information provided: Medication history, allergy history, review of systems beyond details above

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Blood pressure within normal limits (exact value not specified)
* Physical exam: Heart—no murmurs, rubs, or gallops; Lungs—clear; Eyes—no xanthomas; Neck—no thyromegaly; Abdomen—no hepatomegaly or splenomegaly
* Test results: Cholesterol 210 mg/dL (elevated)
* No information provided: Height, weight, BMI, other laboratory or imaging findings

A (Assessment):

* Hypercholesterolemia

P (Plan):

* Order full cholesterol panel, glucose, complete metabolic panel, thyroid studies, and liver panel
* Perform genetic testing to evaluate for familial or secondary causes
* Nutrition referral for dietary counseling and education on foods lower in saturated fat and sugars
* Recommend continuation of regular physical activity
* Advise well-balanced diet low in saturated fats and sugars
* Repeat cholesterol level in 3 to 6 months after dietary changes
* Follow-up visit after repeat laboratory results and nutritionist consult

S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Chest pain
* History of present illness: Intermittent dull, pressure-like chest pain occurring during walking for the past 3 months, relieved by rest, does not radiate, not present at the time of visit; unable to maintain regular walking due to pain; no current shortness of breath, no diaphoresis, no nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea
* Past medical history: Diabetes, high blood pressure (documented by other clinicians, but not previously formally diagnosed), no known medication side effects
* Medications: Metformin 500 mg twice daily
* Social history: Trying to reduce soda intake, attempting to improve diet and exercise
* Family history: Heart disease
* Other relevant information: Ophthalmology appointment for eye exam scheduled in two weeks

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided
* Physical exam: No jugular venous distension, no neck swelling, no carotid bruits, lungs clear (no crackles or rhonchi), heart regular rate and rhythm with 2/6 systolic ejection murmur (chronic), pulses equal, abdomen soft and non-tender without guarding or masses, back normal, 1+ nonpitting edema in lower legs/ankles, no calf tenderness
* Test results: In-office EKG normal (no signs of myocardial infarction); previous hemoglobin A1c 7%; blood pressure has been trending high per chart review

A (Assessment):

* Unstable angina, suspected
* Diabetes mellitus, stable
* Hypertension, newly identified trend
* Edema, lower extremity, suspected related to hypertension

P (Plan):

* Start aspirin 81 mg orally once daily
* Prescribe nitroglycerin sublingual as needed for chest pain (may take up to 3 tablets, one every 5 minutes, seek emergency care if pain persists)
* Refer to cardiology for further evaluation and stress test within one week
* Start hydrochlorothiazide for blood pressure and edema
* Home blood pressure monitoring with daily morning logs, report findings via patient portal
* Continue metformin 500 mg twice daily
* Order repeat hemoglobin A1c
* Encourage dietary modifications (reduce soda and sweets)
* Attend ophthalmology appointment in 2 weeks for diabetic retinopathy screening
* Provide handout on hydrochlorothiazide side effects
* Outpatient follow-up in 2 weeks to reassess chest pain, blood pressure, and diabetes management

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Bilateral knee pain for approximately six months
- History of present illness: Deep, achy pain felt behind kneecaps, sometimes associated with creaking sounds; pain worsens with standing from seated position, after periods of inactivity, and when going up or down stairs; pain improves with rest; unable to run more than half a mile due to pain (previously could run 5-6 miles daily); no recollection of injury or trauma preceding onset
- Past medical history: Remote history of arm fracture in sixth grade, no prior knee injuries or fractures
- Social history: Works from home, previously active runner who enjoys outdoor and treadmill running, experiences reduced activity due to knee pain
- Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: Reviewed and within normal limits
- Physical exam: Heart—regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs; Gait—normal; Lower extremity muscle strength—abduction 3/5 bilaterally, remainder 5/5; Knees—no erythema, ecchymosis, warmth, or effusion; Tenderness to palpation of bilateral retinaculum; Positive patellar grind test; Pain with squatting; Lachman, anterior/posterior drawer, and McMurray tests negative bilaterally; Patellar and Achilles reflexes symmetrical
- Test results: Knee x-rays—no fractures or osteoarthritis; MRI reviewed (specific findings not detailed)

A (Assessment):

- Patellofemoral pain syndrome

P (Plan):

- Continue ibuprofen or anti-inflammatory medication as needed for pain
- Initiate physical therapy for lower extremity strength, mobility, and correction of running mechanics
- Advise patient to refrain from running for now; gradual return to running as symptoms improve
- Regular follow-up visits to assess progress

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Low back pain
* History of present illness: Severe low back pain started a couple of weeks ago after lifting a box of books with improper technique, described as achy and sharp; initially localized to low back, now radiates down the left leg, pain worsens with lumbar flexion, sitting usually does not aggravate pain.
* Associated symptoms: Denies numbness, tingling, loss of sensation, or weakness; no loss of bowel or bladder control.
* Treatments tried: Ibuprofen and acetaminophen with some relief.
* Past medical history: No information provided
* Social history: Sedentary job, exercises a few times a week inconsistently, does not smoke, former soccer player (midfield), supports Tottenham Hotspur.
* Family history: Father has back pain.

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Blood pressure ~130/70 mmHg, respiratory rate 18/min
* Physical exam: No overlying redness or bruising on back, midline tenderness at L4-L5 disk space, right lumbar paravertebral tenderness, pain with lumbar flexion, able to bend forward and backward, positive supine straight leg test, patella and Achilles reflexes are symmetrical, heart rhythm regular without murmurs/rubs/gallops, lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.
* Test results: MRI shows disk desiccation and bulge with paracentral disk herniation at L4-L5, resulting in moderate right neuroforaminal stenosis.

A (Assessment):

* Herniated disk with radiculopathy at L4-L5
* Lumbar back pain due to disk herniation

P (Plan):

* Perform spinal injection with strong NSAID and corticosteroid under fluoroscopy in the office today
* Provide written information on procedure, including risks and complications
* Address any further patient questions after review of written consent and explanation
* No information provided on follow-up or additional recommendations

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Left knee pain
- History of present illness: Left knee pain started about a week ago after twisting injury during running with niece; pain initially rated 4/10 and worsening, described as throbbing, more on the medial side than lateral, associated with limping and difficulty bearing weight; no improvement with time; heard a "pop" at the time of injury
- Medications tried: Tylenol (provides temporary relief), unable to take NSAIDs (due to history of ulcer), applied kinesiology tape
- Past medical history: Ulcer (history of)
- Social history: No information provided
- Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Physical exam: Edema and effusion of left knee, moderate range of motion, pain on flexion and extension, tenderness on medial aspect, Lachman's test negative, valgus and varus tests negative
- Test results: Left knee X-ray normal (no fractures, no bony abnormalities)
- Vital signs: No information provided

A (Assessment):

- Medial collateral ligament (MCL) strain, left knee

P (Plan):

- Prescribe tramadol 50 mg twice daily (non-NSAID pain medication)
- Continue Tylenol as needed for breakthrough pain
- Apply knee immobilizer for one week
- Ice knee 3-4 times per day for 20-30 minutes each session
- Avoid running or strenuous activities for three weeks
- Expected recovery in about one month
- Advise follow-up or call if symptoms worsen or do not improve; consider MRI if condition deteriorates
- No information provided regarding referrals, patient education beyond above, or additional tests

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Shortness of breath
- History of present illness: Developed lightheadedness and shortness of breath after a three-hour bike ride over the weekend; surprised as regular morning bike rides previously did not cause issues; reported some lightheadedness, difficulty catching breath after exercise; possible mild chest pain which resolved after about an hour
- Associated symptoms: No fever, no persistent chest pain, no recent cough (history of brief cough with last cold, resolved), no nausea, vomiting, or abdominal pain
- Past medical history: Migraines (well controlled with Imitrex and lifestyle management), gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD; managed with Protonix), history of cataract surgery approximately 4.5 months ago with good postoperative vision
- Social history: No information provided
- Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: All within normal limits; oxygenation reported as perfect
- Physical exam: Neck supple, no jugular venous distension, regular heart rhythm without murmur, lungs with bilateral expiratory wheeze, trace lower extremity edema noted
- Test results: Chest x-ray normal (no pulmonary edema, no pneumonia), pulmonary function tests (PFTs) normal, laboratory results normal

A (Assessment):

- Asthma exacerbation from exercise and allergies, suspected
- GERD, stable
- Migraines, stable

P (Plan):

- Prescribe albuterol inhaler, two puffs every four hours as needed for wheezing or shortness of breath
- Pulmonary referral ordered
- Continue Protonix for GERD
- Continue Imitrex as needed for migraines
- Follow-up visit in a couple of weeks
- Instructed patient to call the office immediately if shortness of breath recurs

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Follow-up for abnormal lab finding (low hemoglobin)
- History of present illness: Fatigue and decreased energy over the past couple of months; unable to maintain previous exercise level (downhill over last month); occasional mild weight loss attributed to increased exercise; denies blood in stools, dark or black stools, or spotting with periods; denies chest pain, shortness of breath, fever, chills, or body aches; denies lower extremity swelling
- Past medical history: COPD, congestive heart failure
- Social history: Quit smoking several years ago (cold turkey), no current tobacco use; has strong support system (boyfriend and brother nearby)
- Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: Within normal limits in office (no specific values provided)
- Physical exam: No cervical lymphadenopathy, lungs clear, heart with 2/6 systolic ejection murmur (previously noted), no lower extremity edema, abdomen with mild tenderness to palpation in the right lower quadrant
- Test results: Hemoglobin 8.2 g/dL (reference: normal for patient 13–14 g/dL), some anemia labs pending, other reviewed labs within normal limits (specifics not stated)

A (Assessment):

- Anemia
- COPD, stable
- Congestive heart failure, stable

P (Plan):

- Await results of pending anemia labs
- Schedule endoscopy and colonoscopy to rule out GI bleeding
- Refer to gastroenterology for endoscopy and colonoscopy
- Continue current medications: Toprol, lisinopril, and furosemide (Lasix) 20 mg daily
- Continue smoking cessation
- Continue to monitor diet and salt intake
- Close follow-up within one week after labs return
- No new inhalers or referrals for COPD at this time

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Annual exam
- History of present illness: Reports no back pain or limitation in movement since prior treatment for herniated disc; no numbness or tingling in hands since carpal tunnel release and has full range of motion; returned to work without issues. Over the past month, reports intermittent chest pain described as a burning sensation in the middle of the chest, occurring approximately three times per week, brought on by walking and relieved by rest, denies chest pain at rest, and does not consider it severe enough for emergency care. Denies shortness of breath, nausea, vomiting, lower extremity edema, muscle aches, fever, or chills. Reports some nasal congestion due to allergies.
- Past medical history: Coronary artery disease with prior stenting, carpal tunnel syndrome (status post release), herniated disc (status post steroid injection).
- Social history: No information provided
- Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: Blood pressure under good control, oxygenation normal
- Physical exam: Heart with grade 3/6 systolic ejection murmur (previously documented), lungs clear, no carotid bruits, no lower extremity edema, healed surgical scars on right wrist
- Test results: Echocardiogram from last year shows left ventricular ejection fraction 45%, mild mitral regurgitation; ECG stable with no new changes, consistent with prior coronary artery disease

A (Assessment):

- Coronary artery disease with recurrent exertional chest pain
- Status post carpal tunnel release, currently well
- Herniated disc, currently well
- Mitral regurgitation, mild, previously known
- Left ventricular systolic dysfunction (EF 45%), previously known

P (Plan):

- Continue aspirin and Toprol
- Start Crestor 20 mg once daily
- Order cardiac stress test
- Order lipid panel
- No further intervention needed for carpal tunnel release or herniated disc unless symptoms recur
- Follow-up after cardiac workup or as needed
- Patient education regarding symptoms to monitor and when to report/seek care

- History of present illness: Reports increased anxiety and stress due to holiday preparations; experienced enjoyment and stress during Thanksgiving; could not continue outdoor walks due to cold weather; not ready to start antidepressant medications; no desire to harm self or others; managing diabetes with some difficulty maintaining diet during holidays; monitoring blood pressure, reports values as "pretty moderate" and "pretty good"; no chest pain, shortness of breath, abdominal pain, blood in stool, or weight loss
- Past medical history: Depression, type 2 diabetes, hypertension
- Social history: Planning to take a vacation; previously enjoyed outdoor walks and yard work during warmer seasons

O (Objective):

- Physical exam: Neck—no carotid bruits; Heart—a slight 2/6 systolic ejection murmur at the left base, previously noted; Lungs—clear; Lower extremities—1+ non-pitting edema bilaterally
- Test results: Office EKG normal; Hemoglobin A1c elevated at 8; Diabetes logs reviewed; Lab lipid panel not yet obtained

A (Assessment):

- Depression
- Type 2 diabetes with elevated hemoglobin A1c
- Hypertension
- Heart murmur, previously evaluated

P (Plan):

- Follow-up as needed

transcription:
[doctor] okay . maria martin , date of birth 03/05/1946 , has been informed and consents to have this visit recorded . the patient is here for follow-up .
[doctor] hi , maria . how have you been doing ?
[patient] same i guess . pretty good .
[doctor] okay , so you got my letter last time on the results . your sugars are not very well controlled .
[patient] yeah , i got them .
[doctor] okay . so did you increase your glimepiride ?
[patient] did i increase it ?
[doctor] yeah .
[patient] i'm still taking the two milligrams .
[doctor] yeah . so we want you to , as the letter said , from the last time , when your a1c was 9.9 , we wanted you to increase it to four milligrams twice a day , so let's start that .
[patient] okay , sure . so you want me to take two of the pills , now twice a day ?
[doctor] yes . uh , how much of it do you have ?
[patient] well , i just filled it .
[doctor] okay , good . so yeah , you can take two of them twice a day , of what you have . the new prescription will be for four milligrams twice a day .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] great . and are you trying to eat healthier : less sugars , less carbohydrates ?
[patient] uh , well ...
[doctor] not really ?
[patient] . well , i have n't had any pasta ; i just do n't really like it , so we do n't have any in the house . we do n't often have bread , and if we do , we buy wheat bread .
[doctor] okay . but even the wheat bread , try to cut down on the number of slices you eat per day .
[patient] i just usually have two in the morning . i do n't care for sandwiches much ; maybe peanut butter sandwiches once in a while .
[doctor] yeah .
[patient] i hardly drink , drink any sodas .
[doctor] well , that's great .
[patient] i drink club soda .
[doctor] okay .
[patient] seltzer water , that's what i prefer , so that's my water . i do n't drink regular water .
[doctor] okay , that's fine . how about your eye exams ? are they up-to-date ?
[patient] yep . i just got new glasses .
[doctor] okay . who do you go see ?
[patient] i go to liberty road , the group up there .
[doctor] okay . the , um , the optimum optometrists , right ?
[patient] they keep changing doctors each time i go .
[doctor] a new doc each time ?
[patient] yeah . i got a really nice one i used to see a year ago .
[doctor] was that dr. sanchez ?
[patient] yeah .
[doctor] okay . and you saw him not too long ago ?
[patient] yeah . i just got my prescription from him . well , see , i had the iodine for my eyes .
[doctor] cataracts , yep , okay .
[patient] so he did that and then i had to wait for a month to get healed up and then he wrote my prescription .
[doctor] perfect . and then you've got the high blood pressure .
[patient] yeah . a couple of weeks ago , it was 116 on the dot .
[doctor] okay . well , we will recheck it . you're on a combination of medications . you are on the met- met- uh , metoprolol , 50 milligrams once a day , you're on the lisinopril with hydrochlorothiazide , at 20 , with 25 milligrams once a day , and you're on the amlodipine , 10 milligram once a day . are you taking all of those ?
[patient] well , yeah .
[doctor] perfect . and then you've got the high cholesterol and the vascular disease in your legs . you're on atorvastatin . are you tolerating it okay ?
[patient] yeah , but honestly , my feet feel like hell .
[doctor] yeah .
[patient] all the time , my legs are bugging me ; i ca n't do much walking .
[doctor] okay . yeah , the feet i think is what we call peripheral neuropathy .
[patient] also , i have the pain up to my hip .
[doctor] okay . you have pain in the hips and upper legs ?
[patient] yeah , all of it .
[doctor] okay . so those do seem relatively stable , right ? and are you trying to get the walking in ?
[patient] yeah .
[doctor] okay . and you are smoking still ?
[patient] yeah , still smoking .
[doctor] not ready to quit ?
[patient] no , not really .
[doctor] it's a bad combination .
[patient] i know . i'll think about it .
[doctor] okay . now , let's do my review of systems . you're not having any headaches or dizziness ?
[patient] headaches or dizziness , no .
[doctor] okay .
[patient] nothing , feeling totally normal .
[doctor] good , good . and the vision is better with the cataract surgery ? that's been good ?
[patient] yeah . not happy with this lens ; it's kinda funny . the other one is good .
[doctor] hmm , sometimes they can go in and clean up the eye with laser , but we'll see what they say .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] okay . no shortness of breath or coughing ?
[patient] i've been coughing here lately because i've been congested .
[doctor] what does it look like when it comes up ?
[patient] it's relatively clear .
[doctor] no fever , chills , no shortness of breath ?
[patient] no .
[doctor] okay . no chest pains or pressure or tightness ?
[patient] no .
[doctor] nausea , vomiting , gi symptoms ?
[patient] no .
[doctor] okay . peeing okay ?
[patient] not good . it's , you know , i'm old ; it takes me a little more time .
[doctor] slower stream but stable ?
[patient] yes , but i do pee ...
[doctor] okay .
[patient] . several times per day .
[doctor] mm-hmm . how many times do you have to get up at night ?
[patient] not too bad , just once in a while .
[doctor] okay .
[patient] then i have to pee by morning . i do tend to drink my drinks in the evening .
[doctor] okay . all right , let's have a look at you .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] physical exam : carotids are normal , pulse is no buits . heart exam : rhythm is regular , normal rate , s1 and s2 are crisp . i do not hear any murmurs today , okay . have you lean forward for me . take some deep breaths , in and out . okay , lungs are clear . i do n't hear any rasps or wheezing today .
[patient] my coughing got better this morning .
[doctor] you cleared out the lungs ? all right , let me take a look at your feet .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] okay . extremities are without edema . pulses are palpable on the dorsalis pedis posterial tibial . she has thickened nails .
[patient] yeah .
[doctor] yeah . mildly dry skin , no skin breakdown . l- let me know if you can feel this .
[patient] okay . i closed my eyes . yeah , yeah , okay .
[doctor] mildly decreased sensation in the tips of the first and second toes . okay , we're done with your exam .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] okay . so again , try to keep the feet moisturized .
[patient] yeah .
[doctor] you do have a little bit of periphe- peripheral neuropathy . um , there is a medication we can use if they get really bad , but you're already on so many medications .
[patient] my girl that i talk to and stuff , she uses on her feet ; she really likes it . it's , like , a foot scrub or some type of cream . i put it on when i think of it after the shower . so i could get my own instead .
[doctor] that sounds good . so for now , your sugars , we're gon na check your ... we're going to recheck your blood work today , but the sugars last time we checked , the a1c , your blood sugar average was above nine . i really want you to increase the glimepiride . so the ones you have at home , the two milligram , take two of them twice a day .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] okay . watch for low sugars , weak , shaky , sweaty . if that happens , let us know , and i do n't expect it to .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] okay . the new prescription that i'm going to write is gon na be for the , uh , four milligram pill . so when you get the new one , just one pill twice a day . also , continue the metformin , okay ? blood pressure , when i rechecked it , i got 140 over 60 s- so the numbers at home are better , so we're gon na continue the combination of medications . we'll check kidney function today .
[doctor] for your cholesterol though , you're on the high dose of atorvastatin or lipitor to protect the arteries , so we really wan na keep you on that .
[patient] yeah , no problem .
[doctor] i want you to quit smoking , but we've had this battle before .
[patient] yeah .
[doctor] hmm . and then , we will leave everything else the same . we'll get the labs today and we'll see you back here in four months . sound good ?
[patient] okay .
[doctor] great . have a good day , ma'am . take care of yourself .
[patient] thank you . you too .
[doctor] bye .
SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Follow-up visit
- History of present illness: Reports persistently elevated blood sugars, currently taking glimepiride 2 mg, has not increased dose as previously advised, minimal healthy dietary changes (avoids pasta, prefers wheat bread, two slices in the morning, rare peanut butter sandwiches), rarely drinks sodas, prefers seltzer/club soda over water; intermittent cough with congestion, sputum clear, no fever, chills, headache, dizziness, chest pain, shortness of breath, nausea, vomiting, or GI symptoms. Reports slowed urinary stream and nocturia "once in a while", needs to urinate in the morning, drinks fluids in the evening. Persistent pain in feet, legs, and hips limiting walking. Vision improved after recent cataract surgery but dissatisfaction with one lens.
- Past medical history: Diabetes mellitus, hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, vascular disease in legs, cataracts (post-surgical), peripheral neuropathy (physician stated term in visit)
- Social history: Current smoker, not ready to quit; walking activity present but limited by pain
- Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: Blood pressure rechecked in office 140/60 mmHg; reported value at home 116 mmHg (two weeks ago)
- Physical exam: Carotids normal, no bruits; heart rhythm regular, normal rate, S1 and S2 crisp, no murmurs; lungs clear, no rales or wheezing; extremities: no edema, dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses palpable, thickened nails, mildly dry skin, no skin breakdown, mildly decreased sensation in tips of first and second toes
- Test results: Last A1c 9.9%; blood work and kidney function to be rechecked today

A (Assessment):

- Diabetes mellitus, poorly controlled
- Peripheral neuropathy, mild
- Hypertension, controlled at home, elevated in clinic
- Hypercholesterolemia
- Vascular disease in lower extremities
- History of cataracts (post-surgery)

P (Plan):

- Increase glimepiride to 4 mg twice daily (take two 2 mg tablets twice a day until new prescription filled, then one 4 mg tablet twice a day)
- Continue metformin
- Continue current antihypertensive medications: metoprolol 50 mg once daily, lisinopril/hydrochlorothiazide 20/25 mg once daily, amlodipine 10 mg once daily
- Continue high-dose atorvastatin
- Moisturize feet regularly
- Monitor for hypoglycemia (weakness, shakiness, sweating)
- Recheck blood work, including kidney function, today
- Encourage diet modification (reduce bread intake, overall less carbohydrates/sugars)
- Counsel regarding smoking cessation
- Follow-up visit in 4 months
- Referral or consideration for further eye evaluation if lens dissatisfaction persists
- No new medications for neuropathy at this time due to current polypharmacy

transcription:
[doctor] patient mrn : abc123 . date of birth : january 1st , 1960 . patient is a 60 year old , right-handed male , referred today for evaluation of numbness and tingling .
[doctor] hello , mr. cook . how are you doing this morning ?
[patient] hi , dr. martinez . this weekend was a bit rough . i've had this numbness and tingling for a few weeks now .
[doctor] so it's in both of your hands ?
[patient] yes , ever since my car wreck last december when i broke them ... well , once they healed , i mean , i noticed it more , the tingling and the numbness .
[doctor] and you still wear the splint only on the right wrist ?
[patient] no , i also wear the left sometimes . the right is just worse , but the splint helps . both have really gotten worse over the last month . when i broke them , my right wrist was definitely in worse shape . i've also been having some s- mild stiffness in my neck too . i hit my head during the accident , and they told me it was a contusion .
[doctor] and where would you say the tingling and numbness is ?
[patient] on this side , it goes from here and here up to about here . on the other side , it's from here to here .
[doctor] i see . so on the right side , you're pointing from the middle and ring finger , all the way up the forearm . and on the left , the symptoms extend from the pinky and ring finger . and is there any pain or just tingling and numbness ?
[patient] eh , it's mainly just sore . sometimes they throb , but overall , they feel weaker too , especially when i'm using them . the tingling happens more when they hurt , but when it goes away , the tingling is dull .
[doctor] and when do you feel these symptoms ?
[patient] well , really , i guess , just more so at night , and they come and go throughout the day .
[doctor] okay . and do you experience any loss of sensation in your hands or fingers ?
[patient] like , feeling something ? no , not that i can really think of . though , in general , they may be less sensitive than they should be , but i can still feel . they also gave me some nerve pain medicine , but i have n't been taking it like i should .
[doctor] and are you still on the coreg for hypertension and the lexapro for anxiety ?
[patient] yes , i'm still taking those . i had prediabetes too , but i got it under control by changing my diet .
[doctor] and no history of thyroid issues , correct ?
[patient] nope .
[doctor] all right , thank you , mr. cook . okay , first , we'll go over your review of systems . correct me if i'm wrong in any of this .
[doctor] constitutional , you have fatigue and weight gain ; gi , you have excessive appetite and bloating ; eyes have floaters ; cardiovascular shows shortness of breath and leg swelling ; endocrine , you're always hungry ; skin , you have some nail bed changes , dryness , itching ; musculoskeletal , you have gout and muscle pain . and the remainder of the review of systems is negative .
[patient] yep , that's all correct .
[doctor] all right , we're going to go ahead and do the neurologic examination . let's look at the right hand first . can you feel this ?
[patient] yeah , but a little less on these two fingers .
[doctor] sensation is normal , except pin prick sensation diminished in third and fourth fingers on the right .
[doctor] and how about on the left ?
[patient] um , yeah , but these two a little less .
[doctor] sensation is decreased in the fourth and fifth fingers on the left
[doctor] okay , let's test your reflexes now . reflexes are 1+ and symmetric ; 2+ knees ; toes are downgoing bilaterally .
[doctor] all right , i'm going to tap on your right wrist . do you feel anything ?
[patient] yeah , it feels like a zing up my wrist and something into my elbow too .
[doctor] and how about the left side ?
[patient] yeah , same on that side too .
[doctor] tinel sign positive at both wrists and both elbows . rest of exam is normal .
[doctor] all right , so what i am seeing today is bilateral carpal tunnel syndrome or , potentially , this could also be bilateral cubital tunnel syndrome . however , your symptom presentation suggests car- bilateral carpal syndrome , as the nerve in your wrists are aggravated by your past trauma . this is causing the pain and tingling you were describing to me .
[patient] okay , so how do we make it better ?
[doctor] first , i want to determine exactly where the nerve irritation is coming from . we'll need to schedule you for a nerve test , which is called an emg test . they will measure the responsiveness of your nerves to truly pinpoint where you are having your issues .
[patient] that sounds fine to me .
[doctor] great . after the tests are complete , you can return here for a follow-up visit . if you're still having symptoms , we can consider a referral to our hand clinic , possibly for injections or carpal tunnel release se- surgery . you could also refer ... we could also refer you to an orthopedist for the same treatment .
[patient] sounds good , doc .
[doctor] all right , keep wearing your splints , and i will see you after those studies .
[patient] thank you .
SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Numbness and tingling in both hands
* History of present illness: Numbness and tingling in both hands persisting for a few weeks, worsened over the past month, increased at night and intermittent during the day; symptoms began after a car accident in December with bilateral hand fractures (right worse), history of splint use (right more than left), associated symptoms include soreness, occasional throbbing pain, subjective hand weakness, mild neck stiffness since accident and head contusion at that time; no complete loss of sensation reported, mild subjective decrease in sensitivity; splints provide some relief.
* Review of systems: Fatigue, weight gain, excessive appetite, bloating, visual floaters, shortness of breath, leg swelling, always hungry, nail bed changes, skin dryness, itching, history of gout, muscle pain; remainder negative.
* Past medical history: Hypertension, anxiety (on Coreg and Lexapro), prior prediabetes (now controlled with diet), gout; no thyroid disease.
* Social history: No information provided
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Physical exam: Sensation normal except diminished pin prick in right third and fourth fingers, decreased sensation in left fourth and fifth fingers, reflexes 1+ and symmetric in upper extremities, knees 2+, toes downgoing bilaterally, Tinel sign positive at both wrists and elbows, rest of exam normal
* Vital signs: No information provided
* Test results: No information provided

A (Assessment):

* Bilateral carpal tunnel syndrome
* Differential diagnosis: Bilateral cubital tunnel syndrome

P (Plan):

* Schedule nerve conduction study (EMG) to localize nerve irritation
* Continue wearing splints
* Follow-up visit after EMG results
* Consider referral to hand clinic or orthopedics for possible injections or carpal tunnel release surgery if symptoms persist

transcription:
[doctor] patient shirley taylor . date of birth 5/4/1961 . mrn 0000123 . patient is a 60 year old right-handed female new patient referred by dr. jacob ward for evaluation of bilateral hand numbness and tingling . please note that i personally reviewed the ct brain with and without contrasting did 2/5/21 . uh , no metastatic disease . no acute intercranial abnormalities .
[doctor] hello ms. taylor . how are you doing this morning ?
[patient] hi dr . lopez . this weekend was a bit rough . i've had this numbness and tingling for a few weeks now .
[doctor] so , in both of your hands ?
[patient] yeah . ever since my car wreck last december when i broke them . well , once they heal , i mean , i noticed it more , the , the tingling and numbness .
[doctor] are you still wearing the splint only on your right wrist ?
[patient] no . i wear the left one also sometimes . the right one's just worse . the splint seems to help . both have gotten worse over the last month . when i broke them though , my wrist was definitely in worse shape than it is today . i've been having some mild stiffness in my neck too . i hit my head during the accident , and they told me it was a contusion .
[doctor] okay . and where exactly on the right side would you say the tingling and numbness is ?
[patient] on the right , i can really notice it from my middle and ring finger all the way up to my forearm , and on my left , a bit more the pinky and the ring and not the middle .
[doctor] all right . and , um , is there is pain or , or just tingling and numbness ?
[patient] uh , mainly just sore . sometimes they throb , but overall , they feel weaker too , especially when i'm using them . the tingling happens some more , but when they hurt , you know , it goes away and then the tingling's just dull .
[doctor] what kind of activities ?
[patient] well , really , i guess , just more so at night , and then it just kind of comes and goes throughout the day .
[doctor] okay . and do you experience any loss of sensation in your hands or fingers ?
[patient] uh , like , like feeling something ? no , not that i can think of really . in general , they might be less sensitive than they should be , but i can still feel . they gave me some nerve pain medicine , but i have n't been taking it like i should be .
[doctor] okay . looks like your medical history is notable for chronic kidney disease , gout , hypertension , anxiety , gerd , and diabetes .
[patient] well , i had pre-diabetes , but i got in under control changing my diet .
[doctor] okay . good . and are you still on the carvedilol 25 milligrams two times a day for hypertension and lexapro 10 milligrams a day for anxiety ? looks like your allergic to sulfa drugs as well . is that correct ?
[patient] yeah , i'm still taking those and sulfa just causes me to break out in a rash .
[doctor] and no history of thyroid issues , right ?
[patient] nope .
[doctor] all right . thank you ms. taylor . i'll be right back for your exam . i want to look up that medication you mentioned for your nerve pain .
[patient] all right . thanks .
[doctor] review of systems , please make the following changes . uh , constitutional , patient reports fatigue and weight gain . gi , um , excessive appetite and bloating . eyes , floaters . uh , cardiovascular , shortness of breath and leg swelling . endocrine , positive diabetes , always hungry . skin , nail bed trenches , dryness , itching . musculoskeletal , gout , muscle pain . neurological , parasthesia , bilateral hands .
[doctor] um , please use the default normal neuro-physical exam with the following changes . sensations normal except pin prick sensation diminished in the third and forth fingers on the right . and the fourth and fifth fingers on the left . reflexes are one plus and symmetric , two plus knees , toes are down going bilaterally , tinel's sign positive at both wrists and both elbows .
[doctor] let's move onto assessment and plan , bilateral carpal tunnel syndrome , question of bilateral cubital tunnel syndrome . i discussed my impression with the patient , i will schedule her for emg , ncv . if her symptoms do not resolve , we can consider hand clinic referral for possible symptomatic injections or carpal tunnel release surgery although she can pursue these uh , through her current orthopedist . i encouraged her to wear her splints , returned for emg , ncv . end of note .
SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Bilateral hand numbness and tingling
- History of present illness: Numbness and tingling in both hands for a few weeks, worsening over the last month; symptoms noted since car accident with bilateral wrist fractures in December (right wrist worse initially, both healed); neck mild stiffness; onset of tingling and numbness was more noticeable after healing; symptoms worse at night and intermittent during the day; soreness, occasional throbbing, hand weakness, and perceived decreased sensation but can still feel
- Aggravating/relieving factors: Wearing splints seems to help; symptoms worse at night
- Associated symptoms (review of systems): Fatigue, weight gain, excessive appetite, bloating, floaters, shortness of breath, leg swelling, always hungry, nail bed trenches, skin dryness, itching, muscle pain, paresthesia bilateral hands
- Past medical history: Chronic kidney disease, gout, hypertension, anxiety, GERD, history of pre-diabetes (now controlled with diet)
- Medications: Carvedilol 25 mg twice daily (hypertension), Lexapro 10 mg daily (anxiety), nerve pain medication (name and dose not specified, not taken as prescribed)
- Allergies: Sulfa drugs (rash)
- Family history: No information provided
- Social history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: No information provided
- Physical exam: Default normal neuro-physical exam with changes: pinprick sensation diminished in right third and fourth fingers, left fourth and fifth fingers; reflexes 1+ and symmetric (upper extremities), 2+ at knees; toes downgoing bilaterally; Tinel's sign positive at both wrists and elbows
- Test results: CT brain with and without contrast (2/5/21) - no metastatic disease, no acute intracranial abnormalities; No information provided for additional testing/labs

A (Assessment):

- Bilateral carpal tunnel syndrome
- Question of bilateral cubital tunnel syndrome

P (Plan):

- Schedule EMG and nerve conduction velocity (NCV) studies
- Encourage continued use of hand splints
- Consider referral to hand clinic for possible symptomatic injections or carpal tunnel release surgery if symptoms persist (can also pursue through orthopedist)
- Follow-up for EMG, NCV results
- No medication changes documented

transcription:
[doctor] michelle king , date of birth 01/05/1986 , mrnq27631 . new patient visit for acid reflux . past medical history of anxiety and seasonal allergies .
[doctor] hello , are you mrs. king ?
[patient] i am .
[doctor] i'm dr. phillips . very nice to meet you .
[patient] you as well .
[doctor] how can i help you today ?
[patient] well , my primary doctor , dr. scott , he referred me here .
[doctor] okay .
[patient] i've just got really bad acid reflux .
[doctor] okay . can you tell me more about it ?
[patient] yeah . though i mean i ... right now , i take 40 milligrams of omeprazole twice a day . some days , it is fine , but others are just really bad .
[doctor] what do you feel ?
[patient] it feels like burning .
[doctor] in your chest ?
[patient] yes , in my chest and also in my throat .
[doctor] in your throat and chest . all right . any difficulty with swallowing ? feels like food or liquids kinda get stuck ?
[patient] no .
[doctor] okay . that's good . any abdominal pain ?
[patient] no , not really .
[doctor] nausea or vomiting , changes in bowel movements ?
[patient] no .
[doctor] constipation , diarrhea , rectal bleeding ?
[patient] nope .
[doctor] okay . very good . and how long have you had this problem ?
[patient] i've had acid reflux since i was around 12 , but it has gotten worse over the past few years .
[doctor] okay . and how long have you been on the omeprazole ?
[patient] on the way , it is now i think about a year .
[doctor] okay . do you find that it's done anything for you in the past ?
[patient] i mean , i can tell it's helped because some days , i'll be fine , and then some days , i eat something and it feels terrible .
[doctor] are there any things that make your symptoms worse that you can pinpoint , like food choices or stress ?
[patient] sure . probably stress and food choices sometimes .
[doctor] okay . what things bother you ?
[patient] spicy foods , um , so i try not to eat them too often , but sometimes even drinking a soda can cause it .
[doctor] we do know that caffeine and caffeinated beverages will do that , even sodas . um , even just the carbonation can cause that . how about tomato-based products or citrus products ?
[patient] yeah , sometimes , but i still eat them .
[doctor] okay . it's reassuring that you are n't having any difficulty swallowing , though . how's your weight been ? pretty stable ?
[patient] i'd say pretty stable , although i have n't had much of an appetite for the past two months . i have been under a lot of work stress .
[doctor] what do you do for work ?
[patient] i'm a paralegal .
[doctor] okay . and any family history of gi issues ?
[patient] um , my grandmother had esophageal cancer .
[doctor] on your mom or dad's side ?
[patient] mom's side . and my mom had some issues like acid reflux , and she was taking some medication that coats the lining of your stomach .
[doctor] okay . have you ever had an upper endoscopy ?
[patient] i think maybe when i was younger .
[doctor] but not in the last 10 years ?
[patient] no .
[doctor] have you ever tried any medication other than omeprazole ?
[patient] um , at one point i was on omeprazole and ranititine -dine . it did help . but other than that , those are the only medications i have taken .
[doctor] okay . have a seat here , and let me listen to your heart and lungs , and then we can talk about a plan for you .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] so normal physical exam per my new patient template , except for well-healed abdominal surgical scars noted . what's the surgical scar here on your abdomen from ?
[patient] i always forget about that surgery . i had it when i was a baby . my mom said my intestines were twisted , so i had to have surgery when i was around one month old .
[doctor] hm , gotcha . okay . so let's talk about what you have going on . from what you've told me , it sounds like you've had a several-year history of gerd , which is the medical term for acid reflux . and recently your symptoms have been poorly controlled with the omeprazole , 40 milligrams twice daily . you've been having heartburn despite taking this medication , correct ?
[patient] yes .
[doctor] and you've identified trigger foods like spicy foods , carbonated bev- beverages , citrus , and tomato-based foods , but you have n't cut these foods out of your diet completely yet . so the first thing i'd try is changing your diet because these foods can exacerbate your gerd , even though you're taking the ppi .
[patient] okay , yeah , i could definitely do a better job of avoiding those foods .
[doctor] great . so stress is another trigger that we need to address . high stress can cause worsening of your symptoms .
[patient] yeah , stress and anxiety are definitely big problems for me .
[doctor] so working on that may help with your gerd . additionally , we can consider trying a different ppi since the only one you've tried up to this point is omeprazole . if you're okay with this , we can switch your omeprazole to nexium .
[patient] that's fine with me . i'm definitely open to trying whatever .
[doctor] perfect . i will send a prescription for nexium 40 milligrams twice daily to your pharmacy on file . i'll also recommend that you have a procedure called a egd , or upper endoscopy , to look for potential causes of the gerd . we'd sedate you and then pass a small camera through your mouth , down your throat , through your stomach , and end in the small intestines . we'd look for any ulcers or signs of precancerous or cancerous conditions that we can take biopsies at the same time if we see anything .
[patient] okay . can i schedule that today ?
[doctor] yeah . you can get scheduled at checkout desk . i'll have you follow up with me in the office for the egd so we can discuss the results and talk about how you're doing with the dietary , stress , and medication changes . how does all of that sound ?
[patient] that sounds good .
[doctor] perfect . i will walk you to the checkout desk . be sure to call my office and let me know if anything changes or if you have problems before your egd and follow-up appointment .
[doctor] please insert the procedure paragraph in the plan . i suspect that she likely has gerd with underlying functional etiology as well . reassuringly , she has no unintentional weight loss and denies any dysphagia . if her egd is normal and her symptoms pers- persist despite a trial of nexium , we can consider a trial of protonix and obtain a ph-impedance study . this will allow us to rule out abnormal acid reflux exposure and to decipher between a functional etiology and hypersensitivity .
SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Acid reflux
* History of present illness: Longstanding acid reflux since age 12, symptoms have worsened over the past few years; experiences burning sensation in chest and throat, symptoms variably controlled on omeprazole 40 mg twice daily for about a year, symptoms worsen with certain foods (spicy foods, carbonated beverages, citrus, tomato-based products) and stress; no dysphagia, abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, constipation, diarrhea, or rectal bleeding; appetite has decreased for the past 2 months, attributed to high work stress; no significant weight change
* Past medical history: Anxiety, seasonal allergies, surgery for intestinal malrotation in infancy
* Social history: Works as a paralegal, reports high work-related stress
* Family history: Maternal grandmother with esophageal cancer, mother with acid reflux and use of mucosal-protective medication

O (Objective):

* Physical exam: Normal per new patient template, except for well-healed abdominal surgical scars
* Test results: No information provided
* Vital signs: No information provided

A (Assessment):

* GERD (gastroesophageal reflux disease), longstanding, currently poorly controlled on omeprazole
* Functional etiology suspected
* Reassuring: No unintentional weight loss, no dysphagia

P (Plan):

* Discontinue omeprazole; start Nexium (esomeprazole) 40 mg orally twice daily
* Dietary modification: Avoid trigger foods (spicy foods, carbonated beverages, citrus, tomato-based products)
* Stress management and anxiety reduction
* Schedule EGD (esophagogastroduodenoscopy/upper endoscopy): The procedure will be done under sedation, with a small camera passed through the mouth, esophagus, stomach, and into the small intestine to look for ulcers or precancerous/cancerous changes; biopsies will be taken if any abnormalities are observed
* Follow up in office after EGD to review results and assess response to medication and lifestyle changes
* If EGD is normal and symptoms persist after trying Nexium, consider a trial of Protonix (pantoprazole) and a pH-impedance study to rule out abnormal acid reflux exposure and distinguish between functional etiology and hypersensitivity
* Patient to call office with any new or worsening symptoms prior to next appointment

[doctor] . next patient is michelle king . date of birth : 05/07/1982 . please use toc template . she was admitted to district regional hospital on 06/29/2021 , and was discharged on 07/02/2021 . the patient is a 39-year-old female with history of quadriplegia due to , uh , prior spinal cord injury . she was experiencing increasing concerns for spasms and lightheadedness , significant constipation , and reported diaphoresis . she was evaluated in the emergency department where she was , uh , febrile and had significantly elevated white blood cell count of 23,000 . there were concerns for ongoing urinary tract infection , but she was treated with iv antibiotic therapy . she had labile blood pressure , headache , and vomiting . in the end , she slowly improved . she does have a supra-pubic catheter . cultures were obtained and reviewed . she was eventually discharged after clinical improvement of her symptoms . she presents today to follow up regarding these concerns . hi , michelle . how are you doing ?

[patient] okay .

[doctor] so i'm not concerned about the side effects of this . i do n't think it does anything . um , and we have vaccinated 50 % of the country .

[doctor] so there are definitely potential side effects to the vaccine . i mean , there's guillain-barre , and all these things that could happen from the vaccine , but they're just very rare . my thing for you is i'm not convinced that there's alternative stuff or even the treatment we have , like the monoclonal antibodies , that will give help , but it's just my opinion .

[doctor] so that's what's gon na happen with covid . that's what's mo- most of the science supports and this is how most pandemics end , is that the virus starts losing its potency .

[patient] will do .

[patient] nope . i think i'm all set . thank you .
