[doctor] next line heading will be " acute to chronic constipation " . she believes her hospitalization was more likely due to her dysreflexia , from her quadriplegia that typically occurs . she did have a lot of vital signs changes , including blood pressure fluctuations . the patient feels like she has a good bowel regimen , including taking the miralax regularly as a primary treatment for constipation issues as well as lactulose for severe constipation . she feels like this was less likely a true urinary tract infection and was just related to her constipation . however , we did have a good discussion regarding her leukocytosis .
[doctor] i would recommend just in the next three or four weeks to come back in for some updated fasting labs , and we'll repeat the cbc just to make sure her white blood cells tend downward . uh , next line and heading will be " quadriplegia " . um , next line and heading will be " covid vaccine status " . again , she's hesitant . we had a good discussion , and i recommended that the only true preventative mechanism for covid is the vaccine . i do not believe that supplements are necessarily going to help stave this off . i would be concerned if she does n't get the vaccine and i would consider her at high risk based on her quadriplegia status . she does not want to get covid . however , she needs to make these decisions . she is somewhat homeopathic .
SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Follow-up after recent hospitalization for spasms, lightheadedness, constipation, diaphoresis, labile blood pressure, headache, and vomiting
- History of present illness: Reports recent admission due to concerns over spasms and lightheadedness; significant constipation and diaphoresis prior to admission; febrile episode and elevated white cell count (23,000) noted in ED; had headache, vomiting, and labile BP during hospitalization; improved after bowel movement at home; attributes symptoms primarily to constipation and dysreflexia secondary to quadriplegia; regular use of Miralax, occasional use of lactulose for severe constipation
- Past medical history: Quadriplegia due to prior spinal cord injury
- Social history: Stays indoors more when weather is hot; hesitant about COVID-19 vaccination; uses vitamin C and multivitamins; reports being closely monitored; unvaccinated against COVID-19; does not receive annual influenza vaccination
- Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: No information provided
- Physical exam: Lungs auscultated, no pain or discomfort reported by patient
- Test results: White blood cell count 23,000 during recent admission, urine cultures obtained but not impressive; abdominal x-ray performed, no CT scan; no additional test results provided
- Devices: Has a suprapubic catheter

A (Assessment):

- Acute to chronic constipation, likely related to dysreflexia from quadriplegia
- Quadriplegia
- Labile blood pressure, attributed to dysreflexia due to constipation, not a confirmed urinary tract infection
- Leukocytosis, unclear etiology, to be monitored
- COVID-19 vaccine status: Unvaccinated, hesitant, high risk due to quadriplegia

P (Plan):

- Follow up in 2–3 weeks for updated fasting labs, including complete blood count to monitor white blood cells and a full cholesterol panel
- Continue current bowel regimen with Miralax as primary therapy and lactulose as adjunct for severe constipation as needed
- Patient education and discussion regarding COVID-19 vaccine; physician recommends vaccination as sole effective preventive strategy, expresses concern regarding high risk due to quadriplegia
- Monitor for recurrence of autonomic dysreflexia symptoms, bowel irregularity, and any signs of infection
- Patient to contact clinic with any new or worsening symptoms

SOAP:

[doctor] okay . next patient is ashley james , date of birth 12/27/2006 . ashley is a 14-year-old female , uh , who was previously healthy , now here for evaluation of abnormal renal ultrasound with an atrophic right kidney . hi . good afternoon , ashley . how are you doing ?
[patient] i'm doing okay . how are you .
[doctor] i'm doing well . thanks so much for asking . i'm dr. rogers . i'm one of your kidney doctors . and you guys must be mom and dad .
[patient] yes , that's correct .
[doctor] great . well ... all right . it's so nice to meet all of you . i wish it was under better circumstances , but we're gon na figure it all out , uh , here today . um , speaking of that , let's go ahead and review some of your past medical history , and then i'll complete an exam of her heart and lungs and kind of move from there . would that be all right with you , ashley ?
[patient] yeah , that sounds good .
[doctor] okay . so as i understand it , ashley was found to have a small ... kind of a small kidney on one side . tell me about when that was . um , i do also have records of everything , but i'd just like to hear the story of how it was found out and what you're doing that got us here , uh , today .
[patient_guest] sure . so ashley came home one day sick out of nowhere , rubbing her stomach , and she said it was hurting on her right side . and it was so bad that she was bent over in pain .
[doctor] okay .
[patient] we automatically thought appendix .
[doctor] sure . that makes a lot of sense .
[patient_guest] we took her to her doctor . they treated her for a stomach virus . they get her fluids and sent her back home , and the next day she was twice as bad as the first day .
[doctor] goodness . okay . then what happened ?
[patient_guest] yeah . so i took her back again and they did more testing . i think they did an ultrasound or something , and that's where they found that one kidney was bigger .
[doctor] okay .
[patient_guest] um , then at that time they told us to followup with our primary the next day , which we did . um , but he was heading out on vacation , so he only saw her for a brief 10 minutes and then we were out the door . so she was still throwing up , in a lot of pain , so i took work off to help her .
[doctor] wow . okay .

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Abdominal pain, abnormal renal ultrasound with atrophic right kidney
- History of present illness: Previously healthy 14-year-old female; developed sudden right-sided abdominal pain (severe, bent over in pain), initially thought to be appendicitis; treated for stomach virus with fluids, symptoms worsened the next day; repeat evaluation showed one kidney larger, subsequent imaging revealed right kidney atrophic and left kidney larger; history of prior vomiting and abdominal pain, persistent stomach pain and burning sensation especially with eating, burning sensation with urination particularly after consuming soda, prefers Gatorade or water; reports occasional difficulty initiating urination; no gross hematuria; prior episodes of fever and infection requiring hospitalization at age 4
- Past medical history: Multiple hospitalizations for febrile illness at age 4 (treated with antibiotics and fluids, no clear source identified)
- Medications: Pepcid 40 mg daily, Claritin for allergies
- Social history: Active in softball, plans to join drill team
- Family history: Renal disease in grandfather (posterior urethral valves, obstructive neuropathy, end-stage renal disease, dialysis-dependent, renal transplant, died at 47 of heart attack), great aunt with end-stage renal disease, chronic kidney disease stage 5, diabetes, hypertension (all as adult onset), family history of breast cancer (maternal grandmother)
  
O (Objective):

- Physical exam: Well-appearing female, alert and oriented, sitting comfortably, no acute distress, heart and lungs normal on auscultation, overall exam within normal limits
- Test results: Renal ultrasound showing atrophic right kidney, compensatory hypertrophy of left kidney, cysts identified on kidney and ovaries, swollen lymph nodes noted on prior imaging, no clinically significant mutations on genetic panel
- Vital signs: Kidney function tests and blood pressure reported as normal (specific values not provided)

A (Assessment):

- Atrophic right kidney
- Compensatory hypertrophy of left kidney
- Family history of chronic kidney disease

P (Plan):

- Annual kidney ultrasound to monitor kidney size and function
- Annual urinalysis to assess for proteinuria and hematuria
- Annual blood pressure checks
- Avoid non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) such as ibuprofen; use acetaminophen (Tylenol) if needed
- Maintain adequate hydration (recommend at least 2 liters of water daily)
- Continue a healthy diet and active lifestyle
- Follow up with primary care physician or adult nephrologist as convenient
- Patient education on warning signs and when to seek medical care
- No further intervention required at this time
- No information provided regarding additional laboratory or imaging follow-up outside what is listed above

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Left lower back pain
- History of present illness: Persistent left-sided low back pain since back surgery (microdiscectomy) in November 2020, pain location generally near the previous surgical site, pain described as sometimes occurring on the right side depending on the day, pain worsened by bending over and weightbearing, relieved by stretching, occurs randomly, prior symptoms of severe nerve pain radiating down the leg before surgery (no current leg pain reported)
- Past medical history: Microdiscectomy for herniated disc (November 2020)
- Medication history: Prior high-dose gabapentin (withdrawal described as difficult), currently taking ibuprofen 800 mg/day for pain
- Social history: No information provided
- Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Physical exam: No pain with lumbar flexion or extension, pain on standing (weightbearing), tenderness to palpation at left lumbar region (around L5), no tenderness on right, normal dorsiflexion strength, normal range of motion, no pain radiating down legs, no current nerve pain, surgical site noted
- Test results: Recent lumbar spine X-ray shows no fractures, no spinal bone abnormalities, evidence of prior surgery with proper healing

A (Assessment):

- Muscle pull at left lumbar region due to spinal misalignment
- Referral to pain management for further evaluation and consideration of pain control strategies

P (Plan):

- Prescribe meloxicam in place of ibuprofen for pain management
- Prescribe Demerol as additional pain management
- Refer to physical therapy
- Refer to pain management clinic for evaluation and discussion of non-narcotic pain control options
- No other concerns raised today

reveals posterior chamber intraocular lenses in both eyes right eye the cornea is clear no mvi pciol cup to disc is . two fundus examination of the right eye shows the retina to be attached three hundred and sixty degrees without any tears or holes or pe changes in the fovea posterior segment exam shows drusen in the macula thickening of the retina presence of subretinal fluid and exudates results of your diagnostic tests so for the oct so it shows drusen deposit and the retinal pigment epithelium subretinal fluid accumulation choroidal neovascular membrane can be visualized fluorescein angiography reveals focal areas of leakage in the right eye consistent with neurovascular age related macular degeneration so the diagnostic tests and the eye exam are really indicative of neovascular age related macular degeneration so this is advanced to a stage that usually leads to more severe vision loss and it really happens when those abnormal blood vessels start to grow beneath the retina and they will leak fluid and blood and hints the name wet amd and can create a large blind spot in the center of the visual field and this is really with the most common cause for severe loss of SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Sudden visual distortion and blurring of vision
* History of present illness: Decreased vision when reading, straight lines (e.g., door frames) appear crooked, difficulty adjusting to dim lights (especially when dining out), symptoms present in right eye
* Social history: Currently smokes one pack of cigarettes per day, has attempted but not succeeded in quitting
* Past medical history: No information provided
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Physical exam: Anterior segment examination - posterior chamber intraocular lenses in both eyes; right eye cornea clear, cup-to-disc ratio 0.2, retina attached 360°, no tears or holes, pigment epithelium changes in fovea, posterior segment shows drusen in the macula, retinal thickening, subretinal fluid, exudates, and hemorrhage; left eye cornea clear, cup-to-disc ratio 0.3, pigment epithelium changes in fovea, retina attached, no hemorrhage or subretinal fluid
* Test results: OCT - drusen deposits, retinal pigment epithelium changes, subretinal fluid accumulation, visualization of choroidal neovascular membrane; fluorescein angiography - focal areas of leakage in right eye consistent with neovascular age-related macular degeneration
* Vital signs: No information provided

A (Assessment):

* Neovascular (wet) age-related macular degeneration of the right eye

P (Plan):

* Intravitreal injection of Lucentis once a month after local anesthesia to the eye
* Continue monthly injections as indicated
* Advise patient to monitor and record blood pressure regularly
* No information provided regarding follow-up schedule or additional referrals

* Family history: No information provided

* Test results: Right ankle x-ray shows no acute fracture or bony abnormality, soft tissue injury present

A (Assessment):

* Acute right ankle sprain

* Apply air cast to right ankle
* Prescribe meloxicam 15 mg orally once daily
* Provide crutches
* Advise icing the area for 20 minutes, five times daily

* No information provided regarding patient education or additional referrals

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Status post heart attack (myocardial infarction), follow-up after right coronary artery stent
- History of present illness: No chest pain since stent placement, mild soreness at wrist after procedure but improving, shortness of breath when ascending/descending stairs, feels better than before hospitalization but reports ongoing struggle and fear, watching diet with some indulgent meals on weekends, mainly sedentary but adhering to medications
- Past medical history: Recent inferior myocardial infarction, coronary artery stent placement
- Social history: Right-handed, enjoys swimming (wishes to resume), adherent to prescribed medications, reports being able to afford Brilinta
- Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: Blood pressure 127/60 mmHg (in office)
- Physical exam: Neck—no jugular venous distention, no carotid bruits; Heart—systolic ejection murmur (grade 3/6) at left base; Lungs—clear to auscultation bilaterally; Musculoskeletal—right radial artery cardiac cath site clean, dry, intact, no hematoma, palpable radial pulse
- Test results: Echocardiogram—ejection fraction approximately 50% (low normal), mild mitral regurgitation

A (Assessment):

- Inferior myocardial infarction, status post right coronary artery stent
- Mild mitral regurgitation (noted on echocardiogram)

P (Plan):

- Continue aspirin once daily for life
- Continue Brilinta (ticagrelor) twice daily for at least one year
- Continue Crestor (rosuvastatin) 40 mg once daily
- Continue Toprol (metoprolol) 50 mg once daily
- Order repeat echocardiogram in 6 months
- Order liver function tests and lipid panel before next visit
- Refer to cardiac rehabilitation for exercise and dietary counseling
- Permit gradual return to swimming with caution
- Advise to monitor and limit salt intake, maintain healthy diet
- Outpatient follow-up in 6 weeks

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Right knee pain following a fall from a tandem bike two weeks ago
- History of present illness: Patient reports persistent daily right knee pain since the injury, describes it as sore with occasional clicking on full extension and pain with medial palpation and when walking up inclines; states she took ibuprofen for symptom relief and cleaned/covered the abrasion after the fall; denies previous knee problems; sometimes experiences a sense of instability/shifting during walking; has not resumed swimming since the injury
- Past medical history: No information provided
- Social history: Works at a children's hospital in a NICU, does not bike regularly (just for the incident), typically walks her dog for exercise and swims occasionally, no current participation in team sports
- Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: No information provided
- Physical exam: Right knee with dime-sized dry abrasion over medial patella (appears 1 week old), medial joint line tenderness present, nontender pes bursa, epicondyle, and popliteal space; lateral knee nontender; full extension and flexion noted bilaterally, symmetric range of motion, no deformities, patella tracks normally without crepitus, valgus/lateral collateral ligaments intact, mild (1+) posterior drawer on right knee, anterior drawer and Lachman negative, McMurray negative bilaterally, no gross instability observed
- Test results: X-rays of right knee show no fracture, no bone spurs, preserved cartilage, and normal joint space; kneecap tracking normal; no abnormalities detected

A (Assessment):

- Posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) injury, suspected
- Possible meniscal injury or cartilage injury, cannot rule out without further imaging

P (Plan):

- Order MRI scan of right knee to further assess ligament, meniscus, and cartilage status
- Fit patient with temporary knee brace
- Refer to physical therapy for strength and motion rehabilitation
- Continue ibuprofen up to three times daily as needed for pain; prescribe alternative anti-inflammatory medication to be taken twice daily if preferred
- Recommend use of ice packs several times a day
- Recheck knee in clinic in 4 to 6 weeks
- Consider surgical consultation if instability or symptoms persist after rehabilitation and bracing
- No information provided regarding patient education or additional follow-up outside the above plan

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Left arm and chest pain
* History of present illness: Achy, heavy pain from left elbow up and down the arm, to the neck; chest pain that comes and goes, associated with arm pain; symptoms began yesterday; chest pain sometimes radiates up the neck; symptoms recur a few times a day; no shortness of breath
* Past medical history: Hypertension, diabetes
* Medications: Norvasc 2.5 mg, Metformin 500 mg, Motrin (taken for pain, minimal relief)
* Social history: Right-handed; recently mowed grass, no unusual physical activity or heavy lifting
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Blood pressure 150/90 mmHg (in clinic), patient reports home average 125/72 mmHg
* Physical exam: New heart murmur auscultated
* Test results: Last HbA1c 7.2%
* Other tests: No information provided (pending EKG, glucose test)

A (Assessment):

* Chest pain, possible acute coronary syndrome (physician concerned for mild heart attack)
* New heart murmur
* Hypertension
* Diabetes mellitus

P (Plan):

* Perform EKG
* Administer aspirin and nitroglycerin
* Check point-of-care glucose
* Continue Norvasc 2.5 mg for hypertension
* Continue Metformin 500 mg for diabetes
* If EKG indicates acute coronary syndrome, call 911 and transfer to hospital
* Instruct patient to monitor blood pressure at home and keep a log
* Plan to adjust diabetes medication pending glucose result
* Outpatient follow-up as appropriate after immediate concerns addressed

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Abdominal pain
* History of present illness: Abdominal pain started 10 days ago with mild right-sided discomfort, worsening over the last few days (pain intensity 4-5/10, up to 7-8/10 at maximum), worse after meals, sometimes radiates slightly to the left, associated with tenderness on palpation, nausea, and mild heartburn, no vomiting, no urinary symptoms, no bowel changes, decreased appetite due to nausea, fatigue over the last week, chills but no documented fever, no unusual food intake, and no recent travel outside the country.
* Past medical history: Chronic migraines, hypertension
* Medications: Excedrin Migraine as needed, sumatriptan as needed for breakthrough migraines, lisinopril 20 mg daily
* Family history: No information provided
* Social history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided (physician notes no fever today)
* Physical exam: Grade 3/6 systolic ejection murmur unchanged from prior, otherwise normal cardiac exam; mild to moderate right upper quadrant abdominal tenderness, equivocal Murphy's sign, rest of abdomen soft and non-tender, no right lower quadrant tenderness, no costovertebral angle tenderness, remainder of exam unremarkable
* Test results: No information provided (blood tests and ultrasound pending)

A (Assessment):

* Acute abdominal pain with right upper quadrant tenderness—concern for possible gallstones or gallbladder infection
* Chronic migraine headaches
* Hypertension (adequately controlled)

P (Plan):

* Order CBC, Chem 12, urinalysis, pregnancy test, and right upper quadrant ultrasound
* Keep patient NPO (nothing by mouth) pending results
* Consider emergency department transfer if indicated by test results
* Continue Excedrin Migraine as needed for migraines
* Refill sumatriptan prescription for migraines; use as needed for breakthrough pain
* Counsel to avoid alcohol and caffeine binges and maintain good sleep hygiene
* Continue lisinopril 20 mg daily for hypertension; provide prescription refill
* Advise patient to monitor blood pressure daily
* Outpatient follow-up in approximately 4 weeks
* Immediate review of test results and follow-up with patient today

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Hacking cough for about three days
- History of present illness: Gradual onset cough starting three days ago after exposure to sick sister with similar symptoms, currently productive of green phlegm, associated with sore throat and nasal congestion, denies fever, shortness of breath, body aches, nausea, or vomiting; over-the-counter cough medication and increased water intake have not helped
- Past medical history: Type 2 diabetes, hypertension, seasonal allergies with sneezing and runny nose in spring
- Medications: Metformin 500 mg (recently started, tolerated well), hydrochlorothiazide (taken daily)
- Social history: Recently returned from vacation, no indication of sick contacts during travel except sister
- Family history: Sister recently ill with similar symptoms; otherwise, family doing well

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: Blood pressure 144/72 mmHg; other vitals within normal limits
- Physical exam: No frontal sinus tenderness, mild bilateral maxillary sinus tenderness, pharyngeal erythema without exudate, symmetrical tonsils, anterior cervical adenopathy, regular heart rate and rhythm, 2/6 systolic ejection murmur at left base, lungs clear to auscultation (no wheezes, rales, or rhonchi), no lower extremity edema
- Test results: No information provided

A (Assessment):

- Upper respiratory infection (most likely viral)
- Type 2 diabetes mellitus
- Hypertension

P (Plan):

- Recommend supportive care: increased fluid intake, rest, try alternative cough medication compatible with hypertension and diabetes (e.g., Coricidin HBP)
- COVID-19 test to be performed
- Continue metformin 500 mg daily or twice daily; next hemoglobin A1c to be checked at next visit (every 3 months)
- Increase hydrochlorothiazide to 25 mg once daily, recommend taking in the morning due to diuretic effect
- Continue home blood pressure monitoring several times per week at different times of day
- Follow-up on test results and at next scheduled visit
- No information provided regarding referrals or additional tests beyond the above

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Left shoulder pain for a few weeks
* History of present illness: Left shoulder pain started a few weeks ago without any remembered trauma or specific injury, pain is constant and worsens with movement such as reaching or lifting, unable to raise arm overhead due to pain, pain is increased with pressure (e.g., lying on left side), cannot sleep on left side due to discomfort, pain present even when lying on back but worsened with pressure, no prior significant issues with left shoulder, Tylenol extra strength taken every 6-8 hours provides relief (pain decreases from 7/10 to 2-3/10)
* Aggravating factors: Movement, lifting objects, reaching, lying on left side
* Relieving factors: Tylenol
* Associated symptoms: No numbness or tingling in left arm or hand
* Social history: Active lifestyle, currently engaged in home renovations, has been living in current house for some time, more time at home since pandemic
* Past medical history: No information provided
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Reviewed and within normal limits
* Physical exam: Limited active and passive range of motion of left shoulder, tenderness over greater tuberosity of left humerus, no tenderness at sternoclavicular or clavicular joints, good hand grip bilaterally, neurovascular exam of left arm normal (brisk capillary refill <3 seconds, intact motor and sensation to light touch)
* Test results: Left shoulder x-ray shows no fracture or bony abnormality

A (Assessment):

* Left shoulder pain
* Rotator cuff tendinopathy, likely

P (Plan):

* Order MRI of left shoulder
* Refer to physical therapy for 6-8 weeks
* Continue Tylenol as needed
* Consider steroid injection to left shoulder if symptoms do not improve
* Outpatient follow-up in 2 weeks

* Chief complaint: Right knee pain
* History of present illness: Right knee pain began after playing basketball yesterday; patient felt and heard a pop when landing from a rebound, followed by swelling and difficulty walking; pain described as “real achy,” currently 4/10 in intensity; swelling has decreased since onset; pain located on medial (inside) aspect of knee; able to bear weight but favoring right leg; Tylenol taken with minimal relief, rest helps more.
* Past medical history: Hypertension, diabetes, grade II systolic ejection murmur (chronic, known for years)
* Medications: Norvasc 5 mg daily for hypertension (patient is compliant), Metformin 500 mg daily for diabetes (irregular use due to stomach upset), occasional Tylenol for knee pain
* Social history: No information provided
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided
* Physical exam: Lungs clear, cardiac exam with grade II systolic ejection murmur (known condition, unchanged), right knee with pain on palpation of medial aspect, edema, slight swelling, ecchymosis, mild redness, negative varus and valgus stress tests, pain with movement of knee
* Test results: Right knee x-ray normal (no fracture, no bony abnormalities), most recent A1c 7.2%, home blood pressure readings typically 140–150/80 mmHg, spot blood glucose readings around 150 mg/dL

A (Assessment):

* Right medial collateral ligament (MCL) strain; rule out MCL tear (awaiting MRI for confirmation)
* Hypertension, uncontrolled
* Type 2 diabetes mellitus, suboptimally controlled
* Grade II systolic ejection murmur, stable

P (Plan):

* Prescribe meloxicam 15 mg for pain and swelling
* Continue Tylenol as needed
* Apply knee immobilizer, advise non-weight bearing as much as possible for 2 weeks
* Order MRI of right knee
* Increase Norvasc dose to address high blood pressure
* Nutrition consult for diabetes management and dietary counseling
* Advise patient to check blood glucose daily and keep a log
* Schedule follow-up appointment in 2 weeks
* Instruct patient to avoid excessive intake of strawberries due to sugar content
* No other concerns expressed; nurse to assist with appointment coordination

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Elevated and fluctuating blood pressures
- History of present illness: Over the last 3-4 weeks, has experienced periods of lightheadedness, slight headache, and occasional systolic blood pressure over 180 mmHg; lightheadedness is described as feeling “fuzzy”, with mild unsteadiness; headaches occur when blood pressure is higher; has not had recent syncope; sometimes experiences slight chest heaviness but no sustained episodes, no chest pain, or respiratory difficulty; denies fever, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, palpitations, or heart racing
- Past medical history: Essential hypertension, hyperlipidemia, osteoarthritis
- Medication history: Taking lisinopril 20 mg twice daily (with rare missed doses), atorvastatin, and uses Tylenol for osteoarthritis as needed
- Social history: Remains active, golfs and walks as tolerated; asks about fluid intake and beer consumption in context of blood pressure and activity
- Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: No information provided
- Physical exam: Grade 3/6 systolic ejection murmur unchanged from prior, mild bibasilar rales on lung exam, no wheezes or rhonchi, excellent air movement, trace bilateral lower extremity edema, otherwise normal exam
- Test results: No information provided

A (Assessment):

- Hypertension, uncontrolled
- Hyperlipidemia
- Osteoarthritis

P (Plan):

- Increase lisinopril to 60 mg twice daily
- Add hydrochlorothiazide 25 mg once daily
- Monitor blood pressure twice daily for 2 weeks
- Continue atorvastatin for hyperlipidemia
- Order cholesterol panel, CBC with differential, comprehensive metabolic panel, and urinalysis
- Continue Tylenol as needed for osteoarthritis pain and remain physically active as tolerated
- Advise adequate hydration (6–8 glasses of water per day, adjust with increased activity or warm weather)
- Limit alcohol intake to no more than a couple of drinks per week
- Follow-up appointment in 2 weeks

SOAP:

Self-reported blood pressure over the past three weeks has been higher than usual, with readings of 160/87 mmHg and 175/92 mmHg; previous normal reading was 124/82 mmHg. No previous headache episodes like this; has had rare migraines (once a year or less). Denies runny nose, cough, or congestion. Occasional mild tenderness reported when pressing forehead, cheekbones, and neck.

- Family history: No information provided

- Physical exam: Mild tenderness upon palpation of forehead, cheekbones, and neck; no reported frontal or maxillary sinus tenderness; no lymphadenopathy observed; no symptoms of congestion, runny nose, or cough
- Test results: No information provided

A (Assessment):

- Headache
- Hypertension, uncontrolled
- Diabetes

P (Plan):

- Increase lisinopril to 40 mg once daily
- Continue Tylenol as needed for headache
- Continue regular walking/exercise
- Check blood pressure regularly
- Order laboratory tests including hemoglobin A1c and other routine labs
- Provide diabetic education materials
- Schedule follow-up visit with physician (Dr. Ruth or current provider) after labs are completed

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Left-sided back pain
- History of present illness: Back pain for an unspecified duration, mostly on the left side, with variable character (sometimes sharp, sometimes not; sometimes migratory), increased water intake, waking up at night to urinate more than usual
- Past medical history: Recurrent strep throat (approximately 4 episodes in the last 5 months), history of being told he has "BFS" and strep on multiple occasions
- Social history: Rides a bike occasionally, student (good grades), presence of a smoker (brother) at home, recently started new job at a restaurant (no insurance), prior job with unsatisfactory supervisor
- Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Physical exam: Throat without erythema or swelling, tonsils midline; no cervical lymphadenopathy; lungs clear to auscultation (no wheezes, rales, or rhonchi); heart with normal sounds (no murmur, rub, or gallop); no back tenderness on palpation; abdomen soft, non-tender, no rebound or guarding
- Test results: CT scan noted to show findings concerning for possible glomerulonephritis and swelling; pending laboratory orders including lipid panel, urinalysis (UA), comprehensive metabolic panel (CMP), complete blood count (CBC), vitamin D, and thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH)

A (Assessment):

- Glomerulonephritis, possible
- Chronic/recurrent strep throat
- Rule out chronic kidney disease

P (Plan):

- Refer to ENT for assessment regarding possible tonsillectomy due to recurrent strep throat
- Order laboratory tests: lipid panel, UA, CMP, CBC, vitamin D, TSH (majority to be performed as soon as possible, some requiring fasting)
- Return visit in 1 week, with telephone follow-up if laboratory results are normal, otherwise return for in-person discussion
- Patient education provided regarding salt intake and need for infection control
- No injections required today
- Offer to provide a note for school/work as needed

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Cough
* History of present illness: Cough started approximately one week ago, now productive of yellow sputum, worsening symptoms over the past two days, feels warm but has not measured temperature, denies fevers and chills, reports occasional aches, no shortness of breath, reports congestion, post-nasal drainage, and sinus pressure; fell down 4–5 stairs this morning while coughing and injured right knee, now has pain mainly on the inside of the knee, can walk with a slight limp, no sensation of instability, able to bend and straighten knee; denies taking medication for knee pain, uses over-the-counter cold medications (e.g., DayQuil) with mild benefit for cough.
* Past medical history: Hypertension (diagnosed approximately one year ago), diabetes mellitus
* Medications: Lisinopril (20 mg daily), Metformin (1,000 mg twice daily), over-the-counter cold medications (e.g., DayQuil)
* Social history: Works as a teacher, no mention of tobacco or alcohol use
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Temperature 98.4°F, blood pressure 125/62 mmHg, heart rate in the 80s, oxygen saturation 97% on room air
* Physical exam: Pain to palpation of bilateral maxillary sinuses, erythema and edema of nasal turbinates bilaterally with yellow discharge, uvula midline without erythema, edema, or peritonsillar exudate; bilateral cervical lymphadenopathy; lungs with coarse rhonchi bilaterally that clear with cough; heart with regular rate and rhythm and no murmurs; right knee with pain to palpation and decreased flexion/extension, ecchymosis over the right medial knee, no evidence of effusion
* Test results: No information provided

A (Assessment):

* Viral syndrome with mild bronchitis
* Right medial collateral ligament strain of the knee
* Hypertension
* Diabetes mellitus

P (Plan):

* For cough/viral syndrome: Continue supportive care and over-the-counter medications, prescribe guaifenesin 600 mg twice daily, no antibiotics at this time, advise to call if symptoms worsen, consider chest x-ray if indicated
* For right knee injury: Prescribe meloxicam 15 mg once daily, refer to physical therapy, order x-ray of right knee
* For hypertension: Continue lisinopril 20 mg daily, order lipid panel
* For diabetes: Order hemoglobin A1c, advise to monitor sugar intake and blood sugars, report blood sugar readings via patient portal
* Follow-up: Physician will contact patient with test results

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Headaches and elevated blood pressure
- History of present illness: Intermittent, throbbing headaches at the top of the head for about one month; headaches are relieved by Tylenol. Associated symptoms include occasional dizziness and blurry vision.
- Past medical history: Hypertension (long-standing), diabetes
- Medications: Chlorthalidone (taken every other day, not as prescribed, due to stomachache), Tylenol for headaches (provides relief), metformin (taken every other day)
- Social history: Frequent fast food intake, particularly McDonald's (Filet-O-Fish); not following a low sodium diet; ate children's Easter candy recently
- Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: Blood pressure 172/98 mmHg, heart rate within normal limits, oxygenation normal
- Physical exam: No jugular venous distention, no carotid bruits, lungs clear bilaterally, 2/6 systolic ejection murmur (stable from prior year) on heart exam, slight edema bilaterally in upper extremities, 1+ pitting edema bilaterally in lower extremities
- Test results: Fasting blood sugar 170 mg/dL

A (Assessment):

- Uncontrolled hypertension
- Diabetes mellitus, suboptimally controlled

P (Plan):

- Continue current antihypertensive regimen (chlorthalidone); emphasize daily adherence, suggest setting reminders
- Recommend home blood pressure monitoring three times per week; provide recommendations for suitable devices
- Nutritionist referral for dietary counseling, particularly sodium restriction (start a low sodium diet/DASH diet)
- Increase metformin dosage to 1500 mg daily
- Advise continued regular self-monitoring of blood glucose
- Outpatient follow-up in 1 month to reassess blood pressure and blood glucose control
- No additional questions from patient

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Chronic back pain
- History of present illness: Back pain ongoing for a couple of years following a fall on the back while playing basketball; pain is sharp (NRS 7/10), sometimes throbbing, intermittently radiates down the left leg with episodic numbness in the toes, worsens with standing, improved by lying on side; weakness when standing up or for prolonged standing reported; single episode of bowel incontinence after prolonged standing and drinking, no consistent bladder or bowel control loss; prior treatments include unspecified injections, physical therapy (minimally effective), and an unspecified white pill (patient reports these worked); reports significant reduction in physical activity, mostly sedentary at home, with an 80-pound weight gain in the past year
- Past medical history: No information provided
- Family history: Fourth cousin with scoliosis, no known spine conditions in immediate family
- Social history: Smoked previously (details not provided), not currently smoking, no alcohol history provided, no information on other substances

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: Stated as “might be in the ninety five percentile range” (specific values not provided)
- Physical exam: Heart with regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs; no overlying erythema or ecchymosis on back; midline tenderness at L4-L5, right-sided lumbar paravertebral tenderness; pain with lumbar flexion and extension; supine straight leg test positive; decreased sensation to light touch at right lateral thigh at L4 dermatome; symmetric patella and Achilles reflexes
- Test results: MRI shows disk desiccation, disk bulge with paracentral disk herniation, resulting in moderate right foraminal stenosis

A (Assessment):

- Chronic lumbar back pain due to herniated disk at L4-L5 with radiculopathy

P (Plan):

- Schedule spinal injection with corticosteroid under fluoroscopic guidance
- Prescribe anxiolytic medication to be taken prior to injection
- Assess pain after injection; consider pain medication if pain persists
- Consider surgical options if other interventions fail
- Instruct patient to schedule spinal injection at the front desk
- No information provided regarding follow-up or additional testing

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Vision changes, trouble with right eye
* History of present illness: Difficulty adjusting vision in dark or dim environments, decreased vision when reading especially in dark places, straight lines (e.g., door frames, paneling) appear wavy, symptoms worsening over the past 3–4 months, central visual field black spot reported
* Social history: Eats out nightly, history of smoking approximately 1 pack per day, multiple unsuccessful quit attempts (hypnosis, lozenges, chewing gum)
* Past medical history: High blood pressure
* Medication adherence: Not taking prescribed blood pressure medication regularly, acknowledges forgetting to take it
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Physical exam: Posterior chamber intraocular lenses in both eyes, right eye cornea clear (no NVI), cup-to-disc ratio 0.2, fundus exam shows attached retina 360°, RPE changes in the fovea, drusen in the macula, retinal thickening, subretinal fluid and exudate accumulation, positive for hemorrhage; left eye cornea clear (no NVI), cup-to-disc ratio 0.3, RPE changes in the fovea, no hemorrhage, no subretinal fluid, retina attached appropriately
* Test results: OCT—drusen deposits under RPE, subretinal fluid, choroidal neovascular membrane visualized; fluorescein angiography—focal area of leakage in right eye consistent with neovascular age-related macular degeneration
* Vital signs: No information provided

A (Assessment):

* Neovascular age-related macular degeneration (“wet” macular degeneration), advanced stage in right eye

P (Plan):

* Administer intravitreal injection of Lucentis (anti-VEGF agent) to the right eye today after numbing the eye
* Schedule monthly intravitreal Lucentis injections
* Patient education provided regarding disease, symptoms, and treatment expectations
* Strongly advised to resume and adhere to antihypertensive medication; suggested strategy of keeping pill bottle visible as reminder
* Counselor support and encouragement to reduce or quit smoking
* No information provided regarding follow-up appointment date or additional testing

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Right knee pain and swelling after skiing accident
- History of present illness: Felt a pop and experienced immediate pain in the right knee after a skiing fall while attempting a cartwheel maneuver; event occurred on Saturday (over the weekend); knee has been swollen and painful since injury; reports mild pain with flexion and extension; able to walk a little, but it's painful
- Home treatments: Taking Advil, applying ice periodically, occasional use of heat
- Past medical history: No prior knee injuries
- Social history: Skiing trip in Mt. St. Helens, Washington; active in outdoor sports
- Additional symptoms: Mild bruised sensation in right shoulder, possibly from landing on it during fall; mild tenderness when raising right shoulder
- Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: Temperature 97.9°F, heart rate 64 bpm, respiratory rate 16/min, blood pressure 110/74 mmHg, oxygen saturation 98%
- Physical exam: Edema and ecchymosis around the right knee, pain to palpation over right knee, mild pain with flexion and extension of right knee, full range of motion but slight tightness and discomfort, mild bruising over right shoulder, tenderness with elevation of right shoulder, full range of shoulder motion observed
- Test results: Right knee x-ray negative for fracture or bony abnormalities; no information provided yet regarding right shoulder x-ray

A (Assessment):

- Knee contusion
- Right shoulder injury, possible contusion (pending x-ray)

P (Plan):

- Rest affected knee
- Apply ice to right knee 2–3 times daily for 20 minutes each time
- Take NSAIDs (e.g., ibuprofen) every 6–8 hours as needed for pain
- Obtain right shoulder x-ray
- Consider physical therapy if right knee does not improve
- Return for follow-up if symptoms worsen or do not improve

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Shortness of breath with exertion
* History of present illness: Increased shortness of breath over the weekend, unable to walk as far as usual with dog due to symptoms, dry cough without phlegm, no fever, painful swallowing (odynophagia) especially in chest when swallowing, able to tolerate liquids and Ensure but reduced intake over the weekend due to pain; recent diagnosis of stage III non-small cell lung cancer, currently undergoing neoadjuvant chemotherapy and radiation
* Past medical history: No information provided
* Social history: Previously active, walked mile-long distances with dog before illness, lives with and receives support from husband and daughter
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Normal (including pulse oximetry, per physician)
* Physical exam: No cervical or subclavicular lymphadenopathy, heart exam shows regular rate and rhythm without murmur, bilateral crackles on lung auscultation, erythema present on anterior left chest (consistent with radiation dermatitis), no lower extremity edema
* Test results: Chest x-ray shows mild radiation pneumonitis

A (Assessment):

* Stage III non-small cell lung cancer
* Radiation pneumonitis
* Odynophagia secondary to radiation

P (Plan):

* Continue current chemotherapy regimen (cisplatin and etoposide) and radiation treatment (45 Gy total)
* Prescribe prednisone 40 mg orally once daily for 5 days for radiation pneumonitis
* Prescribe lidocaine swish and swallow, four times daily, for odynophagia
* Emphasize maintaining adequate hydration and oral intake
* Schedule follow-up visit in two weeks after completion of current treatment regimen
* Plan for additional testing and surgical evaluation for possible tumor resection after completion of chemo-radiation therapy

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Right flank pain radiating to groin for the last two weeks
- History of present illness: Intermittent right flank pain radiating to groin, occasional increase in intensity (NRS 1–2/10 most of the time, up to 4/10 during bouts), pain also radiated once to right testicle, no pain with urination, no visible blood in urine, prior episode of chills but no fever, no nausea or vomiting, pain relieved partially by ibuprofen
- Past medical history: Prior history of kidney stones (passed spontaneously and required surgery previously)
- Family history: Family history of kidney stones in multiple relatives
- Social history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: Blood pressure mildly elevated
- Physical exam: Abdomen non-tender to palpation, right-sided costovertebral angle (CVA) tenderness present
- Test results: CT scan shows 0.5 cm stone in proximal right ureter, no evidence of hydronephrosis
- Other interventions: Patient using urine strainer, no stone passed yet

A (Assessment):

- Right proximal ureteral stone, 0.5 cm
- No evidence of hydronephrosis
- No evidence of urinary tract infection at this time

P (Plan):

- Continue pushing oral fluids to facilitate stone passage
- Continue ibuprofen for pain control as needed
- Prescribe tramadol 50 mg for breakthrough pain
- Continue use of urine strainer with each urination to monitor for passage of stone
- Order basic metabolic panel (BMP), urinalysis, and urine culture
- Monitor for signs/symptoms of infection; initiate antibiotics if indicated based on test results
- Outpatient follow-up in 1–2 weeks to reassess symptoms and stone passage; consider lithotripsy if stone remains or symptoms persist
- Nursing staff to provide tramadol prescription

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Shortness of breath
- History of present illness: Shortness of breath for about one week, mostly with exertion (walking, stairs, walking quickly); increased from baseline, similar to episode six months ago that improved after Lasix dose adjustment; also reports bilateral leg swelling, increased use of two pillows at night (previously one), nocturia (urinating at night once or twice now, more than before); denies waking up at night due to shortness of breath during this episode (had occurred six months ago); episode of foot pain (localized in front of the big toe, one foot, lasted 4–5 days, resolved), used Motrin for pain.
- Past medical history: Coronary artery disease with prior myocardial infarction (2018, stent placement in right coronary artery), low ejection fraction (previously ~35%), stage 3 chronic kidney disease
- Medication history: Takes Lasix 40 mg daily (recently increased dose in the past), has taken Motrin for foot pain (recently, discontinued), uses Tylenol but finds it ineffective for pain
- Social history: Admits dietary indiscretion (increased salt intake) during recent holiday gatherings
- Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: Blood pressure 135/80 mmHg
- Physical exam: Jugular venous distention to 9 cm, no carotid bruits, bibasilar crackles with occasional rhonchi (which clears with cough), 3/6 systolic ejection murmur at left base, 1–2+ pitting edema in both lower extremities
- Test results: No information provided

A (Assessment):

- Acute heart failure exacerbation
- Coronary artery disease (history of MI with stent placement)
- Stage 3 chronic kidney disease
- Possible gout flare (recent monoarticular foot pain, possible differential)

P (Plan):

- Increase Lasix from 40 mg to 80 mg daily (start with full dose in the morning; may split to add second dose at 4 p.m. if needed)
- Call physician in 2 days to report weight and diuretic response
- Instruct to call physician if worsening shortness of breath (may need hospitalization for intravenous diuretics)
- Order chest X-ray
- Order echocardiogram to evaluate heart murmur and cardiac function
- Notify cardiologist (Dr. White) for follow-up
- Order complete metabolic panel
- Strictly avoid Motrin, Advil, and other NSAIDs; use Tylenol for pain
- Order uric acid test for possible gout flare
- Dietitian referral for dietary counseling (focus on low sodium and low potassium diet)
- Provide dietary education regarding foods high in potassium (bananas, oranges, potatoes, etc.)
- Patient education on importance of medication and dietary adherence
- No information provided regarding follow-up appointment date

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Minimal cough and sore throat
- History of present illness: Persistent, intermittent sore throat; dry, lingering cough; slight fatigue; no shortness of breath; no nausea or vomiting; able to eat but with reduced appetite; denies dysphagia or sensation of food getting stuck
- Social history: Supported by nursing staff, office staff, and family members who attend treatments
- Emotional/mental status: Feels mentally strong, reports adequate support

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: Oxygen saturation good (no values provided)
- Physical exam: No cervical or supraclavicular lymphadenopathy, cardiac exam normal (regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs), lung exam with bilateral crackles, erythema noted on anterior left chest (possibly radiation-related), no lower extremity edema
- Test results: Chest x-ray shows mild radiation pneumonitis
- Medications: Undergoing chemotherapy with cisplatin and etoposide, receiving radiation therapy at 45 Gy

A (Assessment):

- Stage III non-small cell lung cancer (left upper lobe adenocarcinoma)
- Mild radiation pneumonitis
- Esophagitis (painful swallowing), likely secondary to radiation and/or chemotherapy

P (Plan):

- Continue current chemotherapy regimen (cisplatin and etoposide)
- Continue radiation therapy at 45 Gy, repeat imaging after completion to assess resectability
- Prescribe prednisone 40 mg daily for 5 days for radiation pneumonitis
- Prescribe lidocaine swish and swallow four times daily for esophagitis to facilitate oral intake and prevent dehydration/weight loss
- Outpatient follow-up at next scheduled visit
- No new supportive care or psychosocial interventions indicated at this time

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: New worrisome heart murmur
- History of present illness: Noted heart murmur recently; no known prior symptoms related to murmur; no chest pain; becomes short of breath if overexerting (walking too far/fast or drinking water quickly); ambulates with walker; severe bilateral leg pain for about 1 month and taking pain pills for this; ankle swelling for about 6 months, variable in severity; no palpitations noticed; no fainting; lost 10 pounds over the past year (normally 130 lbs, now 120 lbs), gradual decline; no fevers or chills; feels overly tired, possibly due to medications; takes pill for dizziness (meclizine) as needed
- Past medical history: Hypothyroidism; hypertension; hyperlipidemia; multiple prior surgeries (not listed)
- Medications: Amlodipine, lisinopril, simvastatin 20 mg, levothyroxine, meclizine (as needed for dizziness), pain pills for leg pain
- Social history: Never smoked
- Allergies: No known drug allergies
- Family history: Son with heart attack; brother had stroke (due to diabetes); older sister with heart problems

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: Blood pressure normal today
- Physical exam: Elderly female, no acute distress; normal gait for age; cardiovascular exam - S1 and S2 preserved, normal rate and regular rhythm, 4/6 systolic murmur at right upper sternal border with mild radiation to carotids; no significant volume overload observed
- Test results: EKG today shows sinus rhythm with frequent PVCs and anterior septum infarct pattern; prior outside records note diastolic dysfunction; most recent chest x-ray (from last week) — No information provided (results not stated)

A (Assessment):

- Cardiac murmur, likely aortic stenosis (most likely representative of aortic stenosis; could be moderate given preserved S2, but symptoms could suggest severe aortic stenosis)
- Premature ventricular contractions (PVCs) (noted on EKG today)
- Hyperlipidemia (managed by PCP)
- Lightheadedness, dizziness (on meclizine; possibly related to aortic stenosis and/or PVCs)
- Bilateral leg pain
- Diastolic dysfunction, possible (noted in outside records)
- Anterior septum infarct pattern on EKG

P (Plan):

- Order echocardiogram today to assess cardiac structure, function, and valvular disease severity
- Consider TAVR (transcatheter aortic valve replacement) evaluation depending on echocardiogram findings (if severe aortic stenosis indicated)
- Consider ischemic evaluation or ambulatory heart monitor for PVC burden if indicated by echo/results
- Continue current medications (amlodipine, lisinopril, levothyroxine); defer decision on statin discontinuation to PCP, communicate recommendations and echo results to PCP for review
- Pain management for bilateral leg pain as previously prescribed
- Outpatient follow-up in 3 to 4 weeks after echocardiogram to discuss results and next steps
- Patient education provided regarding potential procedures and next diagnostic steps
- No changes to current medication regimen unless indicated by forthcoming test results

transcription: [doctor] kayla ward , date of birth 4/28/2007 , mrn 384920 . she is here for a new visit with her mother for acne located on the face which started about 2 years ago and is present most every day . she has been using perc gel and washing regularly which is somewhat helpful . there are no associated symptoms including itching , bleeding , or pain . no additional past medical history . she lives with her parents and sister . they have a dog , bird and bonnies . she is in seventh grade . she plays basketball , volleyball and tap . she wears sunscreen in the summer . spf 30 . no additional family history . hi kayla , i'm dr. juan price . i hear you are starting to get some acne on the face . how about the chest and back ? [patient] it's not too bad . [doctor] so it's not bad on the chest or back . you've used some over the counter items like washes and person gel ? [patient] yeah . [doctor] do those seem to be helping ? [patient] yes , i think so a little bit . [doctor] good . what's your skin care routine like now ? [patient] do you wan na know like the things i currently use ? [doctor] yes . what do you do for your acne in the morning and then what do you do at nighttime ? i wash my face more like i wipe it down in the morning then at night i use an l facial cleanser called the superclarity cleanser . i finish with a toner and then the person gel . when you say wipe your face in the morning , do you use a product or just water ? [patient] hmmm just water and a wash cloth really , if i feel really greasy , sometimes i'll use the elf cleanser in the morning too . [doctor] okay and is today a good day , bad day or an average day for you ? [patient] hmmm i would say it's probably a good day for me of course since i'm here right ? [doctor] acne is always good when you come to see the doctor . do you find that your acne flares with your periods ? [patient] no , not really . [doctor] and do you get a regular period ? [patient] yep . [doctor] how long have you been getting a regular period ? [patient] hmmm i think about 2 years . [doctor] okay . the biggest flare probably was when she started school sports in the fall just with all the sweating . yeah , i'll do it . is there anything else that you've noticed , mrs. ward ? [patient] no , kayla really has been doing a good job with the facial care regimen . it just does n't seem to help as much as we wanted . [doctor] got it . okay . well , let's take a look then . full exam is performed today except for under the underwear and under the bra multiple benign navy on the trunk and extremities scattered skin colored papules open and closed comedones and erythematous papules on the face primarily on the forehead and with also some on the central cheeks and chin . the chest and back are relatively spared . and the remainder of the examination is normal . so what i'm seeing from your exam today is mild to moderate acne , mostly comedonal with small inflammatory component . [patient] okay , so is there anything we can do to help it ? [doctor] yes , i would like to start with a topical therapy first . every morning you will wash your face with a mild cleanser . then use a moisturizer label noncommittogenic with sunscreen , spf 30 or higher . this means it wo n't clog your pors . now in the evening , wash your face with the same cleanser and allow it to dry . apply adapalene 0.1 % cream in a thin layer to the areas you generally get acne . i want you to start off using this a few nights a week and slowly work up to using it every night . if it , it is , excuse me , if it is very expensive or not covered by insurance , you can try differin gel over the counter . you can follow that with clean and clear bursa gel and a thin layer where you generally get acne and then a noncommunogenic moisturizer . your topical retinoid wo n't cause sun sensitivity so you will need to wear sunscreen when you are outside . it may also cause some dryness or irritation . [patient] okay . i can do that . [doctor] you also have multiple benign moles on your arms , legs , back , and abdomen . this means they all look normal with no worrisome features . we will see if you have any progress over the next 6 months and follow up at that time . [patient] okay . that sounds good . thank you . [doctor] do you have any questions for me ? [patient] no , i do n't think so . [doctor] okay . if you have questions or concerns before your next visit , please call the office . [patient] thank you , doctor , we will .
SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Acne on the face, present most every day for about 2 years
* History of present illness: Acne partially responsive to over-the-counter products (Percog Gel, person gel, facial cleanser), worsened with initiation of school sports (increased sweating), no significant flares with menstrual periods, no associated itching, bleeding, or pain, current day reported as a "good day" for acne, chest and back acne "not too bad"
* Past medical history: No additional past medical history
* Social history: Lives with parents and sister, has a dog, bird, and bonnies, in seventh grade, plays basketball, volleyball, and tap, wears sunscreen (SPF 30) in the summer
* Family history: No additional family history

O (Objective):

* Physical exam: Multiple benign nevi on trunk and extremities, scattered skin-colored papules, open and closed comedones, and erythematous papules on the face (primarily forehead, some on central cheeks and chin), chest and back relatively spared, remainder of examination normal
* Test results: No information provided
* Vital signs: No information provided

A (Assessment):

* Mild to moderate acne, mostly comedonal with a small inflammatory component
* Multiple benign nevi

P (Plan):

* Initiate topical therapy:
   - Morning: Wash face with mild cleanser, apply noncomedogenic moisturizer with sunscreen (SPF 30 or higher)
   - Evening: Wash face with same cleanser, allow to dry, apply adapalene 0.1% cream in a thin layer to affected areas (start a few nights a week, increase to nightly as tolerated); if adapalene not available/covered, use Differin gel OTC; follow with clean and clear bursa gel if desired and noncomedogenic moisturizer
* Educate patient about possible dryness/irritation from topical retinoid, importance of sunscreen
* Monitor progress and follow up in 6 months
* Instruction to contact office with any questions or concerns prior to next visit

SOAP:

- Chief complaint: Constant pain in left shoulder and left elbow for about 5 months
- History of present illness: Pain began after a fall going up icy stairs, landing on left side; pain worse with lifting weights; unable to lift more than 15–20 pounds; recently stopped gym exercise due to pain; continues to walk 30 minutes almost daily; some relief with rest and ice but pain persists; no numbness or tingling reported
- Past medical history: No information provided
- Social history: Retired from office job last year, enjoys exercise, walks daily with wife
- Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Physical exam: Left shoulder and elbow tender at SA (subacromial) space, no warmth, erythema, or deformity, positive Kiss the Elbow and Neer's tests, normal proximal and distal upper extremity strength, intact median, radial, and ulnar sensation, abduction to 90 degrees, normal Empty Can test
- Vital signs: No information provided
- Test results: No information provided

A (Assessment):

- Impingement syndrome of left shoulder

P (Plan):

- Referral to physical therapy (Dr. Martha Rivera) for 2 sessions per week and home exercises as instructed by PT
- Continue icing the shoulder and rest as much as possible
- Consider cortisone injection if no improvement with therapy
- Instructed to contact office if symptoms worsen or do not improve with therapy
- No medication prescribed at this time

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Runny nose since suppertime last night
- History of present illness: Onset of symptoms last night, runny and stuffy nose with clear mucus, non-barky cough, ear pulling, rubbing nose, low-grade rectal fever (100.3°F), variable appetite (ate normally last night, 7 ounces from bottle this morning, less intake after, refused cereal), irritable and having difficulty falling asleep despite being energetic, whole body sweating with fever, cradle cap reportedly worsening
- Past medical history: No information provided
- Family history: No information provided
- Social history: Exposure—older sister currently sick, recent contact with nephew who was diagnosed with a sinus infection
- Medications (home): Saline mist for nose, Tylenol given early morning, baby Vicks applied to feet, humidifier used, cradle cap brush and Aveeno shampoo (not dandruff shampoo) for scalp

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: Rectal temperature 100.3°F (reported by parent)
- Physical exam: Ears appear normal, patient able to tolerate exam, no abnormal findings noted in conversation
- Test results: No information provided

A (Assessment):

- Suspected viral upper respiratory infection
- Cradle cap (seborrheic dermatitis of scalp)

P (Plan):

- Supportive care: Encourage fluids and rest, monitor for worsening symptoms
- Medications: Continue saline mist, Tylenol for fever as needed, Zarbee’s (pediatric dose appropriate for age) may be used for regular cough; if barky cough develops, give half a teaspoon of prescribed medicine (same as sister’s, at half dose) for 5 days—use only if barky cough occurs
- Cradle cap: Use regular strength dandruff shampoo (e.g., Head & Shoulders, Selsun Blue, Nizoral AD) twice per week, continue soft brushing and use baby oil as needed; avoid contact with eyes while rinsing
- Patient education: Do not give honey to children under one year; agave is acceptable if a sweetener is needed; monitor for symptom worsening
- Follow-up: Return in 1 week or sooner if symptoms worsen or new symptoms develop (e.g., barky cough, increased irritability, decreased oral intake, persistent fever)

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Request for breast reduction surgery
* History of present illness: Considering breast reduction for 6-7 years, symptoms include neck and upper back pain (persistent since high school), bra strap indentations, discomfort/pain with activities involving jumping/running, occasional numbness or tingling in hands or nipple, breasts always sweaty but no rashes
* Past medical history: No information provided
* Medication history: Takes propranolol for migraines
* Family history: Mother had breast cancer at age 40, recommendation to start mammograms at age 30
* Social history: No tobacco or drug use; occasional wine consumption; currently studying psychology; no children but may plan for children in the future; lost 10 lbs recently, would like to lose 20 more lbs

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided
* Physical exam: Asymmetrical breasts with severe ptosis bilaterally, no nipple retraction or discharge bilaterally, no breast tenderness, no palpable masses, no axillary lymphadenopathy
* Measurements: Minimum required resection based on BSA of 2.65 with the Schnur scale is 1792 g (attainable); one breast lower than the other
* Test results: No information provided

A (Assessment):

* Symptomatic macromastia
* Ideal candidate for bilateral reduction mammoplasty
* Potential consideration for free nipple graft due to extremely large breasts

P (Plan):

* Submit documentation and photographs to insurance for approval after new plan is active in July
* Plan for bilateral reduction mammoplasty with possible free nipple graft if indicated by intraoperative findings
* Postoperative expectations discussed: 3-hour surgery, one-night hospital stay, drains in place for one week, activity restrictions (no heavy lifting for ~6 weeks, no driving for 2-3 weeks)
* Counselled on risks: possible altered nipple sensation, potential impact on future breastfeeding (~30% may be unable to breastfeed), anticipated scar maturation over one year
* Follow-up: Await insurance approval; schedule surgery upon authorization; preoperative visit to review surgical plan and answer further questions
* No new medications prescribed at this time

transcription: [patient] judy gomez , mrn 869723 , date of birth 5/7/1961 . she is in office today for ongoing management of psoriatic arthritis . hello judy , how're you doing today ? [doctor] i'm doing good , thank you , how are you ? [patient] i'm great , thanks , so how have you been since the last time , i know the last time we were talking about decreasing your prednisone dose , correct ? [doctor] yes , i'm just on one now and that seems to be enough . [patient] that's great to hear . [doctor] yeah , there are a couple of days there , i took an extra one just because there was a little extra pain in my feet and i do have a desk job , so when i have a day off where i'm moving around a lot , they do tend to hurt a bit more . [patient] okay , how many times did you do that ? [doctor] it was n't often maybe once a week . [patient] okay so it sounds like we are still on track for discontinuing the prednisone , we'll do that today and you can let me know how it goes on your next visit and how about the methotrexate , do you think that helped with your joint pain ? [doctor] yeah , definitely because i went to get my covid shots but from the letter i got about it , it said that it could interfere with the vaccine , you know , reduce the efficacy , so i did n't take it on the week that i got the first shot . [patient] okay and what happened ? [doctor] i felt absolutely horrible until i took it again a week later . [patient] i'm sorry to hear that and , and what did you do about the second dose ? [doctor] well i called into the hotline because i was in so much pain with the first one and they said no , just go ahead and take it , so i did . [patient] okay , that's good then . we do have to keep an eye out on it since it's a high risk medication . do you have an appointment to get your blood drawn for the next time ? [doctor] no , they did n't give me one . [patient] okay . so we can do that for you too . so what questions do you have for me , judy ? [doctor] well i just wanted to know why i was getting all these bruises here so like when i bump myself , i do n't know where they are coming from . [patient] okay , that's probably from the prednisone , it can increase bruising . [doctor] okay , i did n't know that . i do n't even feel it when it happens , they just show up . [patient] yeah , unfortunately that can happen but we are working on discontinuing that , so let's see if the bruises do go away . [doctor] okay , that sounds good , thanks . [patient] okay judy , please sit up here and i'll take a look , shoes and socks off please . [doctor] alright . [patient] alright , let me see here , okay , so where is it hurting , in your joints right here ? [doctor] yeah , a little also in my feet joints as well . [patient] okay and how about when you bend the knee like this ? [doctor] well , it hurt before we increased the methotrexate , but it's doing pretty good now . okay , good . can you flex your toes please ? [patient] good range of motion also ridges and nails that's from the psoriasis . [doctor] yeah , they've been like that for a long time now . [patient] okay . alright miss gomez it looks like we are moving along with your treatment nicely . we will stop your prednisone and continue with the methotrexate . make sure you stop by the front desk and make an appointment for the blood work and i'll see you in 3 months . [doctor] alright , it sounds good . thank you so much . it was great to see you . [patient] it was great seeing you too . thank you .
SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Ongoing management of psoriatic arthritis
- History of present illness: Occasional increased pain in feet joints, particularly with increased physical activity; improved joint pain with methotrexate; recent bruising with no clear trauma, unrecognized by patient
- Medication history: Currently on prednisone (recently reduced dose, took extra dose occasionally for pain, about once per week), methotrexate (paused briefly during COVID vaccination, resulted in increased pain; resumed as advised), inquired about cause of bruising
- Social history: Desk job, more pain in feet joints with increased activity
- Past medical history: No information provided
- Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Physical exam: Good range of motion in toes, psoriatic ridges and nail changes observed, patient reports mild pain in feet joints, improved knee pain since methotrexate dose increase
- Test results: No information provided
- Vital signs: No information provided

A (Assessment):

- Psoriatic arthritis
- Prednisone-induced bruising, suspected

P (Plan):

- Discontinue prednisone
- Continue methotrexate
- Schedule appointment for blood work
- Outpatient follow-up in 3 months
- Patient education regarding bruising and ongoing monitoring for side effects

transcription: [doctor] kelly wood , date of birth february 15 , 1979 . established patient here for renal ultrasound because of hematuria . urine dipstick today negative for leukocytes , nitrates , protein , ketones , bilirubin and glucose color yellow and clear . urobilinogen 0.2 , ph 5.5 , and specific gravity 1.020 . there is a trace amount of blood in the urine and intact . renal ultrasound , impression , right kidney is 10 cm in length by 5 cm wide . there are no stones , masses , or hydronephrosis . the left kidney is 10.8 cm in length and 5 cm wide . there is a 6 mm left renal stone nonobstructing . 533 ml prevoid and 0 ml post void . hi mrs. wood , i see you just finished your ultrasound . [patient] yes ma'am . [doctor] well , it looks like you have 1 stone in the left kidney , but it's not obstructing anything . [patient] i knew it had to be a kidney stone . i passed what looked like two small stones last week after i scheduled this appointment and then for the past 6 weeks , i've had a few episodes of bright red urine , the color of like cherry cholestee , and last week i was constantly having to pee , and it hurt something terrible . [doctor] how bad was your pain on a scale of 0-10 , zero being no pain and 10 being worst as you can imagine . [patient] at the time i'd say an eight . [doctor] are you having any flank pain now or tenderness in your lower back ? [patient] no , after passing those stones , things have felt a lot better . [doctor] that's good to hear . now , it looks like you're only taking alavert 10 mg a day and have no drug allergies . is that correct ? [patient] that's right . [doctor] alright , well let's take a look at you today . let's use my default pe . well mrs. wood , we know that the blood in your urine was due to the kidney stones . fortunately you passed two last week and the blood has nearly subsided . you do still have 1 stone in the left kidney . since it's not obstructing or causing pain , i do n't recommend any surgical intervention at this time . [patient] i would like to know what i can do to stop getting these stones . [doctor] as we discussed last time , the formation of kidney stones can not be attributed to a particular cause . but several factors increase the risk such as dehydration , family history , certain foods , digestive tract disease , and certain medical conditions . [patient] yeah i know i do n't drink near the amount of water that i should . i drink more mountain dew than anything . [doctor] you should drink about half of your body weight in ounces of water a day . [patient] so if i weigh 250 pounds , i should drink . [doctor] that would be 125 ounces of water a day and you should avoid drinking sugary drinks like mountain dew . [patient] okay . is there any food i should n't eat ? [doctor] great question . you should avoid food rich in sodium , oxalate , and animal protein . so that would be salty , processed foods because they are high in sodium . ideally you should consume less than 1000 mg of sodium a day and reduce the amount of beef , poultry , fish , and pork . [patient] what's oxalate ? [doctor] it's an organic acid found in plants that when digested , it binds to minerals that stones are formed from foods like spinach , chocolate , beets , rubar , and soy products . [patient] well , i'll do whatever it takes to try to avoid getting these stones again . [doctor] great and here is a handout that you can look over . it goes over the dietary recommendations and what to avoid . [patient] okay , good . i like to have things in writing to help you remember . [doctor] perfect . well , if you have any more questions , if you do n't have any more questions , you're all set , i wo n't need to see you back until next year as long as you do n't have any more issues like bleeding or pain . if you do have any issues , you can always call the office sooner and if you experience any severe pain or bright red blood in your urine , you should go to the emergency room . [patient] alright , well , let's hope we do n't have to do either of those and i see you next year . [doctor] yes , so let's hope . come right this way and i'll walk you to check out . update pe abdomen , no flank pain and to gu . normal vaginal exam . primary diagnosis is hematuria . secondary diagnosis is chronic urolithiasis . thank you . this is complete . mrs. wood encounter .
SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Here for renal ultrasound due to hematuria
- History of present illness: Several episodes of bright red urine over the past 6 weeks, severe pain with urination (pain rated 8/10 at peak), increased urinary frequency and dysuria last week, passed two small stones last week, symptoms have improved since passing stones, currently no flank or lower back pain
- Past medical history: No information provided
- Medication: Alavert 10 mg daily
- Drug allergies: None
- Social history: Drinks more Mountain Dew than water, acknowledges inadequate water intake
- Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: No information provided
- Physical exam: Abdomen non-tender, no flank pain, normal vaginal exam, genital urinary system normal
- Test results: Urine dipstick negative for leukocytes, nitrates, protein, ketones, bilirubin, and glucose; color yellow and clear; urobilinogen 0.2, pH 5.5, specific gravity 1.020, trace blood in urine, no intact RBCs noted; renal ultrasound—right kidney 10 cm x 5 cm, no stones/masses/hydronephrosis; left kidney 10.8 cm x 5 cm, 6 mm non-obstructing left renal stone, bladder: prevoid volume 533 ml, postvoid 0 ml

A (Assessment):

- Hematuria
- Chronic urolithiasis

P (Plan):

- No surgical intervention recommended at this time
- Advise increased water intake (target: half body weight in ounces daily; for this patient ~125 oz/day)
- Avoid sugary drinks such as Mountain Dew
- Dietary recommendations: limit sodium (<1000 mg/day), decrease oxalate-rich and animal protein foods (avoiding spinach, chocolate, beets, rhubarb, soy products, beef, poultry, fish, pork), avoid salty/processed foods
- Provided patient handout with dietary and hydration recommendations
- Routine follow-up in 1 year unless additional symptoms occur (pain, hematuria); advised to call office sooner if needed or go to the ER for severe pain or gross hematuria
- No information provided regarding additional diagnostics, referrals, or other treatments

[patient] yeah

[doctor] okay alright so see i'm gon na i'd like to do just a quick physical exam and i've reviewed your vitals those look good your no fever so that's good you're ninety seven . eight and your heart rate looks good at sixty two respirations sixteen your blood pressures one sixteen over eighty four that looks fine your oxygen saturation is real good at ninety nine percent so that all looks good so let's take a look at your left at your right shoulder so you have limited active and passive range of motion and there is some tenderness at the great tuberosity of the humerus there is no tenderness at the sternoclavicular or acro acromioclavicular joints you do have a good hand grip okay and on neurovascular exam of your right arm your capillary refill is less than three seconds and your sensation to touch is intact so i've reviewed the results of your shoulder x-ray and there is no fracture so that's good so let me tell you a little bit about my assessment and plan so for your first problem the right shoulder pain your symptoms are most likely due to this rotator cuff rotator cuff tendinopathy that means you that you injured injured the tendons of the muscles that help make your shoulder muscles i think we had to go ahead and order just an mri since you have had some problems before as well to make sure there's nothing else going on with it and i also want to refer you to physical therapy for approximately six to eight weeks and so during that time continue the tylenol and if your symptoms do n't improve we can go ahead and consider a steroid injection of your shoulder which could provide some relief do you have any questions about your plan
