[doctor] yeah so if you do n't feel that you did anything to injure it we might start just maybe do some epsom salts have you tried soaking your feet in epsom salts that will tend to kinda pull out what's going on in there and just help your those muscles to relax and the soreness to to go away you might try that

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Right shoulder pain for several weeks
- History of present illness: Right shoulder pain began after performing multiple backyard projects involving lifting stones and other tasks; the pain is located on the outside of the right shoulder, is sore to touch, and increases with arm movement or when sleeping on that side; not constant—only noticed with movement; no restriction of movement but tenderness is worse on raising the arm; prior mild issues with right shoulder related to baseball in youth, but current pain is described as different from previous rotator cuff issues
- Associated symptoms: No numbness in arm or hands
- Self-management: Takes Advil and applies ice for pain with some relief
- Additional concerns: Both feet are also sore and stiff, with sore ankle joints after prolonged yard work; no clear history of injury to feet; elevating and icing feet provides some relief; patient has not tried Epsom salt soaks
- Past medical history: Prior right shoulder injury from baseball (childhood)
- Social history: Performing extensive physical yard work
- Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: Temperature 97.8°F, heart rate 62/min, respiratory rate 16/min, blood pressure 116/84 mmHg, oxygen saturation 99%
- Physical exam: Right shoulder with tenderness at greater tuberosity of the humerus, limited active and passive range of motion, no tenderness at sternoclavicular or acromioclavicular joints, good hand grip, capillary refill <3 seconds, sensation to touch intact in right arm; no neurovascular deficit in right arm
- Test results: Right shoulder X-ray shows no fracture

A (Assessment):

- Right shoulder rotator cuff tendinopathy
- Plan to rule out additional structural pathology pending MRI of right shoulder

P (Plan):

- Order MRI of right shoulder
- Refer to physical therapy for 6–8 weeks
- Continue Tylenol for pain management
- If no improvement, consider steroid injection to right shoulder
- Suggest Epsom salt soaks, elevation, and ice for sore feet and ankles
- No follow-up interval provided
- No information provided regarding additional lab tests or referrals for foot symptoms

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Hypertension and palpitations
- History of present illness: History of high blood pressure since young age, recent emergency room visit in March for high blood pressure and palpitations (attributed to caffeine intake and skipping breakfast, felt like panic attack), monitoring blood pressure daily at home with recent readings 146-155 mmHg, not yet in target range (<120 mmHg)
- Past medical history: Hypertension
- Medications: Benicar HCT (combination medication with hydrochlorothiazide), amlodipine 10 mg daily
- Family history: High blood pressure
- Social history: Reports reducing dietary salt intake, attempts to walk on treadmill when possible
- No information provided: Additional medical history, allergies, tobacco or alcohol use

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: No information provided
- Physical exam: Heart and lungs auscultation normal, no reported pain on abdominal exam, no ankle or foot swelling observed
- Test results: Potassium 4.0 mmol/L (tested 1 week ago), thyroid profile from March 1, 2021 (details not provided), basic metabolic panel planned in 2 weeks
- No information provided: Other physical exam findings, additional laboratory or imaging studies

A (Assessment):

- Resistant hypertension (explicitly stated)
- Risk for secondary causes of hypertension (discussion regarding potential hyperaldosteronism and future clinic referral)
- Patient education: Informed of risks of high blood pressure complications (heart failure, kidney failure, stroke) and side effects of medications

P (Plan):

- Add spironolactone to antihypertensive regimen
- Continue Benicar HCT and amlodipine 10 mg daily
- Order basic metabolic panel and blood pressure check in 2 weeks
- Monitor for side effects of spironolactone (gynecomastia, electrolyte disturbances, dizziness, dehydration)
- Educate patient on salt restriction (goal <2000 mg/day), fluid hydration, and risks of medication side effects
- Recommend regular treadmill exercise (30 minutes most days)
- Refer to American Heart Association website for dietary guidance
- If blood pressure not controlled with current regimen, consider referral to resistant hypertension clinic for evaluation of secondary causes and potential procedures (e.g., renal denervation)
- Avoid carvedilol at this time due to potential for erectile dysfunction
- Outpatient follow-up scheduled in 2 weeks

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Persistent facial rash, partially improved with current treatment
- History of present illness: Rash has significantly improved after using doxycycline twice daily for 2 weeks; plateaued after dose reduced to once daily last week; current mild residual rash on medial cheeks and under nostrils; no excessive dryness or thinning of skin; reports sun sensitivity while on doxycycline and takes protective measures
- Past medical history: No information provided
- Social history: Not currently breastfeeding; previously stopped breastfeeding before starting doxycycline
- Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Physical exam: Fitzpatrick skin type IV, few faint erythematous papules bilaterally on medial cheeks, mild erythema around and under nostrils, no excessive dryness or skin thinning observed
- Test results: No information provided
- Vital signs: No information provided

A (Assessment):

- Perioral dermatitis
- Rosacea, including ocular rosacea

P (Plan):

- Doxycycline: Increase to 100 mg orally twice daily until rash clears, then reduce to once daily for an additional week before stopping
- Tacrolimus ointment: Apply to affected facial areas twice daily until rash resolves, then discontinue
- Sulfacetamide wash: Continue use, once or twice daily depending on skin dryness/tolerance
- Metrocream: Continue after face wash
- Moisturizer: Recommend basic options such as Vanicream or petroleum jelly for dryness; samples provided
- Eyelid care: Gently wash eyelids once daily with mild cleansers (e.g., Vanicream); use Bruder mask as needed
- Discontinue and remove Elidel and clindamycin from medication list
- Avoid use of steroids on the face and antiaging/plant-based products until further discussion
- Follow-up: Schedule in approximately 4 weeks
- Patient instructed to reach out if rash worsens or new products are considered; monitor for adverse effects and flare-ups

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Request for full-spectrum STD testing
- History of present illness: Reports onset of abnormal vaginal discharge with different color and consistency accompanied by odor for approximately 1 week, right-sided vaginal discomfort and pain that has persisted, denies fever or chills
- Social history: Recently discovered her boyfriend has had sexual encounters with other partners over the past 3 months, in a relationship for 3 years
- Past medical history: Irregular pap smear at age 20, last pap smear 6 months ago was normal
- Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Physical exam: No external lesions, normal labia majora and minora, physiological discharge with normal color and smell, cervix normal, vaginal wall normal, no cervical motion tenderness, no adnexal tenderness or masses noted
- Test results: Swabs obtained for gonorrhea, chlamydia, and trichomonas; blood obtained for syphilis, HIV, and hepatitis C (results pending)
- Vital signs: No information provided

A (Assessment):

- Screening for STD
- High risk for STD due to history of abnormal pap smear and recent discovery of partner's multiple sexual partners

P (Plan):

- STD testing ordered: Vaginal swabs for gonorrhea, chlamydia, trichomonas; blood tests for syphilis, HIV, hepatitis C
- Patient advised regarding timeline for test results and to call in 3 days if no contact from clinic
- Recommendation to return for next annual checkup if test results are normal
- Patient education provided regarding risk factors and follow-up

[doctor] miss taylor is drinking alcohol 4 to 5 days/week to excess . no tobacco , no substance abuse . skin is moist . good trigger . on exam , she is alert , pleasant , in no acute distress . she is not diabetic . there is no tremor . no cva tenderness . chest clear to percussion in a suscultation . unlabored breathing . cardiac rhythm regular . no murmur , no gallop . jv flat with a head at 90 degrees . she does not appear anxious , agitated , or depressed . my impression , alcohol use disorder . she would like to start naltrexone which we have previously discussed . she will take the injectable form and start on may 17 . we reviewed side effects and risks , the potential benefit of alcohol cessation would be highly beneficial to her for many reasons . hypertension , she is taking lisinopril 10 mg daily and hydrochlorothiazide 12.5 mg daily . quite possibly her blood pressure will improve completely with cessation of alcohol . her target bp is 130-140/70-80 . i will see her back week of june 14 which is likely around the time of her second naltrexone injection . i recommend upgrading influenza vaccination and shingrix . # 2 , she did defer this .
SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Follow-up for hypertension management
* History of present illness: Reports struggling with alcohol cessation, drinking hard alcohol 4–5 times per week; last consumed alcohol on Monday (a few days ago). Notes feeling lethargic and tired with full dose of lisinopril, so self-reduced to half dose; symptoms improved. Denies chest tightness, pressure, shortness of breath, fever, cough, or sore throat. Takes antihypertensive medications in the morning. Home blood pressure readings: lower in the mornings, in the range of 130-145/95-100 in the evenings, improves after resting.
* Past medical history: Hypertension, alcohol use disorder, mild hypercholesterolemia, not diabetic
* Social history: No tobacco or other substance abuse, significant alcohol use, no recent travel or COVID-19 exposure, COVID-19 vaccine received on February 9
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided
* Physical exam: Alert, pleasant, in no acute distress; no tremor; no CVA tenderness; chest clear to percussion and auscultation; unlabored breathing; regular cardiac rhythm; no murmur or gallop; jugular veins flat at 90 degrees; skin moist; no peripheral edema; no anxiety, agitation, or depression noted
* Test results: Comprehensive metabolic panel and complete blood count previously unremarkable; home BP readings in the morning are normal, evenings 130-145/95-100
* Current medications: Lisinopril 10 mg daily (patient reports taking half of prescribed 20 mg dose), hydrochlorothiazide 12.5 mg daily, both taken in the morning

A (Assessment):

* Alcohol use disorder
* Hypertension
* Mild hypercholesterolemia

P (Plan):

* Start injectable naltrexone (Vivitrol), first dose scheduled for May 17; reviewed side effects (possible nausea, headache, dizziness, anxiety, tiredness, trouble sleeping) and potential benefits for alcohol cessation
* Continue antihypertensive therapy: hydrochlorothiazide 12.5 mg daily, lisinopril (encourage adherence to prescribed dose as tolerated)
* Encourage ongoing home blood pressure monitoring, target BP 130-140/70-80
* Reinforce alcohol cessation; note possible improvement in BP with alcohol cessation
* Schedule follow-up during the week of June 14 (timed with possible second naltrexone injection)
* Recommend updating influenza and Shingrix vaccinations (patient deferred at this visit)
* Advise to contact clinic with questions or issues after first naltrexone injection
* No additional testing or referrals at this time

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting
* History of present illness: Ongoing cramping and sharp abdominal pain, episodes of nausea and diarrhea, symptoms increase after eating spicy foods, fatty foods, or drinking alcohol; usually has 2–3 formed bowel movements per day, but gets diarrhea after eating out and drinking alcohol; foods such as pasta/chicken alfredo generally do not cause symptoms; recently has avoided heavy foods but occasionally eats fried chicken without significant issues
* Past medical history: Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) diagnosed in August 2019, functional abdominal pain, previously prescribed bentyl and reglan (used as needed for nausea)
* Social history: Eats out on Friday and Saturday nights, consumes alcohol (tequila, dark liquor, martinis), reports better symptom control with increased water intake and reduced soda consumption
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided

* Test results: No information provided

A (Assessment):

* Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) with functional abdominal pain
* Diarrhea, nausea, aggravated by dietary triggers (spicy/fatty foods, alcohol), explicitly associated with IBS
* Plan includes neuromodulator initiation for IBS

P (Plan):

* Start elavil 25 mg nightly at bedtime as neuromodulator for IBS symptom control
* Continue bentyl 20 mg as needed (1 tablet 30–45 minutes before eating out; may repeat up to four times daily)
* Use zofran as needed for nausea, but encouraged to identify and avoid dietary triggers
* Encourage daily fiber supplement (Citrucel) twice daily for regularity
* Advise reducing greasy/fatty foods, sugary drinks, and alcohol
* Patient education on dietary and lifestyle modifications
* Prescription refills for bentyl and elavil sent to pharmacy
* Follow-up in 1 month via MyChart email to assess response and side effects or make medication adjustments as needed
* No new referrals or additional testing at this time

transcription: [doctor] okay , so our next patient is christopher watson , date of birth 4/12/1934 . mr . watson is a 86-year-old male who returns in follow-up for adult hydrocephalus . this is his first visit since undergoing shunt shunt surgery , excuse me , in august 1 , 2020 . i have followed mr . watson since may 2020 when he first presented with 8 to 10 years of progressive gait impairment , cognitive impairment , and decreased bladder control , we established a diagnosis of adult hydrocephalus with a spinal catheter protocol in june 2020 and he underwent shunt shunt surgery on august 1 , 2020 . medtronic strata programmical shunt in the ventriculoperitoneal configuration was programmed at a level of 2.0 was placed . good morning mr . watson , who is the nice lady you have with you today ? [patient] hi document this is my daughter theresa , she is the one who helps me keep things straight . [doctor] mr . watson , have you been sick or been hospitalized since your shunt shunt surgery 3 months ago ? [patient] not that i recall . no , he has n't . he has been doing much better . [doctor] good . i'm glad to hear that . before surgery , you were having some progressive problems that affected your walking , thinking , and bladder control . are these symptoms better , worse , or unchanged ? his walking has improved . he is now able to walk to the dining room just fine but he could not do that before surgery . he still has times where i have to help him . [patient] that's impressive mr . watson ? [doctor] yeah , i guess . now his bladder control did improve some after surgery but now seems to have leveled out , so he is wearing diapers . [patient] no issues with sores from wearing the diaper and any decreased or painful urination ? [doctor] no , not at all . and how about cognition ? [patient] i think i'm better . i do n't feel lost when talking to someone anymore . [doctor] dan and i both think my sister , hannah summarized it best . she said i feel like i can have a normal conversation with him again . not so wonderful . now , have you had any headaches or pain where the shunt is ? [patient] no , has n't bothered me 1 bit . [doctor] okay and any pain in your belly at all ? [patient] ca n't say that i have . [doctor] okay . sounds like you have been improving . alrighty , mr . watson , i'm gon na step out of the room while my resident comes in to do a few tests for me . is that alright ? [patient] sounds good . [doctor] okay . i'm going to go out and review the ct scan you had last month and then we will chat about it when i come in . alrighty mr . watson , so you definitely have made some improvements since the shunt surgery . now on ct scan though , i do believe i see a tiny bit of blood fluid collection in the right parietal region . [patient] now i do n't believe that that's causing any symptoms and i , it actually was n't documented by the radiologist when he read the ct scan . [doctor] what does that mean ? just that i would like to leave the shunt set for another 2 to 3 months before we go in changing it . like i said , if you're not having any headaches or pain and you have improved , so that's all good for me . so really there is , there is nothing to worry about . alright , so i'll come back in 3 months . [doctor] thank you . hmmm alrighty so ros is constitutional significant for impaired ability to carry out daily functions negative for fever or unintentional weight loss . gu is significant for urinary incontinence and wearing a diaper . negative for genital sores , decreased or painful output . neurological significant for continued walking impairment , and cognitive impairment . negative for headaches , recent falls , or hallucinations . psychiatric is negative for depression , excessive worrying , or mood swings . let's go ahead and use the short pe , vitals let's see blood pressure is 124/80 , heart rate 64 , respirations 18 , weight 174 pounds and pain is 0 out of 10 . mr . watson is a pleasant and cooperative man who is able to converse easily through though his daughter does add some details . the shunt site was clean , dry , and intact with a confirmed setting of two . [patient] he was tested for recent remote memory , attention span and concentration and fund of knowledge . he scored a 26 out of 30 on the mmse when tested with spelling and 25 out of 30 when tested with calculations . [doctor] of note , he was able to get two of the three memory words with cueing and the third with multiple choice . this was a slight improvement over his initial score of 23 out of 30 with calculations and 24 out of 30 with spelling . and at the time he was unable in the previous testing , excuse me , he was unable to remember any memory words and cueing without and only one with multiple choice . gait tested using the tinetti assessment tool . he was tested without an assistive device and received a gait score of 6-8 out of 12 and a balance score of 12 out of 16 for a total score of 18-20 out of 28 . this is slightly improved from his initial score of 15-17 out of 28 . cranial nerves , pupils are equal . eoms are intact . face symmetric . no dysarthria . motor normal for bulk and strength , coordination slow from no finger-to-nose . of note , the ct ct scan from the head of 10/15/2020 shows a frontal hornstan at the level of . firm and of menroma of 4.6 cm with a third ventricular contour that is flat with a span of 10 mm . by my reading , there is a tiny amount of blood in the right frontal region with a tiny subdermal collection . this was not noticed or noted by the radiologist who stated in any extra axial fluid collections . there is also substantial small vessel ischemic change . diagnosis adult hydrocephalus , gait impairment , urinary incontinence , and urgency , and cognitive impairment .
SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Follow-up after shunt surgery for adult hydrocephalus
* History of present illness: Progressive gait impairment, cognitive impairment, and decreased bladder control for 8–10 years; underwent shunt surgery on August 1, 2020. Since surgery, gait has improved (can walk to dining room, sometimes needs help), bladder control improved then plateaued (currently wears diapers, no sores, no decreased or painful urination), cognition improved (feels able to have conversations, family notes improvement). No headaches or pain at shunt site, no abdominal pain.
* Social history: Assisted by daughter with daily activities; inquiry about potential to resume driving, but acknowledges functional limitations.
* Family history: No information provided.
* Past medical history: No information provided.

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Blood pressure 124/80 mmHg, heart rate 64/min, respirations 18/min, weight 174 lbs, pain 0/10
* Physical exam: Pleasant, cooperative man, able to converse easily with supplemental details from daughter. Shunt site clean, dry, intact; shunt setting confirmed at 2.0.
* Neurological exam: MMSE 26/30 (spelling), 25/30 (calculations); previously 24/30 (spelling), 23/30 (calculations). Able to recall 2/3 memory words with cueing, third with multiple choice (improved from prior: only 1/3 with multiple choice, unable without cue). Gait (Tinetti): 6-8/12 (gait), 12/16 (balance), total 18-20/28 (previous: 15-17/28). Cranial nerves: pupils equal, EOMs intact, face symmetric, no dysarthria. Motor: normal bulk and strength, slow coordination, negative finger-to-nose. No recent falls, headaches, or hallucinations.
* Test results: Head CT (10/15/2020): tiny blood/fluid collection in right parietal region, not documented by radiologist; frontal hornstan at level of 4.6 cm, third ventricular contour flat at 10 mm; significant small vessel ischemic change.
* Review of systems: Constitutional—impaired ability to carry out daily functions, negative for fever or unintentional weight loss; GU—urinary incontinence (wearing diaper), negative for genital sores, decreased or painful output; Neurological—walking impairment, cognitive impairment; Psychiatric—negative for depression, excessive worrying, or mood swings.

A (Assessment):

* Adult hydrocephalus
* Gait impairment
* Urinary incontinence and urgency
* Cognitive impairment

P (Plan):

* Continue current shunt therapy, no changes to shunt setting recommended at this time; revisit shunt settings in 2–3 months
* Routine follow-up in 3 months
* Monitor for further symptom improvement and safety regarding driving; discuss potential for driver's safety evaluation at future visits
* No immediate interventions for small blood/fluid collection on CT, continue observation
* The patient and family advised to schedule next appointment upfront

transcription: [doctor] tyler nelson , date of birth 3/6/1949 , mrn 385729 . he is here today for ongoing management of rheumatoid arthritis . last time he was here he received a steroid injection in his right knee . hello mr. nelson , how are you ? [doctor] that's it and is it still painful ? [patient] yeah , it's pretty painful and now the whole leg is getting swollen . [doctor] okay . what would you say your pain level is ? [patient] i mean right now it's about a three or so but typically on the normal day , it's around six . [doctor] okay and it's been swollen like that for how long now ? [patient] since i was last here a couple of weeks after that , so about maybe 2 months now . [doctor] okay , but before it was just the knee ? [patient] yeah , the whole thing was n't swollen like this , but i tried to wear compression socks a lot of the time but it has n't been helping . [doctor] okay . okay . so that has n't been working for you . [patient] i mean it helps to some degree but it's still swollen especially around the knee . [doctor] hmmm has it been keeping you from doing things during the day ? [patient] well i slowed down a little bit and i try to do things too fast but when it really hurts is when i've been sitting for a while and then i try to get up . i'm so stiff getting up , i have to use a cane to get my bearings i mean after a little bit it loosens up but at first getting up is really difficult . [doctor] yeah , i can see , that makes sense . have you been taking your medication regularly ? you're on xeljanz , right ? [patient] yeah , the xr i think it's 11 mg a day , yeah , but i'm taking it everyday and i'm also taking celebrex , which i started maybe 2 months ago . [doctor] yeah , the 200 mix daily . how is that working for you ? [patient] pretty good up until this started swelling again . [doctor] okay well come sit over here and if you could take off your socks and shoes and we will take a look at your knee . and just to let you know , i have a service now that writes my note about the visit so you'll hear , hear me call things out and describe what i see fully . okay , gotcha . [patient] right , so let's check your leg , can you straighten it and does it hurt ? yeah , when i try to straighten it all the way , it does . [doctor] okay . range of motion slightly diminished . i'm going to press here , okay ? and how about here ? hmmm i see some pitting around the knee and ankle . normal capillary refill in the toes . does any of this area hurt ? [patient] just like an old bruise . [doctor] so i can feel that the knee is hot and that means there is something going on like some inflammation so we can give you another steroid injection for that . i also want to get an x-ray of that knee so we can see where all the swelling is coming from . yeah sounds good to me . [patient] okay and do we set up physical therapy for you last time you were here ? [doctor] no i was doing some years ago , but that was the other knee . okay so i think we will set that up for you now . we will also do an x-ray on that knee i can send you for a physical therapy and if nothing is helping then we really might need to get a surgery consult to see what we can do with that knee . [patient] okay . sounds like a plan . [doctor] alright , so for today , we'll go ahead and we'll give you the steroid shot . i'll try to see if i can get a little bit of fluid out before i do give you the injection . there might be no fluid , but i'll see if i can get anything out regardless . [patient] okay and that's the procedure you're gon na do right now ? [doctor] yep once we're done talking here and as far as the edema in your legs , we'll take an x-ray to look for the cause , but there is a lot you can . do as well . the compression socks are a good start and also do you eat a lot of salt ? [patient] i mean i , i mean i love my salty snacks . [doctor] okay . well salt does have a tendency to make your body hold on to water , reducing your salt intake could help with some of the swelling . you can also prop your feet up anytime you get a chance especially at night . [patient] and have you talked to your primary care doctor about this at all ? no , i think i would just come here first . okay . so i think try some of those things out first and if it does n't help , definitely make an appointment with them . [doctor] also as you know xeljanz is a high risk medication , so we need to check your cmp levels every couple of months so this time your levels are good but you make sure to make an appointment for the blood work for next time . [patient] alright i can do that . thank you so much doc . [doctor] yes of course well let me go ahead and get supplies and we'll get to work on your knee . fluid aspiration and steroid injection procedure . the risks , benefits , and alternatives were explained . the risks of steroid injection were explained including but not limited to hypopigmentation , soft tissue atrophy , tendon ruptures and transient hyperglycemia among others . verbal consent was obtained . the right knee was accessed through the lateral approach with 3 ml of initially clear fluid , then blood . blood tinged fluid . then the right knee was prepped in a standard fashion . the right knee was injected with 80 mg of triamcin alone . and 1 ml of lidocaine . the procedure was tolerated well with no complications . post procedure instructions were given . patient will follow up with his pcp . thank you .
SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Ongoing swelling and pain in the right knee and leg
- History of present illness: Swelling in the right knee persisted after prior steroid injection; initial improvement for a couple of weeks, but symptoms returned and progressed to involve the whole leg over the past 2 months; compression socks provide limited relief; pain level currently 3/10 but typically around 6/10 daily; worsens after sitting and when standing up; requires cane due to stiffness on rising; knee pain with attempted extension described as painful, knee feels hot and swollen
- Impact on daily activities: Slowed down activity, difficulty getting up after sitting, needs cane for stability initially
- Medication adherence: Taking Xeljanz XR 11 mg daily and Celebrex 200 mg daily as prescribed; Celebrex started 2 months ago; reports Celebrex was effective until recent swelling episode
- Social history: High salt intake reported
- Past interventions: Previous steroid injection to right knee a few months ago, previous physical therapy on opposite knee only
- Past medical history: Rheumatoid arthritis
- Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: No information provided
- Physical exam: Right knee and leg visibly swollen, pitting edema noted around right knee and ankle, normal capillary refill in toes, range of motion in right knee slightly diminished, right knee warm to touch, pain with full extension, tenderness described as "like an old bruise"
- Test results: Comprehensive metabolic panel (CMP) within normal limits at this visit
- Procedure: Right knee aspiration yielded 3 ml of initially clear, then blood-tinged fluid; right knee injected with 80 mg triamcinolone and 1 ml lidocaine via lateral approach; procedure tolerated well without complications

A (Assessment):

- Rheumatoid arthritis
- Right knee swelling and pain, persistent despite previous steroid injection
- Lower extremity edema, suspected related to arthritis and/or other causes

P (Plan):

- Right knee fluid aspiration and steroid (triamcinolone) injection performed today
- Order right knee x-ray
- Initiate referral to physical therapy
- Advise on lifestyle modifications: reduce salt intake, use compression socks, elevate legs (especially at night)
- Post-procedure instructions provided
- Continue current medications: Xeljanz XR 11 mg daily, Celebrex 200 mg daily
- Follow up with primary care provider for further evaluation and blood work (CMP) in a couple of months for Xeljanz monitoring
- Consider surgical consultation for the knee if swelling and pain persist despite interventions

[doctor] okay . so normal physical exam per my new patient template except for a well-healed abdominal surgical scar is noted . what's the surgical scar here on your abdomen from ? i always forget about that surgery . i had it when i was a baby . my mom said my intestines were twisted , so i had to have surgery when i was around 1 month old . gotcha , okay . so let's talk about what you have going on . from what you've told me , it sounds like you've had a several year history of gerd , which is the medical term for acid reflux . [patient] and recently your symptoms have been poorly controlled with the omeprazole 40 mg twice daily . you've been having heartburn despite taking this medication , correct ? [doctor] yes . and you've identified trigger foods like spicy foods , carbonated beverages , citrus , and tomato based foods , but you have n't cut these foods out of your diet completely yet . [patient] so the first thing i'd try is changing your diet because these foods can exacerbate your gerd even though you're taking the ppi . [doctor] okay , yeah , i could definitely do a better job of avoiding those foods . [patient] great . so stress is another trigger that we need to address . high stress can cause worsening of your symptoms . [doctor] yeah , stress and anxiety are definitely big problems for me . so working on that may help with your gerd . additionally we can consider trying a different ppi since the only one you've tried up to this point is omeprazole . if you're okay with this , we can switch your omeprazole to nexium . that's fine with me , i'm definitely open to trying whatever . perfect . i will send a prescription for nexium 40 mg twice daily to your pharmacy on file . i also recommend that you have a procedure called a egd or upper endoscopy to look for potential causes of the gerd . we sedate you and then pass a small camera through your mouth down your throat , through your stomach and end in the small intestines . [patient] we would look for any ulcers or signs of precancerous or cancerous conditions that we can take biopsies at the same time if we see anything . [doctor] okay . can i schedule that today ? yeah , you can get scheduled at checkout desk . i'll have you follow up with me in the office for the egd so we can discuss the results and talk about how you're doing with the dietary stress and medication changes . how does all of that sound ? [patient] that sounds good . [doctor] perfect . i will walk you to the check out desk . be sure to call my office and let me know if anything changes or if you have problems before your egd and follow-up appointment . please insert the procedure paragraph in the plan . i suspect that she likely has gerd with underlying functional etiology as well . reassuringly , she has no unintentional weight loss and denies any dysphagia . if her egd is normal and her symptoms persist despite a trial of nexium , we can consider a trial of protonix and obtain a ph impedance study . this will allow us to rule out abnormal acid reflux exposure and to decipher between a functional etiology and hypersensitivity .
SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Acid reflux
- History of present illness: Acid reflux symptoms (burning in chest and throat) since age 12, worsened over past few years; currently on omeprazole 40 mg twice daily with inconsistent symptom control; symptoms worsened by stress and trigger foods (spicy foods, carbonated beverages, tomato-based and citrus products); denies dysphagia, abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, changes in bowel movements, constipation, diarrhea, or rectal bleeding; weight reported as stable although decreased appetite past 2 months associated with high work stress
- Past medical history: Anxiety, seasonal allergies, surgical correction for intestinal twisting as an infant (abdominal surgery at 1 month of age)
- Medication history: Omeprazole, prior trial of ranitidine with omeprazole; no other reflux medications tried
- Social history: Works as a paralegal, reports high work stress
- Family history: Grandmother (maternal) had esophageal cancer, mother had acid reflux and took medications for gastric protection

O (Objective):

- Physical exam: Normal except for well-healed abdominal surgical scar
- Vital signs: No information provided
- Test results: No information provided

A (Assessment):

- GERD (gastroesophageal reflux disease), likely with underlying functional etiology, suspected

P (Plan):

- Switch from omeprazole to esomeprazole (Nexium) 40 mg twice daily
- Recommend dietary modifications to reduce trigger foods (spicy foods, carbonated beverages, tomato-based and citrus products)
- Advise stress reduction measures; address underlying anxiety
- Schedule EGD (esophagogastroduodenoscopy/upper endoscopy) to evaluate for ulcers, precancerous, or cancerous lesions, and to obtain biopsies if needed
    - "We sedate you and then pass a small camera through your mouth down your throat, through your stomach and into the small intestines. We would look for any ulcers or signs of precancerous or cancerous conditions. We can take biopsies at the same time if we see anything."
- Schedule follow-up visit in office to review EGD results and response to dietary/stress/medication changes
- If EGD is normal and symptoms persist despite Nexium, consider trial of protonix and obtain pH impedance study to differentiate abnormal acid reflux from functional etiology and hypersensitivity
- Advise patient to contact office if symptoms change or problems arise before scheduled EGD and follow-up

- Chief complaint: Spasms, lightheadedness, significant constipation, diaphoresis
- History of present illness: Hospitalized 6/29/2021–7/2/2021 for increased spasms, lightheadedness, severe constipation, diaphoresis, labile blood pressure, headache, and vomiting; reported improvement in symptoms after bowel movement at home; feels back to normal now
- Past medical history: Quadriplegia due to prior spinal cord injury
- Medication history: Regular use of Miralax for constipation, uses lactulose as rescue medication, takes vitamin C and multivitamin
- Social history: No information provided
- Family history: No information provided
- COVID-19 vaccination status: Unvaccinated; hesitant regarding COVID-19 vaccination, prefers supplements, describes herself as somewhat homeopathic

- Chronic constipation

- Leukocytosis, differential includes infection vs. inflammation; will monitor trend
- COVID-19 unvaccinated, high risk (discussion regarding vaccine recommendation)

P (Plan):

- Repeat fasting laboratory panel including CBC and cholesterol in 2–3 weeks
- Monitor white blood cell count trend; assess for persistent leukocytosis
- Continue current bowel regimen with regular Miralax and rescue lactulose as needed
- Recommendation reiterated for COVID-19 vaccination due to high risk from quadriplegia
- Patient education regarding importance of hydration to prevent constipation, risk discussion about supplements vs. vaccination for COVID-19
- Follow-up visit in 2–3 weeks
- No information provided regarding other plans or referrals

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Evaluation of abnormal renal ultrasound with an atrophic right kidney
- History of present illness: Sudden onset right-sided abdominal pain leading to work-up; initial symptoms included severe right-sided pain, vomiting, and abdominal tenderness; found to have an atrophic right kidney and cysts on kidney/ovaries, with episodes of pain and burning in the stomach persisting (especially after eating), history of burning on urination with certain drinks (e.g., soda); currently mild stomach pain and burning, occasional difficulty starting urination, denies blood in urine
- Past medical history: Previously healthy, history of multiple hospitalizations at age 4 for fever and infection of unclear source treated with fluids and antibiotics, no prior noted kidney disease
- Medications: Pepcid 40 mg daily, Claritin for allergies
- Social history: Active in softball, plans to join drill team over summer
- Family history: Father with kidney transplant (posterior urethral valves, obstructive neuropathy, chronic kidney disease, dialysis-dependent, died at 47 of heart attack); great-aunt (father’s sister) with end stage renal disease, chronic kidney disease stage V, diabetes, hypertension (as adult); maternal grandmother with breast cancer; family history of renal disease noted
- No information provided: Smoking status, alcohol use, living situation

O (Objective):

- Physical exam: Well-appearing female, alert and oriented, sitting comfortably, no acute distress; heart and lungs normal; exam within normal limits
- Test results: Renal ultrasound—atrophic (smaller) right kidney, left kidney appears larger; presence of cysts on right kidney and ovaries previously reported; lymphadenopathy and evidence of prior infection previously noted; genetic panel—no clinically significant mutations identified; kidney function tests within normal limits; blood pressure within normal range

A (Assessment):

- Atrophic right kidney
- History of severe infection possibly affecting kidney function (as suspected by previous providers)
- Increased risk for hypertension and proteinuria

P (Plan):

- Annual renal ultrasound to monitor kidney size and function
- Annual urinalysis for protein and blood
- Blood pressure checks at routine visits
- Avoid nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory medicines (NSAIDs); use Tylenol instead
- Encourage hydration: at least 2 liters of water per day, especially during sports and physical activities to prevent dehydration
- Continue Pepcid and Claritin as prescribed
- Maintain healthy diet and active lifestyle
- Follow-up with primary care physician or local adult nephrologist for ongoing monitoring
- Instructed to call provider or primary care if symptoms worsen
- No acute intervention required at this time

[patient] no , i also wear the left sometimes , the right is just worse but the splint helps . both have really gotten worse over the last month and i broke them my right wrist was definitely in worse shape . i've also been having some mild stiffness in my neck too . i hit my head during the accident and they told me it was a contusion . [doctor] and where would you say the tingling and numbness is ? [patient] on this side , it goes from here and here up to about here on the other side , it's from here to here . [doctor] i see . so on the right side you're pointing from the middle and ring finger all the way up the forearm and on the left the symptoms extend from the pinky and ring finger and is there any pain or just tingling and numbness ? it's mainly just sore , sometimes they throb but overall they feel weaker too especially when i'm using them . the tingling happens more when they hurt , but when it goes away , the tingling is dull . [patient] and when do you feel these symptoms ? well , really i guess just more so at night and they come and go throughout the day . [doctor] okay and do you experience any loss of sensation in your hands or fingers ? [patient] like feeling something , no , not that i can really think of though in general they maybe less sensitive than they should be but i can still feel they also gave me some nerve pain medicine , but i have n't been taking it like i should . [doctor] and are you still on the coreg for hypertension and the lexapro for anxiety ? [patient] yes , i'm still taking those . i had prediabetes too , but i got it under control by changing my diet . [doctor] and no history of thyroid issues , correct ? [patient] no . [doctor] ri thank you mr. cook okay first we'll go over your review of systems correct me if i'm wrong in any of this constitutional you have fatigue and weight gain gi you have excessive appetite and bloating eyes have floaters , cardiovascular shows shortness of breath and leg swelling , endocrine , you're always hungry , skin , you have some nailbed changes , dryness , and itching , musculoskeletal , you have gout and muscle pain , and the remainder of the review of systems is negative . [patient] yeah , that's all correct . [doctor] alright we are going to go ahead and do the neurologic examination . let's look at the right hand first . can you feel this ? [patient] yeah , but a little less on these two fingers . [doctor] sensation is normal except pinprick sensation diminished in the third and fourth fingers on the right and how about on the left ? [patient] yeah but these two are little less . [doctor] sensation is decreased in the fourth and fifth fingers on the left . okay , let's test your reflexes now . reflexes are 1+ and symmetric . 2+ knees , toes are downgoing bilaterally . alright , i'm going to tap on your right wrist . do you feel anything ? [patient] yeah , it feels like a zing of my wrist and something into my elbow too . [doctor] and how about the left side ? [patient] yeah , same on that side too . [doctor] tinel's sign positive at both wrists and both elbows . rest of exam is normal . alright so what i am seeing today is bilateral carpal tunnel syndrome or potentially this could also be bilateral cubital tunnel syndrome . however , your symptom presentation suggests bilateral carpal tunnel syndrome as the nerves in your wrist are aggravated by your past trauma . this is causing the pain and tingling you were describing to me . okay . so how we make it better ? first , i want to determine exactly where the nerve irritation is coming from . we will need to schedule you for a nerve test , which is called an emg test . they will measure the responsiveness of your nerves to truly pinpoint where you're having your issues . [patient] that sounds fine to me . [doctor] great . after the tests are complete , you can return here for a follow-up visit . if you're still having symptoms , we can consider a referral to our hand clinic possibly for injections or carpal tunnel release surgery . you could also refer , we could also refer you to an orthopedist for the same treatment . [patient] sounds good document . [doctor] alright keep wearing your splints and i will see you after those studies . [patient] thank you .
SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Numbness and tingling in both hands
* History of present illness: Numbness and tingling in both hands for a few weeks, worsening over the past month; symptoms noticed more after bilateral wrist fractures from a car accident last December; right wrist was worse; wears splints (right wrist consistently, left wrist sometimes); hands feel weaker, soreness and occasional throbbing, mild neck stiffness, tingling worse at night and intermittent during day; denies significant loss of sensation but notes reduced sensitivity; taking nerve pain medication inconsistently
* Past medical history: Bilateral wrist fractures (December, status post healing), head contusion from same accident, hypertension, anxiety, prediabetes (now controlled with diet), gout, muscle pain
* Current medications: Coreg (for hypertension), Lexapro (for anxiety), nerve pain medication (not taken regularly)
* Social history: No information provided
* Family history: No information provided
* Review of systems: Fatigue, weight gain, excessive appetite, bloating, floaters (eyes), shortness of breath, leg swelling, always hungry, nailbed changes, skin dryness and itching, gout, muscle pain; remainder of review systems negative

O (Objective):

* Physical exam: Diminished pinprick sensation in right third and fourth fingers, decreased sensation in left fourth and fifth fingers, Tinel’s sign positive at both wrists and both elbows, reflexes 1+ and symmetric, knee reflexes 2+, downgoing toes bilaterally, rest of exam normal
* Vital signs: No information provided
* Test results: No information provided

A (Assessment):

* Bilateral carpal tunnel syndrome
* Differential diagnosis: Bilateral cubital tunnel syndrome

P (Plan):

* Schedule EMG nerve conduction study to localize site of nerve irritation
* Continue wearing wrist splints
* Follow-up after EMG results
* If symptoms persist, consider referral to hand clinic or orthopedist for possible injections or carpal tunnel release surgery
* No changes to current medications until follow-up

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Bilateral hand numbness and tingling
- History of present illness: Numbness and tingling in both hands for a few weeks, noted since December following bilateral wrist fractures; symptoms worsened over the past month. Right wrist symptoms localize to the middle and ring fingers extending to the forearm; left hand more in the pinky and ring fingers. Mild neck stiffness, occasional soreness, throbbing, perceived weakness with use, symptoms worse at night and intermittent during the day. No obvious loss of sensation but possibly reduced sensitivity. Reports fatigue, weight gain, excessive appetite, bloating, floaters, shortness of breath, leg swelling, always hungry, nailbed changes, skin dryness and itching, muscle pain, and gout. No history of thyroid issues.
- Past medical history: Chronic kidney disease, gout, hypertension, anxiety, GERD, diabetes (previously prediabetic, improved with diet)
- Medication history: Carvedilol 25 mg twice daily, Lexapro 10 mg daily, nerve pain medication (unspecified, not consistently taken)
- Allergies: Sulfa drugs (rash)
- Social history: No information provided
- Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: No information provided
- Physical exam: Neurological exam normal except reduced pinprick sensation in the third and fourth fingers (right) and fourth and fifth fingers (left), reflexes 1+ and symmetric, 2+ at knees, bilateral downgoing toes, positive Tinel's sign at both wrists and elbows
- Test results: CT brain (2/5/2021) reviewed, no metastatic disease, no acute intracranial abnormalities

A (Assessment):

- Bilateral carpal tunnel syndrome
- Question of bilateral cubital tunnel syndrome

P (Plan):

- Schedule EMG/NCV studies
- Encourage continued use of wrist splints
- Consider hand clinic referral for possible symptomatic injections or carpal tunnel release surgery if symptoms persist (patient may also pursue this through current orthopedist)
- Return for EMG/NCV

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Follow-up after right medial unicompartmental knee arthroplasty, 6 weeks postoperative
* History of present illness: Reports "no problems" with right knee except for persistent numbness on one side, which has been present since surgery; no pain; expresses satisfaction with surgical outcome; has not returned to work due to job requirements of stair use and lifting
* Social history: Works for UPS; unable to return to standard duties due to physical requirements, employer has asked about return to sedentary work; queries about ability to return to driving
* No information provided: Past medical history, family history

O (Objective):

* Physical exam: Gait is antalgic with slight limp and decreased velocity, no assistive device used, right knee exam shows healed surgical scar, mild swelling, tenderness along area of incision, range of motion 0–120 degrees, otherwise normal findings
* Test results: Right knee radiographs (three views) show implants in stable position, no evidence of loosening or early complication

* Status post right medial unicompartmental knee arthroplasty, 6 weeks postoperative
* Persistent area of numbness, expected to improve as nerves heal

P (Plan):

* Continue physical therapy to improve strength, range of motion, and endurance
* No lifting greater than 5–10 pounds, and no standing or sitting longer than half an hour for work; note provided to excuse patient from regular UPS duties for another 6 weeks
* Discuss return to work at next visit in 6 weeks
* Patient may return to driving when she feels safe and ready, as normal reflex time is expected to return at 6 weeks
* Schedule telemedicine follow-up in 6 weeks to monitor progress

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Longstanding iron deficiency anemia
- History of present illness: Fatigue during the day, feeling feverish with chills during activity, shortness of breath, wheezing, headaches, tingling sensations, increased sensitivity to cold, worsening anxiety and depression
- Past medical history: Diagnosed with anemia since age 13, heavy periods until hysterectomy in 1996, hysterectomy in 1996
- Social history: Alcohol intake once or twice a year
- Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Physical exam: Normal without any significant findings
- Test results: Low hemoglobin, stable hematocrit, normal iron labs, low ferritin (from blood work in January 2020)
- Current medications: Ferrous sulfate 25 mg twice daily, vitamin B12 over-the-counter supplement

A (Assessment):

- Iron deficiency anemia (diagnosed)
- Suspected internal bleeding as a potential etiology

P (Plan):

- Schedule upper endoscopy and colonoscopy to assess for gastrointestinal sources of blood loss
- If upper endoscopy and colonoscopy are inconclusive, consider capsule endoscopy
- Referral to hematologist (Dr. Flores) for further evaluation and consideration of intravenous iron or treatments to improve iron storage
- Instruct patient to continue ferrous sulfate 25 mg twice daily, take each dose with orange juice for vitamin C to enhance absorption for the next 8–12 weeks
- Plan to reassess blood work (CBC, iron, ferritin, B12, and folate) after 8–12 weeks
- Bowel prep instructions provided for colonoscopy
- Advise patient to call if symptoms worsen or questions arise

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Chest pain (resolved)
* History of present illness: Episode of central, sharp chest pain behind the breastbone lasting 4 days in early October 2020; pain was worse with eating, possibly associated with heartburn and difficulty swallowing; resolved about 3 days after ER visit; has not recurred since then
* Past medical history: Uterine fibroids, anemia, cholecystectomy (gallbladder removed)
* Social history: Reports undergoing a stressful job transition at the time of chest pain episode; currently trying to lose weight
* Family history: No known family history of gastrointestinal problems

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided
* Physical exam: Mild tenderness to light palpation in the upper abdominal quadrants, otherwise normal abdominal exam
* Test results: Normal cardiac work-up in the ER

A (Assessment):

* History of isolated chest pain episode, fully resolved
* Differential diagnosis: GERD, dyspepsia, esophagitis, musculoskeletal etiologies, anxiety
* Suspected: Anxiety attack related to job transition, possible contribution from musculoskeletal etiologies

P (Plan):

* Discussed options of EGD (upper endoscopy) versus monitoring
* Patient elected to monitor for symptoms and will call with any recurrence or change
* EGD to be scheduled if symptoms recur
* Follow up as needed for any further GI complaints

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Family seeks evaluation of kidneys due to known syndrome associated with renal anomalies
- History of present illness: 22-month-old female, former 34+3 week twin, history of delayed milestones (could not sit by age 1, now crawling and attempting to walk), history of feeding difficulties and episodes of apnea during feeds in infancy, temperature regulation difficulties as a neonate, ongoing gastroesophageal reflux, transitioned from cow's milk to pea protein milk with improved oral intake, increased fluid intake, 8-10 wet diapers per 24 hours, in feeding, occupational, and physical therapy; speech therapy to begin soon
- Past medical history: Smith-Magenis syndrome (chromosomal deletion syndrome); gastroesophageal reflux
- Family history: Brother with autism, no specific family history of kidney failure, dialysis, or transplant explicitly stated
- Social history: Lives in Dallas, Georgia; has a twin sister who is doing well developmentally

O (Objective):

- Physical exam: Well-nourished female, slightly fussy during exam, small appearing eyes, mild hypotonia of lower extremities and arms, normal external female genitalia
- Test results: No information provided (kidney ultrasound pending)
- Vital signs: No information provided

A (Assessment):

- Smith-Magenis syndrome
- Risk of congenital anomalies of the kidney and urinary tract (screening indicated)

P (Plan):

- Obtain kidney ultrasound today
- Await kidney ultrasound results
- If kidney ultrasound is abnormal, determine further follow-up and management
- Follow-up to be arranged at town center location if needed
- Nurse to complete paperwork and provide ultrasound instructions
- Will call family with results; discharge from nephrology if ultrasound is normal, further nephrology follow-up in case of abnormalities

transcription: [doctor] patient bruce ward , date of birth 5/21/1969 . please use my neuro consult template . this is a 52-year-old male with newly diagnosed pituitary lesion . [patient] the patient is seen in consultation at the request of dr. henry howard for possible surgical mr. ward presented to his primary care provider , dr . howard on 3/1/2021 complaining of worsening headaches over the past few months . he denied any trouble with headaches in the past . his past medical history is unremarkable . work-up for worsening headaches was initiated with brain mri and serology where pituitary lesion was incidentally discovered . i personally reviewed the labs dated 3/3/2021 including cbc , u and e's , coagulation , and crp all were normal . pituitary hormone profile demonstrates a low tsh . all other results were normal . i personally reviewed pertinent radiology studies including mri of the brain with contrast from 3/4/2021 . [doctor] the mri reveals a pituitary lesion with elevation and compression of the optic chiasm . the ventricles are normal in size and no other abnormalities are are noted . hello mr. ward , nice to meet you . i'm dr. flores . [patient] hi doc , nice to meet you . [doctor] i was just reviewing your records from doctor howard and he has referred you because the work-up for headaches revealed a mass in your pituitary gland . [patient] i did review your mri images and . there . can you tell me about the issues you've been experiencing ? [doctor] yeah , sure , so i'm really getting fed up with these headaches . i've been trying my best to deal with them , but they have been going on for months now and i'm really struggling . where are the headaches located and how would you describe that pain ? [patient] located behind my eyes , it's like a dull nagging ache . [doctor] okay . was the onset gradual or sudden ? [patient] well this started about 3 months ago and they've been getting worse over time , at first it was like 3 out of 10 in severity and it just gradually worsened , now it's about 6 out of 10 in severity . the headaches do tend to be worse in the morning and feels like a dull ache behind the eyes . [doctor] they last a few hours at a time and nothing makes them better or worse . [patient] okay . can you tell me if the pain radiates or if you have any other symptoms specifically feeling sick , fever , rashes , neck stiffness , numbness , weakness , passing out ? no . i have n't been sick or felt sick . ca n't recall a fever or any kind of rash . no , no neck issues , no numbness , no tingling and i've never passed out in my life . but for some reason recently i seemed to be bumping the door frames . [doctor] okay , have you noticed any change in your vision or with your balance ? [patient] no , i do n't think so . my eyes were checked in the fall . [doctor] okay , let's see . do you have any other medical problems that you take medicine for ? [patient] no , i do n't have any medical problems and i do n't take any medicines . i tried tylenol a few times for the headaches , but it did n't work , so i stopped . [doctor] let's see . anyone in your family have any history of diseases ? [patient] i was adopted , so i really have no idea . [doctor] okay . what kind of work do you do and are you married ? [patient] i work as a computer programmer and i've been married for 25 years . we just bought a small house . [doctor] well that's nice . do you drink any alcohol , smoke , or use recreational drugs ? nope , i do n't do any of those and never have . [patient] okay . well , let me take a good look at you . now you hear me calling out some details as i perform the examination . these will be noted for me in your record and i will be happy to answer any questions you have once we are done . [doctor] sounds good document . [patient] alright the patient is alert , oriented to time , place , and person . affect is appropriate and speech is fluent . [doctor] cranial nerve examination is grossly intact . no focal motor or sensory deficit in the upper or lower extremities . visual acuity and eye movements are normal . pupils are equal and reactive . visual field testing reveals bitemporal hemianopia . [patient] and color vision is normal . alright , mr. ward , i'm going to review these pictures from the mri with you . now this appears to be a benign pituitary adenoma , but there's no way to be sure without sending removed adenoma to pathology to make the diagnosis , which we will do . here you can see it's a well defined mass and it's pressing right here on what we call the optic chiasm and today when i was having you look at my fingers , you could n't see them off to the side . that's what we call bitemporal hemianopia and explains why you have been bumping into door frames . yeah i never noticed that i could n't see out of the side until you did that test and they closed my eye with both eyes really could n't tell . now because you're having this vision loss from the mask compressing the optic chiasm , the only option we have is to do surgery . okay , i understand . do you think i'll regain my vision ? [doctor] well , there is no guarantee , but it is a possibility . i'm gon na refer you to the eye doctor for a full exam and we will do what's called visual field test . [patient] this will knock out your peripheral vision or side vision prior to surgery and we can monitor after surgery to see if your vision is improving . [doctor] alright . and let's discuss the surgery a little more . we would do what's called a transsphenoidal approach to do the surgery . this is minimally invasive and we go to the sphenoid sinus . [patient] there are some risks i have to inform you of . risks of anesthesia including but not limited to the risk of heart attack , stroke , and death , risks of surgery include infection , need for further surgery , wound issues , such as spinal fluid , leak or infection , which may require a long prolonged hospitalization or additional procedure seizure , stroke , permanent numbness , weakness , difficulty speaking or even death . [doctor] well i guess we have to do it regardless . [patient] okay so i will have you see our surgery scheduler , deborah on the way out to get you set up . we will get this scheduled fairly quickly , so i do n't want you to be alarmed . she will also get you set up today or tomorrow to have the visual field test and you may not be able to see the eye doctor until after surgery but we have the presurgery , visual field test for comparison after surgery . [doctor] okay . i look forward to these headaches going away . i never thought it could be something like this going on . [patient] yeah . come this way , but that things lined up , please call if you think of any questions . [doctor] thanks doctor . [patient] diagnosis will be pituitary adenoma . mr . ward is a very pleasant 52-year-old male who has benign appearing pituitary adenoma incidentally discovered during work-up for worsening headaches . he is symptomatic with . [doctor] clinical and radiographical evidence of optic chiasmal compression therefore surgical intervention to excise and decompress the pituitary fossa is indicated . end of note .
SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Worsening headaches over the past few months
- History of present illness: Headaches started 3 months ago, initially rated 3/10 in severity, gradually worsening to 6/10, described as a dull, nagging ache located behind the eyes, worse in the morning, lasts a few hours, no clear aggravating or relieving factors; recently noticed bumping into door frames; denies prior headaches, fever, illness, rashes, neck stiffness, numbness, weakness, tingling, or syncope; no subjective changes in vision or balance reported; tried Tylenol without relief
- Past medical history: Unremarkable
- Medications: None
- Family history: Unknown (patient adopted)
- Social history: Works as a computer programmer, married for 25 years, recently bought a house; denies alcohol, tobacco, or recreational drug use

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: No information provided
- Physical exam: Alert, oriented to time, place, and person; affect appropriate; speech fluent; cranial nerve examination grossly intact; no focal motor or sensory deficit in upper or lower extremities; visual acuity and eye movements normal; pupils equal and reactive; color vision normal; visual field testing reveals bitemporal hemianopia
- Test results: Brain MRI with contrast (3/4/2021): Pituitary lesion with elevation and compression of the optic chiasm, ventricles normal in size, no other abnormalities; Serology (3/3/2021): CBC, urea and electrolytes, coagulation studies, CRP all normal; pituitary hormone profile: low TSH, all other results normal

A (Assessment):

- Pituitary adenoma
- Clinical and radiographical evidence of optic chiasmal compression

P (Plan):

- Schedule transsphenoidal surgical excision of the pituitary lesion
- Refer to ophthalmology for full eye exam and visual field test (pre-surgical)
- Compare visual field before and after surgery
- Surgical and anesthetic risks explained (infection, cerebrospinal fluid leak, need for further surgery, seizure, stroke, permanent numbness/weakness, speech difficulty, death)
- Surgery scheduling to be coordinated with surgery scheduler
- Instruct patient to call with any additional questions
- No information provided regarding medical therapy or other investigations

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Left-sided back pain
- History of present illness: Back pain is usually on the left, varies in quality (sometimes sharp, sometimes not), sometimes migrates but mostly localized to the left; increased water intake and waking up at night to urinate more frequently; no increase in fatigue; appetite unchanged.
- Past medical history: Recurrent strep throat (four episodes in the past five months)
- Social history: Rides a bike occasionally; attends school (doing well, good grades); lives with a brother who smokes (smoking not allowed in the house); recent or impending job change (old boss unsatisfactory, new job at a restaurant, no insurance yet); class schedule may impact lab timing.
- Family history: No information provided.

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: No information provided.
- Physical exam: Throat without erythema or swelling, tonsils midline, no cervical lymphadenopathy, lungs clear (no wheezes, rales, or rhonchi), heart sounds normal (no murmur, rub, or gallop), no tenderness on left back palpation, abdomen without pain, no rebound, no guarding.
- Test results: CT shows findings concerning for possible glomerulonephritis; no additional lab or imaging results provided.

A (Assessment):

- Glomerulonephritis, suspected (based on CT findings and recurrent strep throat)
- Recurrent strep throat

P (Plan):

- Refer to ENT for recurrent strep throat evaluation and possible tonsillectomy
- Order laboratory tests: lipid panel, urinalysis (UA), comprehensive metabolic panel (CMP), complete blood count (CBC), vitamin D, thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH)
- Advise patient to complete labs as soon as possible, some requiring fasting; lab orders placed today
- Arrange follow-up appointment in 1 week (phone follow-up if results are normal, in-person if further discussion needed)
- Patient education provided regarding salt intake and infection control; conversation about household smoking exposure
- No shots required today

[patient] no the food is not getting stuck it just hurts

[doctor] okay that's that's that's that's good yeah we we definitely want you to to take in as much liquid as possible best especially since you're on the chemotherapy and the radiation just so you wo n't get dehydrated because that will make you feel a lot worse if you are dehydrated okay so on a on a mental emotional standpoint i know you said you have your husband with you how you doing with that you have the support that you need you need to speak to me though
[patient] it's very helpful you know as you can understand i'm just like devastated when i got this diagnosis and i'm just i'm just trying to figure everything out and but he is very good and my daughter is is very helpful too and i you know i think for the most part i'm very fortunate to have them
[doctor] okay so how how are you feeling on your chemo see you're on a combination of cisplatin and etoposide you had your last dose a few days ago any nausea any fatigue from that
[patient] i was a little nauseated and tired but i took the zofran that you prescribed and that seemed to help and you know i i got some rest it's it's it's been okay
[doctor] okay that's good so let me do a quick physical exam on you just gon na check your vitals here so your vitals are normal your pulse ox is okay so everything's good with that so i'm gon na feel your neck on your neck exam i do n't appreciate any cervical lymphadenopathy no subclavicular adenopathy your heart exam regular rate and rhythm no murmur your lung exam so i do notice some crackles in your lungs bilaterally that's just a faint sound we hear when you take a deep breath so that could mean you have some fluid in there and that is to be expected due to your lung cancer diagnosis so i'm gon na look at your skin exam so on your skin exam on your chest i do see some erythema on the anterior aspect of your chest on the left side and that could be due to that radiation sometimes patients do get a radiation burn and it's it'll get better with time especially once you're done with the the radiation treatment and on your extremity it there is no lower extremity edema in your legs so prior to coming to see me you did get a chest x-ray it looks like you do have mild radiation pneumonitis that means you have inflammation of your lungs due to the radiation so let's talk a little bit about my assessment and plan for you so your first diagnosis you know is is the lung cancer so we are gon na continue you on that chemo regimen on that you do have continue on that that current radiation doses i think you're on forty five gray yep you're on that and then when the when the regimen's complete we'll do some more testing and hopefully we can see a resection of that tumor so that has just gotten little smaller and we can go inside and and take it out so for your second diagnosis the radiation pneumonitis i'm gon na prescribe you a low dose steroid prednisone forty milligrams one tablet a day for five days have you been on on a steroids before
[patient] no i've only ever heard bad things about them they make people jittery and gain weight
[doctor] i mean and and i for you that's that that's for patients that you know who are on them for a a long period of time right you're only gon na be on it for five days that should n't affect you too bad you might feel when you coming off of it after the five days a few muscle aches other than that you should be fine you should n't really experience much weight gain other other than not not much at all since you're only on on it for five days so but that's gon na help you reduce some of the inflammation in your lungs help you breathe better so we can continue the radiation treatment because we definitely need to do that because our most important thing right now is to try to decrease the size of that tumor okay and then for your third issue the oddy ophagia or it come terms the painful swallowing right you said you had that from the from the radiation so that's from the inflammation of your lungs that's kinda creeping up to your esophagus that's why you're you're feeling that pain so i'm gon na prescribe you a lidocaine squishy and swallow you can do that four times a day and so you'll do it and you'll be able to eat immediately afterwards because it would do some of that pain free from swallowing and that will help you taking liquids and food because we definitely need you well off it and and and hydrated while you're going through this cancer therapy okay
[patient] okay
[doctor] alright so do you have any questions for me

[doctor] alright so we will get you those medications those prescriptions and then we will see you back in two weeks
[patient] okay great thank you

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Shortness of breath with minimal exertion
- History of present illness: Stage III non-small cell lung cancer, currently undergoing neoadjuvant chemotherapy and radiation; reports increased shortness of breath over the weekend, reduced exercise tolerance (previously able to walk a mile daily, now unable to walk down the street), dry cough without phlegm, no fever, no body aches or sinus pain, painful swallowing (odynophagia) localized to the chest, able to tolerate liquids though intake has decreased due to pain, using Ensure and milkshakes for nutrition, no food sticking sensation
- Past medical history: No information provided
- Social history: Active lifestyle prior to current symptoms, lives with husband, has emotional support from husband and daughter
- Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: Normal (no abnormalities noted), pulse oximetry normal
- Physical exam: No cervical or subclavicular lymphadenopathy, heart regular rate and rhythm without murmur, bilateral faint crackles on lung auscultation, erythema present on left anterior chest (consistent with radiation effect), no lower extremity edema
- Test results: Chest X-ray shows mild radiation pneumonitis

A (Assessment):

- Stage III non-small cell lung cancer
- Radiation pneumonitis
- Odynophagia due to radiation-induced esophagitis

P (Plan):

- Continue current chemotherapy regimen (cisplatin and etoposide)
- Continue current radiation therapy (45 Gray)
- Prescribe prednisone 40 mg orally once daily for 5 days for radiation pneumonitis
- Prescribe lidocaine “swish and swallow” four times daily for relief of odynophagia
- Advise to maintain adequate hydration and nutrition
- Outpatient follow-up in two weeks
- No information provided regarding additional tests, referrals, or patient education beyond instructions above

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Sudden visual distortion and blurring of vision
* History of present illness: Decreased vision when reading, straight lines (e.g., door frames) appear crooked, difficulty adjusting to dim lights (especially when dining out), reports the symptoms are recent/sudden in onset
* Social history: Smokes one pack of cigarettes per day, has attempted to stop but has been unsuccessful
* Past medical history: Hypertension, takes blood pressure medication but reports inconsistent adherence to self-monitoring
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Physical exam: Anterior segment: posterior chamber intraocular lenses in both eyes; right eye cornea clear, cup to disc 0.2; fundus examination right eye: attached retina 360°, RPE changes in fovea, drusen in macula, thickening of retina, subretinal fluid and exudate accumulation, presence of hemorrhage; left eye cornea clear, cup to disc 0.3, RPE changes in fovea, no hemorrhage or subretinal fluid, retina attached
* Test results: OCT shows drusen deposit, RPE changes, subretinal fluid accumulation, choroidal neovascular membrane in right eye; fluorescein angiography shows focal areas of leakage in right eye consistent with neovascular age-related macular degeneration
* Vital signs: No information provided

A (Assessment):

* Neovascular (wet) age-related macular degeneration, right eye

P (Plan):

* Administer intravitreal Lucentis injection once per month to right eye
* Advise regular injections over time, with counseling that treatment may slow progression but vision loss may still progress
* Recommend patient regularly monitor blood pressure and keep a log
* No information provided regarding additional testing, referrals, or follow-up interval beyond injection schedule

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Right flank pain radiating to groin for the last two weeks
- History of present illness: Intermittent right flank pain radiating to groin, occasional increase in intensity (NRS 1–2/10 most of the time, up to 4/10 during bouts), pain also radiated once to right testicle, no pain with urination, no visible blood in urine, prior episode of chills but no fever, no nausea or vomiting, pain somewhat relieved by ibuprofen
- Past medical history: Prior history of kidney stones (passed spontaneously and surgically removed in past)
- Family history: Family history of kidney stones
- Social history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: Blood pressure elevated (exact value not provided)
- Physical exam: Abdomen non-tender to palpation, right costovertebral angle (CVA) tenderness present
- Test results: CT scan shows 0.5 cm stone in proximal right ureter, no hydronephrosis
- Other tests: No information provided

A (Assessment):

- Kidney stone (right proximal ureteral stone, 0.5 cm)
- No evidence of hydronephrosis
- Infection not suspected but to be ruled out pending urinalysis/culture

P (Plan):

- Continue increased fluid intake to facilitate stone passage
- Continue ibuprofen as needed for pain
- Prescribe tramadol 50 mg for breakthrough pain
- Continue use of urine strainer to catch stone
- Order basic metabolic panel (BMP), urinalysis, and urine culture
- Follow up in 1–2 weeks; reevaluate if persistent symptoms or inability to pass stone, consider further treatment (including possible lithotripsy)
- Nurse to provide prescription for tramadol
