SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Weight gain, acne, constipation, feet swelling
- History of present illness: Patient reports weight gain, inquires if prior birth control could have caused it; reports failed switch to new thyroid medication due to cost and is still taking previous one; acne persists; has not previously used clindamycin topical; experiences constipation (uses Miralax as previously recommended); feet swelling reported; sensitive skin with rashes to various products
- Social history: Plans to restart gym in July, received meal plans at prior visit, aiming to improve diet, reports being more available for exercise after July 8, alcohol avoidance discussed
- Allergies: No known drug allergies
- Family history: Cousin with thyroid issue

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: No information provided
- Physical exam: Lungs and heart sounds normal on auscultation, feet and ankles unremarkable on exam (no current swelling or abnormalities noted)
- Test results:
    - Dexamethasone suppression test passed (no evidence of Cushing's syndrome)
    - Salivary cortisol: 2 of 3 normal, 1 abnormal (repeat may be needed)
    - Androgen levels (testosterone, DHEAS) normal
    - Growth hormone normal
    - Total cholesterol 222 mg/dL (elevated; desirable <200)
    - HDL cholesterol 44 mg/dL (low; desired >50)
    - LDL cholesterol 153 mg/dL (high; should be <100)
    - Non-HDL cholesterol 178 mg/dL (high; should be <130)
    - Diabetes screening normal
    - Vitamin D deficiency identified
    - Liver enzymes: ALT improved from 254 (Oct) → 128 (Jan) → 30 (recent), returned to normal after discontinuing birth control
    - Iron and pituitary hormones within normal limits

A (Assessment):

- Abnormal liver enzymes, improved since discontinuing birth control
- Abnormal weight gain; Cushing's syndrome ruled out based on normal dexamethasone suppression test and salivary cortisol results
- Hirsutism: Androgen levels normal
- Acne vulgaris
- Vitamin D deficiency
- Hypothyroidism

P (Plan):

- Prescribe benzoyl peroxide and clindamycin gel separately for acne vulgaris
- Continue vitamin D supplementation; after finishing current dose, start 2,000 IU daily for maintenance
- Print out prescription for Unithroid with discount card; advise patient to compare pharmacy prices and try different pharmacies if needed
- Discontinue previous hypothyroidism medication when able to switch to Unithroid affordably
- Low carb, low cholesterol diet; avoid alcohol and fatty foods
- Miralax recommended for constipation
- Consider weight loss study (provide research contact info and eligibility criteria)
- Alternative contraception: Option for Fexie (spermicidal) offered
- Monitor feet for swelling; report any worsening
- Repeat labs prior to next visit (comprehensive metabolic panel, thyroid, cholesterol, vitamin D, and other relevant tests)
- Discussed supplements: Chromium, CLA, and amino acids not specifically recommended for weight loss
- Outpatient follow-up as needed and after labs are obtained

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Follow-up for chronic congestive heart failure with diastolic dysfunction and preoperative evaluation for right knee replacement
- History of present illness: Increased dyspnea earlier this spring, now improved following switch from furosemide to torsemide; approximately 3–3.5 lbs weight loss since April (possible water weight); using oxybutynin with improved urinary urgency; occasional leg cramps relieved by small amounts of pickle juice; no current heartburn issues after short-term use of Prilosec in January; no bowel or urinary complaints; reports being on iron supplement; no family history of colon cancer
- Social history: No information provided
- Past medical history: Chronic congestive heart failure, anemia (history), type 2 diabetes (A1c 5.5 in March, last check 5.1), previous HPI mentions interest in right knee replacement, scheduled surgery June 24
- Family history: No family history of colon cancer

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: Blood pressure within normal limits (exact numbers not provided)
- Physical exam: Lungs clear to auscultation; breathing nonlabored
- Test results: 
    - BNP: 3000 in March, peaked at 6000 in April, recent value pending
    - Creatinine: 0.7, 9.8 (latest value 0.7)
    - BUN: 23 (slightly elevated, possible mild dehydration per physician)
    - Potassium: 3.9
    - Hemoglobin: Within normal limits (no anemia currently)
    - Magnesium: 1.7 (below “two–ish” target range)
    - Blood glucose: 169 (non-fasting on day of visit)
    - A1c: 5.1 (last check)
    - Recent chest x-ray done previously, not repeated
    - EKG: To be repeated today

A (Assessment):

- Chronic congestive heart failure, mixed presentation, with diastolic dysfunction—recent exacerbation improved following medication change
- Preoperative evaluation for right knee replacement scheduled for June 24
- Screening colonoscopy overdue; to be scheduled prior to surgery
- Diabetes, stable (A1c 5.1, no further A1c needed today)
- Magnesium slightly below target; supplementation considered

P (Plan):

- Continue torsemide 20 mg by mouth daily
- Continue lisinopril 10 mg daily
- No potassium supplementation at this time; monitor levels
- Initiate magnesium supplement twice daily to target “two–ish” range
- Repeat EKG today
- No additional blood work needed at present
- Discontinue clopidogrel 1 week prior to surgery
- Preoperative check to be completed within 2 weeks before surgery (first or second week of June)
- Schedule screening colonoscopy at county hospital within next month before insurance changes; options at county or valley medical
- Educate patient to keep reminders for medication and appointments; provide surgical and colonoscopy scheduling guidance
- Follow up as needed; repeat A1c preoperatively if necessary

transcription: [doctor] patrick allen , date of birth 7/7/1977 . new patient visit . past medical history includes gerd , anxiety , depression , here for chronic abdominal pain , he had an abdominal ct on 1/23/2020 . impression is a normal ct of the abdomen . hello , are you mr. allen ? [patient] yes , i am . [doctor] hi , my name is dr. edwards , nice to meet you . [patient] nice to meet you . [doctor] welcome to the gi specialty clinic . [patient] thank you . [doctor] did you have any problems finding this ? [patient] no , i've been here with my sister once before . [doctor] good , so how can i help you today ? the referral i have is for abdominal pain and diarrhea . [patient] right so i've had been having this pain right here in my stomach like right around here . [doctor] so in the area of your mid abdomen just below the belly button ? [patient] correct . i've had the pain on and off for about 2 years . i finally went to the er and a a few months ago and they did a ct scan . [doctor] i saw that . [patient] yeah , they said they did n't really see anything on the scan . [doctor] yes , i agree , it looked normal . [patient] and the problem is i'm either constipated or have explosive diarrhea . [doctor] is the pain there all the time ? [patient] it's a nagging feeling and it just depends , sometimes it bothers me , sometimes it does n't . [doctor] has this been the case over the past 2 years as well ? [patient] more recently in the past couple of months at least with the constipation and diarrhea . [doctor] and before that , how were your bowel movements ? [patient] they were normal . [doctor] okay , so any blood in your stool ? [patient] nope . [doctor] do you feel like you have more constipation or diarrhea ? [patient] probably more constipation . [doctor] okay , so when you're constipated , do you not have a bowel movement or is the stool hard ? [patient] i usually do n't go , but when i do , it's hard . [doctor] and how often do you have a bowel movement when you are constipated ? [patient] about 3-4 times a week it's like when i need to go to the bathroom if i can massage it , it feels like it's moving some and i can eventually go . [doctor] okay and when you have a bowel movement , does the pain change ? [patient] yeah . it gets a little better . [doctor] and are you eating and drinking okay , any nausea or vomiting , heartburn or indigestion ? [patient] none of that . [doctor] okay , so tell me about the diarrhea . how often do you get it ? [patient] it kinda just depends on what i eat . i think i have a very sensitive stomach if i eat pasta with a creamy sauce i'm probably gon na have diarrhea . [doctor] okay and does it happen for multiple days in a row or is it just one time ? [patient] it's usually just one time and then it's over . [doctor] and how has your weight been , any fluctuation ? [patient] no , it's been pretty stable , although i could stand to lose about 25 pounds . [doctor] okay , and is there any family history of gi issues that you know of ? [patient] not that i can think of . well , actually my sister does have problems with her stomach too . she has irritable bowel syndrome and that is kind of what i always thought i had even though i have never been diagnosed with it . [doctor] okay and is there any family history of gi cancer or liver disease ? [patient] no . [doctor] have you ever had any surgeries on your abdomen ? [patient] i have never had any surgery . [doctor] okay , so your gallbladder , appendix , all of those are still intact ? [patient] yep . [doctor] and have you ever had a colonoscopy ? [patient] no . i thought that happened when you turned 50 . [doctor] well that's for colon cancer screening , but there are other reasons to have a colonoscopy like unexplained abdominal pain and changes in bowel habits . [patient] okay . [doctor] well , come have a seat here and lay back so i can examine you . [patient] okay . [doctor] i'm gon na start by listening to your belly with my stethoscope . [patient] okay . [doctor] and i hear bowel sounds in all four quadrants . [patient] what does that mean , is everything okay ? [doctor] it just means that i can hear little noises in all areas of your belly , which means your bowels are active and working . [patient] okay , good . [doctor] so now i'm going to push on your upper and lower abdomen , let me know if you have any pain . [patient] it hurts a little when you push right there on the left side near my belly button . [doctor] okay , i do feel stool in your lower colon which would coincide with constipation but i also feel a slight enlargement of your liver here on the upper right side . have you had any lab work done recently ? [patient] yes . i had a physical about 4 months ago and they i had blood drawn then . [doctor] okay and did your primary care physician say anything about the lab results ? [patient] he said i had some very slightly elevated liver enzymes but we would recheck them in about 6 months . [doctor] and do you remember what enzymes were elevated , alt , ast , alp ? [patient] he said the alt and the ast were elevated . [doctor] and do you take any medications either prescription or over the counter ? [patient] i take crestor and , and olmesartan daily and then tylenol for occasional , occasional pain . [doctor] and how frequently do you take the tylenol ? [patient] hardly ever , maybe once a month . [doctor] and do you consume alcohol ? [patient] yes , but only a couple of beers after working in the yard on saturdays . [doctor] okay and no previous history of heavy alcohol or drug use ? [patient] no . [doctor] and have you had any recent issues with excessive bruising or bleeding ? [patient] nope . [doctor] and how about any issues with your ankles or feet swelling ? [patient] no . [doctor] okay , i'm gon na take a look at your eyes and skin . i do n't see any jaundice . [patient] what would cause that ? [doctor] issues with your liver . let me take a quick listen to your heart and lungs . [patient] okay . [doctor] lungs are clear bilateral . heart sounds are normal . no murmurs , gallops , or rubs noted . [patient] that's good . [doctor] yes , the rest of your physical exam is normal other than what seems to be an increased stool burden in your colon and a slight hepatomegaly . [patient] what's that ? [doctor] increased stool burden means that there is a lot of stool sitting in your colon . [patient] and that's the constipation , right ? but what about the other thing ? [doctor] the hepatomegaly means the liver is enlarged . [patient] but you said mom was slightly enlarged . [doctor] correct . [patient] so what does that mean ? [doctor] well , let's talk about what we found and then some possible next steps if you're in agreement . [patient] okay . [doctor] so as i said , the hepatomegaly means your liver is enlarged . [patient] could that be why my stomach is hurting and i'm having issues with the constipation and diarrhea ? [doctor] no , i think you're constipated and have occasional bouts of diarrhea because of certain foods you eat and we can get you started right away on a fiber supplement that should help with that . [patient] so what about my liver , why is it enlarged ? [doctor] well , there are many reasons why people can have an elevated liver enzymes and also an enlarged liver . some possible causes are certain medications that can be toxic to the liver . alcohol abuse , fatty liver disease , hepatitis , cirrhosis , and other liver diseases like wilson's disease . [patient] so what do i need to do ? [doctor] well , i think since it's been about 4 months since your blood work was done , we should check your liver enzymes in addition to a few other labs . [patient] okay and then what ? [doctor] we will get those drawn today and then depending upon the results , you may need an ultrasound of your liver . i think we need to talk about your medications too . [patient] which medications ? [doctor] crestor , how long have you been taking that ? [patient] about 18 months . [doctor] okay , well crestor is one of the medications that can cause liver toxicity , so it may be a good idea to discuss other alternatives . [patient] should i talk to my primary care or can you change it ? [doctor] i would recommend calling your primary care and discuss that with him since he follows you for your blood pressure and cholesterol . [patient] okay . i'll call him this afternoon . [doctor] great . i also think we should go ahead and get you scheduled for a liver ultrasound . if your blood work looks good , then we can always cancel that . [patient] okay . when do you think i'll be able to get the ultrasound done ? [doctor] hopefully within the next 2 weeks , you will receive a call from the radiology scheduling this afternoon to get it set up . [patient] okay and then what happens ? [doctor] when i get the results from the tests , i'll contact you and depending upon what we find , we'll come up with our next steps . [patient] and when should i see you again ? [doctor] let's schedule an appointment when you check out to return in 4 weeks . we'll discuss how you're doing with the fiber supplement and your constipation and review test results to determine if we need to do further testing on your liver . [patient] okay . is there anything else i can do to help with these issues ? [doctor] definitely refrain from drinking any alcohol , increase your water intake to at least 48 ounces a day , in addition to taking the fiber supplement to help with your constipation and be mindful of eating foods that you are sensitive to so you can avoid the bouts of diarrhea . [patient] okay and i will talk to my primary care about my crestor . [doctor] excellent and do you have any other questions for me ? [patient] i do n't think so . [doctor] great . so remember when you check out at the front desk , schedule a follow-up appointment with me for 4 weeks and then go to the lab to get your blood work drawn . [patient] okay , sounds good . [doctor] and expect a call from radiology scheduling about setting up your ultrasound . [patient] alright . thanks dr. edwards . [doctor] thank you mr. allen .
SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Chronic abdominal pain, diarrhea
- History of present illness: Mid-abdominal pain just below the belly button, present on and off for about 2 years; worsened in past couple months with alternating constipation (more frequent) and episodes of explosive diarrhea (typically triggered by creamy foods, single episodes, not multiple days). Pain is nagging, sometimes better after a bowel movement. Constipation described as infrequent, hard stools (3-4 times/week), requiring abdominal massage to assist passage. No blood in stool. No associated nausea, vomiting, heartburn, or indigestion. No weight loss or gain.
- Past medical history: GERD, anxiety, depression
- Family history: Sister with irritable bowel syndrome; no family history of GI cancer or liver disease
- Social history: Drinks a couple of beers on Saturdays after working in the yard; denies heavy alcohol or drug use; no prior abdominal surgeries, no prior colonoscopy
- Medications: Crestor, olmesartan daily, occasional Tylenol (about once a month)
- Allergies: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: No information provided
- Physical exam: Bowel sounds present in all four quadrants; mild tenderness on palpation of the left side near belly button; increased stool burden palpable in lower colon (consistent with constipation); slight hepatomegaly noted; no jaundice observed; clear lungs bilaterally; normal heart sounds (no murmurs, gallops, or rubs); no ankle or foot swelling
- Test results: Abdominal CT (1/23/2020) normal; recent lab work (4 months ago) showed slightly elevated ALT and AST liver enzymes
- Additional observations: No excessive bruising or bleeding

A (Assessment):

- Chronic constipation and diarrhea
- Hepatomegaly
- Elevated liver enzymes, etiology to be determined (possible medication-induced, requires further evaluation)

P (Plan):

- Prescribe fiber supplement for constipation
- Advise increase of water intake to at least 48 ounces a day
- Counsel to refrain from alcohol consumption
- Dietary advice to avoid foods triggering diarrhea
- Order repeat liver enzyme tests and additional laboratory work today
- Schedule for liver ultrasound within 2 weeks (to be canceled if labs normalize)
- Recommendation to discuss alternative to Crestor with primary care physician
- Follow-up appointment in 4 weeks to assess response to fiber supplement and review test results
- Outpatient follow-up call from radiology to schedule ultrasound
- No information provided regarding patient education materials or other referrals

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Routine follow-up for chronic conditions
- History of present illness: Reports increased fatigue, particularly after long bike rides (20–30 miles), unable to ride as fast or as far as in previous years, needs to rest after returning home; notes friends/family have observed pursed lips when breathing; no associated wheezing; continues regular exercise (biking, swimming)
- Additional concerns: Noticed a small nodule on the right testicle; unsure if it is testicular or epididymal; denies vasectomy; not overly concerned, but requests evaluation
- Sleep: Sleeps 6–7 hours per night; variable schedule due to work; sometimes wakes early for exercise; wife has noted mild snoring but no episodes of apnea
- Past medical history: Aortic valve replacement and ascending aortic aneurysm repair (1/22/2013)
- Social history: Engages in regular physical activity (cycling, swimming)
- Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: No information provided
- Physical exam: Pursed lips breathing, low exhalation phase; lungs clear to auscultation, no wheezing; right testicle with 2–3 mm palpable nodule, left testicle normal, no hernia, no evidence of epididymal or varicocele involvement; remainder of exam within normal limits
- Test results: 4/10/2021 labs: alkaline phosphatase 156 (elevated), total cholesterol 247 (elevated), HDL 66, LDL 166 (elevated), triglycerides 74, TSH 2.68 (normal), CBC unremarkable, vitamin D 94 (high-normal)
- Vaccination status: COVID-19 vaccine completed (first dose 1/15/2021, second dose 2/5/2021)

A (Assessment):

- History of aortic valve replacement and ascending aortic aneurysm repair (1/22/2013), currently well and asymptomatic
- Elevated alkaline phosphatase, most likely related to bone health but liver involvement considered
- Lung field abnormality: pursed lips breathing, low exhalation phase on exam; ordered pulmonary function test for further evaluation
- Right testicular nodule (2–3 mm), suggests possible further evaluation by urology
- Hyperlipidemia (elevated total cholesterol and LDL)
- Preventive health: due for MMR and shingles vaccines

P (Plan):

- Order echocardiogram and stress test
- Follow-up with cardiology (suggested Dr. Vincent Sanchez)
- Repeat alkaline phosphatase and add gamma-glutamyl transferase (GGT) testing
- Order pulmonary function test
- Refer to urology for right testicular nodule and possible ultrasound
- Administer MMR vaccine today; schedule shingles vaccine next month
- Repeat lipid panel as appropriate
- Continue vitamin D3 supplementation as currently prescribed
- Prescribe clindamycin prior to dental procedures as per protocol
- Routine labs today, results to be communicated via patient portal unless urgent
- Return for annual wellness visit in 1 year; sooner follow-up if new concerns or abnormal test results
- Patient to call with any questions or concerns

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Anxiety and breast lumps
- History of present illness: Anxiety was severe in November and December, now improved with Buspar; previously experienced increased anxiety before her period and at random times, not sure if related to Singulair (which she had started at that time), work-related stress during COVID-19 pandemic noted as a trigger, guilt regarding not being on the "front lines". Reports lumps in left breast, with soreness, history of clog and persistent lumps since breastfeeding; lumps feel smaller but persist. Reports increased hunger after stopping Camilla birth control, some weight loss over past 6 months. No other current issues.
- Medication history: Started Buspar recently, previously on Singulair (aware it may cause anxiety), currently using cream (type not specified) once a week for vaginal itching/discomfort, requests refill. Previously took Camilla birth control and progesterone for period regulation.
- Past medical history: History of abnormal pap in 2009, monitored every 6 months, later returned to normal.
- Family history: Mother diagnosed with breast cancer at age 45.
- Social history: Received COVID-19 vaccine; son also vaccinated. Husband and daughter are unvaccinated and express concerns about vaccination.

O (Objective):

- Physical exam: Face appears thinner; palpable small bumps in neck; left breast feels denser with palpable persistent lumps, tenderness in lower outer quadrant, lumps feel smaller than before; vaginal/groin area appears normal; patient subjectively reports improvement in itching/discomfort with cream.
- Vital signs: No information provided
- Test results: Last pap smear in 2019 was “negative, negative”; no other test results provided.

A (Assessment):

- Anxiety, currently well-controlled on Buspar
- Persistent benign breast lumps (possible cysts or fibroadenomas, per discussion)
- History of abnormal pap smear, now resolved
- Increased risk for breast issues (family history of breast cancer, surveillance ongoing)
- Vaginal itching/discomfort, controlled with topical cream

P (Plan):

- Continue Buspar as prescribed
- Refill prescription for topical cream for vaginal itching/discomfort
- Repeat pap smear
- Refer to breast specialist for further evaluation of persistent lumps (possible ultrasound or further work-up)
- Monitor breast lumps with regular surveillance
- Follow-up as needed or as per specialist recommendation
- Patient education and reassurance regarding breast surveillance and risk
- No additional interventions at this time unless new symptoms arise

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Here to establish care for history of DCIS (ductal carcinoma in situ) of right breast following lumpectomy.
- History of present illness: Status post right breast lumpectomy on January 20, 2020 for DCIS; no current problems or concerns, no palpable changes on self-exam, last mammogram in January 2021 normal.
- Past medical history: High cholesterol (recent diagnosis, managed with lifestyle changes), DCIS of right breast (ER/PR positive, grade 2), tubal ligation, back pain and knee pain attributed to age.
- Surgical history: Right breast lumpectomy (2020), removal of five right axillary lymph nodes, tubal ligation after last pregnancy.
- Allergies: Penicillin.
- Medications: CoQ10, vitamin D, vitamin C, fish oil, elderberry fruit.
- Social history: No illicit drug use, social alcohol use only, former smoker (quit ~30 years ago).
- Family history: Mother with non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, father with prostate cancer and heart disease, no family history of breast cancer, no siblings, children healthy.
- Gynecological history: Postmenopausal for approximately 30 years, gravida 5 para 5, no history of hormone replacement therapy, no history of miscarriages or pregnancy terminations.
- Review of systems: Denies recent weight loss/gain, headaches, bone pain, urinary symptoms, or blood in stool; reports back pain and joint pain.
- Colonoscopy in 2018: One benign tubular angioma polyp removed.

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: No information provided.
- Physical exam: Normal new patient exam except for right breast; skin thickening at medial inferior aspect of right breast (likely post-radiation change), no palpable masses.
- Test results: Right breast ultrasound (November 2019) showed mass at 2 o'clock, 11 cm from nipple, 0.4 x 2 x 3 cm in retroareolar region; core needle biopsy (December 2019) showed grade 2, ER/PR positive DCIS; lumpectomy specimen 8 mm with negative surgical and lymph node margins; post-lumpectomy mammogram (January 2021) normal, no evidence of recurrence; colonoscopy (2018): single benign tubular angioma polyp; ECOG performance status 0.

A (Assessment):

- History of stage 0 ER/PR positive DCIS of right breast, status post lumpectomy with negative margins and negative lymph nodes, completed radiation therapy, declined endocrine therapy.
- No clinical or mammographic evidence of malignancy recurrence.
- High cholesterol.
- Age-related back and knee pain.

P (Plan):

- Surveillance for breast cancer: Annual follow-up; order mammogram before next visit (April 2022)
- Continue lifestyle modifications for cholesterol; monitored by primary care.
- Routine health maintenance; follow up in one year.
- Patient education provided regarding self-exam and symptoms to monitor.
- No new medications prescribed at this visit.
- No concerns raised by patient; nurse to discharge.

transcription: [doctor] next patient is sophia jackson , mrnr 472348 . she is a 57-year-old female who is here for a surgical consult . [patient] her dermatologist referred her . she biopsied a 0.7 mm lesion which was located on the right inferior back . pathology came back as melanoma . [doctor] mrs. jackson , it's good to meet you . [patient] likewise , wish you were under better circumstances . [doctor] yeah , i heard your dermatologist sent you to because she found the melanoma . [patient] yes , that's what the biopsy said . [doctor] okay and when did you first notice the spot ? [patient] my mom noticed it when i was visiting her last month . [doctor] i see and so you went to the dermatologist on april 10 to get it checked out , right ? [patient] yes , i wanted to be extra cautious because skin cancer does run in my family . [doctor] well i'm really glad you took a serious and got it checked . who in your family has had skin cancer and do you know if it was melanoma or was it basal cell or squamous cell ? [patient] my mom and her sister i think they both had melanoma . [doctor] okay . do you have any other types of cancer in the family like breast or ovarian ? [patient] my grandfather had pancreatic cancer . [doctor] okay and what about your mom or dad's father ? [patient] mother's . [doctor] okay and have you personally had any skin spots in the past that you got checked out and they were cancerous or precancerous ? [patient] no , this was the first time i've been to a dermatologist but my primary care doctor looks over all of my moles every year . my physical and has n't said he is concerned about any of them before . [doctor] good , good . let's go over your medical history here in your chart . i have that you are not taking any medications and do n't have any health problems listed , but that you are allergic to augmentin , is that right ? [patient] yes , that's correct . [doctor] okay and for social history , can you tell me what you do for work ? [patient] i own an auto repair shop . okay and have you ever been a smoker ? yeah , i still smoke from time to time . i started that awful habit in my teens and it's hard to break , but i'm trying . [doctor] i'm glad you're trying to quit . what about your surgical history ? have you had any surgeries ? [patient] i had gallbladder and appendix . [doctor] okay , great . we can get your chart up to date now , thank you . and other than the melanoma , how has your health been ? any unintentional weight changes , headaches , fatigue , nausea , vomiting , vision changes ? [patient] no , i've been feeling great . [doctor] good . well , let me take a look at your back here where they did the biopsy if you do n't mind . [patient] sure . [doctor] okay . i'm gon na describe it in medical jargon , what i'm seeing here so that the recording can capture it , but you and i are gon na go over it together in just a moment , okay ? [patient] okay , that's fine . [doctor] alright , so on the right inferior back , there is a 1 cm shave biopsy site including all of the dermis with no residual pigmentation there is no intrinsic or satellite lesions . no other suspicious moles . no axillary , cervical or supraclavicular lymphadenopathy . there is a soft lymph node in the right groin but it's nontender . otherwise normal exam . [patient] okay , you can sit up . so what i was saying there is that i see your biopsy site , but i do n't see any other skin lumps or bumps that look suspicious . [doctor] i also felt your lymph nodes to see if any of them felt abnormal . there is one in the right groin that felt slightly abnormal . it's very likely nothing , but i do want you to have an ultrasound of that area to confirm it's nothing . and you know make sure it's something we need to worry about the reason we are being extra cautious is that melanoma can very rarely metastasize to the lymph nodes . the ultrasound can tell us if we need to look into this further . [patient] okay . i should have worried too much then . [doctor] no , i have a low suspicion that it will show anything . [patient] okay , good . [doctor] so assuming that the ultrasound is normal . the treatment for your melanoma is to cut out the area where the lesion was . with lesions that are 0.7 mm or less and that's what we recommend and yours was exactly 0.7 mm . if it were any bigger , we would have had to do a more complex surgery , but what i recommend for you is what we call a wide local incision , excuse me , excision meaning that i will make a long incision and then cut out an area a bit wider than your current biopsy site . the incision is long because that's what allows me to close the skin nicely . you'll have a fairly long scar from the incision . [patient] okay , that is fine with me . i ca n't see back there anyways . [doctor] yeah , your wife can tell you what it looks like and she may need to help care for the incision at it as it heals . but since we're we are n't doing the more complex surgery , i actually do n't need to see you back unless you wan na check in with me or have any problems , however , it is very important that you continue to follow up with your dermatologist regularly , so she can monitor you . your dermatologist will check if this one does n't come back , but she will also check for other lesions that look suspicious . unfortunately since you had one melanoma , you are at a higher risk of developing another one somewhere else . [patient] yeah , she did say she wants to see me back . [doctor] good and i'm sure she has already told you , but it's very important that you apply sunscreen anytime and anywhere that your skin is exposed to sunlight . [patient] yeah , she definitely went over that several times with me . [doctor] good . other than that , i think that's all for me . we'll get you set up for the ultrasound and the procedure . do you have any questions for me ? [patient] no , i ca n't think of any at this time . [doctor] okay . my nurse will be in to get you scheduled . so sit tight . it was very good to meet you . [patient] thank you . nice to meet you as well . [doctor] please add the following pathology to results a pathology , shave of right inferior back , malignant melanoma , invasive superficial spreading , histology , superficial spreading . clark level iv , breslow thickness 0.7 mm , radial growth phase present , vertical growth phase not identified , mitotic features less than 1 mm² , ulceration not identified , regression not identified , [patient] lymphatic invasion not identified . perineural invasion not identified , microscopic satellitosis not identified , infiltrating lymphocytes , breast , [doctor] melanocytic nevus not identified , predominant cytology , epithelioid , peripheral margin positive , deep margin negative , stage i . also note that i reviewed the dermatologist photo of the lesion , which showed an asymmetric black and brown nevus with central asmelanotic component and a regular border . for assessment and plan , the patient presents today with newly diagnosed melanoma . biopsy revealed an intermediate thickness melanoma . on examination today , there is right inguinal lymph node with slightly atypical consistency . [patient] i recommended an ultrasound to rule out metastatic disease . if the ultrasound is normal , the patient is a candidate for wide local excision with a 1 to 2 cm margin . primary closure should be possible , but skin graft closure may be needed . the relationship between tumor histology and prognosis and treatment was carefully reviewed . the need for follow-up according to the national comprehensive cancer network guidelines was reviewed . we also reviewed the principles of sun avoidance , skin self-examination and the abcde's of mole surveillance . after discussing the procedure , risk and expected outcomes and possible complications , questions were answered and the patient expressed understanding and did choose to proceed .
SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Referred by dermatologist for evaluation of melanoma on right inferior back
* History of present illness: Noticed by patient's mother one month ago; biopsy by dermatologist confirmed melanoma, lesion measured 0.7 mm
* Past medical history: No history of skin cancer or precancerous lesions; annual skin checks by primary care physician
* Surgical history: Cholecystectomy and appendectomy
* Medication history: Not taking any medications
* Allergies: Augmentin (amoxicillin/clavulanate)
* Family history: Mother and maternal aunt with melanoma; maternal grandfather with pancreatic cancer
* Social history: Owns an auto repair shop; current occasional smoker (started in teens, attempting to quit)
* Review of systems: Denies unintentional weight changes, headaches, fatigue, nausea, vomiting, vision changes

O (Objective):

* Physical exam: Right inferior back—1 cm shave biopsy site fully including dermis, no residual pigmentation, no intrinsic or satellite lesions, no other suspicious moles, no axillary/cervical/supraclavicular lymphadenopathy, right groin soft lymph node (nontender), otherwise normal exam
* Test results: Dermatologist-provided photo— asymmetric black and brown nevus with central amelanotic component, regular border
* Pathology (right inferior back, shave biopsy): Malignant melanoma, superficial spreading type, invasive, Clark level IV, Breslow thickness 0.7 mm, radial growth phase present, vertical growth phase not identified, mitotic features <1/mm², no ulceration, no regression, no lymphatic or perineural invasion, no microscopic satellitosis, infiltrating lymphocytes present, no melanocytic nevus identified, predominant cytology epithelioid, peripheral margin positive, deep margin negative, stage I

A (Assessment):

* Newly diagnosed melanoma, intermediate thickness, invasive superficial spreading, right inferior back
* Slightly atypical right inguinal lymph node—ultrasound recommended to rule out metastatic disease

P (Plan):

* Order ultrasound of right groin lymph node
* If ultrasound normal, proceed with wide local excision (1–2 cm margin) of melanoma site; primary closure intended, skin graft closure may be needed
* Review pathology and surgical treatment options, including risks, expected outcomes, possible complications
* Advise continued regular dermatology follow-up according to NCCN guidelines
* Counsel on sun protection, skin self-examination, ABCDE mole surveillance
* Patient expressed understanding and consented to planned management
* Nursing staff to schedule ultrasound and procedure

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Ongoing pain and swelling in the right index finger since a motor vehicle accident in March (approximately 3 months ago)
- History of present illness: Hyperextension injury to right index finger during motor vehicle accident as a passenger; persistent pain, swelling, inability to make a fist, and occasional severe pain, worsened by use including driving; history of occupational and physical therapy; MRI performed; concerns about partial tendon tear; previous providers recommended but deferred steroid injection and surgery; patient reports some numbness and difficulty with finger movement
- Past medical history: No diabetes, no rheumatoid arthritis
- Medication history: Takes blood pressure medication chronically; experienced itching with methylprednisolone and heart racing with dexamethasone
- Social history: Works as an x-ray technician; right-handed
- Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: Heart rate regular, 2+ radial pulse
- Physical exam: Pleasant, cooperative male, no distress; right index finger with no swelling or bruising over the volar surface or palm; normal creases except tip of index finger (slightly diminished); finger rests in 10 degree PIP flexion, discomfort with passive correction; numbness reported over the finger; pain with forced flexion and PIP movement; able to perform some flexion and extension; collateral ligaments and extensor tendons intact; no swelling or bruising noted on current exam
- Test results:
    - MRI (4/24/2021): Focal soft tissue swelling over right index MCP joint, partial thickness tear of right FDS, fluid compatible with tenosynovitis around FDP and FDS, intact radial/ulnar collateral ligaments and MCP joint capsule, intact extensor tendons
    - X-ray (today, 4 views of right hand): No bony abnormalities, joint congruency maintained throughout digits, no soft tissue shadows of concern, no arthritis
- Injection procedure: First attempt at trigger finger injection with 1 cc Celestone + 0.5 cc lidocaine aborted due to dramatic painful reaction; second attempt performed using same technique, minor palmar vein bleed, cleaned and bandaged

A (Assessment):

- Posttraumatic rather severe stenosing tenosynovitis of the right index finger
- Partial thickness tear of right flexor digitorum superficialis (FDS) tendon

P (Plan):

- Trigger finger injection with 1 cc Celestone (betamethasone) and 0.5 cc lidocaine (attempted, limited success)
- Counsel patient regarding therapeutic steroid benefit; recommend icing area and ibuprofen this evening
- Refer to occupational/physical therapy for outpatient therapy once a week for 6 weeks
- Encourage full active and passive range of motion exercises with no restrictions
- Reassure patient regarding minor injection bleeding and safety to drive
- Follow-up as needed, may consider repeat injection if necessary

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Right hip/groin pain
- History of present illness: Right groin pain since February 2020, initially started while walking in an infusion room; pain occurs with movement, particularly when pivoting or taking a step back; frequency and severity vary (pain sometimes occurs several times in a row), sometimes leads to almost falling; pain is rated 2-7/10; improves with rest, but patient prefers to remain active; denies fever, chills, tingling, numbness, or bowel/bladder dysfunction; intentional weight loss of 110 pounds since 2018 with Weight Watchers, current weight maintained for over a year
- Past medical history: Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), history of infertility, cholecystectomy (gallbladder removed), history of bulging lumbar disks
- Family history: Hypertension, diabetes, thyroid disease, heart disease, kidney disease, gastric ulcers
- Social history: Works at an infusion center, lives with roommate, no tobacco use, alcohol intake less than five drinks per month
- Current medications: None
- Allergies: Percocet, Vicodin, Reglan

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: Blood pressure 115/75 mmHg, pulse 67/min
- General: Pleasant 56-year-old woman, 5 feet 6 inches, 169 pounds
- Physical exam: No ankle edema, no calf tenderness, cervical spine exam normal (full range of motion, no pain, Spurling's test negative), lumbar spine exam normal (no tenderness, intact skin, range of motion decreased on exertion but not painful, lateral flexion without pain), no sacroiliac tenderness, hips: right trochanteric nontender, pain in right groin with internal and external rotation and with resisted right hip flexion, decreased range of motion in right hip, motor control and sensation intact in lower extremities, no focal motor weakness, no focal sensory deficit, deep tendon reflexes 1+ throughout
- Test results: MR arthrogram of right hip (June 3, 2021): high grade chondromalacia involving anterosuperior right acetabulum, subchondral marrow edema, and cyst formation

A (Assessment):

- Right hip degenerative joint disease

P (Plan):

- Initiate low impact exercise program (provide exercise handout)
- NSAIDs as needed for pain and discomfort
- Use of a cane to offload the right side
- Cortisone injection into the right hip joint today after obtaining informed consent
- Review risks of injection (including needle, sterile technique, COVID-related risks)
- Schedule follow-up in 3 months to assess response and consider additional injection if needed
- No information provided regarding surgical plan beyond above documentation

SOAP:

- Chief complaint: Left arm pain
- History of present illness: Pain began 2 weeks ago, first noted waking at 2:00 AM, described as severe and episodic, initially improved with ice and arm positioning. Occurred multiple nights, resulting in bothersome symptoms during the following day if experienced at night. Pain starts in the hand and radiates down the left arm. Recent improvement noted in neck pain, but hand symptoms persist. No aggravation of arm pain with neck or shoulder movement except mild neck strain with certain positions.

- Social history: No information provided
- Family history: No information provided

- Test results: Cervical x-rays (6/4/2021): Significant disc degeneration at C5-6, lesser at C4-5 and C3-4, significant lower lumbar facet arthropathy, C6-7 and C7-T1 difficult to visualize

A (Assessment):

- Left upper extremity neuropathy suspicious for cervical radiculopathy, possible contribution of peripheral neuropathy
- Neck pain in the setting of arthritis, disc degeneration

P (Plan):

- Order cervical MRI to assess for nerve root compression
- Tentatively plan for left C7-T1 epidural pending MRI results
- Continue home exercise program
- Continue gabapentin twice daily
- Outpatient follow-up after imaging and intervention to assess symptom relief
- No information provided regarding additional recommendations, referrals, or patient education

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Shortness of breath
- History of present illness: Shortness of breath for a couple of weeks, worse upon waking, occurs at home and during activity; coughing up blood (3–4 cups/day) for about 3 weeks, only when coughing and not associated with other bleeding; denies bruising, bleeding from gums, or other sites. No fever reported.
- Past medical history: Diabetes, hypertension, asthma, chronic knee pain without swelling
- Medications: Metformin (current dose 500 mg twice daily), Norvasc (taken intermittently due to low blood pressure)
- Social history: No recent travel; denied recent hospital or ER visits for current complaints.
- Family history: No information provided.

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: Oxygen saturation 94% on room air in clinic, blood pressure 120/70 mmHg (reported to drop to lower 90s at times)
- Physical exam: No jugular venous distention, no neck swelling, no carotid bruits, lungs with rales and rhonchi (more pronounced on right side), diminished breath sounds on right side, no wheezing; heart regular rate and rhythm, 2/6 systolic ejection murmur (unchanged from previous), abdomen soft, 1+ nonpitting edema on both ankles, no calf tenderness, negative Homan's sign
- Test results: Last hemoglobin A1c approximately 7.7%; home blood sugars: fasting around 150 mg/dL, postprandial over 200 mg/dL (past month)

A (Assessment):

- Shortness of breath, etiology to be determined (possible infection, blood clot, or other pulmonary process)
- Hemoptysis
- Poorly controlled diabetes
- Hypertension, currently on hold due to episodes of low blood pressure
- History of asthma

P (Plan):

- Refer to emergency department for chest x-ray, chest CT scan, and blood testing (to evaluate shortness of breath and hemoptysis, rule out infection or blood clot)
- Hold Norvasc for now; reassess hypertension management after acute event
- Order repeat hemoglobin A1c
- Increase metformin dose from 500 mg twice daily to 750 mg twice daily after acute issue is addressed
- Outpatient follow-up in 3 weeks to reassess diabetes and blood pressure management
- No information provided regarding specific patient education or additional referrals

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Follow-up after inferior STEMI and stent placement
* History of present illness: Recent episode of chest pain similar to prior event, prompting emergency department visit and additional stent placement; currently denies chest pain or shortness of breath since hospitalization
* Past medical history: Coronary artery disease, hypertension, diabetes mellitus, prior RCA stent placement (2018), inferior STEMI with recent stent placement
* Social history: Regularly walks dog 1.5-2 miles daily, able to afford medications, good insurance, no dietary restrictions currently; enjoys pizza (pepperoni) and fries; reports attempts at salt and sugar control
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Within normal limits
* Physical exam: Neck—no jugular venous distension, no carotid bruits; Cardiac—grade 3/6 systolic ejection murmur at left base; Lungs—clear; Extremities—1+ pitting lower limb edema; Right radial artery cath site—clean, dry, intact, pulses palpable
* Test results: EKG—normal sinus rhythm, good R wave progression, anticipated evolutionary changes post-STEMI; Echocardiogram—reduced ejection fraction (35%), moderate mitral regurgitation; Labs—No information provided

A (Assessment):

* Coronary artery disease
* Newly reduced left ventricular dysfunction (EF 35%), moderate mitral regurgitation
* Acute heart failure
* Hypertension

P (Plan):

* Continue aspirin 81 mg daily, Brilinta 90 mg twice daily, atorvastatin (Lipitor) 80 mg daily, metoprolol succinate (Toprol) 50 mg daily, lisinopril 20 mg daily
* Start furosemide (Lasix) 40 mg daily and spironolactone (Aldactone) 12.5 mg daily
* Referral to cardiac rehabilitation
* Repeat echocardiogram in approximately 2 months
* Obtain laboratory studies to monitor therapy and safety
* Nutrition counseling focusing on salt and preserved meat restriction; dietary modification suggestions
* Ongoing monitoring and follow-up

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Right knee injury after playing soccer
- History of present illness: Felt a pop in the right knee three days ago during a soccer game, associated with swelling (partially improved), functional limitation, pain (initially 6–7/10, currently 4–5/10 with decreased swelling), knee feels loose, difficulty bending (hurts at end of motion), difficulty straightening (needs assistance), able to bear weight but with marked limp, uses ibuprofen regularly with some relief
- Social history: Habitual jogger, desk job but currently sitting is uncomfortable
- No information provided: Past medical history, family history

O (Objective):

- Physical exam: Marked limp noted with ambulation, significant effusion in right knee, slight ecchymosis, pain to palpation at medial joint line, decreased passive range of motion (lacking a few degrees of terminal extension to about 115 degrees, lacking 20–30 degrees of terminal flexion), positive Lachman exam, neurovascular status intact in bilateral lower extremities, muscle strength 5/5
- No information provided: Vital signs, test results

A (Assessment):

- Anterior cruciate ligament tear, suspected (right knee)

P (Plan):

- Order MRI of right knee to evaluate ACL integrity
- Prescribe meloxicam 15 mg orally once daily
- Advise using ice for swelling and pain as needed
- Recommend activity modification, use knee immobilizer, and crutches when ambulating
- Advise against jogging until further evaluation
- Counsel to limit work and physical activities as tolerated, with periodic gentle movement to prevent stiffness
- Outpatient follow-up after MRI to reevaluate management plan

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Concern about number of medications, occasional dizziness upon standing, request for medication refills, feeling down since heart attack
- History of present illness: Reports dizziness when standing up quickly, denies chest pain or shortness of breath, states legs feel puffy; expresses feeling down and lonely since heart attack, no suicidal or homicidal thoughts
- Past medical history: Myocardial infarction (heart attack) approximately six months ago with stent placement in left anterior descending artery, stage 3 chronic kidney disease, diabetes mellitus
- Social history: Lives alone with dog, reports loneliness, retiring
- Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: Blood pressure 127/80 mmHg
- Physical exam: No jugular venous distention, no carotid bruits, 3/6 systolic ejection murmur at left base, 1+ nonpitting edema in lower extremities
- Test results: Creatinine/kidney function stable, hemoglobin A1c "close to 16", fasting glucose approximately 130 mg/dL
- Medications: Aspirin, Brilinta, fish oil, Crestor (rosuvastatin), metoprolol (50 mg once daily)

A (Assessment):

- Coronary artery disease with post-stent placement, doing well
- Stage 3 chronic kidney disease
- Diabetes mellitus, poor glycemic control
- Possible mild depression, difficulty adjusting after heart attack

P (Plan):

- Cardiac rehab referral
- Medication refills: metoprolol, Crestor 40 mg once daily, aspirin
- Continue Brilinta for another 6 months
- Avoid NSAIDs (Motrin, Advil); may use Tylenol for headaches
- Referral to nephrologist for CKD follow-up
- Order repeat hemoglobin A1c and referral for diabetic dietitian education; consult with primary care physician regarding insulin regimen
- Referral to psychiatry for mood support and difficulty adjusting post-MI
- Advise to report any chest pain or shortness of breath
- Outpatient follow-up as needed
- No information provided regarding family history

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Numbness and tingling in right hand
* History of present illness: Numbness and tingling in right hand, present on and off for six months, recently more persistent over the last month; some pain, chiefly when typing or using mouse; numbness and tingling are now constant; pain alleviated by rest and worsened by typing and mouse usage; ibuprofen is taken for pain; no nocturnal symptoms or sleep disturbance reported
* Past medical history: No information provided
* Social history: Sits at keyboard all day for work (data entry)
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Physical exam: Pain on wrist flexion and extension, decreased grip strength in right hand, positive Tinel's sign at right wrist, numbness in right thumb, index, and middle fingers; symptoms not present in ring or little finger
* Vital signs: No information provided
* Test results: No information provided

A (Assessment):

* Carpal tunnel syndrome

P (Plan):

* Prescribe wrist splint to be worn at night
* Increase ibuprofen to 600 mg four times daily
* Order outpatient EMG (nerve conduction study) for right wrist
* Reassess after nerve conduction study to consider possible physical therapy or surgical intervention if indicated
* Conservative treatment prioritized; surgical release considered if EMG supports diagnosis and symptoms persist
* Follow-up at next visit after test results
* Patient education provided; questions addressed

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Evaluation of kidney stones
- History of present illness: Sudden onset right-sided back pain about one week ago while working in the barn, initially thought related to lifting hay; associated with sweating and nausea. Pain radiated almost to groin. Pain has recurred a few times but is currently resolved. Has been straining urine with no visible stone passage or hematuria observed. No prior history of kidney stones.
- Family history: Father has had kidney stones.
- Past medical history: No information provided
- Social history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: No fever, blood pressure and heart rate within normal limits
- Physical exam: Abdomen non-tender without rebound or guarding, right costovertebral angle (CVA) tenderness present
- Test results: CT scan shows a 0.5 cm stone in the proximal right ureter, no hydronephrosis
- Additional tests: No information provided

A (Assessment):

- Right ureteral kidney stone

P (Plan):

- Prescribe oxycodone 5 mg every 6–8 hours as needed for pain
- Continue acetaminophen (Tylenol) as needed for breakthrough pain
- Encourage increased fluid intake to facilitate stone passage
- Continue straining urine until stone passes
- Order basic metabolic panel (BMP), urinalysis, and urine culture
- Return visit in 1–2 weeks or earlier if symptoms worsen or stone does not pass
- If stone not passed by follow-up, consider discussing further treatment options including lithotripsy

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Pain on the inside of right knee after playing basketball
- History of present illness: Injured right knee 7 days ago when another player ran into her during basketball, causing her to fall to the ground and land on her side; not able to continue playing; pain localized to the medial aspect of the right knee; denied hearing or feeling a pop during injury; using ice, ace wrap, exercises, and Motrin for pain management
- Past medical history: Diabetes
- Medications: Metformin 500 mg twice daily
- Social history: Recreational basketball at the YMCA; family owns a sporting goods store; no mention of tobacco or alcohol use
- Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: No information provided
- Physical exam: Right knee swollen, ecchymosis and small effusion noted on medial aspect, tenderness to palpation on medial aspect, pain with movement; decreased range of motion; negative varus and valgus stress tests
- Test results: Right knee X-ray: bony alignment in good position, no fracture, small effusion present

A (Assessment):

- Medial collateral ligament strain of right knee, suspected
- Diabetes

P (Plan):

- Discontinue current NSAIDs (Motrin/Advil)
- Prescribe meloxicam 15 mg daily for pain and swelling
- Continue use of ice and ace wrap
- Apply right knee brace for a few days
- Initiate physical therapy for right knee strengthening
- Encourage light walking/exercise as tolerated
- Monitor blood glucose daily; continue metformin as prescribed
- Advise patient to contact primary care physician if significant increase in blood sugar occurs due to limited activity
- Schedule follow-up appointment in 7 days to reassess knee; consider CT or MRI if swelling persists or worsens
- No basketball or strenuous knee activity for at least 7 days

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Severe left back pain, started about three days ago
- History of present illness: Constant pain starting in left back, radiating lower toward groin, not passed stone yet, unable to get comfortable, visible blood in urine this morning, history of two prior kidney stone episodes (this is third), prior stones usually passed in 3-4 days, some chills, poor appetite, mild nausea, no fever, no chest pain, no abdominal pain
- Past medical history: Hypertension, diabetes, recurrent kidney stones
- Medications taken: Tylenol and ibuprofen for pain; Norvasc 2.5 mg for hypertension; metformin 500 mg for diabetes
- Social history: Reports liking and eating French fries; working to reduce salt intake; could use help with dietary changes
- Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: Blood pressure on arrival noted as elevated (exact value not specified); home blood pressure generally 130s–140s systolic, occasionally up to 150 systolic; diastolic 70–80
- Physical exam: Grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur (pre-existing), clear lungs bilaterally, abdominal tenderness to palpation (no rebound or guarding), right costovertebral angle (CVA) tenderness, back tenderness on palpation
- Test results: Last A1c 7.3; blood glucose at home in low 100s; previous office glucose "around 300" (months ago)
- Other: Has acquired but not consistently used a home blood pressure cuff

A (Assessment):

- Kidney stone
- Hypertension
- Diabetes mellitus

P (Plan):

- Prescribe oxycodone 5 mg every 6–8 hours as needed for pain
- Continue tylenol for breakthrough pain
- Encourage increased fluid intake to facilitate stone passage
- Provide urine strainer to check for passage of stone
- Referral to urology (regardless of stone passage in coming days, due to recurrent stones)
- Continue Norvasc 2.5 mg for hypertension, no changes
- Continue metformin 500 mg for diabetes, no changes
- Referral to nutrition/dietitian for dietary support and sodium reduction
- No information provided regarding follow-up interval or additional testing

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Bilateral elbow soreness, right elbow pain is most severe
- History of present illness: Onset approximately 1.5 years ago, pain is worse with use of hands or arms; no prior similar pain during younger years; pain began after starting heavy weightlifting; pain is located on the inside (medial side) of elbows; use of ice has not provided relief; ibuprofen 800 mg three times daily has been used for pain; pain is aggravated by arm/hand use
- Past medical history: No information provided
- Social history: History of playing basketball, baseball, and football when younger; currently lifts heavy weights; expecting a newborn soon
- Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Physical exam: Pain with flexion and extension of both elbows (right more severe), limited range of motion on extension (not on flexion), medial elbow tenderness to palpation, no tenderness on lateral elbow palpation, normal sensation in fingers, pulses equal in all extremities, pain with supination but not with pronation on both elbows
- Test results: X-rays show no fractures or bony misalignment

A (Assessment):

- Medial epicondylitis (golfer’s elbow, also known as pitcher’s elbow)

P (Plan):

- Order MRI of elbows
- Plan for whole blood transfusion procedure (autologous blood injection into tendon) to aid healing
- Continue ibuprofen as needed
- Schedule follow-up after MRI
- Patient education and reassurance provided regarding procedure and expected recovery time

foot where the metatarsals meet your cuboids now there are ligaments at the top of your foot so i'm gon na be ordering an mri to assess for injury to any of these ligaments now based on your exam and from what i'm seeing on your x-ray you're most likely going to need surgery of that foot now the surgery will place the bones back in their proper position and using plates and screws will hold them there while they heal and this is gon na allow those bones and ligaments to heal properly it is a day surgery and you will be able to go home the same day and then i'm going to have you follow up with me here in the clinic you'll be in a cast and you will need to use crutches and you will not be able to use that left foot for about six to eight weeks now after that six to eight weeks you will gradually start walking on your foot based on how you tolerate it and we'll see how you do at that point so i do believe you're gon na need surgery i i'm recommending this because there are significant complications to your foot if we do not do this poor bone and ligament healing can lead to losing the arch of your foot and you're becoming flat-footed you also have a high likelihood of developing arthritis in that foot so what i'm gon na do unfortunately you'll be out the rest of the season but we are gon na get you fixed up and ready for next season if you're okay with all of this i'm gon na have the nurse come in and get you started on your paperwork and then i will see you on monday morning and we will get your foot taken care of
[patient] alright thank you
[doctor] you're welcome
SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Left foot pain
- History of present illness: Acute onset of left foot pain after another soccer player fell onto her right foot during a game yesterday; foot pain started immediately following a twisting injury, unable to continue playing, needed help off the field; pain severity reported as 7-8/10 without ibuprofen and 3/10 with ibuprofen; has been icing, elevating, using compression wrap, and taking ibuprofen
- Past medical history: Multiple prior soccer-related injuries, but never to this (left) foot
- Social history: Plays soccer since age 4-5, participates in school and local leagues; No information provided regarding tobacco, alcohol, or drug use
- Family history: No information provided
- Associated symptoms: Denies numbness, tingling, or abnormal sensations in the left foot

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: Blood pressure 118/72 mmHg, heart rate 58 bpm, respiratory rate 14/min, temperature afebrile, oxygen saturation 99% on room air
- Physical exam:
    - Cardiac: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs, rubs, or clicks, no ectopic beats
    - Pulmonary: Clear and equal breath sounds bilaterally, good air movement
    - Left foot: Bruising on both dorsal and plantar aspects, swelling, tenderness to palpation at midfoot, positive piano key test, brisk capillary refill (<3 seconds), intact and strong dorsalis pedis pulse, intact motor and sensation to light touch
- Test results: X-ray shows subtle dorsal displacement of the base of the second metatarsal, 3 mm separation of first and second metatarsal bases, and bony fragment in the Lisfranc joint space
- No information provided for laboratory results

A (Assessment):

- Lisfranc fracture (left foot)
- Differential diagnosis: Lisfranc ligament injury, to be assessed with MRI

P (Plan):

- Order MRI of the left foot to evaluate for ligamentous injury
- Recommend surgical intervention (open reduction and internal fixation) with casting and non-weight bearing (crutches) for 6-8 weeks
- Postoperative plan: Gradually resume weight bearing after 6-8 weeks, based on tolerance
- Out of soccer play for remainder of the season; plan for eventual return next season
- Referral: Schedule surgery, follow up in clinic on Monday
- Nurse to assist patient with paperwork
- Patient education on nature of injury, surgical plan, risks of non-treatment (possible arch loss, flatfoot, arthritis)

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Diarrhea for the last three days, headache
* History of present illness: Loose and watery stools, occurring six to seven times per day, started three days ago, associated with lower left abdominal pain described as cramp-like, weakness and shakiness, initial vomiting (ceased), loss of appetite but able to tolerate fluids, felt hot (possible temperature) at symptom onset, symptoms impacting work and daily activities, no blood in stool or vomit, no neck pain or stiffness, no visual changes, no photophobia, headache described as coming and going, left-sided, crampy, rated 8/10 in severity, started three days ago, getting worse, not present all the time
* Past medical history: Asthma, uses inhaler (well-controlled), no prior similar headache episodes
* Medications: Inhaler for asthma, Ibuprofen (three tablets per day), no other regular medications
* Allergies: No information provided
* Social history: Works as an accountant, no smoking, no alcohol consumption, lives with wife and two children, one child had vomiting but not diarrhea, no one else with same symptoms at home
* Family history: Mother and sister have migraines (well-controlled)

O (Objective):

* Physical exam: No information provided
* Vital signs: No information provided
* Test results: No information provided

A (Assessment):

* Migraine-like headache, possible/suspected (based on history and family history)
* Acute diarrhea

P (Plan):

* Consider increase in Ibuprofen dosage (up to two tablets, three times daily) if not already done
* Consider prescription for stronger analgesics (options discussed: Naproxen, Paracetamol, Codeine)
* Keep a headache diary to track symptoms and possible triggers
* Outpatient follow-up in 1-2 weeks
* Advise to return earlier if headaches worsen, become more frequent, or if experiencing visual changes, limb weakness, or feeling generally unwell
* Discuss prophylactic headache medications at next appointment if episodes become more frequent

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Diarrhea for the past three days
- History of present illness: Loose and watery stool, frequent bowel movements requiring staying close to the toilet, lower left abdominal cramp-like pain, initial vomiting (now resolved), transient fever/feeling hot at symptom onset (three or four days ago), runny nose, feeling weak and shaky, loss of appetite but able to eat light foods and maintain fluid intake, no blood in stool or vomit, no sore throat, no ear pain, no chest pain, no breathlessness except for asthmatic symptoms, muscle stiffness all over
- Past medical history: Asthma (managed with inhaler), high blood pressure
- Medication history: Lisinopril, inhaler (asthma, specific medication not named), no other medications
- Social history: Nonsmoker, does not drink alcohol, works as an accountant, lives with wife and two children (one child vomited, no diarrhea in household), had takeaway food (Chinese restaurant) 4 days ago
- Family history: No information provided
- Allergies: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: No information provided
- Physical exam: No information provided
- Test results: No information provided

A (Assessment):

- Viral illness, perhaps early flu, suspected

P (Plan):

- Advise rest and plenty of fluids
- Advise regular Paracetamol if feeling hot and cold or sweaty
- Prescribe Amoxicillin (one tablet, three times a day), to use if symptoms do not improve in 24–48 hours or if still feeling breathless and run-down
- Follow up if not better by next week for reassessment

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Diarrhea for the past three days, frequent need to stay near toilet, and left elbow discomfort
- History of present illness: Loose, watery stools six to seven times daily for three days, associated lower abdominal pain (to one side), initial vomiting (now resolved), felt weak and shaky, transient loss of appetite but able to tolerate fluids and light foods, low-grade fever/feeling hot at onset (no current fever), no blood in stool or vomit, no known food intolerance, recent consumption of takeaway (Chinese restaurant) four days ago, required to stay close to toilet, symptoms impact daily activities and work
- Past medical history: Asthma, uses inhaler (well-controlled), previous osteoarthritis diagnosis by GP (location and further details not specified)
- Medication history: Inhaler for asthma (as needed), no regular medications, no allergies to medications
- Social history: Accountant, continues to work despite symptoms, non-smoker, does not drink alcohol
- Family history: No family history of rheumatological diseases (e.g., rheumatoid arthritis, lupus), one child had vomiting (no diarrhea), no other family members with similar symptoms

O (Objective):

- Physical exam: Left elbow observed via video, appears normal except for slight warmth and dry skin at tip, not tender to palpation of nerve, no redness, range of motion intact
- Test results: No information provided
- Vital signs: No information provided

A (Assessment):

- Left elbow bursitis
- Septic arthritis not currently suspected
- Plan to investigate further causes of joint swelling (as per blood test discussion)
- Diarrhea, assessment ongoing (no explicit diagnosis stated by physician)

P (Plan):

- Prescribe ibuprofen 400 mg twice daily after food (advise to stop if heartburn occurs)
- Arrange blood tests for inflammatory markers, infection, rheumatological antibodies, and gout screen
- Send blood test forms and instructions to patient’s home
- Follow-up appointment to review joint and blood test results (can be phone/video or face-to-face as patient prefers)
- Advise patient to seek urgent care if elbow becomes very red, more painful, or if redness spreads or intensifies
- Reassure patient that nothing sinister suspected at present
- Outpatient follow-up after blood test results are available

- Chief complaint: Diarrhea for the last three days
- History of present illness: Loose and watery stools, approximately six to seven times a day, need to stay close to the toilet, lower left abdominal pain described as cramp-like, initial vomiting at the start of symptoms (now resolved), brief period of feeling hot three to four days ago, one episode of temperature, no fever currently, no blood in stool or vomit, loss of appetite, weak and shaky feeling, increased breathlessness over the past couple of weeks (worse in the last few days), breathless on minimal exertion, some swelling in ankles, dry cough that comes and goes, no chest pain, no palpitations, able to keep down fluids, eating mostly soups, smoothies, and light/liquid foods due to loss of appetite
- Past medical history: Heart failure, asthma, past "small heart attack" (no formal diagnosis given)
- Medications: Inhaler (for asthma), diuretics (including Furosemide), Metoprolol
- Allergies: No allergies reported
- Social history: Non-smoker, does not consume alcohol, accountant, works regular hours, lives alone with two cats
- Family history: Father died in his early sixties (no explicit cause mentioned), no relevant family history of similar symptoms, wife and two children not affected, one child vomited but no diarrhea in others

- Heart failure flare-up suspected

- Increase Furosemide to one tablet twice daily for the first few days

- Arrange echocardiogram of the heart
- Schedule follow-up appointment in one week
- Advise patient to contact clinic sooner if symptoms worsen (e.g., increased breathlessness, chest pain, palpitations, dizziness)

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Diarrhea for the last three days
- History of present illness: Loose, watery stool 6–7 times/day for three days, lower left abdominal cramping pain that comes and goes, associated mild weakness and shakiness; no blood in stools; felt feverish/had a temperature at onset (3–4 days ago), but no current fever; vomiting occurred at the beginning but has now resolved; loss of appetite, currently managing to eat light foods and soups, able to hold down fluids
- Aggravating factors: Must stay near toilet, affects daily activities and work
- Past medical history: Asthma (controlled, uses blue inhaler)
- Medications: Blue inhaler (for asthma), no other regular medications
- Allergies: No known medication allergies
- Social history: Non-smoker, does not drink alcohol, lives alone, works as an accountant, has been attending work despite symptoms but with difficulty
- Family history: Mother with diabetes (type unspecified); one child recently vomited, but no diarrhea in family members
- Recent food history: Ate takeaway food (Chinese restaurant) four days ago

O (Objective):

- Physical exam: No information provided
- Vital signs: No information provided
- Test results: No information provided

A (Assessment):

- Gastroenteritis

P (Plan):

- Advise increased fluid intake
- Recommend oral rehydration solution (Dioralyte) from pharmacy
- Paracetamol if feeling feverish or weak
- Take time off work for 1–2 days; return to work only after being diarrhea-free for 24–48 hours
- Follow up next week if no improvement or symptoms persist
- No information provided regarding additional tests or referrals

* Chief complaint: Diarrhea for the past three days

S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Diarrhea for the last three days
* History of present illness: Loose and watery stool, approximately six to seven times per day, need to stay close to the toilet, interfering with daily activities, lower abdominal pain described as cramp-like mainly on the left side below the belly button, pain is intermittent, associated with feelings of weakness and shakiness, loss of appetite, initial vomiting at start of symptoms (now resolved), felt hot at symptom onset (no current fever), no blood in stool or urine, no burning or stinging pain with urination, no headaches, palpitations, or vision problems
* Past medical history: Asthma (uses inhaler, well controlled)
* Medications: Inhaler for asthma, no other medications
* Social history: Does not smoke or drink alcohol, lives with wife and two children (one child had vomiting only, no diarrhea), works as an accountant, continues to attend work despite symptoms
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Physical exam: No information provided
* Vital signs: No information provided
* Test results: No information provided

A (Assessment):

* Possible urinary tract infection (UTI)
* Possible gastrointestinal (gut) infection
* Pregnancy-related cause needs to be considered
* Differential diagnosis: Abdominal pain, cause unclear

P (Plan):

* Prescribe Trimethoprim, one tablet twice daily for three days
* Advise to do a pregnancy test
* Recommend regular painkillers (Paracetamol)
* Encourage adequate fluid intake
* Suggest cranberry juice for urine symptoms
* Advise to return or call if symptoms worsen (increased pain, persistent fever, vomiting, etc.) or do not improve
* Arrange initial tests to assist with diagnosis (specific tests not detailed)
* Outpatient follow-up in a few days if no improvement

S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Diarrhea for the last three days
- History of present illness: Loose and watery stools about six to seven times per day for three days, lower left abdominal cramp-like pain that comes and goes, initial vomiting (now resolved), initial subjective feverish feeling (three to four days ago), weakness and shakiness, no blood in stool or vomit, loss of appetite, able to drink fluids and consume light foods, needs to stay close to the toilet, day-to-day activities and work affected

- Physical exam: No information provided
- Vital signs: No information provided
- Test results: No information provided

- Gastroenteritis

- No antibiotics indicated at this stage
- Patient education provided regarding management and follow-up

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Diarrhea for the past three days
* History of present illness: Loose, watery stool 6–7 times/day for 3 days, lower abdominal (left-sided) cramping pain, need to stay near toilet, impacts day-to-day activities, some weakness and shakiness, palpitations (feels heart beating faster than normal), initial vomiting (resolved), loss of appetite, able to tolerate fluids and light foods, one episode of feeling feverish/hot at onset (3–4 days ago), cough with blood in sputum and pain on one side (recent onset, last day or so), no blood in stool or vomit
* Past medical history: Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), asthma (uses inhaler, controlled)
* Medications: Methotrexate, inhaler (for asthma)
* Allergies: No known antibiotic allergies, no other allergies reported
* Social history: Non-smoker, does not consume alcohol, works as an accountant, lives with wife and two kids (one child recently vomited, no diarrhea in family), owns a cat
* Family history: No family history of blood clots or lung clots reported

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Heart rate estimated at 66–74 bpm by self-pulse check (doctor guided)
* Physical exam: Virtual capillary refill test performed (returns to normal color), throat visualized via video (no abnormal findings stated), neck palpation for lymphadenopathy performed (no abnormalities reported)
* Test results: No information provided

A (Assessment):

* Chest infection suspected
* Differential diagnosis: Pneumonia vs. chest infection, lung cancer to be excluded (not typical presentation, but investigations may be considered depending on in-person assessment)

P (Plan):

* Urgent face-to-face clinic appointment arranged for physical examination (focus on chest auscultation, blood pressure, pulse, and temperature)
* Possible need for antibiotics depending on assessment
* Possible further investigations (e.g., chest X-ray) if clinically indicated
* Patient advised to contact support team to arrange appointment
* No medications prescribed at this stage pending assessment
* Reassure patient; monitor for worsening symptoms
