SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Diarrhea for the past three days
- History of present illness: Loose and watery stool, frequency requiring close proximity to toilet, affecting daily activities; lower abdominal pain (left side, cramp-like); associated with weakness, shakiness, lethargy, loss of appetite; initial vomiting (now resolved); felt feverish with a temperature at symptom onset (three to four days ago), but no current fever; able to hold down fluids, mainly consuming soups and liquid foods; cough (dry, six to seven times daily), runny nose, occasional blocked ears without pain/discharge; cough disturbs sleep; no breathlessness or chest pain on exertion; no skin rash, joint, or muscle problems reported; no urinary problems, able to pass urine and drink fluids; no known allergies; regular medication use includes inhaler for asthma (well-controlled) and Zinopril for blood pressure; past medical history of asthma, diabetes, and hypertension
- Social history: Does not smoke, drinks wine (below or near recommended limits, advised to reduce further), works in IT as an accountant, lives with wife and two children; one child vomited but no diarrhea or similar illness in household; no recent unusual food except for takeaway at a Chinese restaurant four days ago
- Family history: No relevant family history reported

O (Objective):

- No information provided

A (Assessment):

- Viral illness

P (Plan):

- Advise rest and good hydration
- Continue to take regular Paracetamol as needed
- Cut down alcohol intake to two glasses of wine per week, aiming to reduce further
- Consider taking a few days off work to recover
- Follow up if not improving in 2–3 days or if cough, fever, or breathing worsens (potential need for antibiotics if chest symptoms develop)
- Outpatient monitoring; return if symptoms worsen or do not resolve

* Social history: Works as an accountant, continues to attend work despite symptoms, does not smoke or drink alcohol, lives with wife and two children (one child vomited but no diarrhea), has a cat
* Family history: No relevant illnesses or acute allergic reactions reported

O (Objective):

* Physical exam: No visible swelling of lips or mouth, breathing assessed as normal via video, localized rash and puncture mark at left arm consistent with insect sting, no overt swelling or erythema noted by physician, patient appears well and able to speak normally
* Test results: No information provided
* Vital signs: No information provided

A (Assessment):

* Localized allergic reaction to insect (bee) sting
* Acute gastroenteritis, suspected

P (Plan):

* Advise over-the-counter antihistamines (Piriton or Chlorphenamine 4 mg, up to six times a day, or equivalent one-a-day antihistamine)
* Monitor for signs of systemic allergic reaction (swelling of lips, facial swelling, breathing difficulty, stridor)—seek urgent medical attention if any occur
* If rash spreads, feels hot, or signs of local infection develop, consider need for antibiotics
* No immediate need for allergy testing unless reactions become recurrent or non-specific
* Patient education: Provide information about anaphylactic reactions and when to seek immediate care
* Follow-up as needed if symptoms worsen or new symptoms develop

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Diarrhea for the past three days
- History of present illness: Loose, watery stool occurring 6-7 times per day for three days, requiring proximity to a toilet; associated with lower abdominal pain (left-sided, cramp-like), episodic, and some weakness and shakiness. Initial feverish sensation but currently afebrile; vomiting at symptom onset but resolved. No blood in stool or vomit. Loss of appetite, able to tolerate fluids and light foods (soups, smoothies). No headaches, no neck pain, no seizures or fits, no visual symptoms except a transient loss of left peripheral vision. Numbness and weakness in the left arm (front side, second to fourth fingers, from the elbow down), no difficulty in the legs. No smoking, no alcohol consumption. Occupation: Accountant. Symptoms impacting daily work activities. Family: One child had vomiting but no diarrhea; no significant family or neurological history reported.
- Past medical history: Asthma, uses inhaler for control
- Social history: Non-smoker, non-drinker, employed as accountant
- Family history: No significant family or neurological history reported

- Physical exam: No information provided

- No medications prescribed at this time
- Reassurance and patient education provided

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Diarrhea for the past three days
- History of present illness: Loose and watery stool, occurring six or seven times a day, associated with lower left abdominal cramping pain, weakness, and shakiness. Diarrhea has required staying close to the toilet and affected day-to-day activities. Initial vomiting at onset, now resolved. No blood in stool or vomit. No fever at present, but reported feeling hot at symptom onset three to four days ago. Loss of appetite but able to keep down fluids and light foods such as soups and smoothies. Mild dry cough and sore throat started about a week ago; shortness of breath and mild wheeze with some chest discomfort noted in the past three to four days. No chest pain as such, no hemoptysis. No known weight loss, rash, or recent travel. One child in household recently vomited but no one else with diarrhea.
- Past medical history: Asthma (well controlled with inhaler)
- Medications: Inhaler (for asthma)
- Allergies: Peanuts
- Family history: Mother with lung cancer, no family history of clots (DVT/PE)
- Social history: Non-smoker, does not consume alcohol, works as an accountant, lives in the UK, no known occupational exposures (e.g., asbestos)

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: No information provided
- Physical exam: No information provided
- Test results: No information provided

A (Assessment):

- No diagnosis explicitly stated
- Physician provided reassurance and did not express concern for tuberculosis or lung cancer

P (Plan):

- Advise rest, plenty of fluids, paracetamol for symptomatic relief
- Provide sick note for absence from work
- Advise to seek medical attention if symptoms worsen, particularly increased shortness of breath or persistence of symptoms beyond four or five days
- Reassure regarding low likelihood of tuberculosis and lung cancer
- No specific investigations or referrals ordered at this time

- Prescribe Ventolin inhaler
- Prescribe oral steroids (take two tablets in the morning for five days)
- Prescribe a spacer device for inhaler use, provide instructions on use
- Advise rest and time off work as needed (self-certification for up to seven days)
- Counsel patient to seek medical attention if symptoms worsen (increased use of Ventolin—more frequently than every three hours, worsening shortness of breath, chest pain or tightness, light-headedness)
- Educate on possible steroid side effects (mood changes, elevated blood sugar, rash, nausea, headache)
- No information provided regarding further investigations or referrals
- Advise follow-up if symptoms do not improve or deteriorate

- Prescribe a medication stronger than Ibuprofen (not specifically named) and advise Paracetamol can be taken concurrently, both with food

- Advise patient to seek urgent care (A&E) if headache becomes unbearable, worsens, or changes character before the appointment

- Blood pressure to be checked at the time of examination
- Provide support line contact details for booking and further advice
- Patient education on signs requiring immediate evaluation

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Diarrhea for the last three days
* History of present illness: Loose and watery stools, 4–7 times a day, requiring frequent access to toilet and affecting daily activities; lower left abdominal cramping described as muscular cramp, intermittent; initial vomiting at symptom onset (now resolved); feeling weak and shaky; loss of appetite; able to hold down fluids and consume light foods such as soups and smoothies; felt slightly hot/temperature at start of symptoms about 3–4 days ago, but no current fever; no blood or mucus in stool; no recent travel; had takeaway food (Chinese restaurant) four days ago; one child vomited but no one else in family with diarrhea
* Past medical history: Asthma (well-controlled, uses inhaler)
* Medications: Inhaler for asthma (unclear type, possibly trade name “Laxepro”), no other medications
* Allergies: No known drug allergies
* Social history: Non-smoker, does not drink alcohol, works as an accountant
* Family history: Father died of bowel cancer ten years ago

O (Objective):

* Physical exam: Appears well, not dehydrated per physician observation
* Test results: No information provided
* Vital signs: No information provided

A (Assessment):

* Acute diarrhea

P (Plan):

* Recommend maintaining hydration; continue drinking plenty of fluids
* Advise soft diet (avoid dairy, fish, meat, eggs while diarrhea persists; consume foods such as crackers, toast, jam, mashed vegetables)
* Recommend reintroducing meat, eggs, fish only after being diarrhea-free for 48 hours
* Suggest probiotics such as yoghurt to help restore gut flora
* Advise over-the-counter oral rehydration solution (e.g., Dioralyte)
* Monitor for warning symptoms: return if diarrhea lasts longer than one week, if passing blood, or frequency increases to 6–8 times daily or more, or signs of dehydration develop
* Follow-up if symptoms worsen, persist, or develop alarm features
* Patient education provided; instructions given for review in app

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Diarrhea for the last three days
- History of present illness: Loose and watery stools, 6–7 times per day, requiring proximity to the toilet, affecting daily activities and work; associated lower left abdominal cramp-like pain (intermittent), feeling weak and shaky, loss of appetite, and decreased energy; initial vomiting at symptom onset (now resolved), no current vomiting, able to keep down fluids and light foods (soups, smoothies); felt febrile at symptom onset (three to four days ago), but no current fever; denies blood or mucus in stool, and no ongoing nausea
- Past medical history: Asthma (uses inhaler, well controlled); underactive thyroid (stopped taking thyroxine); no reported symptoms consistent with hyperthyroidism
- Family history: One child had vomiting but no diarrhea; otherwise, no family members with similar symptoms
- Social history: Works as an accountant; no smoking or alcohol intake
- Other symptoms: Reports shortness of breath in closed spaces such as lifts (no chest pain, can walk a mile without shortness of breath), and occasional palpitations; no weight loss reported over last six months

O (Objective):

- Physical exam: No information provided
- Vital signs: No information provided
- Test results: No information provided

A (Assessment):

- No diagnosis explicitly stated by the physician

P (Plan):

- Order general blood tests (to assess for anemia, kidney, liver function, vitamin levels, and thyroid function)
- Advise patient to seek medical attention (A&E) if chest pain or severe palpitations develop
- Instruct patient to contact clinic if bowel habits change or if vomiting recurs
- Await blood test results before proceeding to physical examination
- Patient instructed to call support number to organize blood tests and follow up via app upon receiving results
- Reinforce to contact healthcare provider if condition worsens before results are obtained

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Diarrhea for the last three days
* History of present illness: Loose, watery stool occurring 6–7 times per day, associated with lower abdominal cramping pain (mainly left side), weakness, shakiness, intermittent mild fever (felt hot at symptom onset), initial vomiting (resolved), no blood in stool or vomit, burning pain on passing urine for the last three days, loss of appetite but able to tolerate fluids, increased frequency necessitating staying close to the toilet, symptoms affecting day-to-day activities
* Past medical history: Asthma (uses inhaler, under control)
* Medication history: Uses inhaler for asthma, no other regular medications
* Allergy history: Severe allergy to Clindamycin
* Family history: No known family history of kidney, bladder, bowel, or gut conditions
* Social history: Non-smoker, does not drink alcohol, works as an accountant, lives with wife and two children (one child had vomiting but no diarrhea)
* Diet history: Ate takeaway (Chinese restaurant) four days ago; mostly consuming soups and liquid foods during illness
* Sexual history: Sexually active with regular partner, uses condoms for contraception, last period three weeks ago, no vaginal discharge, last STI screen not specified
* No information provided: Travel history, exposure to sick contacts outside family

O (Objective):

* Physical exam: No information provided
* Vital signs: No information provided
* Test results: No information provided

A (Assessment):

* Simple urinary tract infection (UTI) or bladder infection

P (Plan):

* Prescribe Nitrofurantoin or Trimethoprim, one tablet twice a day for three days
* Advise to drink plenty of fluids; consider cranberry juice for symptom relief
* Advise to observe for development of high fever, back pain, or feeling more unwell, and to seek medical attention if these arise
* Advise to avoid sexual intercourse until symptoms resolve; continue use of barrier contraception
* If symptoms do not improve by the end of the week, advise follow-up (call or return visit)
* No further investigations or referrals planned at this time

* History of present illness: Loose, watery stools occurring six to seven times per day for three days, lower abdominal pain described as cramp-like on the left side, weakness and shakiness, mild subjective fever at symptom onset three to four days ago (no current measured fever), episode of vomiting at symptom onset but resolved, appetite loss but able to tolerate fluids, requires proximity to toilet, main diet now consists of soups, smoothies, and light foods, difficulty attending work due to symptoms
* Past medical history: Asthma (uses Salbutamol inhaler, well controlled), history of lip swelling following prawn soup approximately four days ago (developed within half an hour, increasing in size), possible past allergic reactions as mentioned by mother, no previous hospitalizations for severe allergic reactions reported
* Current medications: Salbutamol inhaler, antihistamines (unspecified, has used before)
* Social history: Non-smoker, does not consume alcohol, occupation: accountant, lives with wife and two children (one child vomited but no diarrhea; no similar symptoms in other family members), has been able to attend work despite difficulty
* Family history: No information provided

* Vital signs: No information provided
* Physical exam: No information provided

* Suspected anaphylactic reaction
